webTitle: Wenger's legion equipped to win in style

fields.headline: Wenger's legion equipped to win in style
fields.standfirst:
Danish police go on charm offensive
Henry the red-hot marksman
Second best not an option
Player-by-player guide
fields.trailText: David Lacey believes Arsène Wenger's multinational style wiil ensure Arsenal come away with victory, and one that is altogether more memorable than their previous European triumph in the Parken stadium.
fields.body:
It is just possible that Denmark has heard the one about the ugly duckling that turned into a swan. But in case there are those here who think Hans Christian Andersen was once a sweeper for Brondby, Arsenal will tonight have a chance to prove the point against Galatasaray in what should be one of the better Uefa Cup finals.

Six years ago in the Parken stadium George Graham's solid, well organised but essentially functional Arsenal team won the European Cup Winners' Cup by beating a more individually talented Parma side with the only goal of the game.

Sound though their performance was, it did not send Copenhagen into paroxysms of rejoicing. Alan Smith pounced on a defensive error to give Arsenal the lead in the 19th minute and the rest was largely about Graham's defenders closing down all avenues to Gianfranco Zola, Faustino Asprilla and Tomas Brolin.

It was a worthy but grey-feathered triumph and tonight Arsène Wenger's Arsenal have the capacity to win in rather finer plumage; Wenger's styles puts a greater emphasis on attack, albeit from a strong defensive base.

As an English exercise the success of 1994 will continue to give the greater satisfaction, whatever the result this evening. Ten of Graham's team that night were English and the only exception, Steve Morrow, came from Belfast.

Wenger will field five English players at most, along with three Frenchmen, two Dutchmen and a Brazilian. Arsenal are almost cast in the role of Parma in 1994 since they possess, in Dennis Bergkamp, Patrick Vieira, Marc Overmars and Thierry Henry, a greater number of talented individuals than the opposition.

It will be up to Galatasaray to deny Arsenal space to demonstrate the footballing arts while hoping an old Romanian master Gheorghe Hagi can produce the brush strokes to inspire a Turkish triumph that would bathe the Golden Horn in celebration.

Reports from Istanbul that the Galatasaray players have not been paid and that their coach Fatih Terim is on the point of walking out should not be taken over-seriously. Turkish football thrives on internecine conflict and tonight men such as Hakan Sukur and Erdem Arif would win the Uefa Cup for nothing.

Yet a Gala victory would be against the odds. Arsenal have saved their best form for the season's end and it is difficult to believe they will not have too much pace and scoring power for Terim's defence.

Much will depend on Vieira or Emmanuel Petit keeping track of Hagi as he drifts about the pitch like an evening mist; here one moment, there the next. Leeds found this beyond them in the semi-finals but Arsenal's French pair will be less easily fooled.

Henry, supported by Bergkamp's craft, the power on the flanks of Ray Parlour and Overmars, and the thrust of Vieira and Petit from midfield, is Arsenal's likeliest match winner. Claudio Taffarel, Galatasaray's battle-hardened Brazilian goalkeeper, is the man most likely to keep the contest open.

The status of this final has been raised from sideshow to news event by the ramifications of Galatasaray's tie with Leeds, when two of the English club's supporters were stabbed to death in Istanbul before the first leg. Extra Danish security has been drafted in for fear of extremist groups from England seeking vengeance against innocent Turkish supporters.

It is to be hoped that tonight's game is remembered for the right reasons. Arsenal fans have no record of violence in Europe and their team have not had a fight since Bertie Mee's side were set upon by Lazio players outside a Rome restaurant more than 30 years ago. And Arsenal won that one on points.

fields.headline: Danish police go on charm offensive
fields.standfirst:

fields.trailText: Danish police launched a timely charm offensive here yesterday in an attempt to avoid trouble at tonight's final. They said bars would not be closed and officers would keep a visible but discreet presence before and after the match.
fields.body:
Danish police launched a timely charm offensive here yesterday in an attempt to avoid trouble at tonight's final. They said bars would not be closed and officers would keep a visible but discreet presence before and after the match.

A leaflet in Turkish and English is being distributed at Copenhagen airport and railway stations welcoming Galatasaray and Arsenal supporters to the city and outlining principles of fair play.

It urges them to enjoy themselves, remain peaceful and sample the delights of Copenhagen. But it warns that anyone arrested for causing trouble may be fined and deported.

"We want fans to enjoy themselves," said Mogens Lauridsen, who is in charge of the security operation. "We will not be able to keep them apart in the city centre so we are appealing to the better nature of all those arriving for the match."

But the police are prepared for the worst and about 2,000 officers will be on duty. Scores of them in riot gear will be on standby in nearby side streets in case of trouble.

Some 12,000 fans of each club are expected to attend the final and the bulk of them will arrive this morning, with about 50 flights expected to arrive before midday.

About 9,000 tickets were sold to local fans and several have found their way on to the black market, with prices starting at around £500.

According to intelligence reports some Leeds United fans, seeking revenge for the deaths of two of their number in Istanbul last month, are preparing to attend the final to attack Galatasaray supporters.

"We have got intelligence that a number of Leeds fans have made arrangements to come here," said Inspector Andy Smith, head of security at Highbury. "If they are on their way we say stay where you are because Denmark does not want you here."

A fence almost two miles long is being constructed around the Parken stadium to keep rival fans apart. Barricades are also being erected on roads leading to the stadium and all fans will have to pass through at least three checkpoints before being allowed to enter.

webTitle: Player-by-player guide to Galatasaray v Arsenal

fields.headline: Player-by-player guide to Galatasaray v Arsenal
fields.standfirst:
Second best not an option
Henry the red-hot marksman
Danish police go on charm offensive
Wenger's legion can win in style
fields.trailText: Galatasaray
fields.body:
Galatasaray

Goalkeeper
Claudio Taffarel: Age 34
Veteran of Brazil's last three World Cups and holder of 112 caps. Leeds identified him as Galatasaray's weak point in the semi-final but he made several outstanding saves.

Defence
Umit Davala: 26
Replaces the Brazilian right-back Capone but may appear in midfield, where his passing ability is likely to be seen to more threatening effect.

Gheorghe Popescu: 32
Once scored against Arsenal for Spurs. Should take his tally of Romanian caps to more than 100 during Euro 2000. Top-class campaigner but, as Harry Kewell can testify, partial to a spot of amateur dramatics.

Bulent Korkmaz: 31
Arsenal have Tony Adams; Galatasaray have Bulent. A one-club player, he has won six league titles at the Ali Sami Yen. Holder of 56 caps but Thierry Henry may expose the Gala skipper's ageing limbs.

Hakan Unsal: 27
Predominantly left-footed but capable of playing at right wing-back. A no-frills type of defender, he has earned a reputation as Galatasaray's Mr Reliable.

Midfield
Suat Kaya: 32
The Paul Daniels of Turkish football? Replacement surgery on his balding pate means he now sports a full head of hair. Will quickly make Petit and Vieira aware of his combative presence.

Ergun Penbe: 27
Celebrates his 28th birthday today. A Turkish international who is most at home in midfield but is also a very good defender. Joined Galatasaray from Genclirbirligi six years ago.

Gheorghe Hagi: 35
Should need little introduction. One of the greatest left-footed players ever, the diminutive Romanian (pictured t) and his size-five boots were too much for Leeds to comprehend at Elland Road. Could be his last game for Gala before moving to the United States.

Okan Buruk: 26
Another one-club Turkish international. After a number of injuries the right-sided midfielder is playing the best football of his career.

Attack
Hakan Sukur: 28
The most celebrated player in Turkish football. Robust and rugged, he is lethal from anywhere inside the box. His confrontration with Arsenal's centre-halves makes for an intriguing sub-plot.

Arif Erdem: 26
Likes to run at defenders whereas Hakan Sukur is more a target man. Scored a hat-trick for Turkey in four minutes against Northern Ireland last year.

Arsenal

Goalkeeper
David Seaman: Age 36
Still Arsenal's - and England's No1 - who appears to be back to his best after a hesitant spell this season. The oldest of tonight's team - but arguably still the most physiically daunting with that 6ft 4in frame. Must watch those Hagi free-kicks: long shots are his weakness.

Defence
Lee Dixon: 36
As tenacious as ever, Kevin Keegan and England may regret not taking this vastly experienced right-back to Euro 2000. Bows only to Seaman in age (by six months) but has discovered some new tricks lately, like the header against Deportivo La Coruna and the snooker-like shot against Sheffield Wednesday.

Silvinho: 26
Like Galatasaray's Capone, a Brazilian with the touch you would expect. Joined last June from Corinthians and has displaced Nigel Winterburn at left-back - no mean feat.

Martin Keown: 33
Has won 28 England caps and remains the country's best man-marker. Quick and fearsome in the tackle, this Highbury trainee had spells with Aston Villa and Everton before returning and establishing himself as Adams's central defensive partner.

Tony Adams: 33
Captain and colossus, Arsenal have now run out of superlatives for the centre-back synonymous with their success since 1989. Has won 62 England caps but the future, for club and country, is clouded by back and groin problems. Natural leader, superb positional player.

Midfield
Ray Parlour: 27
Extraordinarily willing worker of the right flank. Inspirational in Lens and a hat-trick scorer in Bremen, Parlour has excelled on foreign fields recently in the Uefa Cup.

Patrick Vieira: 23
Senegal-born French international whose partership with fellow World Cup winner Petit is the Premiership's best. Tall, tentacular in the tackle and superb "breaker" of play. Arguably Arsne Wenger's most canny purchase, from Milan, whose discipline, according to the manager, is improving.

Emmanuel Petit: 29
His seemingly all-embracing anglophobia has not seriously lowered Highbury fans' appreciation of this skilled, highly versatile performer. Look out for his clever chips forward with that lovely left foot. His worldly ways make him a target for Real Madrid and Lazio.

Marc Overmars: 27
Also linked with a move abroad, to Barcelona's Dutch colony. But the Gunners can also offer him Champions League football if he is so concerned about capturing the top trophy again - he won it with Ajax in 1995. Devilishly quick down the left, he can be even more devastating in the middle.

Attack
Thierry Henry: 22
Arsenal's record £11m signing, from Juventus, and worth every penny as the Frenchman scores for fun - 26 goals in his first English season, 12 in his past 10 games. Like Nicolas Anelka, has blistering speed but, unlike the £23m boy-man, does not have the sulks.

Dennis Bergkamp: 31
Is aiming to add a third Uefa Cup winner's medal. Fortunately, Copenhagen is close enough for the aerophobic to play. Flopped in Italy but became England's double player of the year (1998). Elegant technician but becomes frazzled if tightly marked; the Turks may give him that treatment tonight.

fields.headline: Henry the red-hot marksman
fields.standfirst:
The Frenchman was a striker in despair when he rediscovered the target
Second best not an option
Danish police go on charm offensive
Wenger's legion can win in style
Player-by-player guide
fields.trailText: Thierry Henry was a striker in despair when he rediscovered the target, and now Galatasaray may be about to pay the price for his blistering end-of-season form.
fields.body:
By 9.30 tonight Galatasaray could be the latest in a long line of victims wishing Thierry Henry had stuck to his guns. One morning, soon after his arrival at Highbury, the Frenchman dragged himself miserably out of bed intent on demanding a move.

This was not a move from Arsenal but from the striker's role he feared was ruining his career. Out of the Champions League side and looking as potent in the Premiership as John Jensen, Henry decided enough was enough. He had to ask Arsène Wenger to go back out wide.

"It was so hard at the beginning," he recalls. "Patrick [Vieira] used to tease me all the time. At first it was funny but it was true as well. I missed so many chances, not even difficult ones. In my mind I was in the France squad at the World Cup as a winger and one day I decided I had to speak to the boss.

"But when I arrived at training I thought: 'It's all right.' There are players who stop when they have a little problem. I decided I had to keep going and maybe we would see at the end of the season. I had a lot of confidence in Arsène."

Presumably the 22-year-old will not be banging on Wenger's door tomorrow, unless it is to demand a pay rise. He has been sensational of late, his pace, power and finishing mocking the early doubts. Goals have flowed like David Ginola's locks. Why the £11m fee? Because he is worth it.

Henry remembers the day he started to feel a "real striker" again. As a youngster he always had that sense, 45 goals in one season for Monaco's youth team catapulting him into Wenger's side at 17.

But Wenger soon departed and Henry was moved to the wing. Four years later, when he arrived at Highbury from Juventus, the scoring confidence was gone. At home to Derby last November it began to flood back.

Twice set up by Marc Overmars, twice he made no mistake. "When you score two goals, and you win with that, suddenly you feel more like a striker," he says. The statistics tell it all: two goals in 17 games before, 22 in 27 since, 26 in all. Here he hopes to score for the 11th successive match. How different Arsenal's Champions League and Premiership fortunes might have been if Henry had been in this form from the start. "No one," he confesses, "has missed the chances I have."

The new incisiveness is based not just on confidence but on his adjustment to the Premiership. Team-mates have toughened him up in training and this month Henry even brushed aside Marcel Desailly to score against Chelsea. That prompted Wenger to compare Henry's build to a boxer's but not even he expected His 'Enery to settle this fast.

"I didn't expect he would be such a success," says the manager, who originally wanted Henry to play with Nicolas Anelka, not instead of him. "I thought it would need more time. I was disappointed with the way he played at Liverpool alongside Bergkamp. He showed no signs it would be a success. But he learns quickly."

The counter-attacking thrust of Anelka is no longer missed. And Henry - outgoing but not arrogant - has become part of the dressing room and the club in a way his friend never did. In the canteen he pulls faces at Vieira, trying to distract the midfielder from his interview. On Friday he watched the under-18s win the Youth Cup. He remembers how much that meant to him at Monaco - small touches, big impression.

It says much that a message flashed up at Highbury recently proclaiming "Well done Thierry, only 162 to go". Goals to beat Ian Wright's record, that is. Henry studies Wright on video (the goals not the chat show) and there is a sense that he is here to stay.

He enjoys London, though not a in pubbing-kebabing Gazza sort of way. As a teenager at Monaco he ignored the casinos and the beach, and still football comes first. "I go to dance," he says, "but not all the time, you know."

More often he is with friends, visitors from Paris, occasionally tucking into the Caribbean food that reminds him of his mother's Guadaloupe cuisine. He appreciates the less intense life on and off the pitch: "In Italy, if you miss one chance, even if you are Batistuta or Bierhoff, they have to kill you. Here they were singing my name."

Henry says he likes pressure and not only Arsenal should celebrate his reincarnation. France have surely found the striker they won the World Cup without. Henry may be asked to start alone up front in Euro 2000 but he believes he and Anelka could work as a pair.

"Romario and Bebeto used to play together for Brazil," he says, "and they played the same way." Henry and Anelka, 22 and 21, may have to vary the baby-cradling celebrations. Tonight Arsenal would settle for the upraised arm and charge towards the corner flag.

fields.trailText: It is not the final that Arsène Wenger had set his heart on. When his Arsenal side stepped out at Fiorentina, eight months and 14 European ties ago, he had Paris in May on his mind.
fields.body:
It is not the final that Arsène Wenger had set his heart on. When his Arsenal side stepped out at Fiorentina, eight months and 14 European ties ago, he had Paris in May on his mind.

Once again, though, his players failed to get past the hors d'oeuvre in the Champions League, but having left Real Madrid and Valencia to the main course, Wenger is not about to scoff at the consolation of a Danish pastry.

It is two years since Arsenal won a trophy and their failure to stretch Manchester United or live with Europe's elite this season has hurt. So this is their last chance of glory. "If you could see me after every defeat," Wenger said, "you would know how important it is to me to win this match."

Arsenal should not disappoint him if they play to their potential. Since Thierry Henry began scoring as if he would never stop, and the injuries cleared up, they have been in fine form. A run of 12 successive wins ended - at home to Sheffield Wednesday - only when a Champions League berth next season was guaranteed.

Galatasaray, though, are a skilful, hard-working side. Psychologically and physically they met Leeds at the right time in the semi-final but there is no doubting their talent. Victories this season over Milan, Hertha Berlin and Borussia Dortmund show that when they are good they can be very, very good. A 5-0 defeat at home to Chelsea proved that when they are bad they are horrid.

"That result was an accident," Wenger insisted. "A better reference will be the game they played at Chelsea, where they made a big impression, as they have everywhere they have played." The Istanbul side lost 1-0 at Stamford Bridge after being reduced to 10 men.

They, too, are refugees from the Champions League and their determination tonight will be enhanced by the hopes resting on them as the first Turkish team to reach a European final. Last night a clutch of Galatasaray fans, some draped in the national flag, gave their heroes a traditionally noisy welcome to training at the Parken stadium. Some 33 Turkish television crews watched the team work out.

"This is a big, big occasion for my players," said Galatasaray's coach Fatih Terim, who on Sunday won the domestic double. "In the past Turkish players have watched finals on television. Now they have a chance to play a starring role."

Whoever stars, this should be an open, exciting match. Arsenal have scored 21 goals in eight Uefa Cup ties and Galatasaray will not shut up shop. "We will play very aggressive, attacking football because we have nothing to lose," said Gica Popescu.

Their main attacking threat is Hakan Sukur, about whom Wenger made enquiries as coach at Monaco. "He's very quick with quick feet and he's good in the air and mobile," the Arsenal manager said. Sukur admitted at the weekend that the Galatasaray players "have not been able to get [their] money for eight months". All the more reason to chase the £33,000-a-man win bonus.

Roving behind Sukur and Erdem Arif, dictating the play and dangerous at set pieces, will be Gheorghe Hagi. At 35 some of his pace has gone but the brain remains quick. "He can be a major danger," Wenger said. The ability of Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit to stifle him looks a crucial factor.

Wenger has had his players practising penalties in case extra-time comes and goes without a golden goal. He is 70% certain Lee Dixon will recover from a groin problem, although Oleg Luzhny stands by. Definitely out are Fredrik Ljungberg (ribs) and Alex Manninger (infected hand). The 39-year-old goalkeeper John Lukic, who has not played for three years, will be on the bench. Galatasaray lost their right-back Capone to injury in training last night.

Wenger is appealing to all Arsenal's supporters not to lose their heads. "Violence would tarnish any victory," he said. "I am a bit worried because you have so many people in the city and anything can happen. It's an explosive city."

fields.headline: How I recruit great staff
fields.trailText: Alison Parker, 37 chief executive
fields.body:
Alison Parker, 37 chief executive

It's easy to rattle off a CV and covering letter without much thought, so when I advertised for a marketing executive I asked people to write in for an application form - only people who are genuinely interested bothered. Also, when you send out the forms, include a job description that is detailed and explicit in the skills you need. That weeds out more people. And if you are torn between someone who is better qualified and someone who has the right personality, go for the latter. In a small company like mine, team dynamics are extremely important, because everyone has to muck in. It costs a company three times the job's salary to rectify a mistake in recruitment so you have to get it right.

Mary Forrester, 54 careers adviser

It's jolly useful to get a reference from a penultimate employer, because they have no axe to grind; sometimes an employer will give someone a good reference just to get shot of them. I've also learned that you must ask specific questions when taking up references. It's easy for someone to blind you with inspiration rather than give you useful facts. I learned this after I employed a senior administrator who didn't work out. His reference was good, but I needed someone who could follow things through and not just be an ideas person. If I had asked the right questions I would have found that out.

Peter Smith, 45 managing director

I rarely advertise jobs. Instead I offer my staff incentives to recommend people. They get £10,000 if someone they put forward works out in the company for at least a year. Otherwise you have a covering letter, a possibly spurious CV and an hour's meeting to decide, which is ridiculous really. I once employed someone who I thought was perfect to be my PA. She interviewed well and had all the qualifications, but turned out to be a nightmare. I'm recruiting now for a sales manager job and I'll be offering a six-month contract. It seems a bit harsh, but with limited resources you need to replace people with as little hassle as possible.

Catrin Weston, 37 development manager

You have to identify the exact nature of the job you advertise. I once employed someone who then had to resign because he got ill under the pressure of work. He had the qualifications, but at the interview I didn't pester out of him the amount of pressure he'd experienced. The person who did the job before him thrived on pressure, and it's easy to link a position with the way the person who's leaving handles it. The next time, I identified key elements of the job and found someone more suitable.

Richard Hunter, 32 financial services director

Network constantly. If you start looking when a vacancy arises, chances are you won't find anyone in time. When I meet someone who impresses me at an industry dinner or conference, I sound them out. Often you can interview someone informally without them realising it - they're more relaxed and often more honest. When I was last recruiting, I had four or five people already in mind. I took them out for a drink and asked them to post me their CVs. Then I began the formal interview procedure.

Interviews by Cayte Williams

webTitle: Inflation at lowest since records began

fields.headline: Inflation at lowest since records began
fields.trailText: Fuelling the intense debate about whether the Bank of England has squeezed the economy too hard, the underlying rate of inflation fell from 2% to 1.9% in the 12 months to April, according to figures published yesterday by the office for national statistics.
fields.body:
Labour's tough action to drive down gas and electricity bills paid off yesterday as official figures showed the government's target measure of inflation falling to its lowest annual level since records began, a quarter of a century ago.

Fuelling the intense debate about whether the Bank of England has squeezed the economy too hard, the underlying rate of inflation fell from 2% to 1.9% in the 12 months to April, according to figures published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

Although the scrapping of mortgage interest relief led to the all-items retail price index rising by 3% in April from 2.6% in March, the ONS said on the internationally comparable measure, Britain's inflation rate is still the lowest in Europe by a wide margin.

"Today's report is very much a tale of two figures," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC world markets.

"Although the rise in the headline rate to 3% looks worrying, much of this was due to measures announced in the Budget," said the ONS.

If the underlying measure continues falling Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, may be forced to write a letter of explanation to the chancellor.

Threadneedle Street's task is to keep inflation excluding housing costs at 2.5% and if it varies by more than one percentage point above or below the target, the Bank must set out the reasons for Mr Brown.

Inflation has been below the 2.5% target since March last year but the Bank has raised rates four times because it is concerned that most of the improvement in the data has come from sterling's rapid rise up the foreign exchanges, which has led to a reduction in import prices.

Threadneedle Street fears beneficial impact of the pound on prices could easily be reversed if sterling fell sharply.

Yesterday's figures raised hopes that the Bank may keep rates on hold again in June, despite sterling softening over the last two weeks.

"The most notable feature is the fall in the all-services index - which has been a key concern on the inflation front and wages," said Adam Chester of Halifax Bank. "The economic environment is very conducive for themonetary policy committee leaving rates on hold."

Inflation in the services sector fell to 3.4%, from 4.2% the previous month - its slowest since June 1999 - mainly hit by utilities as regulators force down electricity and gas prices across Britain. Cuts in utility bills wiped 0.2% off the retail prices index.

However, not all economists agree the outlook for inflation is benign. Michael Saunders, UK economist with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said falling gas and electricity bills were unlikely to be sustained.

"The MPC will not view one-off cuts in utility prices as a lasting brake on prices.

"Indeed, by boosting consumers' real incomes, the utility price cuts will at the margin add to real consumption growth and fears of overheating," he added.

"It will be much harder to keep inflation under control next year, when the helpful effects of the high pound and cuts in utility prices fade."

fields.headline: Guardian launches new work website
fields.trailText: The Guardian Media Group (GMG), which owns Guardian Unlimited, has announced that it will launch a new online employment network this summer.
fields.body:
The Guardian Media Group (GMG), which owns Guardian Unlimited, has announced that it will launch a new online employment network this summer.

Workthing.com will combine information and advice on the world of work with a recruitment service. The managing director, Andy Baker, described it as a "key information exchange" and added that it would cover many different industry sectors, including education, media and the public sector.

Bob Phillis, the chief executive of GMG and workthing.com's new chairman, pointed out that the growth in online recruitment was "phenomenal". He said the site would appeal to both employers and employees and would complement both Guardian Unlimited and Fish4jobs, in which GMG holds a 20% stake.

Baker, who was responsible for developing CMPnet, a US-based service for IT professionals, declared himself "thrilled" to be involved in the new company.

"There is a huge gap in the market for a site that is about the whole of employment life not just about recruitment. Workthing is the shape of things to come," he said.

Useful links
Workthing.com
Fish4jobs

fields.headline: One-sided portrait
fields.standfirst:
The Turn of the Screw
New Theatre, Cardiff
fields.trailText:
The Turn of the Screw
New Theatre, Cardiff
fields.body:
Judged solely as a musical experience, Welsh National Opera's new Turn of the Screw is impressive. The 13-strong chamber orchestra plays with feeling for conductor Carlo Rizzi, who shapes and paces Britten's lucid and wonderfully imaginative score with a sure sense of tragic drama.

Janice Watson is warmly expressive as the governess, charting her wildly swinging moods with assurance. Mary Lloyd-Davies turns the housekeeper, Mrs Grose, into a real flesh-and-blood character, not the blandly maternal figure of other productions. Paul Nilon is surprisingly touching as the ghostly Peter Quint. As the two children, Oliver Carden is a touching Miles, and Yvette Bonner is so persuasive as Flora that it is possible to believe (for once) that Britten is as interested in her fate as in that of her brother.

Unfortunately the musical performances are weighed down by John Crowley's leaden production. Rob Howell's sets have a sombre, claustrophobic quality, but the ghosts themselves are as creepy as a low-budget Christmas panto: with spirits as solid and unthreatening as these, it is hard to see why the poor governess should find them frightening. The only frisson is provided by the music.

The central platform - raised, lowered and tilted as the action progresses - creaks. One should only see scene-changes when they are actually worth watching. There is one imaginative touch: Quint's crinkly hairstyle looks eerily like Britten's. But if Britten is the sinister seducer, he is also the victim - the charming, talented golden boy. The production ignores that possibility. So we have a fatally one-sided portrait of Britten's sexuality: damaging, but not damaged. This Turn of the Screw might work well enough on the radio; visually it has little, if anything, to add.

The Turn of the Screw will be broadcast on Radio 3 on May 31.

fields.headline: London Sinfonietta/ Peter Eotvos
fields.standfirst:
London Sinfonietta/ Peter Eotvos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
London Sinfonietta/ Peter Eotvos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Hungarian Peter Eotvos (born in 1944) has always been a composer, but until the past few years he was better known, at least in Britain, as a performer and a conductor. From now on, I suspect, we are going to hear much more of Eotvos the composer. Earlier this year, Boulez and the LSO premiered his dazzling orchestral showpiece zeroPoints; it is only a matter of time before we see his first opera, based upon Chekhov's Three Sisters. Another stage work, derived from Tony Kushner's Angels in America, is in the pipeline.

Here, Eotvos conducted a pair of his own works. One of them, Chinese Opera from 1986, showed his ear for vivid gesture and instrumental colour in a series of six pieces for "imaginary theatre". Shadows, first performed in 1997 and getting its British premiere here, showed how powerfully his musical language is developing. There is now more transparency, more emphasis on line, but the ideas are as striking as ever. The sounds of the ensemble were electronically projected around the auditorium, "shadowing" the flute and clarinet soloists (Sebastian Bell and Michael Collins here), whose lines became increasingly elegiac as the work went on.

There was another British premiere in the programme too: a little Concertino for cello and ensemble, by China's Guo Wenjing. It was full of fresh, arresting sonorities and a bracing mixture of styles - the ending sounded like Vaughan Williams's The Lark Ascending heard through Oriental ears.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Every year, Dave and his solicitor come for a conference in chambers to discuss whether his employer's latest bad doings might entitle him to resign and claim that he has been unfairly dismissed. He is my only non-corporate repeat customer.
fields.body:
Every year, Dave and his solicitor come for a conference in chambers to discuss whether his employer's latest bad doings might entitle him to resign and claim that he has been unfairly dismissed. He is my only non-corporate repeat customer.

Not that Dave and I have ever got near a tribunal together. In February he came in with this year's catalogue of hardships:

* Christmas bonus frozen at last year's level.

* Delay in Dave's overtime payments being processed.

* Failure to investigate Dave's complaint about safety gloves being too tight.

Me: This isn't going to do it, Dave. I mean, all these things are really too minor.

Dave: Fair enough.

Me: But you know, Dave, this is the third time you've come to see me. I get the feeling you hate this job. Have you thought of just looking for something else?

Silence. Evidently Dave feels the only way he can leave the job with honour is if he is driven out.

So I was surprised when Dave's solicitor sent me papers again this week. Dave had been sacked for allegedly throwing a banana at his supervisor in the canteen during a disagreement about safety gloves.

Or that was the supervisor's story. Dave's statement said that after a frustrating exchange, he turned to leave, tossing his banana at the coffee machine "in disgust", whereupon it must have bounced back (several feet) and struck the supervisor in the chest.

How bouncy are bananas? I decided to conduct a controlled experiment in the office with a pair of contrasting bananas. Lobbing a banana at the wall caused it to slide down the vertical surface, tipping over a cup of coffee during its descent. No matter how hard I threw banana number one, a mature yellowish-black specimen, it didn't bounce. It just thunked to the floor. Only when I frisbeed it at the doorframe did it make contact with my roommate, who was just entering the room. Sadly, it had developed a side seam by then and disgorged some of its contents on to his trousers.

I switched to the springier, greener second banana. My roommate did the throwing, but still no bounce. I rang Dave's solicitor.

Me: I've been looking at the merits of Dave's case.

Solicitor: Have you been bouncing bananas too?

Me: Yeah. They don't, do they?

Solicitor: No, but Dave wants to come in and prove that they do.

I can't talk them out of it. Dave's union seem perfectly happy to pay for him to come and bounce bananas in chambers. And I know what will happen. When we've all failed to bounce a variety of bananas off a variety of surfaces, I'll turn to Dave and explain why his case is not very strong.

And he'll say: Fair enough.

Dave's statement said that after a frustrating exchange, he turned to leave, tossing his banana at the coffee machine "in disgust", whereupon it must have bounced back (several feet) and struck the supervisor in the chest. How bouncy are bananas? I decided to conduct a controlled experiment in the office with a pair of contrasting bananas. Lobbing a banana at the wall caused it to slide down the vertical surface, tipping over a cup of coffee during its descent. No matter how hard I threw banana number one, a mature yellowish-black specimen, it didn't bounce. It just thunked to the floor. Only when I frisbeed it at the doorframe did it make contact with my roommate, who was just entering the room. Sadly, it had developed a side seam by then and disgorged some of its contents on to his trousers. I switched to the springier, greener second banana. My roommate did the throwing, but still no bounce. I rang Dave's solicitor. Me: I've been looking at the merits of Dave's case. Solicitor: Have you been bouncing bananas too? Me: Yeah. They don't, do they? Solicitor: No, but Dave wants to come in and prove that they do. I can't talk them out of it. Dave's union seem perfectly happy to pay for him to come and bounce bananas in chambers. And I know what will happen. When we've all failed to bounce a variety of bananas off a variety of surfaces, I'll turn to Dave and explain why his case is not very strong. And he'll say: Fair enough.

fields.headline: Off the rails
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack sent senior executives on an 'away weekend', then threatened sackings after reports that it had turned into a drunken bash. But what did they expect, asks Esther Addley
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Railtrack sent senior executives on an 'away weekend', then threatened sackings after reports that it had turned into a drunken bash. But what did they expect, asks Esther Addley
fields.body:
Compared to tearing apart a continental city for love of your football team, it wasn't much of a drunken rampage. According to this week's Mirror, a recent work "away weekend" for 18 employees from Railtrack descended into inebriated misbehaviour: after drinking for most of the evening, the group from the company's London headquarters is said to have become rowdy and abusive over dinner, demanded that the hotel pool be opened at 1.30am and frolicked noisily in the jacuzzi before retiring to bed.

The next day they were up bright and early for a treasure hunt-style bicycle ride, but the damage was done. Unfortunately for the Railtrack staff, some reporters from the Mirror had been staying in the hotel at the same time. The "Railtrack bosses' drunken rampage" - which even more unfortunately had coincided with day two of the Paddington disaster inquiry - was splashed across the paper's front page on Monday. "The behaviour was utterly outrageous and completely against company policy," thundered Railtrack's chief executive. "We cannot tolerate this kind of thing." Paul White, the company's national contracts manager, has been suspended, and the company is conducting an internal inquiry, vowing to sack everyone involved if the allegations are found to be correct. Talk about thumping hangovers.

If it is indeed the case that White and his colleagues were disorderly, as has been claimed, they may still be justified in feeling somewhat aggrieved. Because the fact is that many companies do indeed tolerate "this kind of thing". A great number, in fact, might be said to actively encourage it. Indeed, as drunken excesses at corporate weekends go, this behaviour is relatively tame.

Alison, 25, certainly witnessed far more raucous antics at her previous job in a media firm. "The company went on a conference to an extremely expensive hotel and took some clients, and it was completely mad. We spent tens of thousands of pounds in the bar in one night and made the staff keep serving till dawn, even though they wanted to go to bed. I have been to industry dos where people have been dancing topless on the bar in front of clients they were doing million-pound deals with." She says the tales she could tell of drink and drugs intake, and illicit inter-colleague sex in corridors and cupboards, are hardly secrets. The company's managing directors were well aware of what was going on - several of them were the worst offenders.

All well and good, one supposes, if your boss doesn't mind. But while the issue of drunken behaviour - inside or outside work - may not particularly trouble many employers and staff, employment rights experts suggest that it should. Certainly companies are wrong to believe they can blithely offer lavish hospitality and a free bar only to hastily wash their hands of the matter when staff get a little the worse for wear. One of the most notorious incidents of drunken work behaviour occurred, of all places, during a piss-up in a brewery. Three workers from Whitbread were fired for throwing beer and punches after - in another ironic twist - a seminar on behavioural skills. But in 1996 the court of appeal ruled that the three had been unfairly dismissed. Its decision was based largely on the fact that the incident had taken place out of work hours, but the judge also ruled that the company had to take some responsibility for the incident since it had laid on the free bar. The workers were awarded £2,000 each in compensation.

"It is crucial that companies have in place some guidelines on this kind of occurrence," says Tricia Jackson, a training and personnel consultant, and author of a book on drugs and alcohol policies at work. "They need to think everything through. Are there practical rules for off-site events? Quite often a company will have a blanket drugs and alcohol policy but will not have thought about the situation outside work. When employees are in their own time it becomes difficult."

The law on this subject, says Jackson, is "tricky". "On a training event, is someone working when they are sitting at the bar at 7pm or not? Can you object to someone's behaviour outside company time? It has been successfully argued that some employers have fairly dismissed staff for behaviour outside work that brought the company into disrepute. But it's ever so complex."

Certainly it seems that misbehaviour from staff who are supposedly "bonding" is an issue that employers will need to take seriously. A survey last year of 114 luxury hotels found that complaints about bad behaviour during corporate events had risen by 30% in the previous year. "Some executives are still drunk when morning sessions begin," noted the report from conference organisers Banks Sadler. "Other delegates tend to be marked out by their sexual harassment of staff, for leaving drink stains and food trodden into carpets and furnishings, and for 'talking down' to staff to make themselves feel good in front of colleagues. A minority of delegates refuse to acknowledge house rules or civilised behaviour and think they can get away with everything."

It is perhaps this arrogance that is most offensive. Staff who may be perfectly charming in their own office uncharacteristically begin to throw their weight around, intoxicated by the amount of money their party is about to spend, and according to the manager of one prestigious London hotel, it is women who are the worst. "They can be far more strident and unreasonable than men," he says. "We know the type. They waltz in like a film star and demand everyone rushes around after them. It is quite obvious they are after something for nothing, such as an upgrading, but they are never quite satisfied." The Banks Sadler report has no doubt where the blame lies. "It is very much a consequence of the open-account bar system."

"It's easier to police a total ban on alcohol," says Jackson, "but that is rarely practical and it isn't going to solve the problems either. It is argued that socialising can help people start to network and can help team-building. There's a lot to be said for relaxing with colleagues."

Jackson admits she doesn't have a single answer, but stresses that companies must avoid sending mixed messages on drunken behaviour. "In the Whitbread case, the employer providing the free bar all evening went seriously against them. In any disciplinary case the company has to show that they are consistently applying the rules. It's about making sure you don't impose rulings for employees on the shop floor when senior management have a long-lunch culture and whisky in the boardroom."

In some firms, however, life is blissfully uncomplicated. In November a group of 11 traders on a corporate weekend at a country house hotel caused £20,000 worth of damage after going on what was described as a "wrecking spree". The traders, from a London finance firm, drank 20 bottles of vintage wine at £80 a pop, then allegedly played cricket in the dining room, ripped lights off the walls and smashed a Victorian chair and coffee table, which were piled on to a log fire in the lounge. Before long the chimney had caught fire and the other 100 guests at the £180-a-night hotel had to be evacuated. The incident ended with two of the party being arrested on suspicion of arson.

The response of the company, however, was a relaxed shrug. "It seems it was just rowdiness that got out of control while they were entertaining clients and colleagues," said the company's managing director at the time. "They were relieving the stress of the City and having a good time. It was high-jinks and a case of boys behaving badly." The Railtrack employees will be hoping that their bosses may yet display the same level of understanding.

fields.headline: Tech stocks pound Perpetual
fields.trailText: Fund management group Perpetual missed the explosion in high-technology stocks at the end of last year, hammering the performance of its funds and denting its sales.
fields.body:
Fund management group Perpetual missed the explosion in high-technology stocks at the end of last year, hammering the performance of its funds and denting its sales.

However the group, which last week admitted receiving a takeover approach, insisted yesterday that it had started the second half of its financial year in better shape.

The company usually takes a 4% share of fund sales, but this proportion fell 11% in the six months to the end of March as a result of its underperformance and because it did not have a technology fund to sell to investors.

From October 1 1999 to March 10 this year, when technology stocks were forging ahead, Perpetual's previously top-selling high-income fund was ranked 95 out of 97 funds in its peer group. However, after the shake-out in technology stocks, the group said the same fund now ranked second out of 100, with first place held by another of its funds.

Roger Cornick, deputy chairman of Perpetual, said: "Our fund managers suffered for their prudence, their investment performance was killed".

Despite the downturn in sales during the period, the fund management group achieved an 18% increase in pre-tax profits to £35m after axing an advertising campaign and keeping a tight lid on costs.

Martin Arbib, the founder of the group whose family stands to receive up to £400m if a bid is agreed, said: "Looking to the future we are greatly encouraged by the recent improvement in investment performance."

The shares, which some believe could be sold to a bidder for as much as £45 each, ended the day at £38.82. A 43p dividend, a 16% increase, will be paid on June 5.

fields.headline: The eternal immobility
fields.standfirst:
Saburo Teshigawara Theatre Royal, Brighton
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Saburo Teshigawara Theatre Royal, Brighton
Rating:****
fields.body:
It takes a special presence to turn an arch of the back into high drama, but Saburo Teshigawara is one of those rare performers who could scratch his crotch and make it look like choreography. Not that anything so vulgar occurs in Absolute Zero, a performance trilogy consisting of two solos and a duet in which Teshigawara's declared intent is "to attempt to reach unattainable eternal immobility through dance". There's nothing like knowing you're beaten before you start.

But Teshigawara gives it his best shot, refining gestures of stealth and grace until they are as shiny and smooth as pebbles at the bottom of a waterfall. His charisma draws you in to what is essentially academic and infuses it with an emotional undertow that tugs at the senses.

The remarkable trick that Teshigawara pulls off is to make the moments when next to nothing is happening (and there are many) seem the most significant of all. He is a mesmerising performer, capable of breathtaking outbreaks of high voltage movement - at times it seems the electronic charge of the music is pulsing like a current through his body - so you would expect to yearn for more of the fireworks and less of the inscrutable slow motion.

But the reverse is the case. It is as if Teshigawara is expunging all the irrelevant flash with which we stuff our lives to reach a state of grace where all can be expressed in one small but perfectly formed movement. Absolute Zero reads like a life story, the opening and closing solos expressing youthful innocence and mature serenity, while the middle duet (with Kei Miyata) illustrates how our individuality is circumscribed by the social world.

It is compelling, held together by Teshigawara, the missing link between Butoh and hip hop. But there is one major flaw: when a performance is so dependent on the construction of mood and atmosphere, two intervals almost kills it stone dead. That Teshigawara is able to weave his magic anew after each break is impressive but the fractured mood means the zero of his dreams hovers tantalisingly just out of reach.

fields.headline: Brown carpets big investors
fields.standfirst: Chancellor takes up questions of funds review
fields.trailText: The government-backed review of the pension fund industry, which identified "systemic herd behaviour" in the City investors, will be put to 25 major investors from the US and Europe by Gordon Brown today.
fields.body:
The government-backed review of the pension fund industry, which identified "systemic herd behaviour" in the City investors, will be put to 25 major investors from the US and Europe by Gordon Brown today.

A the breakfast meeting at 11 Downing Street, the chancellor will have his first opportunity to pose the almost 50 questions raised by Paul Myners, the head of the Gartmore fund management group and chairman of Guardian Media Group, who is heading the investigation at the heart of the chancellor's aim to boost productivity in the economy.

As he published the consultation paper on institutional investment yesterday, Mr Myners, who will also attend the meeting, said he wanted to get behind the apparent "consensual way" pension funds and other major assets were invested.

Aware of potential criticism for bias in his review, Mr Myners, as head of the UK's largest fund management group, insisted that he was approaching the investigation with an open mind.

He admitted that he had harboured personal concerns about the multi-billion pound industry for some time. "I have been concerned for some time that we are not making the best possible use of our capital markets," Mr Myners said.

Among his concerns were whether British fund managers were "too prone to invest in established companies, rather than high risk start-ups".

His review, the consultation period of which runs until July 14, follows on from the Don Cruickshank investigation into the banking industry that led to a full-scale competition commission inquiry into banking to small and medium sized businesses. While the Cruickshank review scrutinised the way money was lent to small business, the Myners investigation will analyse the way fund managers make equity investments into such businesses.

Mr Myners admitted that the terms of the investigation, which he intends to conclude in time for the Budget next March, were wide-reaching and insisted that all the issues were as important as each other.

He is calling for responses from all sectors of the industry, including individual pension fund trustees, pensioners and people looking for finance from investment managers, on a diverse range of issues.

These include matters such as why there appears to be a reluctance to invest in venture capital to whether the benchmarks used to measure pension fund performance hinder a long-term view of investment.

In the 20-page consultant paper, available on the internet, Mr Myners said he shared the chancellor's concerns that there may be problems with the industry and that there may be factors encouraging institutional investors to follow standard investment patterns.

He said that, while it was not the government's rule to second-guess investment decisions, if there were structural or regulatory reasons why the industry was behaving in a certain manner then the government may have a role to play in removing any distortions.

 The financial services authority yesterday gave warning that paying into a personal pension, even with the tax breaks they enjoy, is no better in the long run than taking out an individual savings account, because of steep charges on pension schemes.

Fundamental questions

1 We have a large pool of long-term capital but do we invest it with a sufficiently long-term view?

2 Have we as an industry become too risk-averse, concerned more about the risk of underperformance versus some benchmark rather than the rewards of outperformance?

3 Are we too prone to invest in established companies, rather than higher risk start-ups?

4 Is the growth of indexation exacerbating a bias towards companies with large market capitalisations?

5 Do major institutions follow investment patterns that are too standard, seeking safety in numbers rather than pioneering radically different investment strategies?

fields.headline: Taboo of the madhouse
fields.standfirst:
On Raftery's Hill
Town Hall, Galway
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
On Raftery's Hill
Town Hall, Galway
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Irish playwright Marina Carr's new play - her first for Druid/the Royal Court - is a blackly hilarious piece that suddenly descends into the horror of the enclosed, incestuous world of a widower and his two daughters. The satiric language has shades of Abbey lyricists like Tom Murphy and Tom McIntyre, and the tense, taut energy of Garry Hynes' production recalls Martin McDonagh's Leenane trilogy.

But Carr's demented rural Ireland - the madhouse of hill-farmer Red Raftery and his misrule of women, the run-down farm with its putrefying animal carcass in every field - is very much her own. Red Raftery periodically wheels in with his melancholic companion, Isaac Dunne, the pair's swaggering shotguns reminiscent of some wasted aristocracy. Meanwhile Ded, Raftery's psychotic son, is a fright, covered in sores and ringworm, only coming in from the cowshed to smoke butts and eat with his hands.

Everyone knocks back whiskey, including Raftery's daughters: Dinah, the long-suffering wife-and-woman of the house, and pampered young Sorrel. Sorrel's suitor is the upright young Dara Mood who loudly speaks his mind. But Mood reckons without Red Raftery's lustful vengeance, and we are forced to witness the horrific blooding of young Sorrel.

It is a shattering lurch that changes the whole tenor of the play. But it also heightens the comic relief which is constantly provided by the daft old bird, Shalome, Red's snobbish mother. In dementia, she is forever fleeing out the door in her nightdress, off to find her own abusive, long-dead "Daddy" back in Kinnegar.

Daughter-incest seems endemic to Carr's landscape. News comes at one stage of a man who has killed himself with weedkiller after his daughter died birthing his child. Meanwhile, in Rafteryland, the women are complicit in each other's ruination. Historically, Raftery's dead wife, rather than submit to sex, sent in her 12-year-old daughter Dinah instead.

Every performance is in-your-face, and there is huge emotional complexity behind Mary Murray's sacrificial Sorrel, Tom Hickey's gigantic Red Raftery and Cara Kelly's hardy Dinah. But the production is young as yet, and has some weathering to do in certain crucial areas, not least the graphic abuse scene. Nonetheless, this piece will kick your head around: part raw, raging satire, showing the whites of its eyes; part knife-twisting acknowledgment of a reality which, as a society, we can't seem to come to terms with. Snapping in and out of modernity, this is yet another reinvention of stage-Ireland: Hynes, Carr and others keep flinging that old chestnut back at us, each time flailing brand new razor blades.

The satiric language has shades of Abbey lyricists like Tom Murphy and Tom McIntyre, and the tense, taut energy of Garry Hynes' production recalls Martin McDonagh's Leenane trilogy. But Carr's demented rural Ireland - the madhouse of hill-farmer Red Raftery and his misrule of women, the run-down farm with its putrefying animal carcass in every field - is very much her own. Red Raftery periodically wheels in with his melancholic companion, Isaac Dunne, the pair's swaggering shotguns reminiscent of some wasted aristocracy. Meanwhile Ded, Raftery's psychotic son, is a fright, covered in sores and ringworm, only coming in from the cowshed to smoke butts and eat with his hands. Everyone knocks back whiskey, including Raftery's daughters: Dinah, the long-suffering wife-and-woman of the house, and pampered young Sorrel. Sorrel's suitor is the upright young Dara Mood who loudly speaks his mind. But Mood reckons without Red Raftery's lustful vengeance, and we are forced to witness the horrific blooding of young Sorrel. It is a shattering lurch that changes the whole tenor of the play. But it also heightens the comic relief which is constantly provided by the daft old bird, Shalome, Red's snobbish mother. In dementia, she is forever fleeing out the door in her nightdress, off to find her own abusive, long-dead "Daddy" back in Kinnegar. Daughter-incest seems endemic to Carr's landscape. News comes at one stage of a man who has killed himself with weedkiller after his daughter died birthing his child. Meanwhile, in Rafteryland, the women are complicit in each other's ruination. Historically, Raftery's dead wife, rather than submit to sex, sent in her 12-year-old daughter Dinah instead. Every performance is in-your-face, and there is huge emotional complexity behind Mary Murray's sacrificial Sorrel, Tom Hickey's gigantic Red Raftery and Cara Kelly's hardy Dinah. But the production is young as yet, and has some weathering to do in certain crucial areas, not least the graphic abuse scene. Nonetheless, this piece will kick your head around: part raw, raging satire, showing the whites of its eyes; part knife-twisting acknowledgment of a reality which, as a society, we can't seem to come to terms with. Snapping in and out of modernity, this is yet another reinvention of stage-Ireland: Hynes, Carr and others keep flinging that old chestnut back at us, each time flailing brand new razor blades.

webTitle: 'Surly' Thorpe told he still has a future

fields.headline: 'Surly' Thorpe told he still has a future
fields.standfirst: Bumble's England of rebels in the wrong trousers
fields.trailText: England's chairman of selectors David Graveney telephoned Graham Thorpe yesterday morning to assure him he still had a Test future.
fields.body:
England's chairman of selectors David Graveney telephoned Graham Thorpe yesterday morning to assure him he still had a Test future.

Graveney was responding to an attack on the Surrey left-hander by the former England coach David Lloyd, who in his new autobiography has accused the player of being surly and divisive.

"I told him he was still very much part of our plans," Graveney said. "He hasn't shown much form this season but only cricket has been considered in leaving him out.

"He has to scrap for his place like everyone else. I do want him to take more of a lead in the dressing-room. Some find it difficult and he's one of them."

Lloyd, in his book Anything But Murder, said Thorpe "toured Zimbabwe in 1996 in a surly disposition and he could not or would not shake it off". Lloyd also described as "divisive" Thorpe's decision not to attend a reception with Kent members last year and criticised his non-conformist attitude to dress. Thorpe had already come under fire from the former selector Mike Gatting, who said: "He brings nothing to the table bar runs."

Thorpe opted out of last winter's tour of South Africa and was not included in the dozen players centrally contracted to the England and Wales Cricket Board. He was also overlooked for this week's first test against Zimbabwe in favour of the unproven Nick Knight when Michael Vaughan cracked the knuckle of his left hand.

Although Thorpe would be welcomed back into the side by his close friend Nasser Hussain, the England captain, his form this season has been dire and it was revealed yesterday that he had fractured his left thumb while practising with Surrey on Sunday.

The only fitness worry among the squad England did select is the uncapped leg-spinner Chris Schofield, who has a viral infection. He was sick several times yesterday morning but is expected to be fit for selection.

If Schofield and Steve Harmison do win their first caps it may be something of an anti-climax, as the crowd is likely to be the smallest for a Lord's test in modern history. Only 8,000 tickets have been sold for the first day, followed by 11,000 and 10,000 for the next two days.

Another bowler desperate to play is Ed Giddins, who was dropped after his only test at the Oval last year despite taking four wickets. "I wasn't really fit then," said Giddins, who spent £7,000 of his own money at the Lilleshall fitness centre over the winter. "But this time, if picked, I really want to do myself justice."

webTitle: Bumble's England of rebels in the wrong trousers

fields.headline: Bumble's England of rebels in the wrong trousers
fields.standfirst: 'Surly' Thorpe told he still has a future
fields.trailText: Harry Pearson "David Lloyd's new autobiography does not shed direct light on why cricketers draw such inspiration from programmes aimed at younger viewers, though reading his description of the England test team's antics during his spell in charge it is easy to guess."
fields.body:
The former England coach David "Bumble" Lloyd is one of a number of cricketers whose nicknames derive from children's TV - in his case a Michael Bentine character. Other notable examples include Phil "Daffy" DeFreitas, Andrew "Fred" Flintoff and, of course, Chris Smith who was known as "Why Don't You Just Switch Off Your Television Set And Go And Do Something More Interesting Instead" Smith. Or he was in my house.

Lloyd's new autobiography, Anything But Murder, does not shed direct light on why cricketers draw such inspiration from programmes aimed at younger viewers, though reading his description of the England test team's antics during his spell in charge it is easy to guess.

Nowadays county sides style themselves after wild beasts, so that damp afternoons in Basingstoke or Bletchley are rendered more exotic. The genial Lancastrian's memoirs, however, point to an altogether more prosaic truth. It is a jungle out there all right, but strictly of the blackboard variety.

Lloyd re-introduces all the figures familiar from our schooldays: the nerdy outcast, the golden boy gone bad, the non-conformist, the lad whose bad behaviour satisfies a craving for attention. Indeed the reader must conclude that, if discipline on and off the field is ever to be properly enforced, the England and Wales Cricket Board should drop the current system of financial penalties in favour of the offending player being forced to stay behind after matches and empty the litterbins.

According to Lloyd, Graham Thorpe is the class rebel. Cricket has a long association with rebelliousness, of course. It began in 1850 when Garibaldi and his Thousand were skittled out for 43 by Alfred Mynn and "ten gentlemen of Kent" and reached its apotheosis in the late-1960s when Scarborough Festival welcomed a TN Pearce's XI which included Patrice Lamumba and Abbie Hoffman (Ulrike Meinhoff was scheduled to keep wicket but on, discovering she was a lady, the skipper Roy Virgin sensibly instructed her to "seize the means of production" (ie two sliced loaves, half-a-dozen eggs and a bottle of salad cream) and make the teas instead. Even today the selectors demonstrate their adherence to the Berlin situationist school of absurdist anarchy by sometimes picking Ian Salisbury.

Sadly, it appears that Lloyd believes Thorpe is no theoretician, unlikely to rouse the masses with assertions that "change will come from the barrel of a Gunn and Moore", but more the angst-riddled Mickey Rourke-type to be found in sixth form common rooms. Perhaps this is not so surprising. After all his nickname, "Thorpie", fairly shimmers with uncontrolled rage at the unfairness of it all.

As an example of the Surrey left-hander's seditious behaviour Lloyd cites the time during a tour of the West Indies when he appeared at an official reception aboard John Paul Getty's yacht wearing jeans. To some this may appear trivial but Lloyd knows what boys are like. Where Thorpe leads, impressionable juniors will follow. Civilisation is only a veneer. Left to their own devices beneath the palm trees, it is a potential Lord of the Flies scenario: one minute non-regulation trousers, the next loincloths, war paint and the ritual slaughter of the fat lad using pointy sticks. No wonder John Crawley never looked comfortable in an England cap.

Poor Andy Caddick, meanwhile, is regarded as a nerd by the more popular boys. Lloyd suspects this is because he moved in different social circles and was not au fait with the clique's in-jokes and expressions. I bet his Mum bought him the wrong sort of trainers too.

Lloyd is a shrewd and acerbic observer, though he does make one lapse of judgment, in my view, when dealing with The Head Boy Who Let Down The Whole School, Adam Hollioake. Apparently the Surrey skipper once stopped his car in Hampshire to yell abuse at players in a village match.

Lloyd sees this as a breach of discipline. Personally I feel it shows a commendable concern with standards at the game's grass roots on the part of the dashing all-rounder. Indeed Hollioake's example should be taken up by more of his colleagues.

We are always told that club cricket in this country needs a tougher edge. What is more likely to provide it than the thought that some giant of the world game like Peter Such might pull his sponsored Renault Laguna on to the grass verge and yell "Have you never heard of the long-barrier position, lardarse?" at the fine-leg?

webTitle: Six players fighting for three final places

fields.headline: Six players fighting for three final places
fields.standfirst:
The squad
Fowler put on finals footing
fields.trailText: David James
fields.body:
David James

England debut: March 1997 v Mexico.

Strengths: Has had excellent first season at Aston Villa, conceding 34 goals in 38 games.

Weaknesses : Has traditionally been liable to the odd rush of blood, particularly on crosses and corners.

What he has to prove: That the 'Calamity James' tag is no longer justified and he can be trusted not to relapse.

Richard Wright

England debut: No caps

Strengths: Regarded as the best young keeper in country.

Weaknesses : Has known no pressure at the top level. Has played only three Premiership games for Ipswich.

What he has to prove: That he would not freeze if thrown in at the deep end.

Kieron Dyer

England debut: September 1999 v Luxembourg. Won 6-0

Strengths : Skilful, quick player with good vision and an eye for goal.Versatility

Weaknesses : Question marks remain about his defensive capabilities, particularly at international level.

What he has to prove : That he is strong enough not to leave England vulnerable down the right.

Steven Gerrard

England debut: No caps

Strengths: An impressive season for Liverpool. Strong tackler who could challenge Dyer at the problem right-back spot.

Weaknesses : Not so good going forward. Temperament.

What he has to prove: That Euro 2000 has not come too soon.

Jason Wilcox

England debut : May 1996 v Hungary. Won 3-0

Strengths : Natural left-sided player and a good crosser who set up countless goals for Alan Shearer during their time together at Blackburn.

Weaknesses : Does not score too often.

What he must prove : That he can beat world-class opponents, create chances and get into scoring positions.

Nick Barmby

England debut : March 1995 v Uruguay. Drew 0-0

Strengths : Skilful and creative, he is in good scoring form.

Weaknesses : More a clever player than a crosser of the ball and defensively more suspect than Wilcox

What he has to prove: That he is not too lightweight.

webTitle: At the very foot of Buddha stands His Poshness Beckham

fields.headline: At the very foot of Buddha stands His Poshness Beckham
fields.trailText: First there was Eric Cantona depicted as Jesus, then Ronaldo posing as Christ the Redeemer. Now David Beckham has joined the exclusive list of footballers who could be suffering from delusions of deity.
fields.body:
First there was Eric Cantona depicted as Jesus, then Ronaldo posing as Christ the Redeemer. Now David Beckham has joined the exclusive list of footballers who could be suffering from delusions of deity.

Resplendent in Manchester United kit but completed, alas, before the £300 'short Beck and sides', this sculpture of Mr Posh himself has taken pride of place in one of Thailand's most popular places of worship.

At a spot usually reserved for angels, Beckham has been immortalised by the sculptor Thongruang Haemhod at the foot of Buddha in Bangkok's Pariwas Temple.

The hair may be a touch dated but the elaborate finishing of gold leaves and the sculpture's prominent position in the midst of more than 100 statues of supreme beings should appease Victoria.

"Football has become a religion with millions of followers," says the temple's senior monk Chan Theerapunyo. "So, to be up to date, we have to open our minds and share the feelings of the millions who admire Beckham.

"This is contemporary art and we want the people of this and the next generation to know what was happening in the year 2000."

Beckham, of course, gained even greater notoriety for his crosses when he posed for a photo-shoot draped in crucifixes at Easter last year.

But even if the Church is crying sacrilege he still has some way to go before moving in the same mysterious ways as the previous incumbent of Manchester United's No7 jersey.

An eight-foot, luridly coloured Cantona (or Le Dieu, as the Gallic genius may prefer to be known) sparked an unholy row at Manchester's City Art Gallery in Michael Browne's interpretation of Piero della Francesca's Resurrection of Christ and Andrea Mantegna's Julius Caesar on his Triumphal Chariot.

Before that Diego Maradona infamously claimed his first goal against England in 1986 was "the hand of God", although who is responsible for Diego's current waistline is anyone's guess.

Ronaldo, Brazilian by birth but sometimes (when not injured) lending his feet to football miracles in Milan, confirmed his divine qualities by posing as Christ not in Rome but above Rio de Janeiro. "The Phenomenon", as he is known in Italy, was advertising Italian tyres.

fields.headline: Popescu dreams of repeat
fields.standfirst: He put one over Seaman in the north London derby and he plans to do the same for Galatasaray
fields.trailText: He put one over Seaman in the north London derby and he plans to do the same for Galatasaray. Gica Popescu talks to Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
Gica Popescu does not mention an ancestral link to Romania's gypsy fortune-tellers but already he can picture his winning goal against Arsenal and the wild celebrations. The decisive moment is simple. Running on to a pass he hammers the ball beyond David Seaman. The Galatasaray defender talks about the moment as if it has already happened.

Then again, it has. Five years ago, during a brief stay at Tottenham, Popescu secured a 1-0 win over George Graham's Arsenal side. His opponents that night included not only Seaman but Lee Dixon, Ray Parlour and Nigel Winterburn. They will not need reminding that a former Spurs player, Nayim, spoiled Arsenal's last European final in 1995.

"I hope to score the winning goal again," Popescu said as he prepared for tomorrow's Copenhagen final. "I have great memories of that match. It was Tottenham's first win against Arsenal for four years." Not quite. In fact it was their first for 20 months but in north London derby terms that presumably feels about twice as long.

So, too, did the fortnight which separated the two legs of Galatasaray's semi-final against Leeds. Popescu and his team-mates were at their pre-match base when they learned of the fatal stabbings. They shared the horror and disgust. The extreme emotions and the bodyguard protection is not something they want to go through again.

"I think and I hope it will not be a problem," Popescu says. "The supporters have to remember it is a football game. They have to forget what happened in Istanbul. It is bad history - very bad history - but they have to think about fair play.

"The fans must remember it was not Galatasaray who killed. We had nothing to do with it. We were in our camp and we saw the terrible things that happened on television. But what can we do? We are football players and we do our jobs. We had nothing to do with the killers."

With 96 international caps and a spell as Barcelona's captain, Popescu has experienced pressure and intensity few can match. But the fervour which accompanied Galatasaray in the semi-finals touched him.

"On the day of the first game everyone talked only about what happened the previous night," he recalls. "It was a horrible day and terrible for Turkey's image. Everyone thought it was the supporters of Galatasaray. It was very difficult but we tried to separate the game and what had happened. It wasn't easy to play in those circumstances.

"Then at Leeds there was a lot of pressure. We knew the media talked a lot about what had happened in Istanbul and people were talking about revenge. It was very difficult for us with all the bodyguards and the security on the plane and in the hotel. And the pressure from the crowd when we came out was terrible. They said a lot of bad words about us. They tried to intimidate us but we kept our heads."

That should be little surprise. Ask Popescu about the qualities of this Galatasaray side and the first things he mentions are spirit and mental strength. The horrors of the Turkish earthquake and the Istanbul killings have brought them closer together. Add a sprinkling of world-class talent and it is easy to understand their progress.

The spine of the team is outstanding, from Popescu at the back to Hakan Sukur in attack via Gheorghe Hagi. Bobby Robson, who coached Popescu at PSV Eindhoven and Barcelona, is glowing in his assessment of the 33-year-old. He recalls how the deal to take Popescu to PSV from Steaua Bucharest included two washing machines, three televisions and other Philips technology. Popescu was worth every plug cord.

"He has all the ingredients of a top player," said the Newcastle manager. "He's a big-match player; he's got that temperament. There was quality in everything he did. It will certainly be a test for Arsenal to get past him because he's a gem."

The description at Leeds might rhyme more with feet after accusations that he play-acted to get Harry Kewell sent off. Popescu - "dead honest," says Robson - denies it.

He admitted, though, that the style of English football never suited him. And having left Gerry Francis's Spurs for Johan Cruyff's Barcelona to chase his dream of a European trophy, the Cup Winners' Cup duly arrived under Robson.

Not that he is content with that. Tomorrow a country will be watching and hoping. Even many Fenerbahce fans are rooting for their rivals. "This is the first time a Turkish club has been in a European final," Popescu says. "We will be playing with a lot of determination. It is important not only for Galatasaray but for the whole Turkish nation."

They must hope the tarot cards do indeed point to a Popescu repeat.
