Ask Popescu about the qualities of this Galatasaray side and the first things he mentions are spirit and mental strength. The horrors of the Turkish earthquake and the Istanbul killings have brought them closer together. Add a sprinkling of world-class talent and it is easy to understand their progress. The spine of the team is outstanding, from Popescu at the back to Hakan Sukur in attack via Gheorghe Hagi. Bobby Robson, who coached Popescu at PSV Eindhoven and Barcelona, is glowing in his assessment of the 33-year-old. He recalls how the deal to take Popescu to PSV from Steaua Bucharest included two washing machines, three televisions and other Philips technology. Popescu was worth every plug cord. "He has all the ingredients of a top player," said the Newcastle manager. "He's a big-match player; he's got that temperament. There was quality in everything he did. It will certainly be a test for Arsenal to get past him because he's a gem." The description at Leeds might rhyme more with feet after accusations that he play-acted to get Harry Kewell sent off. Popescu - "dead honest," says Robson - denies it. He admitted, though, that the style of English football never suited him. And having left Gerry Francis's Spurs for Johan Cruyff's Barcelona to chase his dream of a European trophy, the Cup Winners' Cup duly arrived under Robson. Not that he is content with that. Tomorrow a country will be watching and hoping. Even many Fenerbahce fans are rooting for their rivals. "This is the first time a Turkish club has been in a European final," Popescu says. "We will be playing with a lot of determination. It is important not only for Galatasaray but for the whole Turkish nation." They must hope the tarot cards do indeed point to a Popescu repeat.

fields.headline: Danish police on red alert
fields.trailText: Fans arriving in Copenhagen for tomorrow's Uefa Cup final will be faced with the biggest football-security operation Denmark has ever mounted amid growing fears of trouble between Turkish and English fans.
fields.body:
Fans arriving in Copenhagen for tomorrow's Uefa Cup final will be faced with the biggest football-security operation Denmark has ever mounted amid growing fears of trouble between Turkish and English fans.

Almost 20% of the Danish police force will be on duty for the Galatasaray v Arsenal match and a team of Turkish magistrates has already flown into the capital to deal with potential troublemakers from their own country.

As many as 2,000 police officers will be on duty and will be working closely with their west Yorkshire and Turkish counterparts, who will be in the city to help identify known troublemakers. Dozens of plain-clothes officers will also be mingling with the crowds.

Around 24,000 Turkish and English fans are expected in the city while another 9,000 tickets went on general sale before it was known who had qualified for the final.

It is believed that the majority of them have found their way on to the black market, with Turks in particular paying high prices for them, raising concerns over segregation in the Parken stadium.

A Turkish anti-terrorism squad is also travelling with the Galatasaray team due to fears that players might be threatened in the run-up to the match. All the hotels used by players and officials, and the stadium itself, will be checked out by sniffer dogs at least twice before the match kicks off.

Danish authorities have already warned fans that they will not tolerate trouble and stated that those arrested will be immediately deported. However, police have decided not to close bars in the city, where the bulk of the fans are expected to arrive tomorrow.

Fears of violence have increased following the death of two Leeds United fans on the eve of the semi-final first leg in Istanbul last month.

Danish police say they have received intelligence reports that Leeds fans are planning to attend the final to attack Galatasaray fans, and police in London said last week that they know of Arsenal troublemakers planning to travel to Copenhagen.

Police patrols in the centre of the capital have already been stepped up. A special fence is also being erected at the stadium to keep rival fans apart.

The past few days have also seen an increase in threats posted on the internet against Galatasaray supporters, although British police are quick to point out that they consider many of them to be mere bravado.

Mogens Lauridsen, the Copenhagen police chief who is in charge of the security operation, said: "We can't keep the two teams' fans apart all the time but we're intensifying patrolling in areas with pubs and restaurants. We'll have people everywhere."

The British government, meanwhile, has warned English fans that anyone identified causing trouble at Euro 2000 next month will be banned from following any English club's matches in Europe for 10 years.

"This ban is the harshest punishment handed out to English football fans; we will not tolerate any misbehaviour," said Lord Bassam, the Home Office minister with a brief for football hooliganism.

 Jose Antonio Lopez Nieto of Spain will referee tomorrow's Uefa Cup final. The 42-year-old officiated at Leeds' home game with Spartak Moscow in the same competition last December. Both linesmen and the fourth official are also from Spain.

fields.headline: Fowler put on finals footing
fields.standfirst:
The squad
Six players fighting for three final places
fields.trailText: David Lacey reviews Kevin Keegan's preliminary squad selection and finds ominous signs that all will not be well at the back.
fields.body:
Whatever else happens in the European Championship England probably will not play like a team with two left feet. In fact Kevin Keegan's final squad may include only one naturally left-footed player, Jason Wilcox, if Robbie Fowler fails to convince the England coach that he is sufficiently match-fit to be included.

Keegan travelled to Valley Parade on Sunday with the intention of checking Fowler's state of health when Liverpool met Bradford City. Not that his journey was really necessary, Fowler having been left out following a bust-up with Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier.

So now Fowler will have to prove his current fitness in training next week when England begin preparations for the warm-up matches against Brazil, Ukraine and Malta. Then, and only then, will Keegan decide if it is worthwhile playing the Liverpool striker against Brazil or Ukraine, after which the England coach will reduce by six the squad of 28 he announced yesterday.

"Robbie's general fitness may be OK," Keegan said, "but his match fitness is something else. I've got to see him in a training session to find out if he is sharp enough to play in a major tournament. If I think it's right to put him in, then I'll put him in.

"If I do pick him then I've got to leave out one of my other five strikers. It's up to Robbie to give me that problem." It is assumed that the fifth striker's place lies between Fowler and Manchester United's Andy Cole, although Keegan was at pains yesterday to cast doubt on this theory.

"Whoever I leave out I'm going to be hammered," the England coach observed gloomily. "It's just a question of how I get hammered. That's part of the job." True enough, although Keegan will only discover just how punitive the media's anvil can be once Euro 2000 is under way.

Not that the Fowler-Cole debate is entirely relevant to the sort of difficulties England are likely to face in their first-round group games with Portugal, Germany and Romania, countries against whom they have won only four times in a total of 18 European Championship or World Cup encounters. Neither striker has so far come remotely close to reproducing his club form in internationals and of the two Fowler alone has scored for England.

Keegan is likely to encounter more problems in midfield and at full-back. The inclusion of Jamie Redknapp, recently recovered from a knee injury, as a possible alternative to Dennis Wise, hardly makes the heart pound with anticipation, and while there might be a case for taking Nick Barmby as a cover on the left Ray Parlour, Arsenal's serving man, does not really come into the argument.

The situation at full-back will still be dire even if Kieron Dyer makes the Euro 2000 squad. That an England squad of 28 should include only two specialists in these positions, and one of those, Phil Neville, is a right-footed left-back, shows how thin the nation is in the type of footballers who once queued up for caps.

It is hard to believe that Keegan will not take Gary Neville although yesterday he did remark that "to ask certain people to play slightly out of their normal position is not a problem for us". This, and a later observation that Steven Gerrard, the Liverpool 19-year-old who seems assured of a squad place, could play at right-back as well as midfield, did little to allay suspicions that the older Neville may be left behind. Yet, if Keegan is going to leave a defender out then surely it should be the superfluous centre-back Rio Ferdinand.

At this distance the idea of using Gerrard at right-back looks like theory running ahead of reason. Dyer would be a better bet although he, like Gerrard, is happiest in midfield. Keegan laughed off the idea of every member of the team being able to play in his favourite position but there are limits to the number of people you can move around.

This squad is worthy but unremarkable and Fowler is not the only player whose fitness is in doubt. Martin Keown, Tony Adams, Michael Owen, Gary Neville and Redknapp have all had recent problems. Ron Greenwood, Bobby Robson and Graham Taylor, among Keegan's England predecessors, have all suffered through losing key players to injuries suffered just before or during major tournaments.

Reasonably strong in goal, at centre-back and up front and able to call on players of genuinely high quality in David Beckham, Paul Scholes, Owen, Adams and, if he can shed some years, Alan Shearer, England should make satisfactory progress this summer provided they are able to get off to a sound start against Portugal.

The downside is that if Keegan wants to play with four at the back his choice is already restricted and if he does not take Gary Neville he could find himself forced to use the 3-5-2 formation exposed by Romania in Toulouse in the last World Cup. The bigger the tournament the more ill-fitting your square pegs are likely to be.

webTitle: The man who makes Zimbabwe tremble

fields.headline: The man who makes Zimbabwe tremble
fields.standfirst: Duncan Fletcher plans to make life for his old side as hard on the field as off, writes  Donald McRae
fields.trailText: Duncan Fletcher plans to make life for his old side as hard on the field as off, writes Donald McRae.
fields.body:
"I don't want to appear callous," Duncan Fletcher says with the voice of a man who has mastered the neutral tone of the sporting professional, "but there won't be room for emotion. Events unfolding 6,000 miles away can have no real bearing on my own job. I just want us to go out and win every game we play. The fact that the opposition happens to be Zimbabwean is, for the most part, incidental."

That mild qualification of "for the most part" may hold the key to both the success of the disarmingly unobtrusive Fletcher and the outcome of test cricket's basement scrap between England and Zimbabwe, which begins on Thursday at Lord's.

In his seemingly delicate position as a Zimbabwean now coaching England in his first home series against his troubled country of origin, Fletcher is notably stoical. Yet he is too shrewd a strategist not to make the most of his intimate knowledge of the vulnerable Zimbabweans - a team whose primary virtues of boundless optimism and spirit have been blunted by the political crisis engulfing their country.

The Zimbabweans themselves are without illusion when reflecting on Fletcher's significance. When six members of the visiting squad are asked to name the man they fear most in English cricket, five point to Fletcher. The sixth, Zimbabwe's own coach Andy Pycroft, initially highlights the threat of Andy Caddick and Darren Gough. But he soon provides a more telling insight into Fletcher's potentially crucial impact.

"I know him very well," Pycroft confirms. "He was Zimbabwe's captain when I played and I eventually succeeded him. Duncan is always very astute when analysing opponents and identifying their weaknesses. And he obviously knows the Zimbabwean character and temperament inside out. He understands better than anyone what gets us going and what brings us down."

Fletcher defines the Zimbabwean cricketing psyche as being based on "the determination to keep grinding away. They've got some very effective cricketers who niggle away in the hope that you'll lose patience and make a mistake. They bowl relentless line and length, believing that you will eventually crumble. It's my job to ensure England keep their concentration. That task will keep my emotions in check."

Yet Fletcher admits to more turbulent feelings when he accepted the apparently poisoned position of England coach. He remembers his trepidation in the build-up to last winter's tour of South Africa.

"I had a lot of reservations and was told repeatedly: 'Duncan, be very careful when you walk into that [England] dressing-room. It won't be like a Western Province or Glamorgan dressing-room where there is an overwhelming sense of fun and camaraderie. The England atmosphere is sour and negative.' I didn't know any of the players and so I was very worried."

England's early disasters in Johannesburg mirrored Fletcher's apprehension with traumatic effect. "We faced our nightmare scenario in the first test," he says. "Two runs on the board, four men in the pavilion. I sat there thinking: 'Hell, this cannot be happening.' I couldn't imagine a worse start to my career as a test coach.

"We took an almighty knock and the press were aggressive. The guys, however, held their heads high and I did my best to encourage them by creating this bubble where we'd work hard but, most of all, enjoy each other's company. Before I came into the job I was described as a disciplinarian. Yet every team I've coached has, more than anything, enjoyed themselves.

"I was delighted to discover a great bunch of guys. The England dressing-room was as happy as any I'd known. For me that was the most heartening aspect of the whole tour."

England's final test victory in rainy Pretoria, when Hansie Cronje engineered a result, has been tainted by the betting scandal which Fletcher says "rocked me as much as anyone. It made me wonder where cricket could go after such a devastating revelation.

"But I don't believe Cronje threw that match. The South Africans were really annoyed that they'd lost to us. They're either the greatest actors in the world or we simply beat them by reaching a challenging total of 250 in 70 overs."

Fletcher believes this summer's series against Zimbabwe and West Indies present an ideal opportunity for England to mount a recovery. "We lack Australia's depth," he admits, "but we have a chance to get the team into decent shape. There's still a lot wrong with the English game but we have a group of players who are going somewhere.

"Nasser Hussain deserves a lot of praise. I just like the guy. He's a good captain who knows what he wants. I've always said the captain is the manager of the shop and the coach is his chief consultant. We work very well together."

England's Zimbabwean consultant will have a former compatriot uppermost in mind when he offers a "quiet word of advice" to each of the players this week. Graeme Hick's perennial "comeback" resumes on Thursday.

Fletcher, who knew Hick when he was showing Bradmanesque potential as a Zimbabwean teenager, is convinced that a lasting resurrection is possible for a player whose commitment and temperament have since been questionable.

"We need more senior pros," Fletcher emphasises, "to support Hussain, Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart. There's no doubt that Graeme Hick is a great batter who could be at the core of our team. I still think he can finally deliver true quality at test level. They certainly rate Hick in Zimbabwe. It's time for him to earn that same respect in this country."

fields.headline: Rudolph Giuliani
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Big Apple's hard-hitting mayor on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the Big Apple's hard-hitting mayor on the net
fields.body:
1. Rudolph Giuliani, New York's controversial mayor, has been denying reports that he will step down from the race for the senate because of his prostate cancer.

2. First Lady Hillary Clinton, Giuliani's rival for the seat, will have been cheered by the news of his possible demise (reported in Monday's Newsweek).

3. Giuliani had enjoyed a resurgence in popularity after announcing that he was suffering from the disease.

4. But don't think New Yorkers have gone soft; one well-wisher wrote: "I pray for you and I hope you beat this dreaded, horrible thing. And I'm talking about Hillary, not the cancer."

5. In fairness, Giuliani shows no waning in his vitality. He has reportedly abandoned his mistress, and announced that he is seeking a separation from his wife, in order to spend more time with his "good friend" Judith Nathan.

6. He's never been far from controversy. As mayor of New York, he's presided over a massive reduction in crime rates, although at the expense of race relations, civil liberties and the reputation of the NYPD.

7. So much so that New York's police force is under investigation by the US justice department, for the alleged shooting (with 41 bullets) of an unarmed black man.

8. Giuliani also recently kicked up a fuss over the display of Britart's Sensation exhibition, which he described as "sick".

9. Rudy's influence spreads far and wide. His "success" as mayor of New York was influential in the decision to appoint a mayor for London.

10. He is not, though, without his admirers. Rudy's robust approach to law and order has lured a prominent British politician over the pond to see how it's done: who else but Ann Widdecombe?

But don't think New Yorkers have gone soft; one well-wisher wrote: "I pray for you and I hope you beat this dreaded, horrible thing. And I'm talking about Hillary, not the cancer." 5. In fairness, Giuliani shows no waning in his vitality. He has reportedly abandoned his mistress, and announced that he is seeking a separation from his wife, in order to spend more time with his "good friend" Judith Nathan. 6. He's never been far from controversy. As mayor of New York, he's presided over a massive reduction in crime rates, although at the expense of race relations, civil liberties and the reputation of the NYPD. 7. So much so that New York's police force is under investigation by the US justice department, for the alleged shooting (with 41 bullets) of an unarmed black man. 8. Giuliani also recently kicked up a fuss over the display of Britart's Sensation exhibition, which he described as "sick". 9. Rudy's influence spreads far and wide. His "success" as mayor of New York was influential in the decision to appoint a mayor for London. 10. He is not, though, without his admirers. Rudy's robust approach to law and order has lured a prominent British politician over the pond to see how it's done: who else but Ann Widdecombe?

fields.headline: Ofsted admits errors at school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The education watchdog, Ofsted, has admitted that mistakes were made during a school inspection after which a dedicated teacher killed herself.
fields.body:
The education watchdog, Ofsted, has admitted that mistakes were made during a school inspection after which a dedicated teacher killed herself.

Pamela Relf, 57, committed suicide in January. Inspectors had criticised her teaching on their visit to Middlefield primary school in Eynesbury, Cambridgeshire, two months earlier.

Miss Relf, the longest serving teacher at Middlefield with a career spanning 36 years, felt unable to return to work after the Office for Standards in Education inspection, which left her stressed and tearful.

She jumped into a river, leaving a handwritten note which made it clear that she could no longer cope with the stress of modern teaching.

"I am now finding the stress of my job too much. The pace of work and the long days are more than I can do," she wrote. The coroner recorded a verdict of suicide while Miss Relf was suffering from depression.

Yesterday Ofsted confirmed that it had partly upheld a complaint brought by the school, admitting that there had been a breakdown in communication between its inspection team and members of the staff.

The school's complaint centred on the way the inspection was carried out, rather than its conclusion that there were serious weaknesses. The headteacher, Brian Rayner, felt it was not conducted in the same professional and rigorous manner as inspections there in the past.

Yesterday Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers - the union Miss Relf had joined - said that since the school made a formal complaint, Ofsted should publish the results of the inquiry. "We want assurances that Ofsted will take immediate action to ensure that these mistakes are not repeated."

fields.headline: Headmistress 'slapped boy's face'
fields.trailText: A headmistress lost her temper and slapped an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face when he started struggling with her after being told he could not go swimming, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A headmistress lost her temper and slapped an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face when he started struggling with her after being told he could not go swimming, a court heard yesterday.

Marjorie Evans, 55, who has been suspended since the alleged incident, denies assaulting the boy at a junior school in south Wales in September last year.

She claims that the boy, who has learning difficulties, tried to push, punch and butt her.

Abergavenny magistrates' court was told that the incident took place on a day when there was a "crisis" in the school because the teacher who usually took the boy's class was in hospital.

Christopher Rees, prosecuting, said some pupils were taken swimming by another teacher. But the pupil who is alleged to have been assaulted could not go because he had been banned.

The boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, and a number of other pupils who had also been banned from swimming, were due to be taught that day by Mrs Evans.

Mr Rees said that when the headmistress told the boy he was not going swimming he became sullen "and to some extent unruly".

When he refused to get his work she took him out of his class and walked to the main school building. The boy became physically difficult and struggled with the headteacher, who then slapped him.

The boy, now aged 11, said an argument began between him and Mrs Evans over trays in which the pupils kept their work.

"She grabbed me and took me outside and picked my trays up and pushed them against my chest.

"I pushed her back. I pushed her and she fell backwards on to the bench."

He said the teacher then grabbed him by the collar and took him towards the school's main building. She held his arm and slapped him across the face.

An 11-year-old classmate of the boy said the headmistress would make pupils cry by shouting at them.

He described the slap as a "stinger" which made the boy cry and whimper afterwards.

Ian Williams, defending, suggested the whole story had been a plan hatched by the boy and his mother to get Mrs Evans into trouble.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Till birth us do part
fields.standfirst: As a heavily pregnant Cherie Booth prepares to take on her husband's government in the High Court, Guardian political correspondent Lucy Ward examines the couple's professional differences over parental leave rights.
fields.trailText: As a heavily pregnant Cherie Booth prepares to take on her husband's government in the High Court Guardian political correspondent Lucy Ward examines the couple's professional differences over parental leave rights.
fields.body:
Breakfast in the Blair household must have been a tense affair this morning. With the arrival of Downing Street's newest resident only days away, Cherie Booth, top employment lawyer and - incidentally - wife of the prime minister, Tony Blair, prepared to take on her husband's government in the High Court over TUC claims that ministers have broken European law in excluding 2.7 million working parents from new parental leave rights.

Her husband, meanwhile, has just confided to the New York Times that, while he will reduce his workload around May 24 - the day his fourth child is due - full paternity leave is not an option.

The first couple's professional differences of opinion over family-friendly working, or work-life balance as the government now prefers to call it, reflect tensions at the heart of the Blair administration which have led to today's court case.

The row between unions and ministers centres on the fact that, while the New Labour government has gone much further than its Tory predecessor in signing up to the European Parental Leave Directive, it has chosen to implement the law in a way many regard as minimal and deeply grudging.

The new right entitles each parent to take up to 13 weeks off work to spend with their child up to its fifth birthday, but the leave is unpaid and applies only to parents of children born before last December 15, when the law was introduced.

Ms Booth QC, in what will probably be her last court appearance before giving birth, argued that the cut-off date was an unlawful restriction, based on a false interpretation of the directive. Applying the right from December 1999 may be fine for the new Blair baby, but it excludes 2.7 million working parents of older children, according to the TUC.

Including those parents in the scheme would cost employers around £50m, which Ms Booth claimed was "small beer" compared with the £2.5bn cost of the minimum wage regulations.

The smart money is on Ms Booth, and suggests that the government will lose the case, although a judgment is not due for around a week. Either way, the clash exposes the impossibility for the government of keeping business sweet - the main concern of the Department of Trade and Industry - while simultaneously encouraging a family-friendly culture in which parents are able to balance work and caring for their children.

Those sympathising with the ministers' dilemma should note that other EU countries have avoided becoming similarly bogged down in restrictions by opting from the first to abide by the spirit of the directive. No other member state has attempted to introduce a cut-off date, with the exception of Ireland, which has recently backed down after receiving an official opinion against the move from the European Commission. Many other countries, including Italy and Sweden, have been more generous still, making parental leave available to all working parents with children up to the age of eight.

Britain, however, is still trying to reconcile two impulses, aiming to achieve a culture change towards more family-friendly working with the minimum of regulation. Tony Blair can only become more aware of the stresses involved in that compromise as he rushes between baby and office attempting to make a go of his "third way" version of paternity leave.

fields.headline: Telford takes lead in broadband
fields.standfirst: ... and Johnny Herbert's virtual racing car is among the latest projects to enter the National Grid for Learning.
fields.trailText: ... and Johnny Herbert's virtual racing car is among the latest projects to enter the National Grid for Learning.
fields.body:
The UK's biggest e-learning facility is being installed in schools in Telford and Wrekin. The £7.5m system is the first secure, high-speed broadband network and the largest school-based video-conferencing facility in Europe. Telford and Wrekinês Grid for Learning, funded by the council and supplied by ICL, Telewest and Synetrix, comprises 500 desktop video-conferencing units and 15 group-conferencing facilities. This infrastructure will enable both individual and whole-class interactive tuition, as well as the simultaneous broadcast of lessons from a central service to the areaês 85 primary and secondary schools. Parents can become more involved in their childrenês education when the network is extended into local homes and libraries.

 The Minister for Learning and Technology, Michael Wills, has announced an extensive evaluation of the gridês content to test the effectiveness of technology in learning. Games, animation and video will be assessed for classroom use in the UK and in developing nations. Speaking at the first Digital Learning Resources Conference in London, he said the Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia project will also be expanded to include reviews of content available on the internet. An Education and Training ICT Export Strategy Group will be formed to support this further work in digital resources.

 Northern Irelandês ICT programme is set to boom with the provision of laptop computers for every teacher over the next three years. The Western Education and Library Board has so far invested £7m in a pilot project and initial orders of the free equipment. IT company Sx3 has distributed almost 5,000 Compaq laptops, complete with Windows 2000 software and 24-hour technical support. The contract will see the country's 1,300 schools better equipped to meet the targets of the NGfL and Northern Ireland's Classroom 2000 initiative.

 In England, more than 13,000 teachers have taken up the governmentês offer of assistance to buy their own computers. The Computers for Teachers scheme is contributing £20m to the cost of accredited computer packages. The DfEE, says teachers are buying a broad range of products, but with a bias toward desktop PCs. Those who have the forms can submit them with the relevant receipt and documents up to June 5. A second phase is planned to run next year.

 Maths is being driven forward with a national competition in which children devise a virtual Grand Prix racing car. Working in teams of four, primary-school pupils develop mathematics and ICT skills by calculating their carês fuel requirements, pit-stop timings and maximum safe speeds. Launched with Jaguar Racing driver Johnny Herbert at Silverstone, the Grand Prix Online Maths Challenge supports the government's Maths Year 2000 initiative. Online regional heats between schools will be held in October, with finals in November. The champions will win computer equipment and a day out at a Jaguar Racing event. Schools can download the free software from mathschallenge. ngfl.becta.org.uk

 The first managed services contract has been activated between Dumfries and Galloway Council, IBM and DIALnet. The £1.9m, three-year deal will see IBM supply 16 secondary schools in the county with PCs and cabling infrastructure, while DIALnet will provide the internet connection, including free dial-up access (from teachers' and pupils' homes) and web mail.

webTitle: Rebrov signs for Spurs in £11m deal

fields.headline: Rebrov signs for Spurs in £11m deal
fields.trailText: Tottenham have finally signed Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov in an £11m deal.
fields.body:
Tottenham have finally signed Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov in an £11m deal.

The deal looked in doubt when the Ukrainian international admitted to a long-standing knee injury earlier this month. But earlier today Rebrov passed a medical and finalised the terms of a five-year contract at White Hart Lane.

A statement from the north London club read: "Tottenham Hotspur are pleased to announce the completion of financial agreements with Dynamo Kiev for a transfer fee of £11million.

"Sergei has successfully passed a medical examination and has also agreed the terms of a five-year contract with the club. He will return to the Ukraine where he awaits his work permit."

Rebrov has earned a reputation as one of Europe's most formidable strikers in recent seasons. His partnership with Andrii Shevchenko took Dynamo to the semi-finals of last year's Champions League. This season, without his partner, he scored eight times in the same competition.

fields.headline: Tor-Schlußpanik
fields.standfirst: What is happening to Germany's football players - are they going down the drain?  Nicole Prestle canvasses opinions
fields.trailText: What is happening to Germany's football players - are they going down the drain? Nicole Prestle canvasses opinions
fields.body:
"Ribbeck geht - aber leider erst nach der Europameisterschaft." Diese Schlagzeile über den Trainer der deutschen Fußball-Nationalmannschaft, Erich Ribbeck, sagt unverblümt, was viele Deutsche seit Wochen denken: Mit solch einem Mann an der Spitze kann die deutsche Elf bei der Europameisterschaft (EM) im Juni zeinen Blumentopf gewinnen, geschweige denn den Titel verteidigen. Ribbeck habe kein Konzept, keine Ausstrahlung und vom Fußball, da verstehe er auch nicht viel. Kurz und gut: Es war ein Eigentor, daß ihn der Deutsche Fußballbund 1998 als Nachfolger von Berti Vogts anheuerte.

Seit Wochen zeigt die deutsche Elf kaum akzeptable Leistungen, überzeugt nicht einmal gegen schwache Gegner. Kenner befürchten schon jetzt, die einst so erfolgreichen Kicker könnten bereits nach der EM-Vorrunde ausscheiden. Woher die Torschlußpanik rührt, darüber können alle nur spekulieren - denn ein falscher Trainer allein kann am Unglück der Elf nicht schuld sein.

Im größten Dilemma stecken die Spieler selbst: Sie sind hin - und hergerissen zwischen dem - finanziell einträglichen - Engagement im Verein und dem Prestigeobjekt Nationalmannschaft. Doch der Job für den Verein zehrt: Während die Spieler alles geben, um ihren Club in Bundesliga oder Champions League voranzubringen, sind sie bei den internationalen Spielen eher zurückhaltend und ausgelaugt. Hinzu kommt: Für ein gezieltes Training im Vorfeld der Europameisterschaft bleiben Ribbeck und seinem Team gerade einmal sieben Tage - ein Drittel dessen, was Vogts noch bei der EM 1996 in Anspruch nehmen konnte. Zu sehr sind die Spieler durch ihre Vereine an andere Termine gebunden. Gerät die deutsche Fußball-Nationalmannschaft ins Abseits? Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen erkundigt.

Woran liegt Eurer Meinung nach die Misere der deutschen Fußball-Nationalmannschaft?

Robert (15): Schuld ist der Trainer. Er setzt die falschen Spieler ein. Jeremies zum Beispiel ist ein guter Mann, aber den hat Ribbeck auf der Bank gelassen, weil er gesagt hatte, der Zustand der Nationalelf sei jämmerlich. Dabei hat Jeremies it seiner Aussage nicht Unrecht.

Andreas (14): Nach der Weltmeisterschaft 1998 hat die eine Hälfte aufgehört, die andere hat jetzt keine Motivation mehr. In der Nationalelf zu spielen ist für die nur noch Nebensache.

Katharina (16): Ich glaube, das Problem ist, daß die Spieler keine Disziplin mehr haben. Die sehen nur noch die Kohle, die sie kriegen, egal, ob sie sich anstrengen oder nicht.

Fußball-Experten behaupten, der Nationalelf fehle es an Spielern, die auch in ihren Vereinen Schlüsselpositionen einnehmen. Viele seien nur Mitläufer, die eigentlichen Stars kämen aus dem Ausland...

Michael (18): Da mag etwas dran sein. Die Zeiten von Uwe Seeler und Paul Breitner sind vorbei. Man verbindet zwar noch Namen mit der Nationalelf - Lothar Matthäus zum Beispiel. Aber man sollte nicht vergessen, daß diese Spieler schon recht alt sind.

Wolfgang (19): Das Problem ist, daß man auch Spieler, die einmal einen Fehler gemacht haben, sofort auf die Ersatzbank verbannt. Auf diese Weise kann sich niemand einen Namen machen.

Champions League und Bundesliga halten die Spieler in ihren Vereinen auf Trab. Können sie in der Nationalelf noch gute Leistungen bringen?

Michael: In den vergangenen Jahren gab es zu viele Cups. Die Spieler sind ständig im Streß, irgendwelche Titel zu holen oder zu verteidigen.

Wolfgang: In Freundschaftsspielen der Nationalmannschaften strengen sich die Deutschen meistens gar nicht mehr richtig an, weil sie Angst haben, sich zu verletzen und dann für den Verein auszufallen.

Welche Lösungen seht Ihr für die Nationalelf?

Robert: Man müßte die Spieler vor wichtigen Begegnungen freistellen. Sie sollten sich ganz auf die Nationalmannschaft konzentrieren können.

Natalie (15): Ich glaube, beim Fußballspielen ist das wie beim Muskelaufbau. Das geht nicht von heute auf morgen. Vor einer Meisterschaft sollte die Nationalmannschaft deshalb in ein Trainingslager gehen und täglich zusammen spielen. Das fördert ja auch den Teamgeist.

Welche Chancen rechnet Ihr den Deutschen bei der EM im Juni aus?

Robert: Die scheiden in der Vorrunde aus. Gegen Rumänien und Portugal haben sie keine Chance, gegen England schon gar nicht.

Wolfgang: Selbst wenn wir den Titel nicht holen, was ist schon dabei. Wir haben mitgespielt, das ist das Wichtigste. Und auch für den deutschen Fußball kommen irgendwann wieder bessere Zeiten.

Prof. Wilfried Kindermann betreut die Nationalelf seit zehn Jahren medizinisch. Er befürchtet, daß der Termindruck in Vereinen und Nationalmannschaft der Gesundheit der Spieler schaden könnte.

(Diese Zitate sind in deutschen Zeitungen erschienen) Noch nie war das Mißverhältnis so groß zwischen Vorbereitung und Anzahl der Spiele. Niemand kann zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt sagen, wie sich das auswirkt. Die Bayern sind zwar konditionell gut drauf. Die Frage ist nur, inwieweit das reicht bei der EM. Früher konnten wir noch eine Woche Aufbau durchziehen, das ist jetzt absolut nicht mehr möglich. Schwerpunkt kann diesmal nur die technisch-taktische Arbeit sein - alles mit dem Ball. Das Risiko, daß irgendwann der Körper streikt, wenn einer so viele Spiele absolviert hat, ist allerdings da. Das System ist deshalb auf Dauer so nicht haltbar.

Zu sehr sind die Spieler durch ihre Vereine an andere Termine gebunden. Gerät die deutsche Fußball-Nationalmannschaft ins Abseits? Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen erkundigt. Woran liegt Eurer Meinung nach die Misere der deutschen Fußball-Nationalmannschaft? Robert (15): Schuld ist der Trainer. Er setzt die falschen Spieler ein. Jeremies zum Beispiel ist ein guter Mann, aber den hat Ribbeck auf der Bank gelassen, weil er gesagt hatte, der Zustand der Nationalelf sei jämmerlich. Dabei hat Jeremies it seiner Aussage nicht Unrecht. Andreas (14): Nach der Weltmeisterschaft 1998 hat die eine Hälfte aufgehört, die andere hat jetzt keine Motivation mehr. In der Nationalelf zu spielen ist für die nur noch Nebensache. Katharina (16): Ich glaube, das Problem ist, daß die Spieler keine Disziplin mehr haben. Die sehen nur noch die Kohle, die sie kriegen, egal, ob sie sich anstrengen oder nicht. Fußball-Experten behaupten, der Nationalelf fehle es an Spielern, die auch in ihren Vereinen Schlüsselpositionen einnehmen. Viele seien nur Mitläufer, die eigentlichen Stars kämen aus dem Ausland... Michael (18): Da mag etwas dran sein. Die Zeiten von Uwe Seeler und Paul Breitner sind vorbei. Man verbindet zwar noch Namen mit der Nationalelf - Lothar Matthäus zum Beispiel. Aber man sollte nicht vergessen, daß diese Spieler schon recht alt sind. Wolfgang (19): Das Problem ist, daß man auch Spieler, die einmal einen Fehler gemacht haben, sofort auf die Ersatzbank verbannt. Auf diese Weise kann sich niemand einen Namen machen. Champions League und Bundesliga halten die Spieler in ihren Vereinen auf Trab. Können sie in der Nationalelf noch gute Leistungen bringen? Michael: In den vergangenen Jahren gab es zu viele Cups. Die Spieler sind ständig im Streß, irgendwelche Titel zu holen oder zu verteidigen. Wolfgang: In Freundschaftsspielen der Nationalmannschaften strengen sich die Deutschen meistens gar nicht mehr richtig an, weil sie Angst haben, sich zu verletzen und dann für den Verein auszufallen. Welche Lösungen seht Ihr für die Nationalelf? Robert: Man müßte die Spieler vor wichtigen Begegnungen freistellen. Sie sollten sich ganz auf die Nationalmannschaft konzentrieren können. Natalie (15): Ich glaube, beim Fußballspielen ist das wie beim Muskelaufbau. Das geht nicht von heute auf morgen. Vor einer Meisterschaft sollte die Nationalmannschaft deshalb in ein Trainingslager gehen und täglich zusammen spielen. Das fördert ja auch den Teamgeist. Welche Chancen rechnet Ihr den Deutschen bei der EM im Juni aus? Robert: Die scheiden in der Vorrunde aus. Gegen Rumänien und Portugal haben sie keine Chance, gegen England schon gar nicht. Wolfgang: Selbst wenn wir den Titel nicht holen, was ist schon dabei. Wir haben mitgespielt, das ist das Wichtigste. Und auch für den deutschen Fußball kommen irgendwann wieder bessere Zeiten. Prof. Wilfried Kindermann betreut die Nationalelf seit zehn Jahren medizinisch. Er befürchtet, daß der Termindruck in Vereinen und Nationalmannschaft der Gesundheit der Spieler schaden könnte. (Diese Zitate sind in deutschen Zeitungen erschienen) Noch nie war das Mißverhältnis so groß zwischen Vorbereitung und Anzahl der Spiele. Niemand kann zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt sagen, wie sich das auswirkt. Die Bayern sind zwar konditionell gut drauf. Die Frage ist nur, inwieweit das reicht bei der EM. Früher konnten wir noch eine Woche Aufbau durchziehen, das ist jetzt absolut nicht mehr möglich. Schwerpunkt kann diesmal nur die technisch-taktische Arbeit sein - alles mit dem Ball. Das Risiko, daß irgendwann der Körper streikt, wenn einer so viele Spiele absolviert hat, ist allerdings da. Das System ist deshalb auf Dauer so nicht haltbar. fields.headline: Act now
fields.standfirst: Children can sample the cut and thrust of politics on a website simulating a Commons debate, as Roger Frost finds out
fields.trailText: Pupils can now debate topical issues and vote on Acts of Parliament using a website from the House of Commons education unit. The site helps young people see how parliament works and tell their "noes" from their "ayes". It is timely in helping to cover the new "citizenship" requirements of the curriculum, so it could also win the teacherÕs vote.
fields.body:
Pupils can now debate topical issues and vote on Acts of Parliament using a website from the House of Commons education unit. The site helps young people see how parliament works and tell their "noes" from their "ayes". It is timely in helping to cover the new "citizenship" requirements of the curriculum, so it could also win the teacherÕs vote.

"Act of Parliament" (www.explore.parliament.uk) is an online debating chamber on to which schools register to take. Like British Parliament, bills in the chamber go through all the various stages leading up to the final vote. Only last term a first bill calling for draconian fines for smokers was discussed and passed by pupils of 30 schools.

One of these was King Harold School, Essex, where teacher Malcolm Burnett reports that getting involved is easy. "The whole of the actÕs timing is set out for you, so you just log in at each stage of the debate. I got the class round, we debated the smoking issue and they used PCs to email their opinions. Being able to read other peopleÕs opinions stimulated the kids to debate; most felt that smokersÕ fines should be heavy while two held that people could not afford to pay them. They modified the fine system as a result.

"It was interesting that at first they thought they could make a decision immediately, but they soon realised that everybody had to contribute before the bill could move to the next stage. They learned to hold a group opinion as well as an individual opinion. Talking to them afterwards, they had a better understanding of whatÕs going on in parliament and why decision-making takes a long time."

The work fits in well, concludes Burnett. "It cuts across lots of things that we do Ñ we use it in a Ôkey skillsÕ unit with our pre-16s. It helps with ICT and communication skills. ItÕs solved lots of things in one go." At All Saints School, they also worked through the stages of the bill. As pupils did research, made speeches and discussed the issues, assistant headteacher Mike Aylott noted that the work offered a good curriculum fit. "The website fits in well with political history as well as with the idea of formal debate in English. It gets pupils involved with democratic processes Ñ we have a school council and elections for it, which is another piece of the jigsaw."

The trigger for all this comes free from the Parliamentary Education Unit at the House of Commons. The website, produced by RM which won the tender to build the site, has been extraordinarily popular, taking 300,000 page hits a month. RMÕs Finbar McGaughey says that its success comes from encouraging involvement. "ItÕs actually participative. Instead of just offering pupils information on the internet, weÕre trying to involve them. The smoking issue was pretty compelling and it gets them talking.

They actually enjoy discussing it. It also opens up a whole lot of opportunities to explore the topic further. But that is very much the idea Ñ to make the subject broad."

Next term, pupils can debate a new bill on an environmental issue. To help schools pressed for curriculum time this term, the parliamentary process has been tweaked. "It should make things easier," says McGaughey. "We have learned some lessons and have shortened and simplified the process to retain interest."

fields.headline: Closing young minds
fields.standfirst: The internet may provide children easy access to controversial subject matter, but are net nannies the answer? Martin Cohen thinks censorship is not the way forward
fields.trailText: A great debate is going on in schools over fundamental issues of freedom, citizenship and empowerment. One particularly vexed issue has been homosexuality - should children be discussing it (in the context of PHSE in general and sex education in particular) or should these already peculiar lessons carry on as though any politically controversial behaviour did not exist?
fields.body:
A great debate is going on in schools over fundamental issues of freedom, citizenship and empowerment. One particularly vexed issue has been homosexuality - should children be discussing it (in the context of PHSE in general and sex education in particular) or should these already peculiar lessons carry on as though any politically controversial behaviour did not exist?

The answer, formalised in Clause 28, has been very much the latter - the "pretend it does not exist" option. It is not so much censorship but ostrich-like optimism that is deciding such issues. If only a small, sanitised curriculum could be arranged, it would be much nicer and better for the children.

But is it better for the children? Some teachers think not. Certainly, there is some doubt as to whether it is in the interests of homosexuals. But the issue is much, much wider than that. In schools across the UK, the internet has opened up new doorways and potential for exploration, to both content and lesson styles. Yet they are now being firmly shut again and, this time, firmly padlocked.

Itês because teachers are terrified of letting their children have free access to the internet. Undoubtedly the net carries a lot of thoroughly nasty things. There is sex. A lot of it. In fact, if not for the remarkable affinity of the medium for pornography, the internet would probably never have got beyond simple lab-to-lab data exchanges.

But that's not all. Thereês also racism. Type in "niggers" and you will be offered not one but 5,000 racist websites and bigots' homepages - and that's just in the UK. Great if you are a racist, but if not, itês a salutary reminder of the reality and prevalence of this vile element in all societies. There is advice on cheating, plagiarism and homework scams, both informal and formal. There is drugs information - not of the local council sort to guide young people away, but of the drug dealer sort, to people. There is all sorts of nastiness and rottenness.

But this is precisely why the censors and net nannies have it wrong. Today's children are surrounded by racism, pornography and violence. They need schools that don't pretend itês not there but provide them with the maturity and life skills to meet and resist them, and seek out and value the right. The net nannies assume children are weak and incapable of judgment. They ban the use of the computer for surfing, and throw away the educational opportunities in the name of safety. But outside, in the playground, the children are passing around drugs, pornography and racist literature. The teachers have missed their opportunity to help them resist.

One teacher, who strongly believes that children actually need to be exposed to the freedom of the internet, puts it this way: "Those who control the websites people can visit think they are helping the children but, actually, they are damaging them, letting them down. They need to let classes work out their own rules and systems of control. "Then when the filtering system lapses - as they all do - letting a pornography site throw up automatic windows of intimidating and disgusting material, for example, the children will be ready to calmly shut down the windows, and not be powerless in front of it."

The teacher can still say to a child: "Hey, do you really think that is an appropriate use of the computer resources?" But instead of schools leaping for the most authoritarian and draconian system of computer control of the internet and email, they should consider the wider context and purpose of education.

Perhaps classes should be using the issues as a starting point for meaningful debate about the citizenship issues, devising and agreeing their own standards and rules - in a word, being treated like people who will one day need to take their own decisions. The teacherês job is to help them to reach this stage, not to leave it to net nanny to provide a quiet life of censorship and control.

Martin Cohen is a researcher at the Centre for IT and Education in Plymouth

fields.headline: Just my type of program
fields.standfirst: John Bald samples a new game and software that helps children have fun learning how to type
fields.trailText: John Bald samples a new game and software that helps children have fun learning how to type
fields.body:
Nearly everyone knows the Qwerty typewriter keyboard was developed in a way that made typing more difficult, as placing the most frequently used letters directly under the typist's fingers made early typewriters jam. Qwerty's survival into the computer age, when it is relatively easy to program a keyboard in any way you choose, is due to force of habit and economics - it probably costs less to train new users than retrain all the old ones.

Meanwhile, anything to cut down time wasted by children using hunt-and-peck methods on computers is useful, and Keyboard Crazy (£48, RLS, 0151 226 5000) seems to be doing this pretty effectively with infants. It comprises an attractive yellow moulding of the basic computer keyboard layout, with square holes in the positions of the letter and top row of number keys. You slot a card into the moulding, so that the numbers and letters show through the holes in upper or lower case as desired. Children can then play a range of simple games involving sequencing sets of letter and number tiles and slotting them into the right positions in the keyboard.

Some games are individual, some involve pairs and teams, and you can keep children's interest by tackling almost the same problem with a choice of approaches. The easiest game uses a picture to reinforce the letter, and the hardest two have children reconstructing the keyboard from scratch.

Keyboard Crazy comes with a sheaf of recommendations from primary and special schools in Liverpool, from the LEA advisory service, and from Liverpool University, which notes benefits in social skills as well as improved speed and recognition of symbols.

The comments from special schools are especially positive. "Fabulous results," says Alison Carter, ICT coordinator at Longwill School for Deaf Children. "Pupils develop their keyboard skills away from the pressures that can come from having to type their work quickly so that the rest of the class can have a go."

The tiles are large enough to be used by partially sighted children, and a Braille version is being prepared.

In fact, there is now a good choice of typing software specially designed for children. Inclusive Technology (www.inclusive.co.uk) offers First Keys (£30, single user licence), a program that can be recommended for infants for its good combination of typing with pictures, early phonics and spelling.

The same company offers Ultrakey 4 (£39, single user), a sophisticated Canadian production supported by a website, with good animation and video features, unusually detailed feedback on the sources of errors and more interesting test material than most tutors. This is aimed at children from seven upwards, but is a good buy for a teenager or adult.

Ultrakey 4 is probably worth its premium over full-priced versions of Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing, though I have personally found this program useful, and it has been part of a package in Software World for £5 - a bargain!

TAG Technology (www.tagdev.co.uk) has produced Jump Ahead Typing (£30), a course which probably tries a little too hard for street cred with children aged seven to 10, though it has a good, clear parents' guide from the Parents' Information Network.

Also from TAG is Type To Learn (£69.95), a good choice for teaching whole classes of older junior and younger secondary children, with an attractive layout, a tracking system for up to 15 classes, and good games to build speed. All of these will do a good job in the right context, but need to be checked out, particularly for the more expensive licences.

fields.headline: Case studies in website design
fields.standfirst: John Davitt talks to four teachers about how they constructed their websites
fields.trailText: John Davitt talks to four teachers about how they constructed their websites
fields.body:
Mark Robinson is head of ICT at Ambleside CE Primary School. He's keen to get the pupils involved in web page and multimedia production using Macromedia's Flash 4 software. Flash 4 has transformed how we approach multimedia. It is almost the perfect software for schools, especially secondary, where it could have unlimited potential. It delivers true multimedia and interactivity in an ultra-compact format. We make heavy use of its streaming MP3 audio capabilities for our website. It produces many of our interactive games, for example at www.ambleside.schoolzone.co.uk/ambleweb/lookcover/lookcover.html Flash 4 is also used by children for online presentations. It's as easy as a painting program and, as it stores images in a very effective way, it is simple for any child to create interfaces in no time at all. It can import almost any media that the children produce, such as audio or scanned pictures, using a simple drag-and-drop process.

Complex interactions can be built using the point-and-click environment that even primary-age children can understand. Finished work does not have to live in a web page; with a single click, it can be made into small, stand-alone applications that can be copied on to a floppy disk to take home or to download for offline use. These will run on any machine with a browser installed.

www.ambleside.schoolzone.co.uk/ambleweb/bagpoem/bagpoem.html

Gordon Beckett is head of RE at Woodford High School

I first got interested in the internet as a way of making RE resources available for my students outside school time, then I began to help design the school website.

First I recruited some sixth formers for a web design team. Then I found a very useful piece of software called Arachnophilia. It lets me build interactive pages with ease, dipping in and out of the html language as and when necessary.

The other key piece of software I use is Paintshop Pro, version 5 or later (found at www.jasc.com). The animation software which comes as part of the package is brilliant; it is simple to make educational animations which are then saved as animated gifs (a series of still images repeated in sequence). Most recently I have been working with the LEA adviser in Redbridge, Bill Gent, to build a religious education resource website. See it at www.re.leonet.co.uk.

At our annual RE conference last year I posted resources and responses in advance so that students could get a feel for the type of work that would be going on. It went down so well that we now use the internet to extend the value and outcomes of live events and visits. I have just returned from a school trip to Corinth and the first outcome is a website detailing the trip and linking it to various curriculum resources.

www.woodford.redbridge.sch.uk/greece2000/greece2000.html

Neil Robinson is head of ICT at Heronsgate Middle School in Milton Keynes

Over the last six years we have worked closely with the Open University on curriculum research projects. Many pupils have since developed skills in digital video editing and web publishing. Now the children can manage a large part of our website - a sort of online paper -called the Heron.

Elsewhere on our site we post our curriculum projects as interactive web pages - a boy in Arizona recently emailed us to say he had seen our water cycle pages and then done his own project.

When pupils get such positive feedback, it dramatically affects motivation and pushes new work even further.

Children use the web to publish their project findings and often include short video clips of classroom work in progress using Apple's QuickTime (see our year seven's animations). Our new guest book also allows me to check all responses before they are published - a very useful safeguard.

We use Adobe GoLive to make all our web pages and manage our website. It's excellent as it's simple enough for nine-year-olds to use with ease but powerful enough for any curriculum or technical requirement.

I have trained up staff so that they can publish pages and update links so that all the work doesn't fall on me. Soon I want the students, especially the editors of the Heron, to be able to publish and update pages directly themselves.

Most children are happy building pages which include image, text and movie files.

Our next project involves control over the internet. Working with the OU, other schools overseas will be able to open valves and control a model of the Thomas Newcomen steam engine in our science lab!

http://heronsgate.open.ac.uk

Digital philanthropy

I first came across the work of educational researcher Dr Geoff Dellow when I saw an unusual offer in the on-line special educational needs and ICT discussion group (www.becta.org.uk/inclusion/discussion/senit.html) ). Geoff had offered to provide free lessons for teachers on the curriculum use of animation using the groundbreaking Macromedia Flash software. The offer was open to any teacher who wanted to learn. They just had to download a trial version of the software (from www.macromedia.com or through a link on Geoff's website at: www.tygh.co.uk) and pay for their phone call to Geoff who then talked them through its use.

The response was dramatic: within three weeks he had students as far afield as the US and Australia. Now some students are sending him work which he develops further and sends it back - collaborative learning on a worldwide scale.

Some 200 million computers are now declared to have the Flash plug-in attached to their browsers so that the audience is there and waiting.

"I have a particular interest in problem-solving," says Geoff. "How can animation be used to help children discover concepts that are not readily accessible on the printed page when represented in text and stationary images?

"It all started when my partner, a maths teacher, asked me to help with some animations showing shapes dividing to get across the concept of halves. Several animation resources are now available on my website at: www.tygh.co.uk

"I am also keen to develop strategies for using these tools with children of all abilities. It's an ideal way of stretching the most able to give them the challenge of building an animation of water flowing into a beaker, for instance. To get there they have to analyse the problem with mathematical thinking. The use of Flash and other interactive animation software as a visual thinking tool looks set to take off in schools.

"I am looking at the use of audio conferencing via the telephone so that teachers in clusters of four or five can receive low-cost instruction and guidance on classroom use of animation software in the comfort of their own homes."

You can contact Geoff at geoff@tygh.co.uk. For free multimedia educational materials in Flash, visit the new site at: www.tygh.co.uk, with the ISP www.dircon.net noted for its fast, friendly and efficient service. fields.bodyText: Mark Robinson is head of ICT at Ambleside CE Primary School. He's keen to get the pupils involved in web page and multimedia production using Macromedia's Flash 4 software. Flash 4 has transformed how we approach multimedia. It is almost the perfect software for schools, especially secondary, where it could have unlimited potential. It delivers true multimedia and interactivity in an ultra-compact format. We make heavy use of its streaming MP3 audio capabilities for our website. It produces many of our interactive games, for example at www.ambleside.schoolzone.co.uk/ambleweb/lookcover/lookcover.html Flash 4 is also used by children for online presentations. It's as easy as a painting program and, as it stores images in a very effective way, it is simple for any child to create interfaces in no time at all. It can import almost any media that the children produce, such as audio or scanned pictures, using a simple drag-and-drop process. Complex interactions can be built using the point-and-click environment that even primary-age children can understand. Finished work does not have to live in a web page; with a single click, it can be made into small, stand-alone applications that can be copied on to a floppy disk to take home or to download for offline use. These will run on any machine with a browser installed. www.ambleside.schoolzone.co.uk/ambleweb/bagpoem/bagpoem.html Gordon Beckett is head of RE at Woodford High School I first got interested in the internet as a way of making RE resources available for my students outside school time, then I began to help design the school website. First I recruited some sixth formers for a web design team. Then I found a very useful piece of software called Arachnophilia. It lets me build interactive pages with ease, dipping in and out of the html language as and when necessary. The other key piece of software I use is Paintshop Pro, version 5 or later (found at www.jasc.com). The animation software which comes as part of the package is brilliant; it is simple to make educational animations which are then saved as animated gifs (a series of still images repeated in sequence). fields.headline: Kids' stuff
fields.standfirst: Britain can learn from the US where many of the government sites now have a children's section, says Abul Taher
fields.trailText: Although parliament has made citizenship education compulsory based on the Crick Reports findings that youngsters know very little about politics, it isn't doing enough to get young people to learn about government on the internet, a medium that schoolchildren are using more and more.
fields.body:
Although parliament has made citizenship education compulsory based on the Crick Reports findings that youngsters know very little about politics, it isn't doing enough to get young people to learn about government on the internet, a medium that schoolchildren are using more and more.

This is in sharp contrast to the US, where all major government websites have an alternative site for kids. The sites are not only informative but also entertaining, packed with games and quizzes.

On the White House's kids' website there is a chance to go on a virtual VIP tour of the place with the First Pets - Buddy and Socks, a cat and dog respectively.

The tour, filled with pictures, not only acquaints the young surfers with the history and significance of the establishment, but also contains pages on past White House pets and children.

In First Kids, for instance, Abraham Lincoln's little imp, Thomas, once rang all the bells at the White House simultaneously, something thought impossible before. And there's a chance for kids to write to the president himself by email, with letters being replied to promptly.

In the US Treasurys website, you can go on a treasure hunt, following in the footsteps of the organisations pet cat, Trez, going through grids such as "Know your money" and "Its Payday".

The FBIs "Kids and Youth Education Page" not only gives concise easy-to-read information on the organisation, but also gives advice on net safety, crime prevention and drugs. And, of course, there are games.

Even the American Air Force and the Federal Emergency Management Agency have websites for children, which are as informative as they are fun.

In Britain its different. Downing Street has a notable website for children, called 10 Out of 10. The site, which has few pictures and no mention of Humphries the cat, has the feel of a late teenage magazine rather achildrens attraction.

Its lengthy newspaper style is unlikely to keep a young surfers attention for long. There is a chance to write a piece called "If I Were Prime Minister"; the best pieces get published on the site every fortnight. There is also a chance for children to email their questions to a different government minister, though not the prime minister, each month.

No other governmental organisations have websites for children. Not even the monarchy, whose website is visited by 250,000 visitors a week, including many children  ironic, considering the site was launched by the Queen in a London school in 1997.

Parliaments website is bland in its design, and can even put an adult off, being purely text-based. The Department for Education and Employment, even though is running a school essay competition on its website, has no separate pages for children. "We dont expect children to visit our site," said a spokesman. "The website merely reflects the policies of the department."

As more youngsters have greater access to the internet at home and school, the web is fast becoming a powerful and convenient tool to spread information and knowledge. So it is vital for government organisations to have websites where children can learn about them, without having to plough through difficult, lengthy texts.

The US approach shows genuine commitment to citizenship education and an interactive democracy, where at the touch of a button, children can send letters and questions to their president. Of course, the president will probably never read any of the mail, but symbolically it brings him closer to young people and makes government more open.

What about it, Tony?

White House: www.whitehouse.gov/wh/kids/html.
US Treasury: www.treas.gov/kids.
FBI: www.fbi.gov/kids.
CIA: www.cia.gov/cia/ciakids.html.
American Air Force: www.af.mil/aflinkjr/jr.html.
10 Downing Street: www.number-10.gov.uk/.
British Monarchy: www.royal.gov.uk.
DfEE: www.dfee.gov.uk/index.htm

webTitle: Cartoons teach a thing or two

fields.headline: Cartoons teach a thing or two
fields.standfirst: If a website is inventive, learning can be fun. Emma Haughton surfs what the internet has to offer for children at home
fields.trailText: If a website is inventive, learning can be fun. Emma Haughton surfs what the internet has to offer for children at home
fields.body:
Miss Dorothy
Based on the adventures of a nine-year-old cartoon character called Dorothy, this website aims to guide children and families on internet use. The brainchild of TV news presenter Sharon Doughty, the site stresses how to use the net safely, guides youngsters to good websites and carries child-friendly international news updates produced by Sniff, the ITN newshound. Dorothy herself has her own soap opera and an ability to travel along computer networks, turning up at the most surprising places. Miss Dorothy has already been adopted by the Brownies in a cartoon strip in Brownie magazine and by Nelson Mandela for his Children's Fund in South Africa. Lively, animated and colourful, it's one that children will want to go back to again and again.

Maths Year 2000
If anything can help maths shrug off its stuffy image, it will be this recently launched website for Maths Year 2000. Aimed at children of all ages, there's lots of highly addictive maths games and puzzles, as well as a special Numberland section with poems and facts for every digit from 1 to 100. The virtual maths museum lets you explore arithmetic aids, global mathematical instruments, practical applications and geometry, while the online dictionary offers a definition for every obscure mathematical term. Parents can also glean details of maths-oriented events in their area - that's if they can tear their kids away from the computer.

Argosphere
You may already be familiar with this commendable collection of cross-curricular activities for use at home and school, offering everything from shape matching for toddlers to map work for teenagers, along with curriculum-based software and other downloadable activities that will save on your phone bills. New to the site, however, is the Millennium Quiz with a live score table, and Beyond Time, an online interactive adventure game designed to develop reading and problem solving skills in eight- to 11-year-olds.

@Kidz
Although still in the offing, the omens look good for this free British site aimed at kids aged seven to 12. With its funky retro design and heady mix of news, games, competitions and reviews, it's bound to be a hit with children, while the key stage two factfiles, created by teachers, will please their parents. Kids can also take part in supervised online chat, send emails or post messages on the virtual message boards, or use the personal planner section to keep a scrapbook and store virtual pocket money.

Homework High
Real live teachers are the main attraction at Channel 4's new homework service for children. Aimed at nine- to 16-year-olds, the free service lets kids pitch tricky problems at practising teachers for four hours, four nights a week, with answers promised within 20 minutes. The site aims to provide around 200 answers a night, with different nights devoted to English, maths, geography/history, and science. The site also offers monitored chatrooms where students can talk to others with similar questions, and an archive of past questions.

Learningstore
Can't find that piece of software you've spent ages searching for? Try Learningstore, the only UK online shop for educational multimedia titles. With over 1,800 CD-Roms, including schools software and special needs titles not normally available on the high street, you can search by title, subject or age, and most items will arrive at your door within five days.

fields.headline: Worldwide links via video-conference
fields.trailText: Conversing face-to-face with Santa. Video-conferencing with Nasa scientists on the ins and outs of global warming. Chatting with schoolchildren in Australia, and singing with peers in Sweden. Not your usual after-school activities, but for eight- and nine-year-olds from St Peter's CE Junior School and the Blue Coat School in Birmingham, these are now part and parcel of their home lives.
fields.body:
Conversing face-to-face with Santa. Video-conferencing with Nasa scientists on the ins and outs of global warming. Chatting with schoolchildren in Australia, and singing with peers in Sweden. Not your usual after-school activities, but for eight- and nine-year-olds from St Peter's CE Junior School and the Blue Coat School in Birmingham, these are now part and parcel of their home lives.

With the help of educational computer specialist RM and funding from the DfEE, the two schools provided six families with a computer, video-conferencing equipment and a dedicated ISDN telephone line to enable the children, all of whom have specific educational needs, to link up with each other regularly to participate in activities designed by the school.

The aim is to bolster their communication skills and self-esteem. "Basically they're learning video-conferencing skills at home, as well as extending the school day," says project manager Diane Geater, "but it's in a way they hardly notice, it's a pleasure for them."

So far, the signs are good. The project started in earnest at Christmas, and the feedback from parents shows a noticeable improvement in communication and verbal skills, and a general growth in confidence and self-esteem. "It couldn't be more positive," says Geater.

So positive, in fact, that the school plans to start rolling it out to other children next year. "The potential is just phenomenal; this is just the first wave. Next year we want to extend it to larger numbers of children, both specific needs and mainstream, but eventually we hope to include the whole school."

fields.headline: Software fun for all ages
fields.standfirst: Children are becoming computer-literate at a progressively younger age. Emma Haughton on CD-Roms for home use
fields.trailText: Children are becoming computer-literate at a progressively younger age. Emma Haughton on CD-Roms for home use
fields.body:
Hot off the press is Reader Rabbit Playtime for Baby Reader Rabbit Playtime for Baby (Learning Company, 9-24 months, £19.99), introducing colours, shapes, patterns, animals, songs and simple stories and simplifying all interactions: striking any key or moving the mouse will bring an instant response. Parents get a video showing easy ways to help your baby use the computer, an audio CD of songs, and the opportunity to personalise the software with your child's name, photo and voice.

Knowledge Adventure, however, goes one further by offering a Baby Ball to go with its Jump Ahead Baby 2000 (9-24 months, £29.99). Designed to replace the conventional mouse and make controlling the computer easier for fumbling fingers, the accompanying CD-Rom covers eight activities, including dressing teddy, animal sounds, and hide-and-seek.

Edging up the age bracket, the three Winnie the Pooh titles (Disney, £19.99) give children aged 18 months to six years a range of activities from letter and number recognition, music appreciation and seasons to early reading and arithmetic, all under the friendly auspices of Owl, Pooh, Eyeore, Piglet and friends.

Though the above is well designed and cute in an Americanised sort of way, AA Milne purists might be happier with Maisy's Playhouse (TDK, 3+, £19.95) which uses the bright, appealing graphics of Lucy Cousin's picture books to present six activities designed to encourage resourcefulness and early learning skills.

Interactive stories are becoming increasingly popular. Dorling Kindersley's The Three Little Pigs (4-6, £19.99) offers an imaginative retelling of the classic fairy tale. I'm usually a huge fan of DK titles, but the surreal computer graphics are strangely disturbing, and the cyber wolf from hell is almost guaranteed to give young children nightmares. That said, the night sequence was marvellous, but frankly I'd prefer something a little more saccharine for my little ones.

You're on altogether safer ground with the two new titles from Tivola, the German publisher gaining widespread acclaim for its innovative and stimulating children's software. Oscar the Balloonist Drops into the Countryside (4-8, £19.99) is a charming exploration of the natural world with quirky animation and an absorbing interactive environment, while Max on the Moon (3-7, £19.99) features an amusing interactive search for moon chickens in a game that invites discovery and non-linear discovery.

But with the push from parents and schools to raise standards, home teaching software is still some of the most lucrative. Knowledge Adventure's popular MathsBlaster and ReaderBlaster titles (£19.99), which aim to take the sting out of basic skills, have recently been revamped for the UK market. Billed as the reading and maths programs that kids will really use, they feature a winning cartoon format and plenty of games and incentives, while parents can relax in the knowledge that the content is matched to the national curriculum key stages one and two.

Letts Maths Explorer Key Stage Two (GSP, £12.99), on the other hand, takes a much more prosaic approach, with straightforward tutorials in various maths aspects, and plenty of opportunities for children to practise and test their skills. But the backdrop muzak as you explore the various "zones" - the Dome has a lot to answer for here - makes it all feel a bit trivial, and the three-dimensional exploratory approach to finding topics is irritating. Whatever happened to good, old-fashioned menus?

Not to be left behind in Maths Year 2000, Europress has launched two new Number Crew titles (5-6, 6-7, £19.99) on the back of the Channel 4 schools programmes. Set on the SS Mathematical, it uses videos to introduce each skills and printable certificates when children attain the target levels. Each CD-Rom also contains two full programmes from the series, and links to the Number Crew website.

Finally, the Learning Company has added Years Five and Six to its Clue Finders series (9-11+, £19.99), which should prove a hit with most kids. There's plenty of atmosphere in this cartoon action adventure with four junior detectives, and the 10 engaging, embedded activities cover no less than 85 skills in various aspects of maths, language, science, logic and critical thinking skills.
