fields.headline: Lapping it up
fields.standfirst: A laptop hire scheme using wireless radio links is allowing parents to keep a close eye on their children's progress, reports Roger Frost
fields.trailText: A laptop hire scheme using wireless radio links is allowing parents to keep a close eye on their children's progress, reports Roger Frost
fields.body:
Hamilton School in Leicester is asking parents to contribute £5 a week to a laptop computer for their child to use. Taken home at the end of the day, the laptop will allow children to finish off schoolwork and, should they need information or worksheets, they will be able to pick this up from the school internet website.

In this taster of tomorrow's school today, parents will be able to keep track of their child's progress, timetables or attendance via the internet. It would seem as if illness is no longer an excuse to miss lessons.

Hamilton is one of the first to pilot a scheme run by partners ABK, Nortel Networks and Toshiba. The school has been experimenting with some 36 laptops and found them to be a huge hit with pupils and teachers.

The cutting edge is that each machine is fitted with a wireless radio link from Nortel. This allows children to go into any classroom, be on the school network and gain access to all sorts of resources. The schools says it's making a major difference to how PCs would be used within the school - otherwise they would just be used as word processors.

"We are moving away from the idea that computers are put in a suite, where children go to 'do ICT'," says a Nortel spokesman. "We are moving to a model which embeds ICT in every nook and cranny of the school curriculum."

So Hamilton now wants to go large with its scheme. It sees the way forward as technology that pupils can take away, but that entails funding that few schools can absorb. Indeed, scaled up nationally, it would need £2-3bn a year - a major acceleration - and several times the government's current commitment to technology in education. Hence it's over to the parents. The upside, says ABK's Mike Fitton, is that the laptop could be used as the family computer, and the deal based on a subsidised rental is a good one.

"What we are trying to do is to offer a complete package that gives peace of mind: it has internet access; it's insured; it's warranted, and if it should break down there is a swap out. The laptop can be bought by extending the contract [for another year], but the discussions we have had to date is that parents seemed quite happy to rent on the basis that £5 per week provides a constant refresh of technology every three years."

Surprisingly, the scheme hasn't been aimed at rich areas but Education Action Zones, where access to technology could provide a boost. The consortium hopes to set up a loyalty scheme with national companies, and that would allow parents to collect reward points to offset costs. Nortel is hoping to blend its scheme with a similar initiative from Microsoft called Anytime, Anywhere Learning. This was launched in March, after a two-year pilot project found impressive gains in children's motivation and learning. Microsoft's approach has been to encourage schools to set up charitable foundations to boost funds through the tax breaks available.

After an open day at Hamilton School where parents of year six and seven were invited in to hear of their plans, headteacher Eddy de Middelar could report only surprise. In a room packed with parents, safety not money seemed to be main topic (see p19). "The costs were compared to pies, pints or packets of fags. The only concern was about all these kids going out and about with laptops worth £1,400 a shot - everything else was very positive."

After discussing ideas such as minibus drop-offs at strategic pick-up points, a local solution, never mind a local revolution in educational technology, seems interestingly close.

fields.headline: Easy access
fields.standfirst: A state scheme is to help low-income learners get hold of computers
fields.trailText: A state scheme is to help low-income learners get hold of computers
fields.body:
Can't afford to buy your children a computer? Worried they might be missing out? You're not alone - the government's recent ICT for All survey showed 41% of respondents saw cost as the main barrier to using ICT.

In recognition that those who most need access to ICT cannot always afford it, and in an attempt to break down underachievement caused by lack of access to ICT, the government is about to launch several pilot schemes to help low-income learners get hold of reconditioned or remaindered computers more cheaply, so as to improve job prospects, lifelong learning, or their children's homework. It could benefit some 100,000 families.

Under the scheme you can either buy the computer package outright or lease it for a small fee, possibly as low as £5 per month. If successful, the Computers In Reach initiative will be subsidising costs of reconditioning computers, and bringing together computer recycling organisations with community groups to supply and support the use of the machines in the community.

Parents Network Schools still have some way to bridge the digital divide and team up with parents to create an online educational community, according to the first national survey of school-based ICT access by the Parents Information Network.

PIN found parents are still more likely to ask teachers about ICT than be offered training or advice, while only 44% of schools make their ICT facililities more widely available. Only 42% of the 437 schools surveyed have a website; only 22% of those include areas specifically for parents. See full survey at www.pin.org.uk.

Safety net A third of UK children have internet access at home, and 80% say it helps with their learning. But is it safe?

KZuk.net has tried to allay parental fears with its free, dedicated internet service for children aged 4-12 years, which offers secure email and chat services, and a monitored net-surfing facility, Net Nanny. There are over 20,000 content pages across 10 different zones - covering art, music, games, penpals, quizzes, and an interactive magazine. Its homework club, with teachers online from 3.30pm to 6.00pm on weekdays, provides online access to teachers five days a week.

For a free KZuk.net CD-Rom call 0845 661 2300.

fields.headline: How to spend £25,000
fields.standfirst: Louise Goldsbury reports on the latest winners of the BT Futuretalk Awards
fields.trailText: Louise Goldsbury reports on the latest winners of the BT Futuretalk Awards
fields.body:
Schools on separate sites know only too well the exacerbated problems in ICT provision - the need to double up on hardware and software, trickier networking and communication systems, the distance between younger and older pupils and staff. New technology can best bridge these gaps using the internet, email and videoconferencing - as long as you can afford them.

The latest winner of the BT Futuretalk awards, Park View Community School, is now able to solve this dilemma with its prize of £25,000. The secondary comprehensive and specialist language college, located at the heart of the former Durham coalmining region, is linking its year seven and eight students with the upper school site to include them in a design and technology (D&T) project.

D&T Live will install videoconferencing facilities in both sites and two feeder primary schools to allow pupils to work together using CAM (computer-aided manufacture). The main machine is worth £7,000 and, due to its size and weight, is not transportable. Web cameras will allow the lower-school pupils to see their work being designed.

"It's giving equal opportunities to all our students, especially the year sevens and eights, to access our computer control equipment," said Park View's head of D&T, Christopher Wilding. "As it is a compulsory part of the curriculum to use these machines, instead of waiting until the end of the GCSE course, they can understand and experience an industrial method in their first year."

The year seven pupils will design a personalised logo, which is then sent to the other site where partner pupils engrave the designs on to acrylic or wood. This process can show pupils how companies use conferencing, web-linking and other communication techniques to make decisions regarding product development. "It mimics what happens in industry when the design is done in one country and manufactured in another," explained Wilding.

About half of the winnings will be spent on a new computer room for the D&T department. The upgrade includes a network extension between the two school sites, 12 PCs, internet access, 10 web cameras, other hardware and CAD/CAM materials, and teacher training.

In the longer term, with its better educated and more competent pupils, the school hopes to develop its relationship with European partner schools to allow a D&T student exchange programme.

 The other school to win a BT/Guardian award is Bishop Stopford School, in Kettering. It receives £5,000 for its project, which will see teams of students develop and write programmes for electronic buggies.

Launched in January, with the Guardian, the BT Future Talk Awards programme is providing £600,000 over two years to groups of schools working on joint projects that promote the best use of new technologies.

Every half-term the winner receives the main prize of £25,000, with up to five further school groups awarded £5,000 each. To link up with partner schools or to get an application form, visit the FutureTalk website at: www.btschoolsawards.co.uk. Also see details on our special report.

fields.headline: Television addicts
fields.standfirst: Using digital TV to bring the internet into every home could revolutionise the way we learn. By George Cole
fields.trailText: Using digital TV to bring the internet into every home could revolutionise the way we learn. By George Cole
fields.body:
Aruna Sharma, head of maths at Henry Gotsch School in Northamptonshire, is showing pupils a video clip of a sliced pizza to reinforce information on the properties of angles. But this is no ordinary TV presentation because she can also access graphics, text and other classroom activities by simply using a remote control handset and an on-screen menu - digital TV. "It's an additional resource we can use in the classroom. It is also motivating and can be used to put mathematics in a practical context, which is valuable," Sharma says.

Digital TV transmits sound and pictures as computer code - binary zeros and ones - and because it uses the same code as PCs, it's possible to offer video, sound, text, graphics and even internet content on the same TV screen. Digital TV programmes can also be interactive, offering a two-way link between the pupils, teachers and on-screen materials.

Digital TV is such a compelling proposition that the government sees it playing an important role in reducing social exclusion and improving education. Around one in four homes has a PC, but almost every household has at least one television. Analogue television can be converted to digital by plugging in a digital set-top box, costing between £200 and £400, although most are free if you subscribe to a digital pay-TV service. And digital TV can be delivered to a home or school via a standard TV aerial, satellite dish, cable link and even a high-speed digital telephone connection.

Earlier this year, a series of Department for Education-sponsored digital TV trials were launched by Anglia Multimedia, the BBC, and Result, a joint venture between Granada Media, IBM and others. The trials lasted around six weeks and each service was used in at least 10 schools, with some students also using the service at home.

The digital TV service was designed for GCSE students studying English, maths, science or humanities, and the materials were viewed on a TV or PC screen. The results of the trials have been evaluated and a report will be published by the British Educational Communications and Technology Agency (Becta) in May.

Anglia Multimedia's trials involved 10 schools in Hertfordshire and more than 300 pupils. Anglia provided history materials in the form of video, text and graphics on CD-Roms, which simulated a digital TV broadcast. "For most teachers it was a real addition to their classroom resources," says Anne Sparrowhawk, who evaluated Anglia's trials. "Digital TV allows materials to be accessed in a non-sequential way - you can watch a video clip and then move on to text, for example - and one of its strengths is that it's all done within one medium. That's a major benefit to learning."

Sparrowhawk says students found the short programmes very useful for revision and reinforcement. Peter Stibbons, managing director of Anglia, says "The project has given us lots of new ideas for interactive TV services."

The BBC's service involved over 2,500 pupils in schools in London, the north-east and the Midlands, who were provided with maths and chemistry materials. The BBC's materials were sent from the internet to a server linked to the school's network. The BBC believes that PCs are currently a better way of delivering the digital curriculum, says Frank Flynn, head of commissioning for children's education. "The PC culture already exists and the government is investing a lot in ICT and the national grid for learning."

Digital TV allows pupils to work at their own pace, and teachers can develop materials for individual pupils, says Flynn. In some cases, teachers used the materials for whole-class teaching, and in others, pupils worked alone, though teachers could track their progress. "Teachers could take a step-by-step approach and that was a real benefit to learning," he says. Result is a collaboration between Granada Media, IBM and others, and its trial involved 10 schools and 12 independent learners based in Hounslow, North Tyneside and Northamptonshire. Result's materials consisted of GCSE maths (shape and space) and science (periodic table and reactions). The materials, stored on computer hard disk, were shown on a TV or PC. Chris Hopson, Result's managing director, says: "We've had an excellent reaction to our service. Teachers liked its flexibility, the rigour of the materials, which could be easily customised, and the ease of use."

Max Buczynski, head of ICT at Henry Gotsch says: "Digital TV has been a major breakthrough for teachers who are reluctant to use ICT - they've been the ones who have used it the most." Digital TV has also made an impact in home learning. Toby Buckle, an able pupil, who also attends Henry Gotsch, has been using Result's materials on his home PC. "It's like having a science lesson, because you can do experiments and make notes," he says. His mother, Linda, agrees: "I used to worry about television, video and computers limiting family talk, but this technology has taken it back out and encouraged more talk."

Although Channel 4 did not take part in the Digital TV trials, the company is interested in using the technology, says Paul Ashton, commissioning editor of Channel 4 Learning. "Interactivity is what education has been waiting for a long time, and at last, the technology has caught up." Ashton adds that Channel 4 has one of the largest archives of moving pictures and is keen to use its resources on all types of interactive platforms, including the internet, DVD-Rom discs and digital TV. "We're preparing our archive for a multiplicity of delivery systems," he says.

A digital TV service for schools

Some schools are already using digital TV in the classroom. In April, Espresso launched its digital TV service for primary schools, and one in 20 English local education authorities (representing over 50,000 pupils) have subscribed to it.

Espresso delivers lessons via an Astra satellite, and educational material is stored on a special server linked to the school's network. It offers a range of multimedia activities based around the national curriculum. There are also specially designed news services for young children and educational materials from around 60 selected websites. Materials are updated each week. Older materials can be accessed from an archive.

"We believe Espresso offers a rich blend of TV and the internet," says managing director Tony Bowden. "You have full-screen, near-TV video and computer data, and materials are refreshed on a regular basis." An Espresso PC server and satellite dish costs around £1,500, including installation, and the service costs £4.50 a year per pupil.

The cable company NTL has launched Knowledge Channel, an interactive TV service for homes and schools. Knowledge Channel can be received on NTL's TV-internet service, which offers internet access on a TV screen, and will also be available on the company's forthcoming digital cable service. The material is being supplied by Anglia Campus and Dorling Kindersley, and includes primary and secondary maths, English and science curriculum content. Around 200 schools currently use the channel, says NTL, and prices are variable.

Espresso: 020 8237 1200, www.espresso.co.uk. NTL: 01256 752465

fields.headline: A key to modern 'hieroglyphics'
fields.standfirst: John Bald starts an occasional column on ICT in foreign languages
fields.trailText: John Bald starts an occasional column on ICT in foreign languages
fields.body:
Modern languages have not been at the front of the queue for IT provision, and most of the handful of projects listed on the Becta website show teachers making do with second-best equipment and software designed for other purposes - typically email, website pages and word processing. These help with writing, but more recent computers, with their fast processors and huge memories, handle speech and writing simultaneously, as well as offering visual support and instant feedback.

The main snag is cost. You need a sound card and good headset for each machine, and site licences for software are well beyond most individual departments' budgets. This is a constant bone of contention for almost all educational software in secondary schools, and one of the main reasons why so little is used.

RosettaStone.com is one of the longest established computerised language courses. It uses "active immersion" to teach 26 languages from Hindi to Welsh, and includes English speech and language therapists among its admirers.

The scheme provides practice in listening comprehension in the early stages, proceeding by carefully graded steps to advanced syntax and spelling. This makes it ideal for schools, which have to introduce large numbers of pupils to foreign languages from scratch, and which also need to provide flexible and demanding teaching for the more talented. Practice is easy and enjoyable, and there is very extensive use of the foreign language in short sentences that make it easy to understand and learn. This is much better than most other software for beginners, which tends to concentrate on vocabulary. Site licences in the US cost $150 per machine for each of two levels in each language, but the free demo disk is well worth investigating.

There is more choice post-GCSE level, including Eurotalk's innovative DVDs. The same company produces Asterix CD-Roms in French and German, each offering 20 hours of individual work in the style of the cartoon. You listen to a page from the story in the foreign language and, if you have fully understood it, proceed to the next. If not, you can call up three levels of help. First, the spoken text and directions appear in the bubbles of the cartoon. Next, you can have teachers notes on difficult points. Finally, there is a translation. You can hear the story, or any fragment of it, as often as you want, and there is a selection of games for consolidation. Price is again complicated - the set in each language costs £29.99 for home use, but schools have to pay an additional £50, with network licences from £85 to £210 for 30 users.

 What's the Point (Staffordshire Language Group, 01782 254242, £28 +VAT) is a 10-minute video designed to encourage young people to continue to learn languages after leaving school. Its style is a fast-moving series of soundbytes and snippets, the most convincing of which are from a personnel manager who will not employ anyone who does not speak a foreign language, and from a young woman working for Michelin tyres who finds her French helpful.

fields.headline: Young citizens
fields.standfirst: Human rights, press freedom, race relations... a host of burning issues will be covered by the new curriculum subject of citizenship from this September. Phil Revell asks what role ICT can play
fields.trailText: Human rights, press freedom, race relations... a host of burning issues will be covered by the new curriculum subject of citizenship from this September. Phil Revell asks what role ICT can play
fields.body:
What's your vision of the citizen of the future? Winston Smith cowering in his flat under the beady eye of big brother? Or Bernard Marx introducing the Savage to a not so brave new world? Or is it Snowball conducting lessons for the animals in the old barn?

Citizenship becomes a curriculum subject in September and is compulsory from 2002. The curriculum orders have been published, and the QCA published guidance earlier this year. Bernard Crick intended schools to have a good deal of freedom in how they approach the new subject and the more imaginative teachers are already looking at the possibilities ICT offers.

A keyboard isn't an obvious starting point for a classroom debate, but James Honeybone, who runs a website offering debating topics for teachers, argues that computer-based materials could allow pupils to enter the discussion better prepared to contribute in a worthwhile way.

"Pupils really value that one-to-one with the computer," he says. Honeybone's website (www.chweekly.co.uk) offers teachers a weekly topic and a structure for classroom debates. A project funded by the Economic and Social Research Council has found that group discussion and reasoning ability of primary- aged children improves significantly after computer activities have been used to stimulate debate.

Pupils were presented with a moral dilemma involving a girl who shoplifted and then told her friend. The study found that children who had used the program spoke with significantly more reasoning words such as "I think" and "because" in later group discussions. Self-confidence and class discipline then improved and measures of reasoning and debating skills showed a fourfold increase.

Dr Neil Mercer, at the Open University's Centre for Language and Communication, says teachers often assume children know how to debate and use the language of reason, but he believes they need to be taught. The value of computers in the exercise lies in the way they have been allowed tasks to be well-structured, says Dr Mercer.

Whether the European Union is well structured might be one of the debating topics, and a rich vein of material can be found on Schoolnet on www.eun.org. The EU-funded Schoolnet has its origins in Sweden*s drive to link all its schools to the net. In March 1997, European education ministers and the European Commission agreed to Sweden*s proposal and Schoolnet was born in September 1998. The website has four main facilities: a collaboration area for teachers to meet and access information on cross-border projects; a resources area holding learning materials; an innovation area to help teachers stay in touch with developments; and a teacher-training area with workshops and self-training materials.

Another element of Schoolnet is the European Network of Innovative Schools, a group of more than 200 pioneering ICT in the classroom. The ENIS website details the best practice made using ICT by the member schools and provides them with a forum to set up joint projects. How much use schools make of resources such as Schoolnet will depend on their approach to the subject. At the Citizenship Foundation (www.citfou.org.uk) director Don Rowe is concerned about some of the material on offer. "There's some old-fashioned civics being published," he says. "My advice would be: don't use the first thing you see." Rowe believes there is a lot of potential for new approaches to learning offered through citizenship.

In some schools citizenship will probably be tacked on to the curriculum as an afterthought. Pupils will be regaled with exciting lessons on parliamentary procedure and the delights of civic responsibility. In others, teachers will try to give young people a sense of their place in the world and build a belief that they can influence the events around them. Tomorrow*s citizen will be living in a global society and the opportunity to make contact with people from other countries and cultures has to be one of the main reasons for using ICT.

Dos and don'ts

Dos

 Check out sites on the net before allowing children to begin research. Internet pornography is not your only worry. There is some unsavoury and inaccurate information on the internet, especially from some far-right groups.

 Make sure you are familiar and confident with the hardware you will be using. Nothing kills a lesson more surely than a technical problem in the first five minutes, which results in the teacher wrestling with an surly printer or program for the rest of the lesson.

 Think about the overall system your school uses. Citizenship is about responsibility and children should be encouraged to take responsibility for their actions when using ICT. Do you have a user's policy? Have children had any say in the rules which govern computer use? Do you encourage good memory management by giving each student their personal directory on the hard disk - with the associated responsibility for back-ups and deletion of redundant material?

 Think about the news websites as a source of material for debate. Guardian Unlimited is a rich source of contemporary material which might have been designed for teachers.

Don'ts

 Allow children to simply cut and paste into their own work. Any material taken from a CD-Rom or website should be edited into the child's own words. Quotes should be properly attributed.

 Allow children to email charities and pressure groups for information. They are voluntary organisations whose resources should really be directed to their target groups. Instead, encourage proper research.

 Allow racist or sexist comments in a classroom discussion lesson. Freedom of speech should be tempered by respect for the rights of others, which is what good citizenship is all about.

fields.headline: Learn online
fields.standfirst: Pick up tips for your own website design from the latest Guardian website to hit the internet - www.learn.co.uk, the place to go for resources. Report by Richard Doughty
fields.trailText: Pick up tips for your own website design from the latest Guardian website to hit the internet - www.learn.co.uk, the place to go for resources. Report by Richard Doughty
fields.body:
Creating a web version of the complete GCSE (upper tier) curriculum content for maths, science, English language and English literature is a tough nut to crack. But making it comprehensible, compelling and above all accessible is even tougher - in size alone, the Guardian's new resources website is over 1,000 pages - and counting. So from the start, a clear and simple site with clear, simple navigation has been a must.

"Many sites try to tell people too much from their front pages," says Andrea Osbourne, website producer for www.learn.co.uk. "The main point of the site is lesson content, not who is behind it, or its aims or anything else."

A user's main concern is getting access to the information immediately. So when you open up the home page you will see a straightforward listing of the subject areas in the centre of the screen. To the left is the main navigation menu which appears on every page and links you to different parts of the site. To the right is an ever-present link where users can get extra subject-specific information such as the web guide glossary and subject lessons menu. An education site has to help, not hinder teachers and pupils - it has to be "where they are at". There is not much point in rewording any of the phraseology or adopting a different colour scheme to those used by teachers in the printed national curriculum materials. "Try finding one to represent the English language lesson unit 'Simile, Metaphor and Personification'. You can't!" says Osbourne.

By its nature the site has to be largely text-based; so icons are introduced sparingly. But it continues to adopt the Guardian's now tried and tested website trademarks (see below), which aim to make it easy to read and easy to use:

 Text is displayed in the middle of a page, filling a third of the width of the screen. This eases reading across the screen and will also fit smaller computer screens (how many websites are almost unreadable with text strewn across the full screen width?)

 Fonts are kept to a minimum on the page - otherwise a site can end up looking like a ransom letter.

 Three fonts are used, Geneva (Mac), Arial (PC) and Sans Serif (will default to this if neither of the other fonts are present), allowing a user's browser to show pages in Arial if it does not have Geneva, and Sans Serif if it has no Arial (it's easy to set up but comparatively rare on other websites).

 A maximum of two mouse-clicks (where possible) will take you where you want to go.

 There is a clear, sequential breakdown of each subject area into reasonably sized lessons and units (eg, the lesson on Digesting Food is split in 10 units - it's too big to put on one page and also has too much material to be taken in at one go).

Added user aids include the same set of navigation links at the top and bottom of each page.

You finish one lesson and go to another - why scroll back to the top of the lesson to move on when you are already at the bottom of the page? Why not pre-empt what the site user will naturally do next?

"The sequence of designing a new website is, first, to decide on content," explains Osbourne.

"Then work out navigation - how people get from A to B via C and D. If a site is not easy to use or navigate around, people will get lost and won't come back.

"After navigation, we do mock-ups (in Microsoft Word) of what the pages will look like and hand them to the designer. This tells them what elements have to be on a page."

Of course, there has to be an incentive to return to the site. You could download all the relevant lessons and see no reason to return very often, but the attraction here is online lesson tests. Interactive, multiple-choice questions requiring single mouse-click answers are randomly selected on a particular topic - the same set of questions never appears twice. It gives your score at the end, along with examiners' comments about why one answer is correct - it's not just tick or cross. Soon, too, teachers will be able to tailor tests to suit their own teaching schedules.

And the site is certainly not all text-based. One of its strengths is the wide range of still images, graphics, animated gifs (these can be picked up by all browsers and are a series of still images repeated in sequence) and interactive flash files (multimedia files containing sound, motion and interactivity - they need a "plug-in" which can be downloaded free from www.macromedia.com/ shockwave/download/ ).

"Another strength is that we are not putting any subject on the web until it is complete," says Osbourne. "Otherwise people would to have to keep returning to check when new material is there."

As to the future, French is the next subject due to be completed within the next few weeks, followed by key stage two and three resources in maths, science and English in the autumn, along with middle and lower GCSE tiers.

History, geography, business studies and computer studies are among subjects due to follow later in the year.

Watch this space.

webTitle: The good, the bad and the ugly

fields.headline: The good, the bad and the ugly
fields.standfirst: Good design is crucial anywhere, and websites should be no exception to this rule. Stephen Heppell offers a guide to aspiring website designers
fields.trailText: Good design is crucial anywhere, and websites should be no exception to this rule. Stephen Heppell offers a guide to aspiring website designers
fields.body:
Back in 1992/3 anyone who could get a world wide website working was immediately feted as a veteran. Now, with a wide range of web-authoring tools to choose from, anyone can be a web jockey. And just as schools discovered at the dawn of desktop publishing seven years earlier, once the task gets easy, excellent design differentiates good from bad.

Unfortunately, while desktop publishing has a rich history of high quality typography as a starting point, some of the most sumptuous and expensive websites are among the worst examples of design anywhere. Corporate often is synonymous with ghastly.

Teachers and students are thus left to plan from first principles and, above all, to do so with their common sense turned on. Luckily, teachers are communication professionals which is why education boasts so many great websites. Here are eight simple rules to start you thinking:

1. Bad web designers often overdo large pictures and add too much special code to showcase their front page when the site is launched. That's without regard for those of us who have to view via a slow internet connection. You know better and must chant the mantra "children hate to wait".

Elegant, lean, fast design takes skill and imagination. Test your pages with the same slow phone connection and poor computer that many users have. Your front page should be less than 25k, including everything. Graphics are more compact if their colour palettes are limited to three or four colours.

2. Leave your guests with a clear model of the website's navigation. This doesn't mean filling half the screen with a contents table all the time. Book and architectural metaphors are so last century. Surely you can do better. Remember your audience will include children. At Ultralab, at Anglia Polytechnic University, when we tested children with some icons from adult life they surprised us with their misunderstandings; faced with a "no entry" sign, they took it to mean "smoking allowed". (There is no diagonal bar through what they took to be a cigarette!)

3. Remember that as many as one in five are poor or reluctant readers. A text-heavy site with complex phrases and adult grammar will repel many. Where you must use text, add simple icons to aid recognition. Remember to complete the "alt" tags that label images and help visually impaired users to get at least a spoken description of the images.

Text alone is rarely seductive and remember that, on a poor screen, tiny, anti-aliased graphics are hard to read. The computer screen is not paper.

4. Be aware that there are many permutations of computer, operating system, browser and service provider, all hoping to persuade you to develop sites that support their monopoly by excluding others. Our largest Ultralab projects regularly count over 50 such combinations accessing our servers, and you should test your site on a variety of them; why would you exclude anyone by design? Stick to open standards.

5. Think hard about how your site handles time. It is not enough to say: "This page revised on 9/5/00." Was that its birthday treat, or is it revised weekly? There is a world of difference between a site that you expect to stay comfortingly static (the complete works of Shakespeare, for example) and one which you hope would change hourly (a news site). Be sure you help to fulfil people's expectations by indicating which of these your page is, and remember there is great merit in announcing forthcoming events and in summarising after closure. Time matters.

6. This is a lesson many sites never seem to learn: the content on your site will always struggle to be up-to-date and seductive if it all has to be handled by a "web team". Imagine if everything on all your school display boards was produced by just a couple of people. Don't build a bottleneck for others' creativity.

A successful alternative, always, is to empower everyone to be able to make a contribution. At its simplest this might be a place on the network where they can find, and complete, standard templates. At best it is a website built entirely on a database so that contribution and editing is a geek-free activity. Children's work needs to be authentic, rather than perfect, just like the work displayed on classroom walls.

7. Be clear that frames are ghastly. People who use them probably can't even spell design. Just say no.

8. Dust off your learning theory; no one ever learned by watching, waiting or scrolling. What is your page for? Think hard about the activities that your website supports: what will users do, can they post the results of their efforts on the site, how will they be rewarded, supported, applauded? Schools are for learning, not for publishing.

Be comforted that many sites that should know better fall regularly into all the traps above: the EU's European SchoolNet site has no "alt" tags in any language; a national instituion's new 3D pages are optimised for one computer chip and don't work at all for many; the front pages of TES Online has a strange use of frames to limit the screen size; and the Open University's news pages have had nothing new added since March 2. At the chalkface, in schools and colleges we know about children, communications, inclusion and design; don't be afraid to trust your own judgment.

 Professor Stephen Heppell is head of Ultralab, a learning technology resource centre based at Anglia Polytechnic University.

Dos and don'ts of website design

By John Davitt

Do

 Look at the webpage layout of others and ask how did they do that? Also look at the hidden code (html) that makes up web pages by selecting view source in your browser.

 Use children's work. Remember that nothing is as engaging as the students' own work. Hand-drawn artwork should be scanned in, and recordings of children's original music performances can now be recorded and played as part of the web page.

 Do it once, update it often. Think of a website as an iceberg where most of the work is hidden beneath the surface and realise from the start that website work is less about doing it once and more about updating it often. Schools taking first steps in this area should start with a clear idea of purpose and audience - it may be a site for the school, a department, or just one built around a particular interest or activity.

Don't

 Use large images. Many commercial producers have a house rule of 60 kilobytes as a maximum page size. That means the page would load inside five seconds on a standard internet connection. Images are the biggest danger. Keep them physically small: 240 by 180 pixels is a common size for web pages.

 Let your page be flat - hint at the third dimension. Any work done for display on the computer screen is stuck in the second dimension, but you can learn how to use shadow and perspective to hint at depth by looking at the work of others. Use your graphics package to give images a drop shadow and capture an illusion of depth.

Our largest Ultralab projects regularly count over 50 such combinations accessing our servers, and you should test your site on a variety of them; why would you exclude anyone by design? Stick to open standards. 5. Think hard about how your site handles time. It is not enough to say: "This page revised on 9/5/00." Was that its birthday treat, or is it revised weekly? There is a world of difference between a site that you expect to stay comfortingly static (the complete works of Shakespeare, for example) and one which you hope would change hourly (a news site). Be sure you help to fulfil people's expectations by indicating which of these your page is, and remember there is great merit in announcing forthcoming events and in summarising after closure. Time matters. 6. This is a lesson many sites never seem to learn: the content on your site will always struggle to be up-to-date and seductive if it all has to be handled by a "web team". Imagine if everything on all your school display boards was produced by just a couple of people. Don't build a bottleneck for others' creativity. A successful alternative, always, is to empower everyone to be able to make a contribution. At its simplest this might be a place on the network where they can find, and complete, standard templates. At best it is a website built entirely on a database so that contribution and editing is a geek-free activity. Children's work needs to be authentic, rather than perfect, just like the work displayed on classroom walls. 7. Be clear that frames are ghastly. People who use them probably can't even spell design. Just say no. 8. Dust off your learning theory; no one ever learned by watching, waiting or scrolling. What is your page for? Think hard about the activities that your website supports: what will users do, can they post the results of their efforts on the site, how will they be rewarded, supported, applauded? Schools are for learning, not for publishing. Be comforted that many sites that should know better fall regularly into all the traps above: the EU's European SchoolNet site has no "alt" tags in any language; a national instituion's new 3D pages are optimised for one computer chip and don't work at all for many; the front pages of TES Online has a strange use of frames to limit the screen size; and the Open University's news pages have had nothing new added since March 2. At the chalkface, in schools and colleges we know about children, communications, inclusion and design; don't be afraid to trust your own judgment.  Professor Stephen Heppell is head of Ultralab, a learning technology resource centre based at Anglia Polytechnic University. Dos and don'ts of website design By John Davitt Do  Look at the webpage layout of others and ask how did they do that? Also look at the hidden code (html) that makes up web pages by selecting view source in your browser.  Use children's work. Remember that nothing is as engaging as the students' own work. Hand-drawn artwork should be scanned in, and recordings of children's original music performances can now be recorded and played as part of the web page.  Do it once, update it often. Think of a website as an iceberg where most of the work is hidden beneath the surface and realise from the start that website work is less about doing it once and more about updating it often. Schools taking first steps in this area should start with a clear idea of purpose and audience - it may be a site for the school, a department, or just one built around a particular interest or activity. Don't  Use large images. Many commercial producers have a house rule of 60 kilobytes as a maximum page size. That means the page would load inside five seconds on a standard internet connection. Images are the biggest danger. Keep them physically small: 240 by 180 pixels is a common size for web pages.  Let your page be flat - hint at the third dimension. Any work done for display on the computer screen is stuck in the second dimension, but you can learn how to use shadow and perspective to hint at depth by looking at the work of others. Use your graphics package to give images a drop shadow and capture an illusion of depth.

fields.headline: Classroom challenge
fields.standfirst: Putting information on the net is one thing; making it accessible is another. John Davitt offers a trainer's view on website design
fields.trailText: Putting information on the net is one thing; making it accessible is another. John Davitt offers a trainer's view on website design
fields.body:
If Sisyphus was around today they might give him the school website rather than a rock to labour over. For the innocent job of knocking up a few web pages and linking them together to become a website has a nasty habit of turning from a small achievable task into something close to a mythical and oft-repeated labour.

Yet the ability to publish fresh, dynamic information about the school is a beguiling opportunity. A well-run website can provide an ideal and cost-effective means of keeping in touch with students outside school and informing parents and the wider community of work in progress.

New software tools and group working practices are starting to make this dream a reality, and schools with successful websites are often those who have learned early that website design and maintenance is a group activity.

If you are to have a broad, balanced and developing website, you need the right software and a group of people with complimentary skills. Too often the job falls to one busy individual and their heroic efforts result in one brief shining moment.

There are many ways to make a web page. Schools are using a range of web page-making software from the ideal starter pack of Netscape Composer, which comes free as part of the Netscape browser package to powerful commercial tools like Adobe GoLive, Macromedia's Dreamweaver and Front Page from Microsoft. These three packages set dramatic new standards in terms of ease of use and media integration, but they all involve a fairly steep learning curve.

Alternatively, there is a variety of free web page software, such as Hot Metal and Arachnophilia, that can be downloaded from the internet from sites such as www.shareware.com.

All web-authoring software allows you to put text and images on a web page and link several completed pages together by means of hypertext links - the blue underlined text which denotes a link to another place. Develop a vocabulary of expectation of what you want to put on your web pages by looking at the work of others - there are over 100 million pages out there to learn from. Many sites like www.msn.com publish template web pages which you can take and adapt to make your own page. Try searching for "web page templates" on the web using the search engine at www.altavista.com to find your own starting points.

Although the web page is a direct descendant of the printed page in evolutionary terms, there are some important differences. The initial design constraint for a web page is the size of the computer screen on which others will view your work - that's a little less than the size of the top half of this page. Try to include all the relevant information in this area in the first few pages of your site - visitors to the page are more likely to leave rather than scroll down to look for hidden content.

White space and page size are two other key design considerations. Neutral space left around the text is essential if the key messages are to be noticed rather than submerged in a sea of content. A general rule of thumb is for text to cover only two thirds of a line with a large left margin taking up the remaining space. When it comes to individual web pages, small is beautiful in terms of memory size - if your final page is small then it will load quickly when someone looks at it on the internet. See some examples of fast-loading, well designed pages at www.zazz.com/fast50/

Decide what you want to do and who your audience will be, then start to gather your assets in terms of text and pictures. Next document the various tasks arising in terms of typing text, scanning pictures and updating milestones. If they are not on board already this is a good time to involve the students, and encourage the development of a web production team.

Get hold of good graphic software such as Paintshop Pro and remember to save all images bound for web-page work in either the jpeg or gif file format. These two formats save memory and are compatible with all browsers.

Over time the web page will become a key curriculum publishing tool, a place where last year's field trip images can live alongside highlights from the school Christmas concert in one interlinked multimedia medley.

Web pages can be written for in-school use and stored as an internal collection of web pages known as an intranet or published on the internet for public consumption. Alongside images and text, web pages can also hold simple animations and sound. Some schools are starting to use sound to dramatic effect, building web pages which resonate to the beat of a year three rap or a solo violin piece. The latest Flash software from Macromedia makes it easy to incorporate sound and movies into small-sized web pages.

Useful downloadable website workshop: Arachnophilia (which is Careware):www.arachnoid.com/arachnophilia/index.html

 John Davitt is a freelance writer and trainer. He runs courses on making your own website in a day. See www.wordroot.co.uk

Q&A: Constructing your website

How can I publicise my school website? Add a signature to your emails that briefly describes your site along with the all-important address. That way all recipients of school emails will have a pointer back to your website. You can also go to your favourite search engine and use the add url option, which tells the search engine that your page exists and what it is about.

What is html? Short for hypertext markup language, html is the code which underpins each web page. It is hidden from you now in all but the most basic of web page editors; you only need to delve into the code if you want to do something special such as adding a midi file (see below). It tells the browser how the page should look, where the images should go and what the links should lead to when they are clicked.

How can I get sound on to my web page? The simplest way is to save a piece of music as a midi file from a keyboard, or download a midi file from the web then include the lines <BGSOUND SRC="GETBACK.MID" LOOP="-1"> in the html of your web page. (where GET BACK.MID is the name of your midi file). Softwaresuch as the new Adobe LiveMotion and Flash from Macromedia automates and integrates moving images, sounds and interactivity into small packages that sit within a web page . They both support the use of MP3 sound files so that good quality sound such as a head's speech or the choir in action can be streamed out to users who browse to your page. Find out more at www.adobe.com or www.macromedia.com

How can I build web pages with questions and multiple-choice activities for students? CourseBuilder from Macromedia is a piece of software which allows interactive content and tests to be built into web-page format. It works with Dreamweaver and it even allows you to keep track of individual student records - just the thing for the end- of-module test on the intranet.

fields.headline: Lies, Cheats and Inducements
fields.trailText: A BRAND NEW SERIES
fields.body:
A BRAND NEW SERIES

Welcome to the first in an occasional series profiling those tedious transfer rumours which drag on and on, hanging around all summer like a hazy cloud of journalist's sweat.

1. Robbie Fowler to Manchester United.

Not to be confused with Robbie Fowler to Arsenal (which will be number 2 tomorrow). The origins of this particular rumour can be found in the Sun, who argue that a irreparable rift has developed between Fowler and Gerard Houllier after the Liverpool manager dropped the world's most mature scamp for the Reds' crucial final game of the season at Bradford.

United have offered £15m to secure what would be the most sensational transfer since United bought Andy Cole, which was the most sensational transfer since United bought Eric Cantona. But the Fiver doesn't fancy their chances much for two reasons. One, hoards of irate Kopites would rip the Anfield boardroom to pieces before turning their attentions to the people in it. Two, the player has denied any such rift exists.

"I am amazed that people have tried to suggest I had a blazing row with the manager and there had been a bust-up," Robbie told the official Liverpool web site. "It simply is not true. The manager explained why I wasn't in the squad on Sunday and I fully respect his decision." That's put paid to talk of the most natural finisher in the Premiership leaving Anfield in the close season, then.

Actually, no it hasn't.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LOW-LYING (BUT NOT LOW AND LYING)

Sign up now for the Euro. It's exactly the Fiver, except it's not, because it's solely about Euro 2000. It'll give you the low-down from the lowlands every morning, so to subscribe, go to Football Unlimited and click on the Euro box, which is somewhere or other. Or send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line. Come June 5, it'll arrive for the very first time.

If you get a incomprehensible mail back, blame our software. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, everything's fine. Oh yes.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AN ADVERT

Need to know what's happening in the world of Marketing Advertising and Design? Then GO MAD with www.mad.co.uk. Free trial subscription details here.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DEAL!

In a smoky room in the back-streets of Copenhagen, Arsenal's card-shark king Arsene Wenger is raising the psychological stakes. "I have a contract with Arsenal until the end of the 2002 season, and I will respect it." That's an impressive opening from Wenger, reassuring his team on the eve of the big game and putting the Gunners into early profit.

"Who says Arsenal are favourites?" responds a fiery Gheorghe Hagi, countering with a verbal flush (4,5,6,7,8). "Every day in training you have to reach into the soul of a player," philosophises manager Fatih Terim, whilst laying down a bicycle wheel. A startled Wenger ups the ante by calling Gheorge Hagi the "European Maradona". But the plan back-fires when it becomes clear he's not referring to the Romanian's age, or his penchant for pies - but his play-making ability.

With Gala ahead and the final hand about to be played, a stranger walks into the room. It's David O'Leary and he's got a set of mirrors strapped to his cufflinks. "I think Arsenal will beat them without too many problems. We beat Roma and Spartak Moscow on our way to the semi-finals and Galatasaray are not in the same class as either of those teams," says the man with the inside knowledge (and a 20-year career at Highbury). "To be honest, I wasn't impressed with their defence. They're there to be got at and I can see Arsenal scoring a few goals," he adds, before laying down five aces.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Gianluca has not achieved anything. Chelsea reached the quarter-finals of [Big Cup] this season, but they have not qualified for next season's competition. It's very easy to go to the top, but far more difficult to stay there" - Chelsea manager is rubbish says Ruud Gullit, ex-Chelsea manager.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHEN IN DOUBT, GET THE CHEQUEBOOK OUT

Barcelona, unassailable titans of the European game (according to themselves a few weeks ago), are on the verge of finishing the season empty-handed. Done over by Valencia in Big Cup, they also been inconsistent in the league, with Deportivo La Coruna needing only one point against Espanyol on Friday to take the title. As a result, Barca are said to have offered their city rivals around £1m in bonuses to win the game. Which is only fair really.

Of course, the whole of Spanish football has exploded in outrage at the suggestion. Espanyol striker Raul Tamudo spoke for many today when he said: "A bonus would go down nicely for the holidays!" You see, offering third parties incentives to win football matches is not illegal in Spain, and is in fact endorsed by names as reputable as, er, Jesus Gil. Barca are also widely believed to have used the tactic before - including the last time Deportivo were challenging for the title in 1994. And as Barca's vice-president Juan Gaspar has revealed: "What was done has to be done again."

This cash incentive will be a lovely parting gift from Barca president Josep Nunez who will, according to Barca TV, be stepping down from the club this summer - a move not in any way prompted by 300 fans trying to bum-rush his directors box last Wednesday. What Barca haven't realised though is that Deportivo can defeat their plan simply by offering a cash incentive to themselves. Or perhaps they could even knock up a trophy with "league winners" on it and promise to give it to themselves if they win. You never know, it might just work.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Fulham's new manager Jean Tigana has been linked with moves for three fellow Frenchmen: Bordeaux striker Sylvian Wiltord, Monaco keeper Fabian Barthez and Auxerre winger Bernard Diomede. All three are current internationals.

Ben Thatcher and Neil Sullivan have been tipped for a move to Spurs this summer following Wimbledon's relegation. Sullivan is already believed to have travelled to White Hart Lane for talks.

Rio Ferdinand is thought to be Leeds' next transfer target after they complete the £7.2m signing of Olivier Dacourt. Peter Ridsdale is expected to tempt West Ham with an £11m bid for the 21-year-old England defender.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Arsenal reserve goalkeeper Alex Manninger has been ruled out of the Euro-Vase final against Galatasaray with a hand infection. John Lukic will stand by as David Seaman's deputy.

Ipswich striker David Johnson is definitely out of his side's play-off semi-final second leg against Bolton with a neck injury. George Burley's other worry, defender Tony Mowbray, is expected to recover from an eye problem.

Roy Keane and Gary Kelly have been ruled out of the Republic of Ireland squad for the matches against Scotland, Mexico, USA and South Africa. The squad: A Kelly (Blackburn), Given (Newcastle), Kiely (Charlton); Carr (Tottenham), Cunningham (Wimbledon), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Everton), Butler (Sunderland), Babb (Liverpool); Holland (Ipswich), Kennedy (Man City), Kinsella (Charlton), McAteer (Blackburn), Kilbane (Sunderland), Duff (Blackburn), Finnan (Fulham), Kavanagh (Stoke), McPhail (Leeds); Quinn (Sunderland), Keane (Coventry), Delap (Derby).

The FA have signed a deal which will see them give technical support to the Asian Football Confederation. Basics such as goal nets will be provided, while professional coaches will be sent out to help with training. It is the latest move in a charm offensive aimed at winning support for the 2006 World Cup campaign, although the FA insist the deal would have gone ahead anyway.

Parma will play Internazionale on May 23 in Verona to determine who takes Italy's fourth Big Cup place for next season.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.35am)
A week after blame, some rain and pain.

Sky Sports 1: Cup Heroes (5.55pm, 10.15pm, 3.15am)
Just because the Premiership has finished...

Best Of The FA Cup (6.30pm, 11pm, 2.45am)
... don't think that Sky will simply keep repeating...

Inside Scottish Football (7pm, 11.30pm)
... the same programmes over and over again just to fill the schedules.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.20pm, 3.20am)
"Let me see that thong! That thong-thon-thon-thon-thong! Gina, you left your fruit pastilles at Nev's chamber music party. He needs you to pick them up ASAP. Alrighty? Love, Minty." We don't care what you've been up to, just don't involve McCaff - he doesn't want to know. Email the.boss@theguardian.com and keep it legit!

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)
What football would be like if it was played by preening self-obsessed pretty-boys. What? Ah, we see.

fields.headline: The unfriendly skies
fields.trailText: What's surprising about today's report of a near miss between a British Airways 747 and a British Midland Airbus over Heathrow is not that the incident took place - but that the planes came so close. The jets are reported to have avoided each other by only 100ft: seconds in flying terms and serious enough for officials at the Air Accident Investigation Branch, which normally only investigates crashes, to study the incident. Fortunately, close shaves like this are rare.
fields.body:
What's surprising about today's report of a near miss between a British Airways 747 and a British Midland Airbus over Heathrow is not that the incident took place - but that the planes came so close. The jets are reported to have avoided each other by only 100ft: seconds in flying terms and serious enough for officials at the Air Accident Investigation Branch, which normally only investigates crashes, to study the incident. Fortunately, close shaves like this are rare.

But for most pilots less serious near misses, or ''aircraft proximity incidents'', are a routine - if disturbing - part of aviation life. Last year a report by French air-traffic controllers revealed a 50% rise in near misses involving civil airliners under their direction: with a peak of nearly one a day in the summer. The report foresaw the chance of a disaster every week within the next 15 years, unless control systems are updated.

In December last year four jets stacking over Biggin Hill, south of London, almost collided while waiting for slots to land at Heathrow: a Boeing 737 from Paris was believed to have come within 1,000ft of a 747 jumbo from Cairo. Two months earlier, malfunctioning computer equipment sent a Korean Air cargo jet into the flight-path of a British Airways flight in uncontrolled airspace over China. The BA plane took avoiding action as the planes passed within two seconds of disaster. Weeks before that, two Concorde flights passed closer than safety margins allow as they crossed the sea near New York's Kennedy airport.

Under the Civil Aviation Authority regulations, aircraft must not be less than 1,000ft apart vertically, or three miles horizontally. But with a plane landing or taking off in the south-east of England every 16 seconds, this limit is being breached increasingly often. With the rapid growth in long-haul travel and low-cost European flights, competition for flight space is getting intense, and some in the industry argue that safety is becoming the victim.

Part of the problem is the confused system responsible for managing Europe's air-routes. Flights remain under national control, with a proposed centralised system still on the drawing board. Adding to the disarray, Britain's new £450m control centre at Swanwick, near Bournemouth, still hasn't opened almost seven years after it was due to begin operations. Its computer systems, designed to relieve traffic-controllers, have failed to cope. Even engineers involved in the project admit it will not open before winter 2001-2. Some doubt it will open at all.

As a result, Britain's existing air traffic-control centre at West Drayton is under ever-greater pressure, with unions saying that the government's plans to part-privatise the National Air Traffic Service (Nats) are likely to make things worse.

Officials at Nats argue that there is no cause for alarm. While they admit that the service is operating at near capacity, they say that safety is not at risk. So far, they seem to be right. People may be shocked by ever-more frequent reports of near misses, but there have been few cases of planes actually colliding. Two years ago more than 300 people were killed outside Delhi when two aircraft strayed into the same airspace: but such incidents remain very much the exception. And as airports around the world get busier still, passengers will be hoping it stays that way.

webTitle: CRE warns of "massive" rise in racist crime

fields.headline: CRE warns of "massive" rise in racist crime
fields.trailText: The number of race-related crimes reported in London has more than doubled since last year, indicating a massive rise in recorded racial incidents across the country, the Commission for Racial Equality warned today.
fields.body:
The number of race-related crimes reported in London has more than doubled since last year, indicating a massive rise in recorded racial incidents across the country, the Commission for Racial Equality warned today.

Metropolitan Police figures show there were 23,346 recorded racist incidents in the capital in 1999/2000, the equivalent of 63 every day, compared with 11,050 in 1998/1999.

While the national figures for this year are not yet available to compare with last year's data, Gurbux Singh, the new chairman of the CRE, said the London figures pointed to a "massive" nationwide rise in recorded racial incidents.

A CRE spokeswoman said she expected the nationwide total to double, in line with the London figures. Speaking today during his first week as the CRE chairman, Mr Singh said: "My job is to make sure that the police never again place a lower priority on catching those who victimise other human beings just because of the colour of their skin."

Mr Singh called for a "zero-tolerance policy" against racists and said lenient sentences "send out a message that it is all right to be a racist". He added: "The proof of whether these policies were working will come in the shape of a greater diversity of people working in the public sector, more emphasis on tackling poor education, poor housing and poor social services that specifically affect ethnic minority communities and individuals."

The Metropolitan Police force has come under fire for its handling of the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence, who was killed in a racist attack in 1993. An inquiry found that the force had failed to investigate the crime properly because of "institutional racism".

Last week, John Grieve, the Met's racial task force director, admitted during a lecture that his was an institutionally racist organisation. He said: "We have made terrible mistakes and my determination is that we seek to build a police service ready to face the challenges of a new millennium - a millennium that is hostile to racists."

Related story
Race in Britain: special report

webTitle: 16 May: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 16 May: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Mendes quashes Kidman and Cruise theatre rumours, Matthew Perry in hospital, Drew Barrymore's mum gets into more trouble, and on the casting couch, Madonna, Geri Halliwell, Jason Schwartzman, John Cusack, Nick Nolte and Tim Allen
fields.body:
 Oscar-winning director Sam Mendes has quashed speculation that Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman to appear in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof at London's Donmar Warehouse. Mendes said: "There is utterly and categorically no foundation in the rumour that they will be appearing at the Donmar. Firstly, we do not own the rights to this play and secondly, Tom and Nicole are tied up with their own projects for the foreseeable future." Well, that's that then.

 Matthew Perry's week-long stay in hospital is already stirring up rumours that the actor may have reverted to his bad old drug-hoovering ways. The star of Friends, who has undergone rehab in the past, was admitted for flu eight days ago, but a spokesperson says there have been complications and that Perry is now being treated for severe stomach pains. The lay-off comes at a time when the actor's career appears to be at its peak. Only yesterday it was revealed that he had secured $750,000 (around £470,000) an episode for the NBC sitcom over the next two years; he has also recently managed a successful move into feature films, co-starring with Bruce Willis in the hit comedy The Whole Nine Yards, which opens in Britain on Friday.

 The Barrymore family's hell-raising reputation took another turn at the weekend when Jaid Barrymore (mother of Drew) was arrested in New York in the early hours of Sunday morning for "criminal mischief" and the possession of a firearm. Barrymore, 53, was apprehended after illegally posting flyers for a Manhattan rock band when city police discovered a gun in her handbag. Barrymore senior has been estranged from her daughter Drew for the past six years.

Casting couch

 Madonna is rumoured to be starring in a trio of movies for art-house British film-maker Peter Greenaway. The music website Music 365 reports that the Greenaway films - known as The Tulse Luper Trilogy - will place Madonna alongside an eclectic cast that includes Dawn French, Richard Griffiths and Debbie Harry. The news confirms the singer-actress's healthy relations with British directors. In the past three years, Madonna has starred in Evita for Alan Parker and the comedy-drama The Next Best Thing for John Schlesinger. And she is of course pregnant by boyfriend Guy Richie, who happens to be yet another British director.

 From Madonna to Madonna wannabe: ex-Spice Girl Geri Halliwell is reportedly set to star in a London-based movie called Therapist about a feisty patient (Geri, natch) who has an affair with her shrink. Buster director David Green will be behind the camera and the film will shoot later this year. The Sun reports that Therapy is budgeted at £7m of which £1m goes direct to the booming Geri bank account.

 Jason Schwartzman - the bespectacled geek icon of last year's off-kilter comedy Rushmore - has signed to star in Donnie Darko. Intriguingly billed as a "sci-fi teenage romance", the picture will be overseen by Drew Barrymore's production house Flower Films. Barrymore will produce and appear in a cameo, while the film will be directed by Richard Kelly.

 John Cusack and Nick Nolte look set to star as rival cops in White Jazz, an adaptation of the novel by James Ellroy. Set in late-50s Los Angeles, White Jazz is a dog-eat-dog story in the tradition of Ellroy's LA Confidential (adapted for the screen in 1997). The book forms the final part in the writer's quartet of police stories. Renowned cinematographer Robert Richardson will make his directing debut on the film.

 American comic Tim Allen is in talks to head the cast of Big Trouble, a freewheeling comedy about a booby-trapped suitcase. Big Trouble is based on the comic novel by Dave Barry and is to be directed by Barry Sonnenfeld. The film goes before the cameras this August.

fields.headline: Chums again?
fields.standfirst: George Low discovers a new harmony between David Blunkett and the mayor
fields.trailText: George Low discovers a new harmony between David Blunkett and the mayor
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's rehabilitation from pariah to politician-Labour-can-work-with has been given a firm boost by the Education Secretary.

Claiming to be the first cabinet member to have shaken the mayor's hand since his election, David Blunkett pledged his support to London's Mayor in a campaign to improve the skills base and reduce unemployment in the capital.

At the launch of a blueprint for a public-private partnership in education and training in Westminster last Tuesday, both men agreed to work together to provide new skills for those out of work and those whose jobs were threatened by rapid technological change and globalisation. There was particular poignancy to this proof of the dictum about a week being a long time in politics. After all it's not long since Blunkett must have okayed the secondment of his right-hand adviser, Conor Ryan, to manage Frank Dobson's bid for selection as Labour's official mayoral candidate.

Blunkett accepted that Livingstone had the right to nominate members to the new London Development Agency, which will oversee further education in the region next year and set the agenda for the local Learning and Skills Councils. "We are not going back to the days of grand gestures, but through partnership we must both find alternatives to unemployment for those whose jobs are threatened and to social exclusion. Ken and I shared the same experiences in the 1980s when we had to pick up the pieces and now there is a new spirit of partnership between the public and private sector and colleges," he said. He promised the DfEE and Department for Trade and Industry would give the new mayor full backing to create a strategy that would "give people the hope and skills they need to cope".

Thanking his former adversary for his kind words and congratulations, Ken Livingstone said he was brought up in a London with full employment and jobs for life. But now "all my friends are on contracts or consultancies, reskilling themselves on quarterly basis... I will work as closely as possible with central government and the private sector to advance the London skills agenda. For example, a reliable transport system is needed to bring the people to where the jobs are. We have got to provide a second-chance programme for the hundreds of thousands to tie them into training opportunities and new skills. I will devote myself to that."

He said he had never accepted that people had the right to sit back as unemployed and receive handouts when there was training and work available. That was why he agreed with the Chancellor's Welfare to Work proposals. He agreed with David Blunkett that London was a tale of two cities - the skills haves and have-nots. Unless the have-nots are given the skills and opportunities to access the good things in life, they would disrupt the peace and prosperity of the haves. As for Blunkett, he joked that it was "a very strange evening - Ken and I seem to be saying exactly the same things and repeating each other".

 A Skills Strategy for All London's People is available from the LDP, 301 Central Market, Smithfield, London EC1A 9LY. Telephone: 020-7248 5555.

webTitle: Merger is on track, says AOL

fields.headline: Merger is on track, says AOL
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Internet service provider America Online moved yesterday to reassure investors that its merger with media group Time Warner was on track yesterday amid concern that regulatory scrutiny would hamper the ground-breaking deal.
fields.body:
Internet service provider America Online moved yesterday to reassure investors that its merger with media group Time Warner was on track yesterday amid concern that regulatory scrutiny would hamper the ground-breaking deal.

In a speech to an industry conference, Bob Pittman, the AOL president, said the group expected combined revenues of $40bn (£26.5bn) next year as well as cost savings of $1bn in AOL-Time Warner's first year of operation.

Rumours about the difficult anti-trust negotiations involving such a large cable network and the world's largest ISP, denied by the groups, have been circulating in the past week.

A note by analysts at Merrill Lynch, AOL's financial adviser, sought to reassure investors by stating that AOL executives were "comfortable the merger will close by the end of the year as expected".

The note, by Henry Blodget and Jessica Reif Cohen, remarked that many investors have called "regarding the progress" of the merger. They also reiterated a buy rating on both companies, mentioning that Mr Pittman was meeting all Time Warner divisions in an attempt to foster greater co-operation between them.

Analysts have raised questions about how the various parts of the group can work together. In an interview yesterday, Ms Reif Cohen said: "There may be a little bit more scrutiny [about the deal] but nobody really thinks that the deal won't get done."

Comments yesterday from Mr Pittman, who is to be co-chief operating officer of the combined group, lifted the share prices of both groups.

AOL rose almost $2 to more than $57, though shares are still trading almost a third below their pre-announcement level. The deal is valued at almost 25% less than in January.

Mr Pittman - who is to take over post-merger cable operations told a conference organised by the Bank of America that cashflow from the combine would increase by 30% in its first year. His forecast for revenues of $40bn in 2001 were made to show growth potential for a combined group.
