fields.headline: Heathrow air miss 'within 100ft'
fields.standfirst: Report suggests congested skies could get worse
fields.trailText: Air accident experts are today investigating an incident last month in which two British passenger planes are believed to have come within 100ft of colliding at Heathrow airport.
fields.body:
Air accident experts are today investigating an incident last month in which two British passenger planes are believed to have come within 100ft of colliding at Heathrow airport.

The Department of Transport confirmed that the Air Accidents Investigation Branch was looking into the incident last month when an incoming British Airways Boeing 747 is believed to have been within a moment of smashing into a British Midlands Airbus A321, which was taking off.

The 747's landing was aborted and the two aircraft were understood to have just missed each other at around 3.06pm on April 28.

A British Midland spokeswoman said: "Our plane was cleared for take off and the BA Boeing was cleared to land. Both aircraft were under the control of Heathrow air traffic controllers."

The issue is likely to raise further concern about the government's planned part-privatisation of air traffic control. According to radio reports, the Heathrow air traffic controller responsible for the planes' movements was reported to be a trainee being overseen by a mentor.

London's congested skies are set to become more so, according to a British Air Transport Association report which today predicted that within five years demand for flights at Heathrow and Gatwick will outstrip capacity by more than 18m passengers a year.

The association's general secretary, Roger Wiltshire, warned that gridlock at the airports meant that the UK was in danger of losing business to other countries.

"While we in the UK are still considering what to do about more capacity, our neighbours in Europe are getting on with it. The extra runways being delivered at Paris and Amsterdam will soon weaken our competitiveness unless we can quickly resolve this critical capacity problem," he said.

But residents and environmental groups are opposed to increasing the number of flights from the airports, as well as the controversial plans to build Heathrow Terminal 5.

The European Court of Human Rights is set to rule today on whether local campaigners are justified in calling on government to cut night flights into Heathrow.

If the campaign is successful, it could lead to challenges against the government from communities under flight paths at other UK airports.

The court case is being brought by eight residents who are all members of the Heathrow Association for Control of Aircraft Noise ClearSkies group. John Stewart, the group's spokesperson, criticised the calls for more flights from London.

"It is particularly unimaginative to call for 'more Heathrow' and 'more Gatwick'," he said. "We need to look at where new airports could be put in the south-east - on the coast, for example, where planes wouldn't fly over people's homes."

An aviation spokesman for the Department of the Environment said the government was preparing a white paper on aviation and airports, but this was being held up while ministers await the findings of the independent inquiry into Terminal 5.

He said: "These things take time unfortunately, but we have to be sure to balance economic, social and environmental needs before deciding what to do about capacity."

fields.headline: Review: The King Is Alive
fields.trailText: With founding father Lars Von Trier moving on to Björk and 100 cameras (in his new film, Dancer in the Dark, in Cannes later this week), people are saying that the Dogme cine-puritan movement has had its day. But now the last film to be unveiled by a member of the original Dogme quartet has redrawn the rules.
fields.body:
With founding father Lars Von Trier moving on to Björk and 100 cameras (in his new film, Dancer in the Dark, in Cannes later this week), people are saying that the Dogme cine-puritan movement has had its day. But now the last film to be unveiled by a member of the original Dogme quartet has redrawn the rules.

Kristian Levring's The King Is Alive is its most adventurous production yet. Plot-wise, it is a fairly traditional psychological nail-biter. A group of travellers in Africa are stranded in the desert with only tinned carrots for food. Before they start tearing each other apart, actor Henry (David Bradley) begins to stage an impromptu production of King Lear.

Like Festen, the script - by Levring and Anders Thomas Jensen - has the feel of a TV drama, or would do if the visual execution weren't so daring. Photographer Jens Schlosser makes Dogme's best-yet use of digital video: the desert colours aresearing; skin and fabrics become translucent, as if about to melt in the heat. And Levring proves a master at directing actors. A nervy, eclectic cast includes Jennifer Jason Leigh and portly British elder statesman David Calder as the most unlikely sexual partners in recent cinema. Questions have already been raised about possible infringements of Dogme rules - if a character hangs himself, should the actor do it for real? But hair-splitting seems less appropriate than in other Dogme film, and this stands out as the most assured of an erratic bunch.

fields.headline: Easy Rider 2: it could happen
fields.trailText: Like a bad acid flashback, the hippie classic Easy Rider looks set to spawn a sequel - some 30-odd years after its first appearance. Variety announces that producer Glen Tobias has purchased the film's rights from Bert Scheider, the executive producer of the 1969 original, together with an option of two further Easy Rider pictures after that. In Tobias's hands, what was conceived as a one-off could now become an ongoing franchise.
fields.body:
Like a bad acid flashback, the hippie classic Easy Rider looks set to spawn a sequel - some 30-odd years after its first appearance. Variety announces that producer Glen Tobias has purchased the film's rights from Bert Scheider, the executive producer of the 1969 original, together with an option of two further Easy Rider pictures after that. In Tobias's hands, what was conceived as a one-off could now become an ongoing franchise.

On the plus side, the Easy Rider sequel appears to be staying true to its ancestor's low-budget origins. Tobias (whose previous credits include a production job on Robert Altman's fumbled The Gingerbread Man) will produce, while the obscure Mikki Allen Willis (who has just completed his first movie, Shoe Shine Boys) is set to direct.

The plan is to shoot the picture in the same locations as the first film, which traced the road-movie odyssey of two all-American hippies (Dennis Hopper, Peter Fonda) on their way to a prolonged LSD session in New Orleans.

Directed by Hopper, Easy Rider is often credited with kicking off the 70s boom in experimental, left-of-centre American cinema. It was the first film to properly give voice to the counter-culture and made stars of Hopper, Fonda and a young Jack Nicholson, who took a vibrant supporting slot as a boozy lawyer.

In true laid-back fashion, the new, improved Easy Rider has yet to find its cast. While Hopper recently starred in a car commercial which intercut his greying, respectable self with his wild-eyed Easy Rider incarnation, he is thought to be unwilling to revisit a film he has little creative control in.

Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Fonda told Variety that the actor was unaware that any Easy Rider sequel was even in the pipeline. She added, though, that the actor was unlikely to be interested in starring in it.

webTitle: Day seven: Breasts and drugs and rock 'n' roll

fields.headline: Day seven: Breasts and drugs and rock 'n' roll
fields.standfirst: Fiachra Gibbons reports on the All Saints on the croisette, and, back in the serious world of movie-making, a Taiwanese film that made critics forget their buttocks and levitate with joy, the charming Fast Food Fast Women, and the shock tactics that caused a walk-out
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons reports on the All Saints on the croisette, and, back to the serious world of movie-making, a Taiwanese film that made critics forget their buttocks and levitate with joy, the charming Fast Food Fast Women, and the shock tactics that caused a walk-out
fields.body:
What lovely people. All Saints are. Looking deeply bored and wearing reflective shades and - in Natalie's case - very little else, three-quarters of the girl band pitched up on the croisette yesterday as if they were Hollywood royalty. Not even Stallone or George Clooney brought along personal body guards, but All Saints turned up with two of the nastiest-looking heavies that you're ever likely to see, each with a large part of the world heritage collection of tattoos on their arms. The nasty smell just got worse during the petulant press conference when director Dave Stewart - who, now he's an auteur likes to term himself Dave A Stewart - bellyached about how he is perceived as a 'mental patient' back home.

"Back in Britain, you have some success and they want to kill you," Stewart said, before blaming the British press for getting the film an 18 certificate. "The censors were so paranoid because of the pile of bollocks about sex and drugs. They write anything they want. [They say] I'm a mental patient, who has a nudist colony in the south of France, and that I teach hairless dogs to speak.

"There is also an assumption that you shouldn't make a film if you are a pop musician. It's nice to be in a country where they are interested in writing about the film rather than my hairless dog farm."

Stewart also complained that the press have played up his film's sex and drugs elements, and were obsessed by Natalie Appleton's breasts. This was the man who drooled over them in the film's climactic scene, and who himself admitted that the bucketloads of LSD he had taken himself helped him shoot the films' overlong trip scenes.

Stewart also revealed that the Jimmy Hendrix estate refused to allow his music to be used in the film because they "did not want Jimmy's name connected with sex and drugs".

He also expounded on his theories about the "paradise syndrome" brought on by consumerism that has kept the present generation of young people from rebelling. All Saint Melanie Blatt complained that modern youngsters were too apathetic to be as exciting as their 1960s counterparts. "I would love to be part of a rebellion about something. Kids today are too spoilt. They have everything they want and nothing to rebel about. There's a lot less to fight for. They are happy to play video games."

Apparently there was some argy bargy at the band's party later on the beach. There is no love lost between them and the tabloid ratpack that trails them everywhere. They deserve each other.

 Meanwhile back in the world of serious films, Amos Kollek's Fast Food Fast Women, starring Jamie Harris - another scion of the Richard Harris clan - proved to be a charmer. Set in New York among mixed up 20-somethings, it has some beautiful performances from Anna Thomson and Louise Lasser. It was almost as big a hit with the critics as the wonderful new Taiwanese film Yi Yi by Edward Yang, which despite being three hours long had normally buttock-conscious critics levitating with joy.

fields.headline: Teacher 'slapped boy's face'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A headmistress lost her temper and slapped an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face when he started struggling with her after being told he could not go swimming, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A headmistress lost her temper and slapped an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face when he started struggling with her after being told he could not go swimming, a court heard yesterday.

Marjorie Evans, 55, who has been suspended since the alleged incident, denies assaulting the boy at a junior school in south Wales last September.

She claims that the boy tried to push, punch and butt her.

Christopher Rees, prosecuting, told Abergavenny magistrates that the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, and a number of other pupils had been banned from swimming, and were due to be taught that day by Mrs Evans.

Mr Rees said that when the headmistress told the boy he was not going swimming he became sullen "and to some extent unruly".

When he refused to get his work, she took him out of his class and walked to the main school building. The boy became physically difficult and struggled with the headteacher, who then slapped him, the court heard.

The boy, now aged 11, said an argument began between him and Mrs Evans over trays in which the pupils kept their work.

Ian Williams, defending, said the story had been hatched by the boy and his mother to get Mrs Evans into trouble. The case continues.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A gossip risotto served on a bed of half-baked untruths
fields.trailText: Manchester United have made a move to sign Robbie Fowler for £15m. According to the Sun, a third party representing United contacted Anfield after Fowler was left out at Bradford on Sunday. Leeds, Arsenal and Chelsea are also monitoring the situation.
fields.body:
Manchester United have made a move to sign Robbie Fowler for £15m. According to the Sun, a third party representing United contacted Anfield after Fowler was left out at Bradford on Sunday. Leeds, Arsenal and Chelsea are also monitoring the situation.

Leeds manager David O'Leary is prepared to break the world record for a defender by signing Rio Ferdinand, reports the Daily Mail. He's also interested in Robbie Fowler because another one of his targets, Monaco striker David Trezeguet, is torn between moving to AC Milan or Manchester United in a £15m deal.

Meanwhile the Sun claims AC Milan are favourites to sign Ferdinand, and will test Harry Redknapp's resolve with an £8m bid.

The Daily Mail reports that Celta Vigo are lining up an unlikely £4m move for Christian Dailly - one of eight players told by Graeme Souness that they have no future at Blackburn Rovers.

The Mail also claims that Marseille midfielder Robert Pires is ready to join Arsenal in a £6m deal and that Liverpool will sign Leicester's reserve keeper Peggy Arphexad by the end of the week.

Meanwhile the Express believes that Spurs are planning to sign both Neil Sullivan and Ben Thatcher from Wimbledon this summer. Sullivan, who is now a free agent, had talks at White Hart Lane yesterday, while George Graham will offer £6m for 24-year-old left-back Thatcher.

Chelsea defender Marcel Desailly is being linked in his native France with a move to Real Madrid, report Planet Football.

Big spending Fulham will make an audacious move for French internationals Fabien Barthez and Sylvian Wiltord according to Teamtalk, who also report that Geoff Horsfield has been told he can leave Fulham and has been unofficially placed on the transfer list.

webTitle: Straw plans tougher sentences for persistent offenders

fields.headline: Straw plans tougher sentences for persistent offenders
fields.trailText: Tough new proposals to punish persistent offenders are to be unveiled by home secretary Jack Straw today, as the government seeks to assert its law and order credentials after apparently successful Tory campaigns on asylum, self-defence and rural policing.
fields.body:
Tough new proposals to punish persistent offenders are to be unveiled by home secretary Jack Straw today, as the government seeks to assert its law and order credentials after apparently successful Tory campaigns on asylum, self-defence and rural policing.

In a speech to probation officers, Mr Straw will call for progressively tougher sentencing for criminals who repeatedly appear before the courts and a range of "short, sharp shock" sentences for those found guilty of anti-social crimes such as assault, vandalism and car theft.

The home secretary's plans also include the implementation of "nine-to-five" prisons, where offenders spend days or weekends behind bars, and mixed sentencing involving jail and community service. Mr Straw will also suggest a greater use of electronic tagging.

Tory shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe called the idea of daytime prisons "lunatic". Mr Straw "is effectively saying he will lock offenders up during working hours and make it impossible to make a lawful living, then release them at night, when most burglaries take place. You cannot put people in jail during the working day and release them at night and not expect an upward impact on crime."

The home secretary's speech comes after Conservative leader William Hague called for new legislation on self-defence and the end of the "double jeopardy" rule. The Tory assault on law and order appeared to have played well with the country's voters, with an ICM poll for the Guardian today showing the Tories had reduced Labour's lead to seven points, the lowest since it came to power three years ago.

Mr Straw said the government wanted to repeat with adult offenders the success it had had in combating repeat offending by juveniles. He also revealed he was considering new forms of sentences, including weekend custody "where you would allow someone to carry on with their occupation during the week, but ensure that they were incarcerated for the weekend, as part of both punishment and rehabilitation".

A senior Home Office source said the measures were not immediate policy proposals but that Mr Straw wanted to start a consultation process about the problem of persistent offenders.

William Hague called for a change in the law after Tony Martin was jailed for killing a 16-year-old who had broken into his farm. It later emerged that the burglars of Martin's remote Norfolk home had more than 100 previous convictions between them, something Mr Straw's plans could address.

Mr Straw accepted that "all projections suggest the prison population will rise" but dismissed fears his measures would exacerbate such trends, overloading the prison system.

"It is about 5,000 below full capacity, and we have plans to build more prisons," the home secretary told the Today programme.

"Prison works for some offenders, it doesn't particularly work for other offenders in terms of getting them out of re-offending. But what is unquestionably the case is that prison works to prevent people from offending while they are in prison," he added.

Paul Cavadino, director of policy at the National Association for Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro), said: "There is a strong case for a review of our sentencing laws. However, the aim must be more effective sentencing, not just tougher punishment for the sake of it.

"Prison sentences have high re-conviction rates, and overcrowded prisons find it harder to provide the rehabilitative regimes which can cut offending on release. There is no point in jailing more offenders only to produce a less effective penal system."

The proposals for progressively tougher sentences might lead to "wholly disproportionate sentences to persistent but petty offenders", he added.

 Mr Straw was guarded about press reports that boxer Mike Tyson had again applied for permission to fight in the UK. He confirmed that he would "consider" the US boxer's application to enter the country for a heavyweight bout in Scotland but said: "I'm not going to pre-empt consideration of the decision in advance of looking at the papers."

Straw's key suggestions
 Progressively more severe sentencing for repeat offenders
 Short prison sentences for "anti-social" crimes
 Reform of sentencing so judges can mix prison and community service punishments
 Reform of prison hours so petty criminals could be jailed at weekends or from "nine-to-five" during the week

fields.headline: European scheme leads dome race
fields.trailText: A plan to keep the Millennium Dome open after 2000, adding more zones and Disney-style attractions, will be one of two bids for the structure's future unveiled today.
fields.body:
A plan to keep the Millennium Dome open after 2000, adding more zones and Disney-style attractions, will be one of two bids for the structure's future unveiled today.

Dome Europe, backed by the Japanese Bank Nomura, is front runner to win the "legacy competition" launched by the government to attract bidders to take over the dome after the present exhibition completes its run.

The shortlist, also thought to include Dome Legacy - a bid which would abandon the present zones and attractions in favour of a new "development of living and working space" - is being published by the government's regeneration agency, English Partnerships, amid fresh alarm over the precarious financial state of the dome.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, yesterday said the attraction should close at the end of this summer unless it could solve its continuing cash crisis without requiring yet more national lottery money.

The early closure suggestion was swiftly dismissed as "not an option" by Mike O'Connor, director of the millennium commission, which allocates funding to the dome.

However, some commissioners are understood to be furious at the expected further government bail-out of the project with more lottery money, only three months after the New Millennium Experience Company, the dome's operator, asked for an additional £60m loan.

The company has now acknowledged that, despite claims it could attract 12m visitors, the maximum total could fall as low as seven million or less.

NMEC's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, is in discussions with the millennium commission about further funding.

Despite the private doubts which many ministers have held about the dome they have remained publicly loyal.

But the success of the Tate Modern, on top of the popularity of the London Eye, has made Labour MPs uneasy and Tories keen to go for the kill.

Mr Ainsworth yesterday predicted that, despite his calls for early closure, the dome would stay open for the planned full year because Mr Blair's personal association with the project created a "political imperative" to seek to make a success of the venture.

Leaders of the Dome Europe consortium believe they can run the dome at a profit on a plan based on the present arrangement of zones and live acrobatics, despite the fact that the attraction is regularly failing to get near its daily target of 35,000 visitors.

The bid, led by the Football League chairman, Peter Middleton, would see the introduction of at least two new zones in 2001 with more to follow in 2002-3, a rolling programme of Europe-themed shows and events, and an adventure playground for younger children.

The successful bidder for the dome will pay around £100m for a 999-year lease on the 50-acre site, with the government insisting that the winner runs a leisure attraction on the site for a set period.

fields.headline: Diaries back besieged Baden-Powell
fields.standfirst: Scholars claim that forced evacuation of blacks at Mafeking 'a blunder, not murder'
fields.trailText: Two military scholars will on Wednesday ride to the relief of the father of scouting, Robert Baden-Powell, whose reputation has been under siege for nearly 40 years as a war criminal and closet homosexual
fields.body:
Two military scholars will on Wednesday ride to the relief of the father of scouting, Robert Baden-Powell, whose reputation has been under siege for nearly 40 years as a war criminal and closet homosexual.

Their book, which sets out to rehabilitate his character, counts as one of the most timely rescue operations in British imperial studies. For it is to be published on the 100th anniversary of what was once regarded as Baden-Powell's most significant moment: the relief of Mafeking.

The defeat of a nine-month Afrikaner siege of the British garrison that he led in the small South African town during the Boer war prompted three days of street celebrations in London.

On the crest of this fame Baden-Powell - until then an unimportant colonel aged 44 - went on to found the worldwide scout movement and become a revered model for youth.

But since the 1960s his prestige has been weakened by a battery of books which accuse him of saving the white garrison only by imposing a racist "leave or starve" policy on its black members, causing hundreds of deaths.

One South African historian, Pat Hopkins, said last year: "This can only be described as a crime against humanity for which he deserves to be reappraised as a war criminal."

Other studies have said he was distracted from his duties by infatuation with Kenneth "Boy" McLaren, a handsome young fellow polo-playing and pig-sticking officer. Colleagues had to stop him from riding single-handedly to the rescue when McLaren was captured by the Boers.

But the new book finds that Baden-Powell was an indisputably brilliant soldier whose mass evacuation policy was a blunder under great pressure - "the product of naivete and misjudgment rather than any concept of premeditated murder".

He abandoned it as soon as it caused deaths, and introduced emergency kitchens with horsemeat soup as soon as he realised hunger was rife. The authors agree that hundreds of black people nevertheless died of starvation or from Boer bullets during the evacuation attempt.

But they add: "These were not the actions of a war criminal." Even Baden-Powell's critics in the garrison gave him credit for his "extensive remedial measures". There was also no clear evidence that the commander, who later married and had three children, was even a repressed homosexual.

The writers, Edmund Yorke and Malcolm Flower-Smith of the Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst, base their defence on what they say is the fullest study and analysis so far made of diaries kept by garrison soldiers and civilians during the siege. "Other writers have used these selectively to attack him," Dr Yorke said yesterday.

Their sources include Baden-Powell's staff diaries, which show he started the evacuations after getting a "bombshell" telegram on February 8 1900 from the British commander, Lord Kitchener, indicating that Mafeking could not be relieved for four months.

Baden-Powell had based garrison rations on a prospect of relief within two months. Kitchener ordered him to "send as many women and children and natives as possible away" to save rations.

But the authors say the papers indicate that this harsh policy was not aimed at the township's 7,000-strong majority of blacks, the Baralong tribe, who were valued soldiers and boosted food stocks by rustling Boer cattle. Its victims were 2,000 "outside Africans", including Shangaans.

Their food rations in Mafeking were cut off. Baden-Powell negotiated safe passage for them with the besieging Boers to British-held territory, supplying a military escort and food wagon. But the truce was broken.

The first attempt to drive 900 blacks out at night was scattered by Boer snipers. The second, by day, saw them "decimated" by Boer attacks. "The policy of forced evacuation was a blunder," Dr Yorke said. "Baden-Powell was the reluctant victim of external military imperatives. He realised his errors and dropped it."

Starvation among Shangaans intensified. Emerson Neilly, a journalist from the Pall Mall Gazette, wrote in his diary: "I saw them fall down on the veldt and lie where they had fallen. The sufferers ... were mostly little boys ... probably hundreds died."

But by March Baden-Powell had soup kitchens running. One of his most severe critics in the garrison conceded: "No one now need starve." The book says his food distribution undoubtedly remained biased towards Europeans and the Baralong black elite, who showed no concern for the Shangaans. "But he was no more racially prejudiced than the vast majority of his generation."

Dr Yorke said: "We don't want to portray him as an angel, but he was not a racialist or a war criminal. The siege was a progressive learning process for him. He was obsessed with defending the town. In the early stages he left rationing to subordinates, who behaved badly.

"Our account of the siege is fuller than in any previous book. In some cases previous authors have ignored some of the material with a view to denigrating Baden-Powell's policies. We have brought out the meetings he held to try to remedy the situation."

Of allegations about Baden-Powell's "confused sexuality", the book says his concern about Boy McLaren was influenced by his role as the captured soldier's senior regimental officer as well as by friendship. His diaries expressed the same concern for McLaren as for all the wounded in the Boer hospital.

And his aborted rescue plan was "exactly the kind of exciting lone adventure" that would have appealed to the founder of scouting.

"There is no evidence of improper conduct," said Mr Flower-Smith.

Mafeking: the story of a siege, Covos-Day Books, £10.

The first attempt to drive 900 blacks out at night was scattered by Boer snipers. The second, by day, saw them "decimated" by Boer attacks. "The policy of forced evacuation was a blunder," Dr Yorke said. "Baden-Powell was the reluctant victim of external military imperatives. He realised his errors and dropped it." Starvation among Shangaans intensified. Emerson Neilly, a journalist from the Pall Mall Gazette, wrote in his diary: "I saw them fall down on the veldt and lie where they had fallen. The sufferers ... were mostly little boys ... probably hundreds died." But by March Baden-Powell had soup kitchens running. One of his most severe critics in the garrison conceded: "No one now need starve." The book says his food distribution undoubtedly remained biased towards Europeans and the Baralong black elite, who showed no concern for the Shangaans. "But he was no more racially prejudiced than the vast majority of his generation." Dr Yorke said: "We don't want to portray him as an angel, but he was not a racialist or a war criminal. The siege was a progressive learning process for him. He was obsessed with defending the town. In the early stages he left rationing to subordinates, who behaved badly. "Our account of the siege is fuller than in any previous book. In some cases previous authors have ignored some of the material with a view to denigrating Baden-Powell's policies. We have brought out the meetings he held to try to remedy the situation." Of allegations about Baden-Powell's "confused sexuality", the book says his concern about Boy McLaren was influenced by his role as the captured soldier's senior regimental officer as well as by friendship. His diaries expressed the same concern for McLaren as for all the wounded in the Boer hospital. And his aborted rescue plan was "exactly the kind of exciting lone adventure" that would have appealed to the founder of scouting. "There is no evidence of improper conduct," said Mr Flower-Smith. Mafeking: the story of a siege, Covos-Day Books, £10. Useful links Dedicated Baden-Powell site ScoutBase UK

webTitle: Millennium wheel in a spin over poet's lost line

fields.headline: Millennium wheel in a spin over poet's lost line
fields.trailText: The Wordsworth sonnet gracing a plaque on the millennium wheel was supposed to soothe passengers as they took to the skies. But instead the lofty tribute left poetry lovers seething after some overzealous editing by the London Eye's owners, British Airways, turned the poet's immortal lines Upon Westminster Bridge into gibberish
fields.body:
The Wordsworth sonnet gracing a plaque on the millennium wheel was supposed to soothe passengers as they took to the skies. But instead the lofty tribute left poetry lovers seething after some overzealous editing by the London Eye's owners, British Airways, turned the poet's immortal lines Upon Westminster Bridge into gibberish.

The sonnet had been cut from 14 lines to 13. And the 12th and 13th lines were fused so that "The river that glideth at his own sweet will:/ Dear God! the very houses seem asleep" appeared as "The river glideth at his own sweet asleep".

British Airways hurriedly removed the 6ft plaque after the mistake prompted laughter from visitors. The words stood out in gleaming steel lettering.

The airline is now trying to rectify the error "in the inter ests of accuracy".

Last night,a British Airways spokeswoman said the line had somehow dropped off between the architects and the printers. "We are not quite sure how it happened, but it is being replaced. We took the plaque down as soon as someone pointed out the error."

The plaque was unveiled in March by Bob Ayling, the then chairman of BA. He failed to spot the error, as did the actress Joanna Lumley, who recited part of the sonnet.

Daniel Karlin, lecturer in 19th Century poetry at University College, London, was unimpressed. "It is what literary critics call illiteracy," he said. "I didn't notice the mistake when I went on the blasted thing. It is the epitome of modern culture. You put this great heritage on your modern item and you get it wrong."

However, Prof Karlin added that Wordsworth "couldn't spell for toffee" and his punctuation was very bad.

webTitle: Smith finally signs to play Ali

fields.headline: Smith finally signs to play Ali
fields.trailText: Will Smith yesterday brought one of Hollywood's more protracted casting sagas to a finish when he finally signed to portray Muhammad Ali in Columbia's big-budget biopic of the boxing icon.
fields.body:
Will Smith yesterday brought one of Hollywood's more protracted casting sagas to a finish when he finally signed to portray Muhammad Ali in Columbia's big-budget biopic of the boxing icon.

The film will follow Ali from his fledgling days as humble Cassius Clay, through his controversial conversion to Islam, to his opposition to the Vietnam war and his career-defining Rumble in the Jungle against the hotly tipped George Foreman. Michael Mann will direct and Variety reports that Smith has already begun training for the role. In line with his A-list status, the Men in Black star will receive an advance of $20m for the role against 20% of the gross.

Still a few months off filming, the Ali biopic already has a well-thumbed look about it. The project was originally discussed 18 months ago as a collaboration between Smith and Barry Sonnenfeld, the star-director partnership behind Men in Black. But Sonnenfeld bailed out last summer, prompted - some say - by the disastrous reception to the last Smith-Sonnenfeld picture, Wild Wild West.

Earlier this year, the film was the subject of a heated tug of war between Spike Lee and Michael Mann. Columbia execs eventually chose Mann, regarding him as more likely to make a populist, successful picture than the maverick and more pointedly political Lee.

The one constant throughout all this wrangling was Smith, who was always Ali's own preferred choice for the role. But the actor's dithers over signing were rumoured to be causing anxiety to the studio, who still aim to have the film completed in time for a release in summer 2001.

Insiders have speculated that Smith hesitated because he has recently been torn between the Ali film and a Men in Black sequel alongside Sonnenfeld. A spokesperson for the actor denied that this was the case.

fields.headline: Poetic licence
fields.standfirst: Today, Tom Paulin will be awarded £75,000 of lottery money - to go away to think for three years. Oh, and to write an epic poem celebrating Britain in the second world war. Isn't that an odd project for an Irish republican? He explains himself to  Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: Today, Tom Paulin will be awarded £75,000 of lottery money - to go away to think for three years. Oh, and to write an epic poem celebrating Britain in the second world war. Isn't that an odd project for an Irish republican? He explains himself to Stephen Moss
fields.body:
Tom Paulin is an amazing person. Don't take my word for it. That is the phrase the new National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts (Nesta) is hanging around the necks of the 13 "fellows" whose names it will announce today. Each of them will be paid to think - in Paulin's case £75,000 over three years. It sounds almost too good to be true and is the antithesis of the Thatcherite notion that all cultural activity should have an economic pay-off.

"Fellowships are designed to help people pursue ideas and fulfil their potential, particularly individuals whose best work still lies ahead of them," says Nesta. It has an endowment of £200m, courtesy of the lottery, and will use the interest to shell out £10m a year to artists, writers, scientists, engineers, film-makers, inventors, anyone who can make a good case for needing cash to help them to develop their ideas.

The way fellows are chosen is shadowy: 100 "independent" (and unnamed) nominators put forward candidates who are then invited to apply via the Nesta website. Paulin has no idea who nominated him, or how they knew he was struggling to combine writing an epic poem based on the second world war with his work as an English lecturer at Oxford. But know they did, and the grant will enable him to reduce his teaching commitments and devote some serious time to the poem.

Nesta, perhaps wary of what the Daily Mail might make of its largesse (£200m is, after all, a lot of nurses or school textbooks), is keen to play up the practical side of the Pauline vision: "He will undertake an intense period of research and experimentation to develop the new project, which Tom describes as 'affirming the struggle and memory of the generation - my parents' generation - that fought in the second world war, and to do so before the doors of living memory are closed on it.' Tom will draw on photography, film and music to create radical new poetic forms and styles aimed at extending the boundaries of our current notions of poetry."

Paulin has a less concrete conception of the project, and would never be so immodest as to claim that he was extending the boundaries of poetry. "It's an almost Jamesian idea," says Paulin. "Go and be Lambert Strether [Paulin hopes and expects you will have read The Ambassadors]; get out of the managerial bureaucracy you're stuck in and go to Paris, hang about, look at some paintings. Part of trying to write is what Hazlitt calls indolence, hanging about waiting for something."

When I met Paulin in his cosy, book-strewn room at Hertford College he had just delivered two one-hour lectures (one on a theme close to his heart - political readings of Keats's To Autumn). And we had to stop after an hour and a half because there were three undergraduates skulking in the stairwell waiting for his thoughts on Blake.

An hour and a half is no time at all with Paulin because his method of exegesis, like his poetry, is highly associative and extremely demanding; his wonderful, cawing voice is also prone to high-pitched hesitation; he is an impressionist's dream. Nesta may have got a succinct summation of his war poem, but I didn't. "I want to write a long poem about the second world war, from the beginning, which is the Versailles peace conference in 1919. I'm nervous about talking about it - partly out of superstition, partly because you worry about taking yourself too seriously - and I'm worried about it because it sounds a monstrous project."

Reading between the lines, and the pauses, I think Paulin - a Northern Irish Protestant who supports republicanism and thinks it inevitable that the north will leave the UK - intends to do something quite fascinating: write a poem in praise of the collective effort of the British people in the second world war, a people who for six years were united in their will to protect freedom and defeat fascism. As Britain bickers over devolution, argues over the EU, frets about identity, he will celebrate a moment of national unity. "I'm worried that in British culture there's a fixation on the first world war, which is to do with a sense of loss, whereas if the British were to talk about the second world war more, maybe a sort of triumphalism would enter. British culture is resistant to that."

It is odd that someone who looks forward to Northern Ireland leaving the union wants to encourage triumphalism, but his point is a subtle one: countries must have a sense of nationhood, so let it be a generous patriotism -"the patriotism you see in Blake and Cobbett, Hazlitt and Orwell, which is a very strong part of this country's culture" - rather than a narrow-minded, bigoted, destructive insularity. "I have thought a lot about the new English nationalism as the old idea of Britain starts to break up, which is what I grew up with in the north of Ireland," he says. "I'm worried about the new English identity. If it isn't inclusive, if it's like the Countryside Alliance, that worries me."

There is a tension in Paulin's attitude that bodes well for his poem: he wants to celebrate the second world war as "the peak of British history" while recognising that it was also the beginning of the end for Britain as a world power and as a country with a sure sense of itself as a nation. Now it is a collection of regions which may face a federal future. "Things have to change with the north of Ireland moving out of the union and maybe Scotland," says Paulin, "but I have a lot of sympathy with John Major's speech where he said that Scotland's independence would impoverish the overall culture."

Paulin, who is 51, has described himself as a failed historian - "growing up in Ireland, you're imbued with history" - and this new poem will call on his historical, as well as his literary, sensitivity. His historically and politically charged readings of texts (notably his view of Ulysses as an attack on colonialism) are powerful, and in everything he writes - poetry, criticism, essays, literary biography - an urgency and engagement shine through. He is the opposite of the ivory towers don: he is down there in the grimy basement, scratching vital messages on the walls.

Paulin, like all poets, is in love with words, but also in love with their power - to dazzle, damage and demand change. Milton was his beginning. "Milton is this extraordinary combination of great artist and great polemicist, whereas the two activities have since been split, often by literary critics with an axe to grind which they are concealing under the idea of art as being above politics."

Paulin's engagement takes him in many directions: a fine book on Hazlitt that took him six years and has helped to reclaim his hero for a new generation; poetry that has never ducked the politics of Northern Ireland, even when its absentee writer has been told he no longer has the right to comment; and those rottweiler-like appearances on the BBC's tokenistic arts-crit shows (currently Review - the periodic name changes suggest deep cultural insecurity over at White City).

In the course of our one and a half hours this most benign and charming of men (he had bought me a baguette - slightly squashed - in anticipation of my being hungry) managed three sudden outbursts, when the voice rose another couple of octaves and the spirit of Swift, who thought it his duty to be vexatious, possessed him.

One: apropos of working on Review. "It's great fun working with people younger than yourself, and sometimes you are left alone with Jackson Pollock's paintings or Monet's Water Lilies - that's amazing. Though you also have to sit through the most terrible things, like that Frank Skinner play with the tortoise - that's the worst night in the theatre I've ever had."

Two: apropos of Kingsley Amis. "Jesus Christ, what an overrated talent Kingsley Amis was. I have just been dipping into his letters, which are absolutely awful. There are wonderful passages in Larkin's letters; they are real letters, whereas Amis's are just like watching some drunkard hit his head against a gas fire."

Three: apropos of my suggesting that his attack on Anthony Thwaite - " a little balsawood minor man of letters" - was over the top. "I was very, very, very, very angry at the way he edited Larkin's letters; I was extremely angry at the reception of the letters. Larkin's racism was tolerated, just as Eliot's anti- semitism has been tolerated. The point I was trying to make was what even filthier racist remarks has Thwaite cut, and I was very angry. My children are mixed race [he is married to a woman of Indian descent], and more or less every day I hear some story. I'm very angry about that sort of institutional tolerance of racism."

Paulin is very angry (often to the power of four) and anxious about a lot of things. "He is one of the great disagree-ers," said the poet Christopher Reid, his former editor at Faber. "Going against the grain seems to give him a kind of energy." Yet, in person, it is his passion, not his anger, that stands out; vexatiousness, not bitterness, that drives his feuds. He lives for his writing - and for the writers he loves. They are living presences, there to be reclaimed. He opposes canonical literature, celebrates the vernacular, is committed to democracy in politics and literature. He is the most engaged and engaging of men. Truly, an amazing person.

webTitle: Snafu, to coin a military phrase

fields.headline: Snafu, to coin a military phrase
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Tories hate it when a Labour government gets involved in a military operation. Labour MPs are supposed to be vegans in beards and sandals who call for further negotiations in a spirit of goodwill. They're not meant to deploy troops round the world or use military jargon in a confident manner.
fields.body:
Tories hate it when a Labour government gets involved in a military operation. Labour MPs are supposed to be vegans in beards and sandals who call for further negotiations in a spirit of goodwill. They're not meant to deploy troops round the world or use military jargon in a confident manner.

Labour ministers, of course, love that stuff. They get the lingo from the hundreds of serving officers in the MoD and drop it casually into debates. The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, yesterday told us that the the situation in the capital of Sierra Leone was "calm but tense". (This is the phrase used by war correspondents who arrived after the fighting and needed to justify their expenses. If the war was still going on, the correct form was: "machine guns answered the clatter of my typewriter as I flew into war-torn Paranoia.")

Mr Hoon had all the patter: "amphibious capability", "the model of the rapid deployment concept" and "robust rules of engagement", which I took to be a euphemism for "shoot first and work out a story for the CO later".

He finished by saying there was "no question" of our taking over the UN role in Sierra Leone, or getting drawn into the civil war there.

The Tories wriggled and twisted to make it clear that they weren't saying a word against our gallant lads. But this is a Labour government. It must be full of milk-toast pacifists and tofu-munchers in duffel coats. Iain Duncan Smith, the Tory spokesman decided to concentrate on troop cuts of the recent past. "Our rapid reaction force is in Sierra Leone," he said. "What reserves do you have if difficulties erupt in Kosovo, Iraq or even in Zimbabwe?"

Zimbabwe? Are we really thinking of sending the lads in there, to defend the very people who caused so much anguish to the 1964 Labour government? Are we going to save Ian Smith? I've heard of kith and kin, but this is ridiculous.

Anyhow, Mr Duncan Smith wanted to make it appear that Labour had reduced our fighting forces to the status of cowboy builders, always taking on more jobs than they could cope with.

"Sorry I didn't turn up last week, mate, had another civil war down Hendon way, and I've had to lay a couple of the boys off, and just my luck, the helicopters are all in the garage, blimey, March 2003 all right for you?"

Mr Duncan Smith ended with a stirring cry for the government to "stop sliding and messing around. No further shilly-shallying!" he insisted. I wondered vaguely how Nelson would have signalled that to the fleet.

Mr Hoon pretended to be upset that he had decided to make capital about our brave boys. Indeed, he coined a new doctrine: an opposition was obliged to support not only our men in uniform, but the politicians who sent them off. "There has been a tradition of giving support to British forces, and that includes giving support to those who take the decisions." By the same token, opposition leaders would have to praise not only the police, but the home secretary; not only our nurses but the health team too.

Tam Dalyell turned out to have an expert knowledge of Sierra Leone demographics. Apparently, the people upcountry are quite different from those in Freetown, who were originally in the slave trade.

Mr Dalyell reminds me of the late Stephen Potter, the brilliant inventor of Lifemanship. If you were sounding off about some country, and to your horror found you were with a real expert who corrected you, all you had to do was say, firmly but quietly, "Yes, but not in the south."

Mr Dalyell has always been a brilliant "not in the south" man.

It must be full of milk-toast pacifists and tofu-munchers in duffel coats. Iain Duncan Smith, the Tory spokesman decided to concentrate on troop cuts of the recent past. "Our rapid reaction force is in Sierra Leone," he said. "What reserves do you have if difficulties erupt in Kosovo, Iraq or even in Zimbabwe?" Zimbabwe? Are we really thinking of sending the lads in there, to defend the very people who caused so much anguish to the 1964 Labour government? Are we going to save Ian Smith? I've heard of kith and kin, but this is ridiculous. Anyhow, Mr Duncan Smith wanted to make it appear that Labour had reduced our fighting forces to the status of cowboy builders, always taking on more jobs than they could cope with. "Sorry I didn't turn up last week, mate, had another civil war down Hendon way, and I've had to lay a couple of the boys off, and just my luck, the helicopters are all in the garage, blimey, March 2003 all right for you?" Mr Duncan Smith ended with a stirring cry for the government to "stop sliding and messing around. No further shilly-shallying!" he insisted. I wondered vaguely how Nelson would have signalled that to the fleet. Mr Hoon pretended to be upset that he had decided to make capital about our brave boys. Indeed, he coined a new doctrine: an opposition was obliged to support not only our men in uniform, but the politicians who sent them off. "There has been a tradition of giving support to British forces, and that includes giving support to those who take the decisions." By the same token, opposition leaders would have to praise not only the police, but the home secretary; not only our nurses but the health team too. Tam Dalyell turned out to have an expert knowledge of Sierra Leone demographics. Apparently, the people upcountry are quite different from those in Freetown, who were originally in the slave trade. Mr Dalyell reminds me of the late Stephen Potter, the brilliant inventor of Lifemanship. If you were sounding off about some country, and to your horror found you were with a real expert who corrected you, all you had to do was say, firmly but quietly, "Yes, but not in the south." Mr Dalyell has always been a brilliant "not in the south" man.

webTitle: Leeds build for Europe with £7.2m Dacourt

fields.headline: Leeds build for Europe with £7.2m Dacourt
fields.trailText: Olivier Dacourt became a Premiership player again last night after finalising a £7.2m move from Lens to Leeds United. Less than a year after returning to his native France from Everton, the 25-year-old midfielder has agreed to a five-year deal which puts him among Leeds's highest earners on £20,000 a week.
fields.body:
Olivier Dacourt became a Premiership player again last night after finalising a £7.2m move from Lens to Leeds United. Less than a year after returning to his native France from Everton, the 25-year-old midfielder has agreed to a five-year deal which puts him among Leeds's highest earners on £20,000 a week.

"It is a club-record transfer but I would not hold your breath on it lasting," said the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. "Qualifying for the Champions League has raised our profile and we have identified three more top-class players we want to bring in over summer."

Dacourt, who passed a medical at Elland Road last week, will complete the formalities on his return from holiday. Leeds' previous biggest outlay was the £5m they paid Sunderland for Michael Bridges last summer.

Fulham's new manager Jean Tigana is hoping to make Auxerre's £2.5m-rated Bernard Diomede his first signing. The 26-year-old winger was a member of France's World Cup-winning squad two years ago.

Paul Bracewell, Tigana's predecessor at Craven Cottage, is expected to be named as assistant manager to Newcastle's Bobby Robson following Steve Clarke's decision to step down.

Paul Gascoigne was in the 19-strong Middlesbrough squad who flew to Libya yesterday for tomorrow's official opening of The Great Man Made River Stadium.

The midfielder, who has been linked with a loan move to Joondalup City in Western Australia, is expected to line up in Boro's 45-minute matches against Tripoli and the Serie A side Bari.

Talks about the 32-year-old's future will take place with management at the end of the week. Gascoigne has not played since breaking his arm in a collision with George Boateng on Valentine's Day.

The England v Scotland match is expected to again become a regular feature of football seasons from 2002. Officials from both country's will meet in the near future to thrash out the details. "It is an appealing fixture and the enthusiasm generated by the Euro 2000 play-off game would be quickly restored," said Scotland's manager Craig Brown.

"Unfortunately I believe England believe they have got bigger fish to dry," he added. "They might want to play more appealing and more glamorous international matches."

The Rangers midfielder Jorg Albertz has signed a three-year deal to stay with the Scottish champions. The 28-year-old, a £4m signing from Hamburg in 1996, scored 20 goals last season but with only one year remaining on his contract, was thought to be on his way out of Ibrox.

Barcelona's chairman Josep Lluis Nunez plans to sell the £37m-rated Rivaldo before he steps down in July, according to reports in Spain. Nunez has said that he wants the Brazilian to state in writing whether he intends to stay. Rivaldo is contracted until 2003.

 Germany's Christian Worns will miss Euro 2000 with a knee injury. The 28-year-old defender tore a ligament during Borussia Dortmund's 1-1 draw with Schalke 04 at the weekend.

fields.headline: Epic tales
fields.standfirst: From Hollywood Gladiators to children's fiction: William Nicholson has come a long way
fields.trailText: From Hollywood Gladiators to children's fiction: William Nicholson has come a long way
fields.body:
Set in a parallel world, but taking a good swipe at some of the values that prevail in our own society, The Wind Singer is a potent mix of thundering adventure and purposeful fantasy.

From infancy, the people of Aramanth go before the examiners for regular assessment, and their quality of life is ruthlessly determined by the ratings they achieve. When Kestrel, the spirited young heroine, rebels against this soulless system she's in big trouble. There's no future for those who defy authority - they are referred for what is euphemistically described as special teaching. But Kestrel escapes, and with her twin brother sets off on a very different learning curve, a dangerous quest to deliver the people of Aramanth from this sinister regime.

Although The Wind Singer is full of unforgettable, eye-stretching imagery and startling, often savage, use of metaphor, the jacket design is a subtle masterpiece of understatement. "I don't want illustrations," says Nicholson firmly, "I want readers to use their imaginations... and that's why, although there's been a lot of interest, I'm refusing to sell the film rights until all three books have been published, and the children of at least one generation have formed their own pictures."

It's a bold approach: you would not guess that this is Nicholson's first children's book. At 52, he has stepped sideways into children's literature from a hugely successful career as a Hollywood screen writer - his credits range from Shadowlands (1993) to the new Ridley Scott blockbuster, Gladiator. And though the film is only just released, it's the book that is uppermost in his mind - and he awaits its reception with an engaging blend of optimism and apprehension - or, as he himself so disarmingly puts it, "a mixture of ridiculous arrogance and trembling insecurity". (He's a master of the self-deprecating aside.)

So what inspired him to write for children? To date, his earnings from this trilogy, published in five languages, scarcely equal one week's pay as a screenwriter, so it can't be the money.

I talk to Nicholson at his home in Sussex, an idyllic spot (as far from Hollywood as it is from Aramanth) where he lives with his wife Virginia (also a writer) and their three young children. Full of light and colour, their converted farmhouse is an impressive and perhaps rare blend of domestic order and creative energy. Virginia is the daughter of Quentin Bell - her grandmother was Virginia Woolf's sister, the painter Vanessa Bell, so it's perhaps not surprising to find the little Nicholson girls busy with paint-brushes - merrily decorating their own arms and legs in a style not unlike that of the Omega workshop.

Family life has been a major source of inspiration for The Wind Singer, and Nicholson writes about it with tenderness and perception. The story centres on the resilience of a family bond that's stretched to the limit, and character development is an important part of the plot. "As a parent, I've read a lot of current children's fiction, which often seems too rich in invention, at the expense of character."

He relished the opportunity to create "another world, "an imaginary place that exists on its own terms... and it had to be for children. Writing it for adults, I'd have automatically been steered towards science fiction, and I didn't want that. Nor did I want to find myself trying to be too clever. As with all eight of my early, failed novels [for adults] - they were far too intricate and over-written. So I thought I would side-step all that by simply writing 'a tale'. The result is a complete mess of stuff that boiled up inside me. I just went with it; a bit like therapy, I suppose."

And of all the bizarre, surreal images that emerge, in a landscape that unfolds with cinematic breadth, perhaps the most disturbing is the marching army of "Zars" - beautiful, baton-twirling, teenage killers, doomed to eternal youth: they were inspired by a weird combination of his own teenage obsession with American youth, and cheerleaders ("to me, banged up in a Catholic boarding school, it all seemed so cool, so sexy") and the tragic events at Columbine High School.

He can't pinpoint the origins of the happy, sensual "mud people" - a brilliantly imagined underclass who live in the bowels of the city - but talking about them somehow leads him to describe how he once heroically unclogged a cesspit. "It's odd, when you think about it, how people are so scared of excrement," he muses.

The book is full of surprises - "I was anxious to maintain a level of energy and excitement. I've got a very controlling mind and what I enjoyed here was the muddle of it all. It was so liberating to be free of the constraints of the film world - the stars, the length, the budget... and it was all mine! But every story needs a driving force - look at Dahl, and the passion and resentment that drive his stories. What drove my story was the great weight of anger I found in myself about the needless stress put on children today by the relentless tests and examinations."

The tyranny of the exam system is something Nicholson probably knows better than most - he's the product of prep school, public school and Cambridge, where he got a double first. His own children attend a private school, where common entrance exams necessitate tests every week. "We've had some vigorous discussions about that! But competition is fine as long as you are competing against yourself, rather than other people. But I think there's increasing confusion about what we want schools to do - in general, exams just serve to standardise the product, with children endlessly absorbing and regurgitating irrelevant information.

"And there's such snobbery about vocational training. I think the notion of education from five to 18 will give way to a more flexible system. Computers are changing everything, you'll have kids of 14 starting their own companies... then at 17, choosing, say, to learn Latin; and at 29 exploring astronomy. School will no longer be a form of social containment for the young. And misfits will no longer be driven to become the aggressors of society."

Paradoxically, as he proposes this radical loosening-up of our education system, he takes on the air of a traditional, tub-thumping headmaster, outlining his prospectus with single-minded fervour.

"Maybe I shouldn't criticise the system, but it sometimes takes an outsider to see sense... and that's the great privilege one has in writing fiction - you don't have to be an expert!"

But he certainly has expertise in structuring a story, a skill well honed by his screenwriting. "Structure is vital to fantasy. I've just had to turn down the opportunity of writing the new Superman film - I was sorry, because that's a very well realised concept, with well-defined limits. Fantasy has to have limits and you have to declare them, so readers know what characters can and can't do - otherwise, if anything can happen, the story is over."

He's now on book three of his trilogy and talks about it with visionary zeal, constantly racing to the story's horizon to bring back news of what's going on there. As creator of this parallel world, how does it feel to be responsible for resolving all the ethical, intellectual and practical issues involved? "I'm pedalling hard to keep up!" he laughs, "but you must understand, this is a story! Not a thesis, not a complete theosophical system. I'm no Jonathan Swift!"

Because of Shadowlands, it's tempting to look for echoes of Narnia in The Wind Singer. Has CS Lewis been an influence? "Like anyone, I'm the product of everything I've seen and read. Obviously, when I was writing Shadowlands, I read CS Lewis with enormous care. And, yes, he was an influence to the extent that there was this thoughtful and intelligent man actually choosing to write for children - and the fact that his work continues to give such joy validates the enterprise, and, yes, makes him a role model. But, I have to admit, I never quite liked the Narnia books. While I love it when you can see his imagination working full-tilt, I really dislike that sense of the wise old man talking 'de haut en bas', guiding the youngsters. I recognise in myself a tendency to pontificate, and it needs curbing! Maybe I'm just doing what I think he should have done."

 The Wind Singer is part one of The Wind on Fire Trilogy, by William Nicholson. Published by Mammoth, £12.99.

fields.headline: The Greenaway Medal
fields.trailText: This year's shortlist for the Greenaway Medal for "outstanding illustration in a children's book" represents a range of books available for all ages, says Annie Everall.
fields.body:
This year's shortlist for the Greenaway Medal for "outstanding illustration in a children's book" represents a range of books available for all ages, says Annie Everall. "It features some of our best-known illustrators: the former 1969 Greenaway winner Helen Oxenbury, and some exciting new talent.

The shortlist ranges from the very simple to the very stylised - a total celebration of the visual image." Thousands of children around the country will be involved in "shadowing" the judging. If your school would like to take part, see the Library Association's website for more details.

The Sea-Thing Child
Patrick Benson
(Walker Books, £10.99)
6+, for shared reading

Benson's best work to date perfectly matches Russell Hoban's story. This 30-year-old classic evokes the beauty and terror of the sea and shore in superb paintings, and delightfully characterises the Sea-Thing as he grows in confidence. A powerful book that explores the fundamental growing experience of childhood.

Wombat Goes Walkabout
Christian Birmingham
(Harper Collins, £10.99)
5+

A funny and touching story by Michael Morpurgo perfectly complemented by Christian Birmingham's atmospheric illustrations, which convey the heat and light of the Australian outback.

That's Me!
Lauren Child and Clarice Bean
(Orchard Books, £10.99)
7+

An inventive and humorous picture book with unexpected combinations of drawing, typography and photographs. The quirky perspectives show cheerful disregard for convention in this unusual take on family life.

Weslandia
Kevin Hawkes
(Walker Books, £9.99)
8+

A fascinating and sumptuously illustrated picture book for older readers that explores the sensitive subject of daring to be different in a highly original way. The deep, vivid colours and interesting perspectives draw the reader into a surreal suburban landscape, developing a new civilisation through a child's imagination.

The Storm
Kathy Henderson
(Walker Books, £9.99)
5+

Kathy Henderson's fresh style cannot fail to impress in this striking portrayal of the elements. The fluid illustrations echo the text perfectly and the young reader can almost feel the land recoil from the power of the sea.

Days Like This
Simon James
(Walker Books, £10.99)
6+ for shared reading

Simon James' expressive line drawings and water-colours bring the selected poems to life. His illustrations evoke the wonder in the everyday world and celebrate the innocence and mischievousness of childhood.

Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
Helen Oxenbury
(Walker Books, £14.99)
7+

An "Alice" for the new millennium, this book is a triumph of design and rare quality. Helen Oxenbury perfectly captures the dreamlike qualities suggested in Carroll's famous classic. The well-known characters are brilliantly realised and have consistency and child appeal. The fresh approach modernises the novel in an original way that will appeal to a new generation of readers.

Castle Diary
Chris Riddell
(Walker Books, £14.99)
9+

Fact and fiction combine in this diary of life in a castle in 1285. An informative and fun read for the older child.

fields.headline: Dole dogs non-white graduates
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: White graduates who have achieved the same degree grades as those from ethnic minorities are up to three times more likely to find jobs, according to research by the higher education funding council for England.
fields.body:
White graduates who have achieved the same degree grades as those from ethnic minorities are up to three times more likely to find jobs, according to research by the higher education funding council for England.

According to the unpublished survey, ethnic minority graduates were between 1.5 and three times more likely to end up on the dole. Though the findings were preliminary, "the effects are so large it seems likely that they will still be significant when a more comprehensive model is developed", it said.

Funding council officials are concerned that if graduates from ethnic minority or poor backgrounds are less likely to find jobs, universities might discriminate against applicants from these groups.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has asked for performance indicators on the employment of graduates to be published by the end of the year. There is pressure for universities to be funded in part according to their graduates' success in finding jobs.

"Given the government's policy to widen access [to higher education], it would be perverse to produce an indicator that would have the effect of discouraging institutions from recruiting such students," the study says. "One rational response to performance indicators would be for institutions to anticipate employers' preferences and prejudices."

Funding council officials are trying to develop measures to gauge job prospects from different universities that would not penalise institutions with high numbers of students from poor or ethnic minority backgrounds.

fields.headline: Armchair critics
fields.standfirst: Journalists are - amongst other things - expected to know about their subject matter. Well, almost. As far as comedy writers  Laurence Marks and  Maurice Gran can tell, everyone thinks they can be TV critic. Why?
fields.trailText: Journalists are - amongst other things - expected to know about their subject matter. Well, almost. As far as comedy writers Laurence Marks and Maurice Gran can tell, everyone thinks they can be TV critic. Why?
fields.body:
Yesterday we caught Doris, our cleaning lady, staring at us with something approaching awe. In fact she couldn't take her eyes off us. Finally she blurted it out. "I never knew you two young masters wrote 'Til Death Us Do Part!" We had to tell her that we didn't know it either. The mystery was partly solved when Doris showed us the crumpled Guardian page she had rescued from beneath the cat litter tray.

It (the page, not the litter tray) contained a TV review by a certain Matthew Baylis - or to be exact, an uncertain Matthew Baylis - of a BBC1 tribute to Warren Mitchell. In his review Matthew wrote:

"...The programme's purpose, if it had one, seemed to be an exorcism of past ghosts. A penitent Lawrence Marks [people always spell Laurence incorrectly] and Maurice Gran, original creators of 'Til Death Us Do Part, were shown surrounded by wine bottles as if they were slowly drinking themselves to death in a subterranean hide-out".

Actually, we were sitting in our favourite country pub discussing one of the most influential TV programmes of all time, written by, you've got it, the late great Speight - Johnny Speight that is. Perhaps we should be flattered that Matthew thought we possessed the brilliance to have created Alf Garnett and family; mind you, he could have attributed the show to Ned Sherrin or Sir Peter Hall, after all, they were both interviewed too.

"Who wrote 'Til Death Us Do Part?" would qualify as one of the easy questions on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, which, some critics might not know, is a popular quiz show, not BBC2's replacement for the Money Programme. In any other field of critical journalism, knowledge of one's specialist subject is a sine qua non. We don't expect to read a blistering review of Oscar Wilde's Romeo And Juliet, fulsome praise for Paul McCartney's 1812 Overture, or a ball-by-ball saga of Blackburn Rovers' attempts to regain The Ashes. Yet seemingly anyone with a pen and a pot of bile to dip it in is allowed to strut his stuff on the TV page.

And what stuff! Among the most treasured relics in the office of the head of BBC comedy are copies of such reviews as "One Foot In The Grave? One script in the bin!" "Absolutely Fabulous? Absolutely terrible!" and a curt notice about the first episode of Fawlty Towers that went "Long on John, short on jokes." All reviewed and dismissed after the first episode, naturally.

Of course there are honourable exceptions: The Guardian's Nancy Banks-Smith, Joe Joseph at The Times, and the nomadic Jaci Stephen, for example, writers who seem to understand and even like television. But they are outnumbered by dyspeptic hacks. For whereas film critics delight in getting on set or into the cutting room, and music critics are barely a toggle away from an anorak in their love for their chosen art form, TV critics prefer to sit at home moaning, surrounded by half-viewed cassettes and half-eaten pizzas.

Perhaps there's just no point reviewing something that has already happened and is never going to happen again. Yet when one national broadsheet abandoned reviews in favour of extensive previews, their readers didn't like it. Why not? Perhaps the best template for TV reviewing is to be found on the back page. After all, sports reporting is about trying to capture the past moment, even more than TV reviewing is.

The hunger is there to read about the football match or the horse race you saw, in the flesh or on the television, and to see if a reporter who knows what he/she is talking about agrees or disagrees with your very own personal review of the game. Was the third goal offside? Did that horse look like someone had slipped a couple of "E"s in his nose bag? Did the challenger take a dive or was it a mismatch?

Good sports reporting illuminates and enhances the enjoyment of the fan, especially the fan who didn't manage to see the event. Good sports reporters are defined by their knowledge and their love of what they write about, while our journalist friend Peter was once turned down for the TV critic's job on his national daily newspaper, after admitting that he liked watching the telly.

So is there a role for television critics, or will they all have to go and get proper jobs? The answer is - more than ever before. For just around the corner lies the terrifying Pandora's box of TV on demand. Every programme ever made anywhere in the world will be available, down a wire into the hard drive sitting where your video recorder used to be. When you next read a glowing review of the next Marks and Gran comedy in The Guardian there'll be no need to grind your teeth because you were out for a takeaway sushi and missed it. Instead you'll be able to download at the press of a button and judge it for yourselves. Because ultimately, it's what the viewers think of a programme that really matters.

fields.headline: EU aid programme waste exposed
fields.trailText: Far-reaching attemtps to tackle the European Unionís chaotic aid programme will be launched today by Chris Patten, the EU external relations commissioner, in a bid to make Brussels a more efficient player on the world stage.
fields.body:
Far-reaching attemtps to tackle the European Unionís chaotic aid programme will be launched today by Chris Patten, the EU external relations commissioner, in a bid to make Brussels a more efficient player on the world stage.

The EUës £7 billion aid budget is the worldís largest, but it has an appalling reputation for getting things done efficiently. It currently has more than £14 billion in unpaid commitments.

According to leaks of a report Mr Patten will present to fellow commissioners today, one of his most devastating findings was that the EU promised £120 million for re construction work in central America after Hurricane Mitch. Two years later, however, not a penny has been spent.

Similar problems -some already well known- were found in Gaza, Bosnia and Tibet.

Reconstruction in Kosovo, a major EU priority after last yearís Nato-led bombing cam paign, has been impeded by wrangling over the use of all 11 community languages.

Last week Mr Patten admitted he was ëíembarassedíí by the yawning gap between committments and delivery in the Balkans.

Proposals to improve the situation include creating a new semi-autonomous agency cal lled Euraid - which Mr Patten hopes will become a globally-recognisable brand name - to set priorites and objectives and then manage projects.

He wants staff working abroad to be able to make quick decisions without referring back to Brussels for micromanagement from afar.

The hope is that eventually the EU can match the United States as a global player -though it will have to make unaminagable strides in common foreign and defence policies before that can be a realistic prospect.

Other ideas include eliminating a backlog of 1,200 projects worth pounds one billion from before 1995 that have never been completed, or, in some cases even begun.

Mr Patten, whose mnatra has become ëídelivery delivery delivery,íí was horrifed to discover the state of the programme when he took over last September -and is determined to make his mark early on his five-year term.

Diplomats in Brussels say it is unclear whether he can succeed. The external relations directorate of the commission is shot through with cumbersome working procedures and a great deal of duplication.

Mr Patten has also been involved in behind the scvenes conflicts with Poul Nielsen, the acerbic Danish aid commissioner.

It is no secret that Mr Patten, who came to Brussels after serving as governor of Hong Kong and investigating the RUC in Northern Ireland, has often been frustrated at the pace and methods of the Brussels bureaucracy.

But he has argued that doing things well is a laudable goal. And, contrary to expectations, he has refused to get embroiled in rows with Javier Solana, the EUís foreign polcy supremo, who is answerable to national govenments.

Mr Pattenís direct boss, commission president Romano Prodi, is said to be delighted with him. And Tony Blair, who strongly backed the former Tory Party chairman for the job of second British commissioner in Brussels, will be pleased with the robust approach to improving aid delivery - very much in line with his own wish to show ordinary people that the EU can work well.

fields.headline: Rail safety training questioned
fields.trailText: Scenes of horror and heroism were revealed at the Paddington rail inquiry yesterday as questions were asked about safety training of staff.
fields.body:
Scenes of horror and heroism were revealed at the Paddington rail inquiry yesterday as questions were asked about safety training of staff.

Mike Thomas, a Virgin Trains manager, commended British Rail for providing better safety training than had been available since privatisation. He told the inquiry: "If staff get minimal training, they do not have confidence. They run round like headless chickens." He accepted that it would have been impossible to create a Paddington scenario in training.

Mr Thomas, who has worked on the railways for 11 years and was a passenger on the Great Western express which collided with the Thames train, was commended by other passengers after he jumped down and helped to secure the track to prevent other trains from crashing into the wreckage.

He said: "I had much more frequent training under BR. I am not so sure I would have been so competent and confident at Paddington if I had recently joined the railway."

Yesterday was the first day of evidence by witnesses of the crash last October, when 30 people were killed after the Thames train went through a red signal at Ladbroke Grove, west London.

One passenger on the Great Western express, Philip Scotcher, 24, from Tetbury, Gloucestershire, said he helped to drag another passenger, Michael Adams, 18st and 6ft 7in tall, to safety.

"He was on fire. I got him up but he fell down again, which extinguished quite a bit of fire on him. I was able to put out other bits by patting him with my hands," said Mr Scotcher.

The inquiry was told that Mr Adams was still in hospital.
