webTitle: The man who used his own blood to paint Hitler

fields.headline: The man who used his own blood to paint Hitler
fields.standfirst: Kate Connolly meets Gottfried Helnwein, the Austrian who is still confronting his country's Nazi past
fields.trailText: Kate Connolly meets Gottfried Helnwein, the Austrian who is still confronting his country's Nazi past
fields.body:
Walking along Cork Street in central London, trying to locate the Robert Sandelson Gallery, I do a double take on seeing Mick Jagger standing at number 5a, gazing through its paneless window. He has the 70s hairstyle, carved cheeks and angular nose, arms folded and face expressionless as he observes the workmen labouring to reinsert the glass. The whole tableau recalls some contrived album cover. Except it isn't Jagger, but one of his biggest fans, Austrian artist Gottfried Helnwein.

It could have been worse. At least he doesn't look like his self-portraits, in which bandages swathe his head, bent forks pull his mouth into a mocking smile and blood drenches his torso. Helnwein, 52, is a master of the scandalous and the art of shocking. The artist Robert Crumb once said of him: "Helnwein is a very fine artist and one sick motherfucker."

He earned his first gallery show in the 70s by driving around his native Vienna dressed in Nazi uniform, his head bandaged, fake blood trickling from his mouth. It caught the eye of an art dealer who signed him up and has remained faithful to Austria's enfant terrible ever since.

The decision to become an artist came to Helnwein "in a split second" at the age of 18, he says. "I saw it as the only way to find answers to the questions that no one in Austria would give me, such as why the post-war republic portrayed itself as the first victim of the Nazis rather than as one of the main perpetrators." He enrolled at the Experimental Institute for Higher Graphic Instruction in Vienna, but soon got bored. One day he took a razor blade and cut his palms, using the blood to paint a portrait of Adolf Hitler. The academics stormed in, confiscated the painting and Helnwein was expelled.

"This was the moment when I sensed for the first time that you can change something with aesthetics," he says. "You can get things moving in a very subtle way, you can get even the strong and powerful to slide and totter - anything, actually, if you know the weak points and tap at them ever so gently by aesthetic means." He painted more Hitler portraits throughout the 70s. They attracted attention from everyone, from concentration camp victims to SS officers, most of whom opened up to him. Somehow neo-Nazis got to hear of his pictures, knocking at his studio door to say: "We've heard you have a painting of the Führer. Can we come in?" According to Helnwein, they confided in him their dreams of German supremacy and told him how they were infiltrating the far-right Freedom Party.

Now, Helnwein has clear opinions on Jörg Haider and his party's blitzschnell rise to government; but he seems typically wary of being labelled as having an anti-Haider agenda. "I cannot understand why everyone makes so much fuss now," he says. "The situation was far worse in the past, when the former Freedom Party leader [Friedrich Peter] was an SS soldier who had been involved in the exterminations. Everyone knew about it and it was well documented, but he always said "I don't remember" and everyone accepted that."

But as with his repressive Roman Catholic upbringing, it seems that Helnwein, born in 1948, will never escape the Nazi theme (in fact, he sees the two traditions as inextricably linked). Spurred into action by an interview in an Austrian tabloid in which the country's top court psychiatrist, Dr Heinrich Gross, admitted killing children at Vienna's Am Spiegelgrund Paediatric Unit during the war by poisoning their food, Helnwein painted Life not Worth Living - a watercolour of a little girl "asleep" on the table, her head in her plate. The painting sparked a nationwide debate that finally led to Gross appearing before a Vienna court in March. The judge ruled Gross was mentally unfit to be tried.

Outside the courtroom I met relatives of his alleged child victims, bearing photographs of them: their bellies distended from drug experimentation, their skulls clamped in head-measuring instruments. The brains of more than 400 of them ended up pickled in jars in the basement of the hospital where Gross experimented on them. Helnwein's first solo show in the UK consists largely of frail and tender formaldehyde-yellow or x-ray-blue images of pre-natal babies and children, reflecting the horror of the Nazi euthanasia programme, but brought close to the 21st century by the freshness of the Gross story. The huge portraits have been reworked from deformed teratological images from Austria's Anatomical Museum.

Another exhibit, the Epiphany, shows uniformed Nazi soldiers inspecting a naked baby "Jesus" who is held by a beautiful Aryan goddess. The widow of one of the Nazi officers is suing Helnwein for the unauthorised use of the image of her husband.

Children and child abuse have long been a central theme in Helnwein's work, "years before anyone would dare talk about it," he says. The images of seemingly innocent children in compromising positions, with a threatening look of experience in their eyes, have the ring of Mapplethorpe about them. He depicts not the act of violence but, perhaps more disturbingly, the result of the violence, as in the 1971 watercolour Embarrassing, which shows a child in her Sunday best, with a serious harelip and a squint, sitting on the floor against a white wall. Her emaciated right arm dangles, her bandaged left hand is placed on a comic book.

According to Alexander Borowsky, curator of contemporary art at the state Russian Museum, St Petersburg, comic books gave the teenage Helnwein his "Damascus experience". His allegiance to Walt Disney and youthful experience of arch-conservative catholicism prompt him to describe Donald Duck and Jesus as the most important influences in his art. "When I opened my first comic," Helnwein says, "I felt like someone who has been buried in a mining accident and emerges into the daylight again after days in the dark. I was back home in a reasonable world where one could be flattened by road rollers or riddled with a hundred bullets without being harmed - a world where people looked decent once more."

Helnwein sought to find this decency in the real world for years, and failed. He moved from Austria ("If I stayed I would have become a terrorist") to more liberal Cologne in Germany. Then in 1997 the Lutheran church spearheaded a smear campaign denouncing him as a member of the Scientology sect. He has been open to various philosophies and teachings, he says, but the Scientology claim is one that he passionately denies, adding: "It's as if the German psyche thrives on witchhunts".

He took his complaint to Germany's constitutional court, which last November ruled that Helnwein and Scientology could no longer be mentioned in the same breath. ("Please write mainly about the art and not about the Scientology," he pleaded at the end of our interview.) Partially as a result of the hate campaign against him, three years ago, Helnwein upped and left Germany with wife, Renate and their four children. They found a new home in a castle just outside Clonmel near Cork, and, says Helnwein, "we feel at home there like we have nowhere else before and there are good vibrations." Asked how much of the attraction is to do with his tax-free status there as an artist, he says:

"Because the authorities have such a respectful attitude towards artists there's a spirit there to create that you find nowhere else in the world. Even the fishermen understand where you're coming from." Moving house is as important to the restless Austrian as changing styles. He detests the Roy Liechtenstein format of one idea, one picture. The work of the self-styled "whirling dervish of the art world" spans an incredible range of media from sculpture to photography to etching. "I try to escape the seduction of a certain medium," he explains. "I love to start something new with all the risks and the uncertainty." It is the equivalent, he says of colonic irrigation - the only way to avoid artistic blockage and complacency.

I was back home in a reasonable world where one could be flattened by road rollers or riddled with a hundred bullets without being harmed - a world where people looked decent once more." Helnwein sought to find this decency in the real world for years, and failed. He moved from Austria ("If I stayed I would have become a terrorist") to more liberal Cologne in Germany. Then in 1997 the Lutheran church spearheaded a smear campaign denouncing him as a member of the Scientology sect. He has been open to various philosophies and teachings, he says, but the Scientology claim is one that he passionately denies, adding: "It's as if the German psyche thrives on witchhunts". He took his complaint to Germany's constitutional court, which last November ruled that Helnwein and Scientology could no longer be mentioned in the same breath. ("Please write mainly about the art and not about the Scientology," he pleaded at the end of our interview.) Partially as a result of the hate campaign against him, three years ago, Helnwein upped and left Germany with wife, Renate and their four children. They found a new home in a castle just outside Clonmel near Cork, and, says Helnwein, "we feel at home there like we have nowhere else before and there are good vibrations." Asked how much of the attraction is to do with his tax-free status there as an artist, he says: "Because the authorities have such a respectful attitude towards artists there's a spirit there to create that you find nowhere else in the world. Even the fishermen understand where you're coming from." Moving house is as important to the restless Austrian as changing styles. He detests the Roy Liechtenstein format of one idea, one picture. The work of the self-styled "whirling dervish of the art world" spans an incredible range of media from sculpture to photography to etching. "I try to escape the seduction of a certain medium," he explains. "I love to start something new with all the risks and the uncertainty." It is the equivalent, he says of colonic irrigation - the only way to avoid artistic blockage and complacency.

webTitle: No rightist could be the right person for this job

fields.headline: No rightist could be the right person for this job
fields.standfirst:
The BBC's new political editor has everything it takes, including impartiality

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The politician and the journalist start from different places. I'm talking about the good ones on both sides, not the tossers and the hacks. Their occupations draw them apart, whenever there's a search for truth.
fields.body:
The politician and the journalist start from different places. I'm talking about the good ones on both sides, not the tossers and the hacks. Their occupations draw them apart, whenever there's a search for truth. Their mind-sets are irredeemably at odds, in a way that makes it harder for the politician to understand the journalist than vice versa. At some deep level, he doesn't understand what the journalist is about. The main theatre where this incomprehension is played out is the BBC.

In the mind of the average politician, there's no such thing as detachment. Every politician lives by bias. An absence of bias, which would mean an absence of one-sided commitment, is inconceivable. The professional pol exults in the stuff, can't live without it, depends on a rhetoric that can never admit to more than a single version of wisdom. Which is all very well - but it doesn't stop there. Such minds find it hard, usually impossible, to understand that other minds are different. Especially the mind of the journalist, who deals in the same issues and drinks from the same tap, and must therefore surely experience the same strong opinionated pull to one side or the other.

It's not surprising that the latest display of this deformity should be directed at the new political editor of the BBC, Andrew Marr. There's no more important job in political journalism, and it has gone to a man with form as a commentator as well as a reporter, who comes from the centre-left and not the right. Though the Tories have officially been careful in their response to this, their proxies in the press have not.

The ingrained political mind-set extends to the propagandists of the Mail and the Telegraph, who see nothing other than politics in the appointment of Mr Marr and are bitterly attacking it before the man has uttered a word to camera. The Bolshevik Broadcasting Corporation, once made famous by Kenneth Baker, is now the Blairite BC, and Marr is its predestined foghorn.

The critics have a piece of history on their side. However innocent the substance, the perception looks bad. Marr is inserted into a pattern begun by the appointment of Greg Dyke, a £50,000 donor to New Labour, as BBC director-general.

I'm sure Dyke didn't initiate Marr's appointment, and doubt that Marr's politics had anything whatever to do with the decision. But the poison of Dyke's conflicted roles seeps outward, as some said it always would. There's a contamination. Good professional decisions can be treated, by the BBC's numerous enemies, as something else. If this gets an outstanding journalist off to a bumpy start, it's not his fault.

Otherwise, two interesting issues arise which point the other way. The first concerns this matter of truth-telling. The critics' assumption seems to be that a man who has been a commentator, with opinions about prominent matters on the govern ment's agenda, is incapable of being a bias-free reporter. He cannot make the switch. Even if he makes an honest try, the weasels insinuate, he won't make enough people believe him. So he shouldn't have the job.

This not only assumes that all journalists are crypto- political, but that opinions debar them from honestly evaluating the words and deeds of politicians. Journalists are naturally inquisitive, and likely to form opinions about the people they cover, but to say that an opinion inevitably constitutes a bias is a fallacy born of paranoia. What good journalists care about far more than seeing their opinion prevail is seeing their account of reality borne out by events. They want to tell their audience what is going on, as to both fact and meaning, and to get it roughly right.

In present times, this will be doubly the ambition of the BBC and its political editor. Perhaps it's a pity no candidate could be found who was trained for a lifetime in BBC habits. But the job needs authority, judgment, experience, presence, all to be rewarded over time with public trust and credibility. It also needs a deep resistance to the manufacturing of politicians' version of the truth, otherwise known as spin.

Andrew Marr has everything it takes to occupy the post. Above all, he and his employers will be concerned for reputations which all political parties seek, when it suits them, to diminish if not destroy. This means forswearing secret biases and overt opinions - something good reporters practise but politicians cannot understand. Curiously enough, it's the only thing that matters. One can be certain Mr Marr will observe the rules to a fault.

Second, the cry goes up, why didn't a rightist get the job? Could he ever have done so? Why not Boris Johnson, instead of Andrew Marr? The question is asked, by the rightist Telegraph, with knowing incredulity. They're sure it could never have happened. Their conspiratorial view of the world tells them the BBC would never let it, because the BBC, as we all know, was Blairite before Blair, a den of progressives from way back. I think this is a false analysis, but one which points some of the way towards the answer to their own question.

Given that the BBC's only interest was the test of professional competence, the question should rather be: why would no prominent rightwing commentator be a credible political reporter? What names could you put on a short list that didn't come with polemical baggage which nobody would believe they could shed? Would Boris do, even if he wanted to quit the Spectator? I don't think so. The reasons tell one something about the state of the right, and of the press that makes them famous.

Most rightist commentators are polemicists above all else. There's a rage about them that speaks against a world permanently stacked the other way. It may be a strange legacy of two decades that were defined by the rightist triumph of Thatcherism, but the right still speaks from the bunker of the dispossessed. In some ways, it produces more fiery and therefore more readable journalism than the left, but most of it is a long way from attempting to tease out the truth of what is actually happening. That's not the right's game.

It is nourished, moreover, by proprietors with a similar mentality. Propaganda rather than news has all too often, on certain subjects, been the guiding light of the rightist press both broad and tab. The tradition doesn't breed natural BBC reporters, steeped in the need for balance, or a habit of mind that could comfortably absorb that way of doing things. On the right, so much more sure of its capacity for outrage than the soggy centre-left, everything but everything is political.

The new evidence of this is its reaction to Andrew Marr's appointment. The right says he cannot be impartial: he must be political: he's proof of the cancer at the heart of the BBC. Such paranoid certainties, without objective inquiry or the awaiting of evidence, show rather eloquently that the best man got the job.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
No Service Please, We're British
8pm, Channel 5
"There is a disease in Britain, people won't complain", says David Pryer of CAMRA, a man who spends his working life checking whether frothing pints contain too much froth and not enough actual beer. A crucial issue, but it's maybe unfair that this series on bad customer service kicks off with a film that makes little distinction between lousy pubs and endearingly odd hostelries, such as a bar in Leicestershire that opens for just four hours a week on Fridays.

Reputations
9pm, BBC2
In 1972, Olga Korbut's performances at the Munich Olympics somersaulted the 17-year-old gymnast to stardom. But Korbut's success came with a high price tag for the 17-year-old. According to Korbut, her coach Renald Knysh ("a loner, a despot, a weirdo"), raped her in the build-up to the games. Knysh, meanwhile, denies her claims and notes that Korbut was "lazy" and "capricious". A documentary that casts a harsh light on the pressurised world of top-class sport.

When I Get Older
9.50pm, BBC2
"When you're in love, everything is easy", notes Jan as she recalls her Danish husband, who died 20 years ago. At 83, after living and working abroad for years, Jan is returning to England from Copenhagen. But within a few months, Jan, still independent in sheltered accommodation in Oxford, regrets her decision, upset that she hasn't managed to build a closer relationship with her English relatives. A poignant film to begin a series on ageing and society's attitudes towards the elderly.

Family Secrets
10pm, Channel 4
At 31, Samantha Gillingham leads an ordinary life bringing up her young son. Yet her childhood was extraordinary. In 1996, Samantha's father Russell (who had moved his mistress, Patricia Causley, into the marital home) was sentenced to life for the murder of his wife, Carol. Carol's body has never been found, and the crime was only discovered when Russell faked his own death in an insurance scam. Samantha testified against Russell to "make amends" to her mother.

fields.headline: Spanish spring $10bn offer for Lycos
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's growing influence in the global internet sector was underlined yesterday by reports that the Spanish internet service provider, Terra Networks, is preparing to take over American-owned search engine, Lycos, in a deal worth around $10bn (£6.6bn).
fields.body:
Europe's growing influence in the global internet sector was underlined yesterday by reports that the Spanish internet service provider, Terra Networks, is preparing to take over American-owned search engine, Lycos.com, in a deal worth around $10bn (£6.6bn).

The acquisition, if completed, would be the first takeover of a leading US internet company by a European competitor and would have been almost unthinkable a year ago, when Terra Networks did not have a stock exchange listing and was barely known outside its home market.

Shares in Lycos surged as much as 17% in early trading amid reports that Terra is prepared to swap more than 1.5 of its shares - or around $90 - for each Lycos share.

It is understood that Lycos is holding out for a higher exchange ratio and could pull out if it is not guaranteed the terms it wants.

Lycos shareholders would have to decide whether to exchange their shares in a well-known, profitable portal for a lossmaking Spanish ISP. Last year Lycos management agreed to merge with Barry Diller's USA Networks in a complicated deal that shareholders eventually rebuffed - not least because key shareholder CMGI publicly denounced the offer and withdrew its representation from the Lycos board as a result.

Lycos and Terra, which is majority-owned by Telefonica, the Spanish equivalent of BT, both refused to comment. Last week the two companies said they were in discussions about an undisclosed alliance.

Analysts believe the talks relate to an all-share merger which would effectively translate into a takeover by Terra - which, with a market capitalisation of around €18bn, is significantly larger than Lycos.

"We think they've got the agreement in the bag apart from a few details, and that it will be a merger," said Ramon Ortega, an analyst at Madrid broker Safei.

A takeover of Lycos would give Terra improved access to more than 30m Hispanics in the US, and analysts confirmed that the Spanish com pany has been prepared to make aggressive bids in the past.

However one Madrid analyst warned: "It looks like a good match but some people might not like the idea of moving into the United States, which is the most competitive market there is."

The Spanish company, which is valued at around €18bn, is also looking to expand southwards into Central and South America.

Terra Networks attracted a great deal of publicity last November, when it saw its initial public offering almost triple in value on its first day of trading and ended that day as Europe's largest publicly traded internet company.

But the recent turmoil in internet stocks has hit Terra shares, knocking nearly two-thirds off its value since the beginning of the year.

News of the probable link-up hurt Freeserve shares in early trading.

Dealers, fearing the UK company's prospects in the European market would be hit by the merged entity, marked the shares down as low as 427.5p before a rally saw them close up 16.5p at 469.5p.

The net sector has already seen consolidation with deals from firms such as Yahoo!, which a year ago bought online community operator GeoCities and net video provider Broadcast.com.

Profits remain elusive, however. The primary example of delivery and content fusion was last year's $6.7bn merger of portal Excite with the high-speed access provider At Home, which has done little so far to pull the two companies out of the red.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... Carrie Brownstein
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Full Name: Carrie Rachel Lawrence Brownstein

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? In the late 70s I went under the name Silky Rumbler at poetry slams. I still get the occasional "Silky, is that you?" when we play in certain cities. My hair is so much shorter now, I don't know how they recognise me.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Yes. I enjoy the occasional senior discount at All You Can Eat restaurants. The "endless" macaroni salad and "bottomless" coffee goes down a lot easier with a 10% discount.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? I'm a square looking for another square for some square dancing.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Treason.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Rescued a puppy from drowning in the Deschutes river in Olympia, Washington. I made the front page of our local paper.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Chloe Sevigney.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? Y.O.U.K.N.O.W.W.H.O.Y.O.U. A.R.E.

Has a critic ever made you cry? Yes. Mothers can be so cruel.

What would you advertise without a fee? Fake moustaches.

What would you never advertise? Cigarettes.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? The person lying next to me screaming.

What takes you to a "happy place"? I don't like to be taken anywhere.

 Sleater-Kinney's album All Hands On The Bad One is out now on Matador

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Das Boot: The Director's Cut (Wolfgang Petersen, 1981) 9pm, Carlton Cinema

Petersen's account of a wartime U-boat crew hunting allied shipping in the north Atlantic, which is based on a submariner's autobiography, is sweatily authentic and at times almost unbearably tense. The camera roves through the confined spaces of the war machine, but the focus is firmly on the grizzled, gaunt fighting men, led by the haunted Jurgen Prochnow. And the advantage of this epic, extended version is that we come to know them even better.

Mrs Dalloway (Marleen Gorris, 1997) 10pm, Sky Premier

Vanessa Redgrave's Clarissa Dalloway, radiant politician's wife, is preparing for one of her famous parties but wandering in bittersweet reveries of youthful romance; in flashback, Natascha McElhone, as her younger self, is wooed by Peter (Alan Cox). And coming to the party is the mature, still ardent Peter (Michael Kitchen). Eileen Atkins's adaptation of Virginia Woolf's novel is wistful and touching.

Wise Blood (John Huston, 1979) 10pm, FilmFour

The haunted-child face of Brad Dourif sets an awkward, disquieting tone to Huston's tragi-comedy of religious manners, adapted from Flannery O'Connor's novel. Dourif plays a disturbed army veteran who returns to his Deep South hometown and becomes a preacher, although an atheist one. His Church Of Truth Without Jesus Christ is only his first, dispiriting protest against neon-lit fundamen talism. Ned Beatty, Harry Dean Stanton are among the excellent cast.

Deliverance (John Boorman, 1972) 10pm Sky Cinema

Four city slickers, canoeing in the wild Appalachians, are sorely tested in a clash with weird, inbred backwoodsmen. Burt Reynolds is at his best leading the fight for survival, while Jon Voight sinks his liberal principles when their chum Ned Beatty is raped. Powerful, gut-churning adventure, complete with Boormanesque state-of-the-planet undercurrents.

His Church Of Truth Without Jesus Christ is only his first, dispiriting protest against neon-lit fundamen talism. Ned Beatty, Harry Dean Stanton are among the excellent cast. Deliverance (John Boorman, 1972) 10pm Sky Cinema Four city slickers, canoeing in the wild Appalachians, are sorely tested in a clash with weird, inbred backwoodsmen. Burt Reynolds is at his best leading the fight for survival, while Jon Voight sinks his liberal principles when their chum Ned Beatty is raped. Powerful, gut-churning adventure, complete with Boormanesque state-of-the-planet undercurrents.

fields.headline: The quiet riot
fields.standfirst: Mikhail Pletnev has a passion for fast cars and playing his piano so loudly that audiences fear the instrument will fall apart. Yet in person he refuses to play the superstar.  Jessica Duchen reports
fields.trailText: Mikhail Pletnev has a passion for fast cars and playing his piano so loudly that audiences fear the instrument will fall apart. Yet in person he refuses to play the superstar. Jessica Duchen reports
fields.body:
There are so many stories about Mikhail Pletnev that I half expect to meet a colossus, an arrogant New Russian who will stop at nothing to achieve his artistic ends. It is something of a surprise to encounter a tired little fellow in a crumpled tweed jacket who greets me, rather disconcertingly, in perfect German. His manager prompts him gently: "Misha, I think it's in English..."

Pletnev is a living legend of the piano; in person, however, he seems not larger than life, but smaller. He is short, slight, inscrutable, and so softly spoken that I have to strain to hear his words in the hotel bar in Helsinki, where I have caught up with him a few days before he comes to the UK. He looks more like an English schoolmaster than a Russian superstar; his self-deprecation too seems echt-English. "All I do is play the piano, and enjoy life," he says. Then a tell-tale vestige of Russian gloom invades: "I hope I survive some more time to continue enjoying it."

Gradually, as he relaxes, a laconic charm begins to emerge, subtle and ironic. Yet between questions he seems beset by a nervous tic, lips working backwards and forwards. It is impossible to tell what he is thinking.

At the piano, Pletnev is a powerful force. Tempos and volume can reach every extreme known to the instrument, and his interpretations often polarise listeners. Critics eulogise him wildly, but a Chopin recital I attended seemed to have very little to do with Chopin and a great deal to do with Pletnev himself. At his best - his own transcription of Tchaikovsky's Sleeping Beauty ballet music, or his Hommage to Rachmaninov, on the composer's own piano - Pletnev can be stunning: glittering, passionate and gut-wrenchingly compelling. At other times, the music feels icy, distorted and self-willed, the tone so violent that you almost expect the piano to fall apart. To some musicians, every mark on the composer's page is sacrosanct. For Pletnev, "It is a starting point...

"You've touched a delicate question," he acknowledges, "but it is quite complicated. Often musicians have played differently from the composer's indications, even Liszt himself. At other times, people have said that we should only play what is written down - but then this is not enough by itself." He laughs. "So everything is wrong!"

How does he account for the extreme reactions he seems to inspire? Pletnev shrugs. "Sometimes I play well," he says, "and sometimes I do not. I always try to do my best."

Pletnev is the only child of two musicians: his mother was a répétiteuse and his father played and taught the bayan (a Russian accordion). He underwent the classic Soviet hothouse musical training - the Central Music School in Moscow from the age of 13 followed by the Moscow Conservatory - and he still lives partly in Russia. "I live in the field, beside the river," he declares poetically. His mother used to travel everywhere with him, and a rarified, protected aura around him is maintained by his manager and friends, who tend to mother him too.

Maybe he needs protecting - he seems to enjoy certain types of danger. If a musician's inner life shows in his playing, then Pletnev's mind must have some very unorthodox corners indeed. More definably, he has a passion for fast cars. "There aren't many roads left in Russia where you can drive like this," he says regretfully. "You cannot go faster than 120km. They fine you!"

Speed notwithstanding, he is not tempted to leave Russia permanently and is relatively optimistic about the country's future. On the day of our interview, Vladimir Putin was inaugurated as Russia's first elected president, something Pletnev regards as a very positive step. "The first election has been accomplished without any bloodshed, without any shootings. And it is good for Russia to have a leader now who can be strong but not extreme and who can think clearly and coldly about what is going on. Russia needs some organisation."

What are his feelings about the war in Chechnya? "I think if there are people there who are trying to solve problems with their guns, or taking children hostage, they must be stopped - but eventually there should be some political solution. Perhaps the way to achieve this is with education, gradually." He believes that western claims of human rights violations by the Russians may be exaggerated. "There has been a similar situation in Northern Ireland for years," he announces, continuing whimsically: "Imagine that in the US, the state of New England declares that it is against the president and wants to destroy all Americans who are not from New England. I am not sure that the US would give it independence so quickly."

Pletnev is like a musical, slightly out-to-lunch version of Putin - he has that determination, that cleverness and something of that steely gaze. He launched his career in 1974, aged 21, by winning the Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow, one of the world's most important musical prizes. By all accounts, he set about winning quite deliberately and with absolute conviction. "I decided I wanted to win the Tchaikovsky competition because I knew it would open many doors for my career," he says. True, but not the language of the surprised-and-delighted winner more common on the concert scene.

In 1991, with equal determination, Pletnev founded the Russian National Orchestra - the first Russian arts organisation independent of the state since 1917. Mikhail Gorbachev encouraged Pletnev in his plans; much has been made of this, but Pletnev explains that "I founded this orchestra in November 1991, and by then Gorbachev's position was doubtful. There had already been this putsch, and Yeltsin took power two or three months later. I told Gorbachev about this idea and he was very supportive. I respect him very much: he enjoys classical music, especially Tchaikovsky, which is not a common thing among Russian politicians. But the orchestra had more enemies than friends. And the enemies were the powerful ones."

The creation of the orchestra rubbed people up the wrong way throughout the Russian musical system. Several other conductors were incandescent with fury as their best players decamped for the RNO's higher salaries. Nearly a decade later, however, the RNO is a well established international presence and Pletnev is leaving his position as music director and principal conductor. Isn't it a wrench to leave an organisation to which he has devoted so much time and effort? No, he says. He will still work with the RNO as its conductor laureate, but he is glad to be free of certain administrative responsibilities that he felt were falling too heavily on his shoulders.

Steely and determined he may be, but Pletnev can seem impossibly laid-back about his music-making. Conducting? "It's a nice thing to do. You do not have to practise. But it is difficult because the orchestra never plays the way you want it." Or try this: apparently he once recorded three and a half CDs of piano music in one week flat, sleeping in until nearly noon each day and usually giving up well before 4pm. Few musicians would dare to work this way. But he has that kind of brain: highly absorbent, super-charged, mercurial. He composes too: he has written "a big, romantic viola concerto" for Yuri Bashmet and reworked the Beethoven Violin Concerto for his friend Michael Collins to play on the clarinet. And he speaks at least five languages fluently, including Japanese.

Pletnev's forthcoming Tchaikovsky concerts are sure to be crowd-pullers - everyone loves Tchaikovsky. Is he an easy composer to identify with? Pletnev doesn't think so. "He was a very complicated person. There are very few musicians who play Tchaikovsky properly - there are many one-sided performances. Most of the time Tchaikovsky is taken as an emotionally exaggerated composer. But his music ranges from the big, powerful things to some which are small and very delicate. As well as the Russian character of his music, there are influences from German and French music; as well as emotion there is intellect and philosophy."

There is pride in his tone, even possessiveness. Maybe the restrained demeanour is misleading, for there is no false modesty about Pletnev.

At some point after his manager returns, Pletnev disappears so quietly that I do not notice him go. When he returns, he drifts over like a shadow wreathed in smoke. But just wait until he gets to the piano.

 Mikhail Pletnev and the Philharmonia Orchestra performTchaikovsky's three piano concertos at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), tonight and Saturday.

fields.headline: The executioner's song
fields.trailText: True Stories | Holiday Airport - Palma | The Natural World
fields.body:
There are good documentaries, and there are bad documentaries, and then there are BBC wildlife programmes, which are in a league of their own. All three species were on show last night, in an evening of programming that seemed determined to educate the audience into submission. Must be payback for all those Bank Holiday Mondays we've been having recently.

Channel 4's reliable True Stories strand returned with Dr Death, an engrossing study of hubris and ignorance in the unlovely form of Fred Leuchter Jr. This amphibious little man described himself as "an engineer from Boston, Massachusetts", but he was much more than that: he'd carved himself a niche as a specialist in execution machines. Faulty electric chair? Dodgy gas chamber? Leuchter's your man, and he recounted with gleeful pride the improvements he'd made in various American prisons ("our electric chair has a drip pan"). As a specialist in the machinery of death, Leuchter was recruited by notorious Holocaust denier Ernst Zündel (author of Did Six Million Really Die?) to testify on his behalf at a trial in 1988.

So, armed only with a hammer and chisel and blind self-belief, Leuchter trotted off to Auschwitz with his newly married wife in tow, and spent his honeymoon tapping away at the walls of the crematoria. The sight of Leuchter, oversize fur hat pulled down over tiny head, prancing among the ruins of Crematorium 2 was ghoulishly comic. Lowering himself through the gas inlets into the chamber where 500,000 people were killed, Leuchter said "it's kind of spooky". Such was his empathy with his subject.

His illegal chippings at Auschwitz were bad enough, but Leuchter went on to complete a report suggesting that no trace of hydrogen cyanide (Zyklon B) was found at Auschwitz, and therefore it was not used to kill people. He testified at Zündel's trial, and his report was published to delighted neo-Nazis the world over. Zündel lost, and Leuchter's methods were discredited, but in the topsy-turvy world of the extreme right this just made their message even more important, and Leuchter found himself a celebrity on the Nazi lecture circuit.

Errol Morris's film allowed the tale of a little man caught up in a big story to unfold with unhurried eloquence, giving Leuchter enough rope to hang himself. There were grisly touches: some 1903 footage of the electrocution of an elephant was, weirdly, more shocking than the death-camp images. Occasionally Morris got carried away with his arthouse ambitions - slowed-down video transferred to film is a bit too Derek Jarman for this kind of thing. But these are minor quibbles in a film that walked the tightrope between dispassionate journalism and passionate campaigning with brilliant aplomb.

Such finesse made ITV's Holiday Airport - Palma look even more threadbare than it already was, which is saying something. We found ourselves in departures at Palma de Majorca, with a lot of nobodies running around the shiny new corridors furiously auditioning for all they were worth. Trouble was, nothing happened. Airport delays are excruciatingly dull when they're happening to you, so why would we watch them on TV? Biggest drama of the hour was a child with chickenpox: "getting home now depends on the state of Amy's spots" was the cliffhanger before the first ad break. Yes, it was that exciting.

Which brings us with some relief to The Natural World (BBC2) about which there isn't much to say except that it was beautiful, inspiring and uplifting. Last night's subject was the Hanuman langur monkeys of Jodhpur, who flew across the old city's rooftops like furry angels and co-existed in comic harmony with their human neighbours. The pampered town monkeys enjoyed lavish hospitality as the earthly representatives of the monkey god Hanuman; their lean, mean country cousins were a different matter, and every so often would bounce into town for a fight. This culminated in a night of murder and rapine with horrible echoes of similar human conflicts, but peace was restored by the end of the show. The patience and skill of the film-makers was, as ever, humbling.

fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: In the first of an occasional series  Adrian Searle looks at a highlight of the world's biggest modern art museum  This week: Der Tisch, by Peter Fischli and David Weiss
fields.trailText: In the first of an occasional series Adrian Searle looks at a highlight of the world's biggest modern art museum This week: Der Tisch, by Peter Fischli and David Weiss
fields.body:
Walking through the suite called Still Life/Real Life/Object on the third level of Tate Modern, you come to a gallery with a gorgeous river view. I have watched visitors pause here for a moment, admire the view, glance uncertainly about, and pass on. The builders appear to have left the room unfinished: everywhere there are stacks of boards, scuffed plinths, workmen's detritus and annoying piles of abandoned rubbish. It is as if the builders and decorators went for lunch and never came back.

The gallery is devoted to the work of two Swiss artists, Peter Fischli and David Weiss. This, surely, is just another modern art come-on. But no. Nothing in the room is real - not the wooden palettes on which the wall boards are stacked, nor the boards themselves, nor the plinths, nor the little pile of peanut shells on the lid of a plastic paint tub. Nor, for that matter, the tub itself, the brushes caked with paint, nor the motorbike helmet, the electric drill, the child's bootee, the bowl of cat biscuits, the fag packets, the wood-shavings and paint spatters. The very dust is unreal.

I wonder, for a moment, if even the air in the room is rendered in the finest reconstituted nothingness, flown in in crates from the artists' native Switzerland. The entire room is a re-made ready-made, a collection of perfect trompe- l'oeil objects.

So much attention to so many sorry details is absurd. It is also cunning, devious and very funny. Where, you ask, does this perfect, straight-faced reconstruction of an imperfect world end? Glancing through a doorway to Tony Cragg's cubic stack of ordinary objects in the adjacent gallery, one begins to doubt its veracity. And thinking about Duchamp's Fountain, a few rooms away, one remembers that this perfectly ordinary porcelain urinal is itself a reconstruction, a 60s replica. And where, even in Cézanne's paintings, does the original paintwork end, the crack-filler and touched-up restoration begin?

Fischli and Weiss are not Chardin. One imagines them giggling as they carve away at blocks of plastic, paint the Marlboro logo on the fake cigarette packet, manfully hew the cat biscuits and the peanut shells. Their work - which has included the making of sculptures from cocktail sausages, and a pyrotechnic, maniacal film, The Way Things Go, which demonstrates the physical laws of cause and effect - also has a more serious purpose. They represent the world unhinged from itself, with all its accidents intact. They make us look with sharper eyes, and with an acute sense of disbelief, and tread more lightly from here on.

Tate Modern is at Bankside, London SE1 (020-7887 8000).

fields.headline: West Bank explodes in fury
fields.standfirst:
Violence flares as Israeli PM sees his grip on power slipping

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Palestinian police and Israeli security forces engaged in gunbattles and teenagers hurled petrol bombs and rubble from rooftops yesterday as the West Bank and Gaza exploded in the worst violence for nearly four years. The toll rose to two dead and more than 300 injured.
fields.body:
Palestinian police and Israeli security forces engaged in gunbattles and teenagers hurled petrol bombs and rubble from rooftops yesterday as the West Bank and Gaza exploded in the worst violence for nearly four years. The toll rose to two dead and more than 300 injured.

Yesterday's clashes threatened to eclipse the other news of the day: the decision by the Israeli cabinet to transfer two villages straddling Jerusalem's city limits to full Palestinian control.

The day of rage in the West Bank and Gaza was intended to mark the 52nd anniversary of the nakba - literally the catastrophe - that befell the Palestinian people when the Jewish state was created in 1948. But, fuelled by the discontents of what has passed for peace these past six years, and a campaign for the release of 1,650 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails, the protesters' anger and frustration seemed boundless.

In approving the transfer of the villages of Abu Dis and Azariya to full Palestinian sovereignty, the cabinet was trying to mollify that anger. But the goodwill gesture - undertaken after weeks of dithering by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, immediately earned the wrath of the Israeli right.

It also puts his coalition at risk. Although parliament approved the transfer last night, two parties in Mr Barak's coalition voted against - deepening doubts about the viability of his alliance.

"This is the beginning of the end of Barak's government," a Likud party leader, Danny Naveh, said. "This is the begining of the process of the division of Jerusalem."

The religious, rightwing and immigrant parties have seized on the otherwise unremarkable village of Abu Dis as an augury that Mr Barak intends to give up part of the holy city to the Palestinians. The village is the site of the Palestinian parliament in the making from which Yasser Arafat will enjoy stunning views of the golden Dome of the Rock.

Settler groups began their campaign to punish that affront last night with a demonstration in Zion Square, Jerusalem. Brandishing posters with a death's head wrapped in a Palestinian keffiya , they put on their biggest show of strength since the assasssination of the then prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, in November 1995.

"Today they have brought the mass murderer Arafat within the gates of Jerusalem, and I hope that people will rise up against this anti-Jewish act," said Nadia Matar, leader of the Militant Women in Green.

With his voice hoarse from shouting, and repeatedly interrupted by hecklers, Mr Barak tried to convince parliament that giving up Abu Dis was the only way forward, and presented no threat to the existence of the state.

"We are at one of the most important junctions for the future of the country, and its citizens," he told MPs. "The big picture is clear. They are there, and we are here. There must be a division between us. But we have maintained the unity of Israel, and Jerusalem is our capital. "

But he was barely convincing. Mr Barak's argument relied heavily on a recitation of the concessions made by earlier rightwing Likud governments to the Palestinians. He added that the villages constituted barely a quarter of 1% of the 39.8% of the West Bank that has been yielded to Palestinian control so far. After six years of the peace process, such miserly results - only partially alleviated by the transfer of Abu Dis and Azariya, which had been under Palestinian civilian control for some years anyway - is hardly likely to impress yesterday's rioters.

The violence comes just 48 hours after the expiry of another deadline in the peace process, when Israeli and Palestinian negotiatiors were to have unveiled a blueprint that would guide them towards a final peace.

Those missed opportunities, and Israeli refusals to honour its own undertakings to free Palestinian prisoners during the peace process combined to produce yesterday's explosive displays of rage.

The clashes were the worst since September 1996, when 80 Palestinians and Israelis were killed in three days of rioting, ignited by Israel's decision to open a tunnel beneath a Muslim holy place in Jerusalem.

"Where is peace?" said Ali Ismail Abu Subah, a restaurateur who spent three years in Israeli jails, watching the rioting in Manger Street, Bethlehem.

fields.headline: Palestine negotiator quits
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The head of the Palestinian team negotiating with Israel resigned yesterday after discovering that a second set of talks had begun secretly in Sweden.
fields.body:
The head of the Palestinian team negotiating with Israel resigned yesterday after discovering that a second set of talks had begun secretly in Sweden.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is said to have approved the second channel without consulting his chief negotiator, Yasser Abed Rabbo.

Mr Abed Rabbo accused Israel of trying to manipulate the Palestinians by creating an alternative to the official talks.

He said he was resigning "to prevent the existence of more than one negotiating channel and to pave the way for the negotiating team in Stock holm to do this mission alone".

According to Palestinian sources, the Swedish talks were set up by Mr Arafat and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, at their summit meeting last week. The discussions in Stockholm during the past few days are led by Ahmed Qureia, speaker of the Palestinian parliament, on one side, and Shlomo Ben-Ami, the Israeli minister of public security, on the other.

In 1993 Mr Qureia was involved in the secret talks with Israeli officials in Oslo which helped to get the peace process under way. But Mr Abed Rabbo argued yesterday that the situation this time was different.

He said the 1993 talks had to be conducted secretly because Israeli law at the time forbade contact with the Palestine Liberation Organisation, which Israel considered a terrorist organisation. He called the latest secret talks "an Israeli game" aimed at fragmenting the Palestinian position.

It was not clear yesterday whether Mr Arafat would accept Mr Abed Rabbo's resignation. He has refused some resignations in the past, allowing discontented officials to continue working with a clear conscience. But yesterday Mr Abed Rabbo insisted that his resignation was final, whether Mr Arafat accepted it or not.

The establishment of an alternative negotiating channel almost certainly reflects Israeli dissatisfaction with the progress through the official channel.

Equally, Mr Abed Rabbo's resignation, along with the trouble on the streets during the past few days, reflects growing Palestinian hostility to the direction the negotiations have been taking.

The draft maps of a future Palestinian state are dotted and crossed with Israeli settlements and roads and there is no sign yet of a plan for Jerusalem or for the refugee problem which could win public acceptance on both sides.

With no Israeli-Syrian deal to pressure Mr Arafat's negotiators, the Palestinian track appears to be heading for a stalemate or a stitch-up under intense pressure from the US.

webTitle: The day Hezza refused the chance to take on Ken

fields.headline: The day Hezza refused the chance to take on Ken
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague asked Tory grandee Michael Heseltine to join the contest to become London mayor rather than risk having Steve Norris's candidacy self-destruct in scandal as Jeffrey Archer's had, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
William Hague asked Tory grandee Michael Heseltine to join the contest to become London mayor rather than risk having Steve Norris's candidacy self-destruct in scandal as Jeffrey Archer's had, it emerged last night.

Mr Heseltine was the original advocate of directly elected mayors in the 1980s. But the former deputy prime minister, who last month announced his retirement from the Commons at the next election, did not hesitate to reject the Conservative leader's overture - leaving his former ally, Mr Norris, an all-but-clear run.

Mr Hague's initiative, an indication of Tory desperation over the mayoralty, was made in the wake of Lord Archer's resignation over the disclosure of a false alibi concocted during his successful libel action against the Daily Star in 1987.

"The leadership was all over the place, it didn't know whether to give Norris a clear run or to block him. Everyone was afraid of another scandal in which six more mistresses turned up in Parliament Square," one senior insider said last night.

In the event, Mr Norris ran a successful campaign and helped win the Tories their best vote in London for years.

Close Heseltine allies said last night that their hero, who is 67 and busy expanding his Haymarket publishing empire, would not have hesitated in saying no to a hands-on job which might have undermined his health. But his enduring appeal underlines how one-nation Tories are still short of leadership material.

Despite the heart attack which finished his hopes of succeeding John Major in 1997, there was even talk of Kenneth Clarke standing aside for Mr Heseltine when the ex-chancellor's campaign to beat Mr Hague, the candidate of the Tory right, looked doomed in the closing stages. That also came to nothing.

After Lord Archer's fall, party HQ was desperate and names like Archie Norman and Virginia Bottomley were briefly considered. Mr Norris, whose resumed candidacy was briefly blocked by the "blue rinse brigade" before the party chairman, Michael Ancram, reinstated it, would not have allowed either of them a clear run.

But Mr Norris privately concedes that Mr Heseltine, whose leadership bid he backed against Margaret Thatcher in 1990, would have beaten him - though not Mr Livingstone.

webTitle: Now Stelios takes Easy's brand of net café to US and Europe

fields.headline: Now Stelios takes Easy's brand of net café to US and Europe
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: EasyGroup, the company which runs the no-frills airline EasyJet, has set its sights on expanding its chain of internet cafes into the US and Europe.
fields.body:
EasyGroup, the company which runs the no-frills airline EasyJet, has set its sights on expanding its chain of internet cafes into the US and Europe.

The company will use £10m financing secured from investment group, Apax Partners, to part-fund the launch of its EasyEverything stores - which have proved popular in London.

Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the chairman of EasyGroup, said he expected the number of stores to grow from the five existing London operations to 20 by the end of 2000 and as many as 60 by the end of 2001.

Key locations include Paris and New York, and Mr Haji-Ioannou claims that the shops "will roll out in premium, high footfall locations across Europe and the US".

James Rothnie, the director of corporate affairs, confirmed that a flotation of EasyEverything was inevitable at some stage, saying that this was in line with EasyGroup's "masterplan to float individual companies within the group in their own good time".

Mr Rothnie claimed that despite the trend toward cheaper internet access and the development of Wap technology allowing web access via mobile phones, the EasyEverything brand still had a viable long-term future. "The industrial scale internet cafes" developed by EasyEverything he said, meant that it was "carving out a brand new market [which] fostered further expansion".

According to EasyEverthing, its in-store research shows that as many as 25% of all visitors to the five London stores are individuals who not only live in London but also have independent access to the internet at home. Approximately 40% are tourists.

Mr Rothnie predicted that rather than the high levels of internet penetration in the US presenting a threat to the enterprise, it would actually bolster success simply because Americans are "particularly internet literate". A global budget of £9m has been set aside for marketing until the end of 2000.

EasyGroup came to prominence in 1995 with the launch of low-cost carrier EasyJet; a partial float, in November, was announced in January.

webTitle: Programmed for growth RM to meet schools' demand for bandwidth

fields.headline: Programmed for growth RM to meet schools' demand for bandwidth
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: RM, the educational software company, says it stands to benefit from increased government funding of information technology facilities in schools such as Laurelhill College, Lisburn, as well as a lucrative contract in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
RM, the educational software company, says it stands to benefit from increased government funding of information technology facilities in schools such as Laurelhill College, Lisburn, as well as a lucrative contract in Northern Ireland.

After announcing better than expected interim results, chief executive Richard Girling said yesterday that RM would also be looking to expand into the US. "We see more opportunities for acquisitions and partnerships than in the past, particularly in the US, but will still continue to concentrate on organic growth and broadening our product range," he said.

In the six months to March 31 RM recorded pre-tax profits of £1.5m, down from £2.5m on the previous period but still ahead of an alyst expectations. RM's figures are skewed towards the second half as schools spend most of their IT budgets in the summer holidays, in time for the start of the academic year.

Turnover rose 10% to £78.1m, with the interim dividend up 21% at 0.8p per share. Mr Girling said the figures took into account the £2.1m costs of the Classroom 2000 project, which will deliver informa tion and communications technology into schools in Northern Ireland in the first half of this year.

RM is also looking to capture a significant slice of the market for connectivity to schools by offering to double the bandwidth available to existing customers at no extra cost.

The government has pledged to contribute £37m during the present financial year towards the costs accrued by schools getting broadband connections. This is in addition to an increased £168m in funding it has said will be available for software initiatives.

"We are seeing an increased demand by schools for more bandwidth," Mr Girling said. "They want faster access to the internet and the ability to access more exciting educational online content."

fields.body:
 On the ball Computer software company Software4Sport , which sells sports venues and events management applications to customers including Bradford City and Chelsea football clubs, is planning a flotation on AIM which could value the company in excess of £13m.

The company, led by non-executive chairman Michael Jackson, who is also chairman of the Sage Group, plans to raise over £3m from institutional and private investors.

Software4Sport's customer relationship management software products are designed to manage everything from event ticketing to advertising and promotions.

 Fighting talk A report issued by consultant KPMG said yesterday that trusted brands and large customer bases will help traditional banks throughout Europe fend off competition from new entrants in the internet sector. Traditional retail banks have three competitive advantages, the report said - customer traffic, trust and multi-channel access - and were better placed to exploit business on the internet than new entrants and standalone online banking operations.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.standfirst: FilmUnlimited: The mood matcher
fields.trailText: The mood matcher
fields.body:
Feeling the colour of the summer sky, only less sunny? Got the sense that someone else is living the life you'd planned to have, leaving you with the dreggy, thrill-free remainder? Girlfriend, get a video. According to the latest psycho-pop stateside, the right movie can help you work through all manner of subconscious concerns.

Slumping in your crap slippers, grinding crisps into the carpet and finding it increasingly difficult to pour the wine straight is, according to cinematherapy proselytes, a psychologically productive enterprise. But be careful matching movie to mood: Educating Rita for father issues, Body Heat for the recently dumped, Hitchcock for anyone in a dysfunctional relationship. But heaven forfend that a woman with PMT should end up watching Fatal Attraction - she'd doubtless end up boiling more than the kettle.

Or that we be taken in by that most insidious of genres, the faux-weepy, à la Jerry Maguire, slammed as a "gal film that's really a guy film" because it's about a doormat who marries a man who doesn't really love her. Cinematherapists aver that women actually watch and respond to films differently from men. Which is, of course, correct: ladies spend their time wondering if they're doing it with tongues and whether that toilet dolly is available in Bhs, while men are memorising punchlines to re-use endlessly late into the night. Those double-helix chasers are mapping it on to the human genetic code as we speak.

fields.headline: In the wee small hours
fields.trailText: Ultrasoundings
fields.body:
Week 24
This is it, finally. I've definitely got a Complication. I may have failed to manifest much morning sickness, my slightly loose pelvis may have clicked back together as firmly as Barbie's and my blood may abound in iron (thanks, I'm sure, to my diet of steak, chuck steak, minced steak, organic, naturally; the cow had a happy life in deep grass and its sole ambition was to be chucked and minced, it signed the certificate), but I've certainly got pregnancy-related insomnia. Every night, I go to sleep readily, then wake, calmly, naturally and irrevocably, at half past four in the morning. It isn't because the baby kicks me. It isn't because I'm too big to turn over or desperate for the loo. It isn't - and this is strangest of all - because I'm worried about anything, though after an hour of tossing and turning, I can generally rustle up a grudge or two.

It is impervious to all treatment, including: getting up and reading, hot milk, just lying there, walks round the block, relaxation exercises, deep breathing and the cure you're thinking of. Recently I've found lying on the dining room floor and having a full-scale tantrum most effective.

It's been going on for three weeks now. My eyes are red and my face grey and strangely stiff. My short-term memory is shot and my mind flits from object to object, leaving me staring into space. I must be a very dreary conversationalist because I am permanently on satellite phone: words echo in my head and there's a delay before I can think of an appropriate reply. I leave my shopping at the checkout. I've smashed half the wedding presents on the kitchen tiles.

But the midwife assures me that, as Complications go, this is minor and very common. The doctor jokes that it's a good preparation for life with the baby. Some experts think it's caused by hormones, others the demands of the baby's metabolism. It's not worth investigating since I'm not allowed any drugs anyway. It's no excuse, in other words, and if I had a proper job, I'd still be doing it, every day.

It's quite a thought. I'm always vague, but at the moment I'm dangerous. If I were taking care of a young child, I'd have damaged it by now. If I were doing anything that required motor control, such as using a sewing machine or a nuclear safety system, my hand would have slipped. The Horses of the Apocalypse, I expect, will be absent-mindedly unleashed by someone with pregnancy-induced insomnia. I'm glad I'm not teaching at the moment - I'd be ripping some child's self-esteem to shreds, laying into my colleagues and leaving the coursework in Tesco.

At least I wouldn't worry about losing my job. In teaching, no one else would want it. But imagine if I had a corporate or city job, one with a suit, glass elevator, glass ceiling. I would have lost contracts, contacts, my rag, my secretary. My colleagues would be tutting at me, pitying me, resenting me, and they would have reason because I'd be leaning on them. I would be noted down as someone not coping with pregnancy. The firm would start to ask about how I would deal with returning to work. The glass ceiling would thicken and lower. Other women would feel I was letting the side down, proving that women can't cope. Whatever my beliefs about employment rights, I would start to feel the same.

I am very lucky. The line between coping and not coping is actually very thin. I can still do a day's work because I'm freelance: I can write through those strange blank hours in the middle of the night and nap in the day. I can lie down and stare at the ceiling when I feel giddy, store up my emails and excise bonkers remarks before sending them off. My financial disasters are limited to shopping and my bile is reserved for Henry the Cat who, though he has a fine line in wide-eyed outraged expressions, has a tenuous grasp of English and rarely holds grudges.

And, of course, I get to complain in public. From smugly outside the corporate structure, I can boldly say that inflexible employers, brutal hours and a culture of presenteeism discriminate against women and oppress families. Perhaps, as a freelance, I shouldn't be allowed to comment. But who else would? Women inside the structure have to keep quiet.

In fact, women everywhere keep silent about all sorts of pain associated with childbirth. Like pregnancy-related insomnia, for example. Had you ever heard of it? I hadn't. As I wail to the dining room floor during my tantrums, I should have been told.
fields.bodyText: Week 24 This is it, finally. I've definitely got a Complication. I may have failed to manifest much morning sickness, my slightly loose pelvis may have clicked back together as firmly as Barbie's and my blood may abound in iron (thanks, I'm sure, to my diet of steak, chuck steak, minced steak, organic, naturally; the cow had a happy life in deep grass and its sole ambition was to be chucked and minced, it signed the certificate), but I've certainly got pregnancy-related insomnia. Every night, I go to sleep readily, then wake, calmly, naturally and irrevocably, at half past four in the morning. It isn't because the baby kicks me. It isn't because I'm too big to turn over or desperate for the loo. It isn't - and this is strangest of all - because I'm worried about anything, though after an hour of tossing and turning, I can generally rustle up a grudge or two. It is impervious to all treatment, including: getting up and reading, hot milk, just lying there, walks round the block, relaxation exercises, deep breathing and the cure you're thinking of. Recently I've found lying on the dining room floor and having a full-scale tantrum most effective. It's been going on for three weeks now. My eyes are red and my face grey and strangely stiff. My short-term memory is shot and my mind flits from object to object, leaving me staring into space. I must be a very dreary conversationalist because I am permanently on satellite phone: words echo in my head and there's a delay before I can think of an appropriate reply. I leave my shopping at the checkout. I've smashed half the wedding presents on the kitchen tiles. But the midwife assures me that, as Complications go, this is minor and very common. The doctor jokes that it's a good preparation for life with the baby. Some experts think it's caused by hormones, others the demands of the baby's metabolism. It's not worth investigating since I'm not allowed any drugs anyway. It's no excuse, in other words, and if I had a proper job, I'd still be doing it, every day. It's quite a thought. I'm always vague, but at the moment I'm dangerous. If I were taking care of a young child, I'd have damaged it by now. If I were doing anything that required motor control, such as using a sewing machine or a nuclear safety system, my hand would have slipped. The Horses of the Apocalypse, I expect, will be absent-mindedly unleashed by someone with pregnancy-induced insomnia. I'm glad I'm not teaching at the moment - I'd be ripping some child's self-esteem to shreds, laying into my colleagues and leaving the coursework in Tesco. At least I wouldn't worry about losing my job. In teaching, no one else would want it. But imagine if I had a corporate or city job, one with a suit, glass elevator, glass ceiling. I would have lost contracts, contacts, my rag, my secretary. My colleagues would be tutting at me, pitying me, resenting me, and they would have reason because I'd be leaning on them. I would be noted down as someone not coping with pregnancy. The firm would start to ask about how I would deal with returning to work. The glass ceiling would thicken and lower. Other women would feel I was letting the side down, proving that women can't cope. Whatever my beliefs about employment rights, I would start to feel the same. I am very lucky. The line between coping and not coping is actually very thin. I can still do a day's work because I'm freelance: I can write through those strange blank hours in the middle of the night and nap in the day. I can lie down and stare at the ceiling when I feel giddy, store up my emails and excise bonkers remarks before sending them off. My financial disasters are limited to shopping and my bile is reserved for Henry the Cat who, though he has a fine line in wide-eyed outraged expressions, has a tenuous grasp of English and rarely holds grudges. And, of course, I get to complain in public. From smugly outside the corporate structure, I can boldly say that inflexible employers, brutal hours and a culture of presenteeism discriminate against women and oppress families. Perhaps, as a freelance, I shouldn't be allowed to comment. But who else would? Women inside the structure have to keep quiet. fields.headline: Material witness
fields.standfirst: British car workers have won public sympathy and government support as their industry has crumbled, but there is another crisis going on in manufacturing, one involving equally devastating job losses. So why haven't we heard about it?  Mel Steel reports
fields.trailText: British car workers have won public sympathy and government support as their industry has crumbled, but there is another crisis going on in manufacturing, one involving equally devastating job losses. So why haven't we heard about it?  Mel Steel reports
fields.body:
First Longbridge, then Dagenham. If there's anyone left in the country who hasn't heard that there's a crisis in the car industry, chances are they are equally oblivious to the fact that Ken Livingstone is mayor of London. Yet there's another crisis going on in manufacturing which has escaped most people's attention. This industry is the eighth largest manufacturer in the UK. It employs around 300,000 workers: more than farming, more than the car industry, more than chemicals. Job losses ran to over 41,000 last year, another 25,000 are expected this year, and most of those made redundant are Labour-voting breadwinners in areas of high unemployment. But we're not talking cars or coal or farming or steel. We're talking textiles. And we're talking women.

Maggie Rowley worked as a machinist for Coates Viyella, a major supplier to Marks & Spencer, for 20 years. She was one of 450 women made redundant 18 months ago, when M&S moved to Morocco its manufacturing base for the trousers on which she worked. Her factory was one of two in Rossington, an old mining village outside Doncaster. On the one road into the village is the pit where her brothers, all miners, were once employed; one still is, the rest work on chicken farms.

Rowley's is a fairly typical story. She was lucky enough to get another textiles job after the factory closed. It meant two bus journeys to work and the minimum wage in a non-union factory, but her husband was on long-term sick and she was the wage-earner, so she didn't have a choice.

She was made redundant from that job, too. Now she works in a lighting components factory, still two bus journeys away, still non-union. She can't see any chance of working in textiles again and neither can most of the women with whom she worked. "In my factory, we had grandmothers, mothers and daughters all working together," she says. "We were very close-knit, very involved in the miners' strike, 100% union membership. I was proud of my time there; we had a strong workforce and produced quality garments. But there was no investment, no training, no planning. Now we're losing a whole industry and it's devastating."

As for the car workers: "Don't get me wrong, I feel for them, I really do. I just wish we could get the same publicity. The thing is, they're focused in one area, whereas we're scattered. And we're women."

Many workers believe their plight has considerably more to do with gender than geography. Among them is Maxine Nixon, North West representative for the GMB clothing and textile section. Born and bred in the mill town of Oldham, and a textile worker since she left school at 15, she sees Labour's neglect of the issue as unforgivable. "It doesn't matter that the job losses are scattered - 40,000 is 40,000, wherever they are. I genuinely believe this isn't being taken as seriously as Longbridge because it's a women's industry. If we were men, something would have been done about it years ago."

The unions agree. The GMB has already accused the government of sexism over its failure to offer the same kind of rescue package to the textile industry as it has to cars, coal and farming. Textiles union KFAT, while fighting shy of using the S word, is equally furious. But while trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has hastily put together a strategy group, there is no promise of immediate government intervention to help with widespread redundancies.

It might make less spectacular headlines than Longbridge or Dagenham, but the fact that textile workers are scattered does not lessen the impact of redundancy. While a quarter of the industry is based in the east Midlands, there are significant centres in Yorkshire, Lancashire, Scotland and south Wales. Most of these are traditional mining heartlands, where textile plants have replaced pits as the main employers. Around the same time as the closure of the Coates Viyella factory at which Rowley worked, the plants in Wretford, 10 miles away, and Missterton were also shut. Not counting closures in Doncaster itself, 1,000 textile jobs have gone in the area.

In south Wales, where Bairdwear Textiles, another M&S supplier, has shut down all its plants, 4,500 jobs have been lost. Ann Leader, who worked at the Baird factory in Maesteg until Christmas, says she is fortunate that her children have been able to help out. "People automatically assume men are the breadwinners," she says. "But that's not the case. It hasn't been for years. We're not talking about pin money. It's women who are keeping their families."

One of the major problems for women in these areas is accessibility. In south Wales, as in other mining communities, textile factories were set up precisely where there was a small, local workforce desperate for a full-time wage. Women could get to work without travelling and many of them didn't have transport. Now they are stuck. What jobs there are available are part-time, poorly paid and unskilled. Some women have moved into shop or care work, some into components factories, a few back into education. There are new call centres in Cardiff and Swansea, but getting there is a problem.

It's the same story in Scotland. Ruby Murray has just lost her job at the Baird plant in Grangemouth, Stirlingshire. Her daughter, sister and best friend worked there, too. "We're looking at devastation," she says. "I'm disgusted at the way Blair has handled Rover. When our plant closed, not even our local MP turned up. We're talking about single parents, we're talking about women who were sole breadwinners. Most of those women are now unemployed. If you can't drive, there are no jobs. We'll never get the industry saved in Britain without government intervention. And there has been no intervention because we're women."

KFAT has warned: "If the government pays just lip service to the forthcoming report, we will be very angry indeed." Most of the women who have lost their jobs, their skills and their chance of a decent wage are already angry. It's just that no one's listening.

webTitle: Ford drive to recoup lost market share

fields.headline: Ford drive to recoup lost market share
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford hopes to push back its share of the European car market to above 10% within three years. This follows the restructuring of its operations - which included the shutdown of its car assembly plant at Dagenham in east London.
fields.body:
Ford hopes to push back its share of the European car market to above 10% within three years.

This follows the restructuring of its operations - which included the shutdown of its car assembly plant at Dagenham in east London.

Ford commands about 8.6% of the market, a much reduced figure from the near 12% share it used to enjoy in the 1980s.

The US car company wants to increase the number of new models designed to appeal to European consumers, according to a report pub lished in the Wall Street Journal yesterday.

The company believes that it can speed up the time it takes to bring a car to market - from the moment it is designed to the point where it reaches the showroom.

The newspaper noted that Ford also wishes to reposition itself as a manufacturer of "elite" models in Europe, even in the light of its announcement on Friday of production cuts.

First in the line of launches is the new Mondeo, which is due out this autumn.

The Mondeo has lost out to VW's Passat in many countries, but the company hopes to reverse that trend by employing design and marketing tactics which have won plaudits for the Focus, which is Ford's most highly rated car.
