webTitle: Lawyer wants World Online float nullified

fields.headline: Lawyer wants World Online float nullified
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A Dutch lawyer yesterday filed a suit against World Online, its former chairwoman Nina Brink and ABN Amro, a lead manager of the internet service provider's now infamous initial public offering (IPO).
fields.body:
A Dutch lawyer yesterday filed a suit against World Online, its former chairwoman Nina Brink and ABN Amro, a lead manager of the internet service provider's now infamous initial public offering (IPO).

The lawyer, Bob van der Goen, said he was acting for more than 1,000 clients who wanted answers to questions surrounding the company's flotation, and that the answers would be used to claim damages.

Mr van der Goen alleged that the IPO prospectus omitted key details such as Brink's involvement in five bankruptcies, including one still active in Belgium. "The ultimate goal is to get the whole IPO nullified for my clients ... to declare the IPO null and void."

Mr van der Goen said he was particularly concerned about disclosures that A-Line Data Belgium, a company he said was chaired until recently by Ms Brink, was in bankruptcy proceedings in Belgium. There was no mention of this in the prospectus.

Ms Brink denied any involvement in the daily management of A-Line Data Bel gium, and said it was not her responsibility to include it in the prospectus.

"I have not worked for A-Line since September 1995. And that was A-Line Holland, not A-Line Data Belgium," she said. "I was never the chairwoman of that company."

She said she might have been listed in company documents because she was a stakeholder and that the reason the bankruptcy, initiated in 1994, was still open was because of a cross-action against a supplier. It was a "clean bankruptcy".

On allegations about the other five bankrupt companies, she said that while she might have been an investor and on the boards of several companies that went bankrupt, it was not her responsibility to detail that information in the prospectus. "You are only responsible for things if there is fraud _ There was never any question of an investigation. This is such a character assassination."

World Online said it was not aware of Ms Brink's alleged involvement in bankruptcies and would contest the suit. ABN Amro was unavailable for comment. Reuters

webTitle: Airlines call for expansion at gridlock airports

fields.headline: Airlines call for expansion at gridlock airports
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government was warned last night that Heathrow and Gatwick airports are bursting at the seams. Demand will exceed capacity by more than 18 million passengers over the next five years.
fields.body:
The government was warned last night that Heathrow and Gatwick airports are bursting at the seams. Demand will exceed capacity by more than 18 million passengers over the next five years.

Britain's 10 largest airlines, - including British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and British Midland - said unsatisfied demand at both airports would reach 60 million passengers in 30 years, even if Heathrow's fifth terminal were built.

Roger Wiltshire, secretary of the British Air Transport Association, said that an independent study commissioned by the association, showed that the UK's most popular airports "are heading for gridlock unless more capacity can be created."

He welcomed the government's initiative to explore the scope for developing regional airports. But "the inescapable fact is that passengers are being turned away in massive numbers from the London area airports from which they want to fly."

Mr Wiltshire pointed out the threat posed by Britain's neighbours in Europe, particularly Paris and Amsterdam. "While we in the UK are still considering what to do about more capacity, they are getting on with it."

The government has promised a statement on airport capacity, but it is being held up by the public inquiry into terminal five at Heathrow. Ministers say publishing their views before the inquiry inspector has reported could be prejudicial to his report.

The options appear to be a further expansion at Stansted or Luton, a second runway at Gatwick, and a possible third main runway at Heathrow.

webTitle: UK troops 'will stay out of civil war in Sierra Leone'

fields.headline: UK troops 'will stay out of civil war in Sierra Leone'
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said yesterday that there was no question of UK troops being drawn into the civil war in Sierra Leone as he faced more demands to clarify British intentions in the Commonwealth country.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Chris McGreal in Freetown
fields.body:
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said yesterday that there was no question of UK troops being drawn into the civil war in Sierra Leone as he faced more demands to clarify British intentions in the Commonwealth country.

In a Commons statement, Mr Hoon declined to set a time limit on the presence of UK troops in the country, saying only they "will stay no longer than is necessary".

In the capital Freetown, it was reported that UK forces could soon supply ammunition to government troops fighting rebels of the the Revolutionary United Front.

Mr Hoon's statement - designed to counter opposition fears of "mission creep" - coincided with reports that 139 of an estimated 500 UN peacekeepers being held by rebels had been released.

The release was brokered by Charles Taylor, the Liberian president. In return, he has asked the US and UK for financial aid and an end to the arms embargo against his government. He has also warned the UN that if the assault is kept up on the RUF, it could endanger the lives of the peacekeepers still being held.

Mr Taylor, who is the RUF's chief foreign backer, appears to have persuaded the UN representative in Freetown, Oluyemi Adeniji, that the best option would be to allow the RUF to administer areas it controlled at the time of the peace accords last July.

British military chiefs oppose the idea, believing it would hold the country hostage to the peacekeepers' fate and detract from the need to cut off the RUF from the diamond mines that fund its war.

Mr Hoon, who said the role of 700 British paratroopers was expected to end next month, told MPs: "There is no question of the UK taking over the UN mission or being drawn into the civil war".

But he said that even after a withdrawal of British troops, "we will continue ... to help train and build effective ... Sierra Leonean armed forces."

In Freetown, General Sir Charles Guthrie, the chief of the defence staff, said Sierra Leone had made no formal request for ammunition. "We have no plans to do it," he said.

Iain Duncan-Smith, the shadow defence secretary, said that with reports of special forces operating in the countryside and patrolling Freetown, British officers are "to all intents and purposes" running the day-to-day UN operation.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Lloyd Evans's afternoon play Zero Tolerance (2.15pm, Radio 4) is a splendidly witty romp built around the curious fact that Italy's use of Roman numerals lasted well into the 14th century. When Lorenzo, a young Venetian mathematician, encourages the Doge to update the city's tax system by adopting the Arab cipher, he unleashes the wrath of the Vatican. In short order he finds himself on the rack and the city preparing for a religious war.

Russell Davies launches three hour-long programmes devoted to Tony Bennett - The Art Of Excellence (9pm, Radio 2). His biography is almost a showbiz cliché - made fatherless in the Depression, brought up by his seamstress mum, he was a singing waiter whose voice impressed his wartime buddies. The big break came when a friend dug out a discarded song for Bennett's 1961 appearance in San Francisco. It told how the singer had left his heart there - two Grammy awards mark the spot.

fields.standfirst:
Concession on RUC name change unlikely to sway rebels

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, last night appeared to have secured a victory of sorts in his battle to retain the RUC's name, but it seemed too little to quash a groundswell of opposition within his party to a return to government with Sinn Fein next Monday.
fields.body:
David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, last night appeared to have secured a victory of sorts in his battle to retain the RUC's name, but it seemed too little to quash a groundswell of opposition within his party to a return to government with Sinn Fein next Monday.

Government sources indicated that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, would reserve the power to rule on the force's name when the policing bill is published today. It means at most a temporary reprieve, for he is adamant the name will change next year.

But Mr Trimble could choose to sell the development as a government concession in an attempt to persuade his ruling party council on Saturday to back the restoration of devolution two days later. There was no sign last night that he was ready to do so.

The controversial flags issue was resolved in a similar manner. MPs will tonight debate an order giving Mr Mandelson the power to intervene where local parties fail to agree on which flags should fly over government buildings on designated days.

Ulster Unionists are happier with that solution. They expect Mr Mandelson to outline his preference for the union flag tonight, and it appeared yesterday that Sinn Fein would reluctantly acquiesce.

But there will be no debate on the policing bill until next week.

One senior Ulster Unionist said: "It's smoke and mirrors. The name will change to the Police Service of Northern Ireland next year, as the government always planned. It's only the announcement that is being delayed."

Mr Mandelson also announced he was setting up the Royal Ulster Constabulary George Cross Foundation, which he said would mark the sacrifices and honour the achievements of the 78-year-old force. Ulster Unionists welcomed it, but pointed out it had been under discussion for some time and said it would not change many minds.

The British and Irish government attempts to prompt a return to devolution next Monday were also hit after Mr Trimble met with IRA weapons inspectors Cyril Ramaphosa, the former secretary general of the African National Congress, and Martti Ahtisaari, the ex-Finnish president. They met with Tony Blair, Mr Mandelson and Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign affairs minister, and the political parties in Belfast.

Mr Trimble suggested that putting arms beyond use, as the IRA had promised to do, could only be an initial step towards formal decommissioning, not a permanent solution.

John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, said yesterday: "I feel downhearted compared to a week ago. I always had reservations, but they have increased in the past eight days rather than decreased. The government is dragging its feet."

David Burnside, the PR guru who forwarded the motion to tie a return to government to retention of the RUC's name, said it was too early to judge whether Mr Trimble would even forward a motion seeking to go back into the executive. There would be no point, as matters stood.

Mr Burnside, who confirmed that he was considering standing for the vacant south Antrim seat, is, like Mr Taylor, regarded as critical. Their doubts underscored last night's sense of crisis.

Sources from the two governments are deeply disappointed at Mr Trimble's failure to seize the initiative and sell the IRA's unprecedented offer on arms to his party. They fear he will have lost too much ground if he leaves it until late in the week.

webTitle: Mugabe finally sets date for election

fields.headline: Mugabe finally sets date for election
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's long delayed parliamentary elections will be held on the weekend of June 24 and 25, according to a government notice issued yesterday. Both the ruling party and the opposition welcomed the news, expressing the hope that the ballot would end the violence that has claimed 20 lives since April 1.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's long delayed parliamentary elections will be held on the weekend of June 24 and 25, according to a government notice issued yesterday. Both the ruling party and the opposition welcomed the news, expressing the hope that the ballot would end the violence that has claimed 20 lives since April 1.

The announcement of the date came as the Commonwealth secretary-general, Don McKinnon, arrived in Harare to discuss sending observers to monitor the ballot. A delegation from the EU is also in Zimbabwe to arrange for observers to monitor the vote.

The elections will give President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party its toughest electoral challenge since it came to power 20 years ago at the country's independence. The public was not informed of the election in the state-owned news media yesterday, but the date was announced in the government gazette.

The 150-seat parliament dissolved on April 11, ending a five-year term. Under the constitution, elections must be held within four months of parliament's adjournment.

Just last month, the delimitation commission formed to update the country's hopelessly outdated voter lists and to set new electoral boundaries said that it would need three months to accomplish its mission before elections could be called.

But the local media reported on Monday that at least some of the boundaries had been set, and Zimbabwe's urban areas, where Mr Mugabe's support has been traditionally weak, will lose seats to his rural strongholds.

The president's party has already launched a vicious campaign of intimidation across the country, in which 20 opposition supporters have been killed by Zanu-PF supporters and thousands have been beaten and tortured. The invasion of more than 1,200 white-owned farms by Zanu-PF supporters is the centrepiece of the party's platform, as poor black people have been promised the farmland.

"Yes, the elections will be held in June," said Jonathon Moyo, a Zanu-PF spokesman. "We are looking forward to the elections. We are the only party with candidates in all constituencies. Our campaign is to give people what they fought for and have waited for for 20 years: ownership and control of the basic means of production, which is land."

Mr Moyo downplayed the campaign violence, saying that it had been much less than in South Africa's elections. "The violence in South Africa last year between the ANC and Inkatha was without parallel in all of Africa. Yet the international community deemed those elections to be free and fair. So I think that the violence here, while it has been regrettable, should not jeopardise these elections."

Zimbabwe's leading opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) also welcomed the announcement of the election date. "It doesn't give us a lot of time to prepare, but for five years the people of Zimbabwe have known that change must come, and for the past four months they have seen that change will come from the MDC," said a party spokesman, Learnmore Jongwe. "We are in these elections to win and we are confident we will form the next government."

The MDC's president, Morgan Tsvangirai, was in South Africa yesterday.

"Clearly free and fair elections cannot be held in this climate of intimidation, but we will contest the elections to allow people to vote for change. People will vote on hope, not on fear."

David Coltard, an MDC official running for parliament in the south-western town of Bulawayo, also said the prospect of fair elections was scant. "With the amount of violence that has gone on, with the total denial of access to the media, with the fact that we have not had an opportunity to look at the voter rolls yet, there is just no way that a free and fair elections can be held," Mr Coltard said.

The party urged the international community to press the Mugabe government to accept substantial numbers of election monitors, so that people will have some confidence that their vote will be secret.

webTitle: New bid could value Hyder at £465m

fields.headline: New bid could value Hyder at £465m
fields.trailText: Western Power Distribution, the US group vying with Nomura for control of Hyder, the debt-laden Welsh utility, is expected to launch its formal bid for Wales's biggest plc later this week despite growing concerns it would be referred to the competition authorities.
fields.body:
Western Power Distribution, the US group vying with Nomura for control of Hyder, the debt-laden Welsh utility, is expected to launch its formal bid for Wales's biggest plc later this week despite growing concerns it would be referred to the competition authorities.

Hyder, which has accepted a bid worth £400m from Nomura, the Japanese bank, could be subject to a counter-bid that the analysts reckon will reach £465m or 300p a share.

Nomura's advisers insist that any such move by WPD, an elec tricity distribution company owned by PPL and Southern Co, would be sent to the competition commission following remarks by water industry regulator Ian Byatt last week.

Mr Byatt, who has taken a tougher stance over competition in the run-up to his retirement this summer, appeared to pour cold water on WPD's plans for Hyder. The US group plans to hive off Hyder's main asset, Welsh Water, into a non-profit, mutual company managed and operated by United Utilities, the group based in north-west England. The move is an echo of a similar scheme by Kelda, owners of Yorkshire Water, to split its own business.

Mr Byatt said the separation of assets from operations, more debt financing and mutual ownership would require new licence conditions and raise several regulatory issues.

Nomura, which has been cresting a wave of local support for its offer - especially its repeated reassurance that it envisages no job losses above the 1,000 already put in train by Hyder, insists the WPD approach would fail to meet any of Mr Byatt's strictures. "There's no way that their bid isn't going to be referred," one insider said.

But WPD yesterday reiterated it was confident it could meet Mr Byatt's concerns. "We share his view that any structural legal changes should not impede the primary objectives of maximising efficiency," it said.

But its advisers refused to comment on any likely bid this week or on reports that Citicorp, the US bank, has stepped in with financial backing for WPD after the sudden withdrawal of Barclays Capital, two weeks ago.

Nomura insiders said: "Let's see their cash; make it real. We have offered shareholders money and they know it's for real; all Hyder stakeholders gain under our offer and welcome it."

fields.headline: Granadaland chutzpah turns to chill
fields.standfirst: Media group may suffer
fields.trailText: The untimely disclosure through these pages of the plan to merge Granada with contract cater Compass and then to split the monolith between media and hospitality left the market gasping for more information yesterday - and market participants lacking firm facts always tend to make them up themselves.
fields.body:
The untimely disclosure through these pages of the plan to merge Granada with contract cater Compass and then to split the monolith between media and hospitality left the market gasping for more information yesterday - and market participants lacking firm facts always tend to make them up themselves.

There were immediate concerns that Compass risks being landed with some unattractive businesses, not to mention disappointment over the likely terms of its nil-premium takeover by Granada.

For Granada, however, it was a no-brainer. Despite the patience of the company's shareholders, demerger of the media and hospitality businesses has long been inevitable and the combination with Compass gives the catering and hotels arm the muscle to compete with the largest in the world.

But for all the chutzpah, Granada looks more than a little exposed when stripped of its hospitality business.

It no longer dwarfs its smaller competitors - last year it had revenues of just under £1bn compared to Carlton Communications, which had turnover of £1.9bn - although that, too, will be diminished by the sale of Technicolor, also an effort to clear the decks for the fight to control ITV.

The prospect of demerger underlines just how vital it will be for Granada chief executive Charles Allen to regain the initiative in the fight for dominance of ITV. Mr Allen's determination is not in doubt, as the Compass deal itself proves, and investors have had little cause so far to complain about Granada's deal-making abilities.

But if he fails in an attempt to wrest either Carlton or United News & Media from their putative merger, Granada will be left very much a minority shareholder in the network.

Not only that, but with the exception of LWT, Granada holds less valuable northern franchises which attract lower advertising premiums.

More worrying still is the potential effect on Granada's programming business, which fills more than 50% of the network's airtime. Carlton and United will clearly need to carry programmes such as Coronation Street, Blind Date and Emmerdale, but there is a likelihood that other programming could be squeezed out by a newly dominant company and replaced with their own. A Granada media business clinging to the bottom of the FTSE 100 would seem an attractive morsel for one of the larger players on mainland Europe.

But then we really must assume that Mr Allen has thought all this through long in advance.

Liquidity query

Something rather odd is happening in the rough old world of foreign exchange trading: liquidity is on the wane.

In some currencies where competition used to be fierce, only a handful of banks are now prepared to quote prices. Even in the big currency pairs, like sterling-dollar, deals that could be done in a twinkling are now sticky. Worse, when big business is transacted it tends to impact on underlying currency prices.

Market insiders point to a recent deal in sterling-yen. Because business be tween these currencies is relatively small, the deal had to be done in two parts: sterling-dollar and then dollar-yen. Although chunky it was hardly off the scale, yet the transaction is said to have moved prices by about 2%.

In financial markets the resulting volatility from all this raises the cost of capital for everyone, so the factors at work are worth examining.

Banks are said to be turning more of their resources towards equity markets in search of quick returns, rather than playing the foreign exchange market - and that matters when the intrabank market has traditionally been the engine of the foreign exchange market.

Falling liquidity, meanwhile, feeds on itself. As it shrinks, banks cut their exposure further.

Ironically, however, a key factor in the fall in liquidity has been the scaling back of the activities of those forex scourges - the hedge funds. Even George Soros is now out of the market, with reports yesterday suggesting the speculator's flagship Quantum Fund, which is being turned into a conservative long-term investment fund, is now 90% cash.

Of course, lower liquidity presents the European Central Bank with an opportunity to get more bang for its bucks if it wants to redress the perceived imbalance in the dollar-euro exchange rate.

But while intervention might move the euro by say 5%, holding it there is another matter, and there is also the danger that it might ease the pressure for structural reforms in euroland - the lack of which lies at the heart of the currency's woes. On top of this comes the worry that an excessive market shock might further damage confidence.

These are tough days for central bankers as well as the foreign exchange traders. We should, perhaps, feel a little sympathy for them.

webTitle: It's Kraft v Evian in battle for top cookie company

fields.headline: It's Kraft v Evian in battle for top cookie company
fields.trailText: At least three companies are understood to have made offers for all or part of the food business belonging to Nabisco, the US tobacco and food group.
fields.body:
At least three companies are understood to have made offers for all or part of the food business belonging to Nabisco, the US tobacco and food group.

Philip Morris, the tobacco company which also owns Kraft, and Danone - the French dairy products, biscuits and Evian water empire - are vying for the entire Nabisco food business.

Nabisco is best-known for its Oreo biscuits, Ritz crackers and Planters peanuts. It also has a sizeable confectionary arm, which is understood to be a target for Britain's Cadbury Schweppes.

Danone acknowledged yesterday that it was involved in preliminary talks but Philip Morris and Cadbury refused to confirm their interest.

The auction underlines the extent of consolidation in the global food business. Bestfoods, another US food group, is considering a bid offer from Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer group.

Shares in Nabisco Group Holdings rose more than 10% yesterday morning on the first reports of the auction.

After selling off the RJ Reynolds tobacco business last year, the group's sole asset is an 81% stake in Nabisco, which is America's largest biscuit and cracker company. The group was restructured to limit potential liabilities from anti-tobacco litigation in the US.

The group is also subject to a takeover offer from Carl Icahn, the financier known for corporate raiding in the 1980s, who has offered $22 a share.

If Mr Icahn loses out to the trade buyers, his 10% stake in the company is still likely to earn him a profit.

Analysts believe that the winning bid for the food business could be as high as $50 a share, a market value of $15bn. Any deal for the group must ring-fence any future legal liabilities from the tobacco business. It is expected to be structured so as to leave a shell with a large cash sum to settle tobacco claims.

Diane D'Oleon, a spokeswoman for Danone, said yesterday that the group was "interested" in the food business. "We're at the stage of studying the dossier and holding preliminary discussions," she said.

Although it refused to comment last night, Cadbury Schweppes has made no secret of its long-term international strategy for expansion.

webTitle: Deutsche Bank subsidiary faces Tokyo suspension

fields.headline: Deutsche Bank subsidiary faces Tokyo suspension
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank faces possible sanctions in Tokyo for allegedly selling financial instruments that helped clients to conceal their losses. Japan's securities watchdog, the SESC, has passed the file to the country's financial supervisory agency (FSA) with a recommendation for action.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank faces possible sanctions in Tokyo for allegedly selling financial instruments that helped clients to conceal their losses. Japan's securities watchdog, the SESC, has passed the file to the country's financial supervisory agency (FSA) with a recommendation for action.

Last year, Credit Suisse was severely punished after an inquiry into its sale of similar products was frustrated by a "shredding party" in which local staff destroyed sensitive documents to prevent regulators from seeing them.

The products themselves were not found by the Japanese authorities to be illegal, though Credit Suisse admitted they were "inappropriate". The withdrawal of an operating licence from the subsidiary concerned related to the shredding rather than the products.

What was not immediately clear last night was the extent to which Deutsche's products mirrored those sold by Credit Suisse. Nor was it certain whether Deutsche's products would fall foul of tighter rules implemented in the wake of Japan's banking scandals of the late 1990s.

Banking sources told Reuters in Tokyo that the FSA was likely to order the Deutsche Securities subsidiary to suspend some business, such as bond trading, for several weeks and to improve its operations.

The SESC accused Deutsche Securities of offering three corporate clients a scheme that allowed them to conceal losses suffered on bond holdings. It also alleged that between November 1998 and October 1999, Deutsche Securities did not submit transaction reports on some orders for futures trading from its parent.
fields.bodyText: Deutsche Bank faces possible sanctions in Tokyo for allegedly selling financial instruments that helped clients to conceal their losses. Japan's securities watchdog, the SESC, has passed the file to the country's financial supervisory agency (FSA) with a recommendation for action. Last year, Credit Suisse was severely punished after an inquiry into its sale of similar products was frustrated by a "shredding party" in which local staff destroyed sensitive documents to prevent regulators from seeing them. The products themselves were not found by the Japanese authorities to be illegal, though Credit Suisse admitted they were "inappropriate". The withdrawal of an operating licence from the subsidiary concerned related to the shredding rather than the products. What was not immediately clear last night was the extent to which Deutsche's products mirrored those sold by Credit Suisse. Nor was it certain whether Deutsche's products would fall foul of tighter rules implemented in the wake of Japan's banking scandals of the late 1990s. Banking sources told Reuters in Tokyo that the FSA was likely to order the Deutsche Securities subsidiary to suspend some business, such as bond trading, for several weeks and to improve its operations. The SESC accused Deutsche Securities of offering three corporate clients a scheme that allowed them to conceal losses suffered on bond holdings. It also alleged that between November 1998 and October 1999, Deutsche Securities did not submit transaction reports on some orders for futures trading from its parent.

fields.headline: New poll shock for Labour
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives have cut Labour's opinion poll lead to seven points - the lowest since the general election - according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
The Conservatives have cut Labour's opinion poll lead to seven points - the lowest since the general election - according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

The survey is the third poll in a week to register a sharp drop in Labour support, and confirms an anti-government shift in the mood of the voters in the wake of the local election losses and the election of Ken Livingstone as the mayor of London.

The ICM poll, taken between Saturday and Monday, puts Labour on 41% (down four points on last month); the Conservatives on 34% (up two); the Liberal Democrats on 18% (up three) and others on 7% (down one). Labour's lead over the Tories was 13 points in April.

This evidence that William Hague is finally finding some momentum coincided last night with a warning from Tom, now Lord, Sawyer, Labour's former party general secretary and a leading architect of its modernisation, that Tony Blair's "command leadership style" is no longer appropriate and is leaving many Labour members and MPs feeling cast aside.

Lord Sawyer, who was central to the reforms of both Neil Kinnock and Mr Blair, also urged the prime minister to appoint a powerful party chairman to coordinate the sometimes warring factions in party and government. He suggested that the party's leadership needed to rebalance its rhetoric and show greater respect for Labour's traditions and achievements.

The four-point fall in Labour's poll position to 41% - for the first time below its May 1997 general election performance of 44% - is the second opinion poll in the last week to show the party's lead being squeezed sharply. The first was a private ICM poll for Conservative central office. A third poll, a Gallup for the Daily Telegraph, published on Friday showed a much bigger Labour lead but also registered a three-point drop in support for the government.

Conservative strategists believe that Mr Hague's tough talk on asylum and law and order lie behind Labour's drop in the polls, and hope that the four years of "flatlining" during which the Tories' poll rating has wavered only a point or two around the 30% mark may be over.

The ICM poll also shows that most of the cabinet big-hitters have suffered sharp falls in their popularity in the last month, and that Mr Blair is only just an electoral asset to the party.

Lord Sawyer's remarks last night are probably the most critical to emerge from party modernisers since the local and devolved election reverses this month. He retired as general secretary after the 1997 election and Downing Street is bound to take his criticisms seriously.

There has been a growing clamour inside the party for a change in tone from Mr Blair, with calls for him to pay greater heed to Labour's traditional supporters, especially in its heartland seats.

In a speech in London, Lord Sawyer claimed that at present the Labour "party machine, the political leader's office, the cabinet office, the No 10 policy unit, the whips office and the parliamentary Labour party remain disconnected, separate and sometimes in competition, when they should be tightly focused and working together"

He suggested that the present concept of a party moderniser at the helm, with "a party harmoniser" as deputy, in the shape of John Prescott, has not resolved the problem. "As you know", Lord Sawyer said, "dream tickets are only made in dreams."

He conceded that Partnership in Power - the new policy-making process largely masterminded by him - "in reality only goes a small part of the way. In my opinion, New Labour therefore remains incomplete".

Echoing criticisms already voiced by the modernisers grouped around the journal Renewal, Lord Sawyer said: "The modernisation project was at its zenith when Labour won the 1997 general election. That was the end of a period of opposition. What we have not yet done is to develop a successful modernisation project for a party in government.

"Moving from opposition to government requires a reassessment of leadership in every sense of the word. Translating a command style of leadership that worked in opposition into government can prove difficult."

"The sheer pace and grind of government, the intrusion of civil servants into what had in the past been a private Labour world, and the whole host of people from different walks of life who were co-opted into the government's new project, made many party members and MPs feel left behind'.

"Put another way, before the election, there was only one Labour party canteen and we all ate lunch together. It was all we had. Today, we seem never to eat together."

webTitle: Not lost. Not discredited. The WTO hits back

fields.headline: Not lost. Not discredited. The WTO hits back
fields.trailText: The World Trade Organisation yesterday called on governments and international institutions to head off a protectionist backlash against free trade as it defiantly hit back at opponents of globalisation.
fields.body:
The World Trade Organisation yesterday called on governments and international institutions to head off a protectionist backlash against free trade as it defiantly hit back at opponents of globalisation.

In its annual report, the WTO said forecasts of doom following its failure to launch a new trade round in Seattle last December had already been debunked.

"The WTO is not lost; and it is not discredited", the report said. "It is the more extreme critics who are becoming discredited as the WTO system shows its resilience."

The organisation has spent recent months trying to repair the damage to its reputation in Seattle, where violent protests accompanied aborted attempts to construct a framework for free-trade talks.

WTO sources said the report carried the imprimatur of the organisation's director-general, Mike Moore, who has decided to confront critics of free trade head-on. "The multilateral trading system will continue to deliver a vital contribution to economic growth and stable economic relations" among countries at all levels of development, it says.

While some critics portrayed it as "a malign force or even a conspiracy", the report said: "Globalisation is not a programme or an agenda. But the widespread public confusion and apprehension about it calls for a positive agenda from governments and international institutions if they are to forestall a populist and protectionist backlash."

The European Union and other key players hope a new round of liberalisation talks can still get under way this year, but there are deep divisions between rich and poor countries, and among the rich countries themselves. And the US presidential election has encouraged protectionist sentiment in America.

fields.headline: Granada confirms £6bn Compass takeover talks
fields.trailText: Granada said yesterday that it aimed to demerge its media and hospitality businesses within 12 months after confirming that talks are under way for a £6bn takeover of the Compass catering group.
fields.body:
Granada said yesterday that it aimed to demerge its media and hospitality businesses within 12 months after confirming that talks are under way for a £6bn takeover of the Compass catering group.

Granada has long made it clear that it needed a deal that would bolster its hospitality business before splitting the two sides of the company.

The decoupling will leave a media business with revenues of around £1bn and a combined hospitality company with pro forma sales of £7.5bn.

Most analysts view Granada's plans chiefly as a means of getting into shape for the forthcoming battle over control of the ITV network.

The media business consists of the Granada, Tyne-Tees, Yorkshire and London Weekend ITV franchises, plus stakes in ONdigital, Scottish Media Group and ITN, as well as TV and film production. The plans were confirmed in a statement from Granada, prompted by disclosure of the talks in yesterday's Guardian. The company is expected to seal the deal with Compass this week.

The statement said the merger would be based on recent average market values of the two groups. Shares in Compass fell 14.6% to 771p in response to the nil-premium terms; Granada shares gained 6.5p to close at 639.5p.

The deal also appears to have satisfied Granada chairman Gerry Robinson's stated aim of pulling off one more big deal before retiring. The group said yesterday he would step down once the demerger was complete but will remain a consultant to the hospitality business and a non-executive director of the media arm.

Charles Allen, Granada chief executive will become executive chairman of the media business and Compass boss Francis Mackay will run the hospitality company.

Granada's hospitality business includes contract catering as well as the Travelodge, Little Chef, Posthouse and Meridien hotel chains but is regarded as being too UK focused.

Granada was caught flatfooted by plans of its two rival ITV groups, Carlton Communications and United News & Media, to merge and has said it is "minded" to bid for one or the other. The possible combinations are being examined by the competition commission.

webTitle: Premier Oil admits abuses in Burma

fields.headline: Premier Oil admits abuses in Burma
fields.standfirst: Executive denials crumble under pressure from rights groups and UK government
fields.trailText: Executive denials crumble under pressure from rights groups and UK government
fields.body:
Human rights abuses have been taking place inside an area of Burma controlled by Premier Oil, the British company conceded yesterday, despite previous denials from top executives.

Last month ministers asked the oil company to abandon its petroleum interests to pressurise the country's repressive military junta. Burmese opposition leader and Nobel prize-winner Aung San Suu Kyi has also called on Premier to withdraw, and yesterday's admission by the company will intensify pressure on it to pull out of the country.

Chief executive Charles Jamieson told the company's annual meeting last year that he was "not aware of any abuses in our pipeline area or of cases of forced labour being used in Burma."

But at yesterday's annual meeting he was asked how he could remain unaware of such issues when an environmental assessment report by oil group Texaco had warned from 1996 there were likely to be problems. It had looked at the impact of a proposed pipeline - which has now been built - from the offshore Yetagun field to the Thai border, which was protected by the army.

Following the meeting Mr Jamieson admitted his com pany had raised with the government examples of continuing abuses in its controlled areas. "It is not just human rights but environmental [abuses], too," he volunteered.

But he insisted they were only isolated incidents. Asked how this tallied with contrary statements in the past, he replied: "If I said that [last year] it was not what I meant."

In April the government said it had taken the unprecedented step of asking Premier Oil to withdraw from its 27% interest in the Yetagun gas project as part of an attempt to increase pressure on the authorities.

The Confederation of British Industry criticised the government's call, saying that "in the absence of clear legal sanctions from the UK or UN, it should be left up to companies to make decisions about where they do business".

It also emerged yesterday that Premier might become the target of a legal action seeking compensation for human rights abuses associated to its relationship with Myanmar's military government, according to Kate Wredford, a US attorney and the director of EarthRights International.

Ms Wredford said that it was "a possibility" that Premier Oil could face legal action as its involvement with Burma's military government had been no different from a US oil group, Unocal, , which is involved in a legal action against Ms Wredford's organisation and other groups over claims that hundreds of Burmese citizens were used as forced labour on a Unocal gas pipeline project.

She said the "crux" of such a case was that Premier "should have known that human rights abuses were occurring" in its infrastructure in Burma.

Mr Jamieson reiterated Premier's commitment to "constructive engagement" in Burma, arguing that pulling out would lead to huge contractual problems, and would not solve political or social problems there.

Premier was one of the independent oil exploration and production firms founded in the 1980s to develop the North Sea fields. In recent years it has moved into Asia. Its main projects are now in Pakistan and Indonesia as well as Burma.

The stock has performed badly over the same period but a 25% stakeholding by US oil group Amerada Hess has protected the company from a takeover. Last September Premier strengthened its defences and financial muscle by bringing in Petronas of Malaysia as another big stakeholder.

The company came under ferocious attack from shareholders at its London meeting over its commitment to Burma, its sagging share price and breaches of governance standards. The shares last night were unchanged at 12p, against 55p in 1997.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Royal Dutch Airlines yesterday denied that it was in alliance talks with British Airways. A spokesman confirmed that KLM is still looking for an international partner.
fields.body:
KLM denies BA tie-up

Royal Dutch Airlines yesterday denied that it was in alliance talks with British Airways. A spokesman confirmed that KLM is still looking for an international partner. KLM had been widely reported to be seeking a tie-up with BA after breaking off an alliance with Alitalia over concerns about delays in the Italian carrier's privatisation and Milan's new Malpensa airport.

Marconi pledge to Rover staff

Communications group Marconi intends to interview workers set to lose their jobs at Rover to help fill 2,200 jobs at their new headquarters, to be built on the site of a former airfield at Ansty in the West Midlands.

The company will receive a £25m government grant for the headquarters, which will be sited 30 miles from the Rover Longbridge plant in Birmingham where 1,000 workers are expected to be laid off. Around 700 new construction jobs are likely to be created building the new centre.

Jospin alert on phone bids

French prime minister Lionel Jospin is concerned that bidders for third generation mobile phone licences in France are not burdened by high prices. "Our concern must be to safeguard the state's national interest while at the same time ensuring that major companies are not handicapped," he said.

The French government is to decide by the end of the month whether to allocate the licences by competitive tender or by auction. In Britain, successful bidders in last month's auction of licences paid between £4bn and £5.96bn each.

Crackdown on fake goods

The government has started a campaign against counterfeit goods and will begin by targeting traders who sell such products.

Consumer affairs minister Kim Howells said the department of trade and industry would hold roadshows to warn the public about the dangers of buying counterfeit items. He said his second target was consumers who knowingly bought these goods.

The minister cited the example of Manchester United to show how fake merchandise had hit revenues. He said the trade cost the club £6m in lost revenue in the 1990s, with £2m of that accounted for in the past two years.

Failure pays for BoS chief Burt

Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland which failed to win control of NatWest, last year took home £109,000 more than the previous year.

His total pay, including bonus, profit share and salary, was £595,000 in the 1999-2000 financial year.

In the annual reports and accounts published yesterday, governor Sir John Shaw hit out against corporate governance rules. "Disappointingly, the recent proliferation of codes intended to help boards discharge their responsibilities for good corporate governance appears to distract attention from their fundamental objectives [to create shareholder value]," Sir John wrote.

He said his second target was consumers who knowingly bought these goods. The minister cited the example of Manchester United to show how fake merchandise had hit revenues. He said the trade cost the club £6m in lost revenue in the 1990s, with £2m of that accounted for in the past two years. Failure pays for BoS chief Burt Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland which failed to win control of NatWest, last year took home £109,000 more than the previous year. His total pay, including bonus, profit share and salary, was £595,000 in the 1999-2000 financial year. In the annual reports and accounts published yesterday, governor Sir John Shaw hit out against corporate governance rules. "Disappointingly, the recent proliferation of codes intended to help boards discharge their responsibilities for good corporate governance appears to distract attention from their fundamental objectives [to create shareholder value]," Sir John wrote.

fields.headline: Technicolor auction opens
fields.trailText: Carlton said yesterday the auction had begun for its Technicolor business to clear the decks for the ITV company's proposed merger with United News & Media.
fields.body:
Carlton said yesterday the auction had begun for its Technicolor business to clear the decks for the ITV company's proposed merger with United News & Media.

Investment bank UBS Warburg has been asked to find a buyer for a business analysts value at between £1.1bn and £1.7bn. Carlton paid £460m for it in 1988.

It also has a for sale sign on a business making film production equipment.

Technicolor makes cinema film prints and video cassettes for clients such as Disney, Warner Bros and DreamWorks. Its biggest attraction could be its claim to a 30% share of the market for producing DVDs - the entertainment industry's biggest growth story.

Potential buyers are thought to include Bertelsmann, Time Warner and Matsushita of Japan. Last year Technicolor produced revenues of $1.5bn.

webTitle: Renault-Nissan aims to top European league

fields.headline: Renault-Nissan aims to top European league
fields.trailText: Renault and Nissan claimed yesterday that combining their operations will allow them to become Europe's best selling motor group within five years - leap-frogging Volkswagen and Ford.
fields.body:
Renault and Nissan claimed yesterday that combining their operations will allow them to become Europe's best selling motor group within five years - leap-frogging Volkswagen and Ford.

The alliance, formed when Renault bought 37% of Nissan for $5.4bn last year, will restructure its European dealer networks and introduce limited cross-badging of vehicles to speed the struggling Japanese carmaker's return to profit. It aims to increase its share of the European market for cars and light commercials from 14.2% to 17% by 2005.

More than 800 Nissan employees will lose their jobs, though this will be offset by the creation of nearly 400 Renault jobs. Further job cuts are expected at Nissan and Renault dealers.

Francois Hilfray, Renault's executive vice president for sales and marketing, said the alliance's policy was to develop shared platforms and power trains, but this required time.

In the interim, there would be some cross-badging, with some Nissan off-road vehicles appearing under the Renault name, and some Renault light commercials with the Nissan badge. They would be adapted to give an appropriate brand identity.

Renault is particularly interested in the Nissan Terrano, made in Spain, and the Patrol, made in Japan. Both would have to be restyled to give them a Renault "look". Nissan wants to exploit Renault's successful Trafic, Master and Kangoo vans. The first shared platform will be for the new Nissan Micra and Renault Clio, expected in 2003.

Nissan confirmed that the company might decide to move Micra production from its Sunderland plant to a cheaper location on the continent. A final decision would be taken at the end of the year. A senior official blamed the strong pound for increasing costs at Sunderland, even though it is the most efficient car plant in Europe.

Loss of Micra production could cost several thousand jobs at the Sunderland plant and at associated suppliers.

The European dealer networks of Nissan and Renault are to be restructured to create new superdealers who will handle back office work - such as parts and accessories, accounting and legal services - for dealers of both marques in a given area.

Last year Renault sold 180,000 cars and vans in the UK, while Nissan sold just under 100,000. Combined Renault and Nissan sales in Europe last year totalled 2.4m vehicles. Renault has 11.3% of the market against Nissan's 2.9%.

Renault said that many small dealers would probably be taken over by the larger companies or join with others to create their own joint back office operation.

This would leave small dealers as little more than showroom and servicing operations possibly with an interest in a back office business.

webTitle: Straw faces fresh row over boxer

fields.headline: Straw faces fresh row over boxer
fields.standfirst: Seconds out, round two  Tyson plan to fight here again
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night plunged into a new row over whether the American boxer, Mike Tyson, should be allowed into Britain after it was revealed that he has applied for permission to fight in Scotland on June 24.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night plunged into a new row over whether the American boxer, Mike Tyson, should be allowed into Britain after it was revealed that he has applied for permission to fight in Scotland on June 24.

The prospect of Tyson, a convicted rapist, being allowed back into Britain so soon after his February bout with the British heavyweight, Julius Francis, in Manchester, sparked immediate protests in the Scottish parliament and among women's groups.

Scotland's national football stadium, Hampden Park, and Celtic's Parkhead stadium are believed to be competing to stage the fight, which would be with Lou Savarese.

But a Labour member of the Scottish parliament, Hugh Henry, said last night that he had tabled a motion criticising the move with the backing of other Labour figures: "I understand that the immigration laws in this country ban foreign nationals who have criminal convictions of more than a year from entering the country. Mike Tyson clearly falls into that category."

But when Mr Straw gave special dispensation for Tyson to enter Britain in January after the Home Office first refused him entry, the home secretary also made clear that he believed the immigration rule was inconsistently applied in that it only caught celebrity villains. At the time, the home secretary hinted that the permit was a one-off and that Tyson would be refused a work permit if he tried to fight in Britain again.

This time Mr Straw will be considering the boxer's visa application in less charged circumstances than in January when the 21,000 tickets for the fight had already been sold and when the commercial disaster that cancellation would have triggered contributed to the "exceptional circumstances" of his decision.

Last night Sandy Brindley, of the Rape Crisis Line, said it would be hypocritical of the government to allow Tyson to return: "We would be very concerned about what kind of message that sends out and how seriously the offence of rape is taken," she said. "We also feel strongly that it would conflict with the government's stated commitment to tackle violence against women."

Tyson's advance visa application, lodged with the British consul general in New York last Friday, means the decision is taken by Mr Straw and not left to the individual immigration officer on duty at Glasgow on the day that Tyson flies in.

webTitle: No food, no ammunition but still primed for battle

fields.headline: No food, no ammunition but still primed for battle
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Bin Bah is the West Side Boys' only girl. The young woman, with a gold stud in her nose and a British rifle on her knee, is sucking on a "morale booster", one of the plastic sachets of gin which help to keep Sierra Leone's soldiers fighting in the absence of adequate food.
fields.body:
Bin Bah is the West Side Boys' only girl. The young woman, with a gold stud in her nose and a British rifle on her knee, is sucking on a "morale booster", one of the plastic sachets of gin which help to keep Sierra Leone's soldiers fighting in the absence of adequate food.

Bin Bah claims to have spent half of her 18 years fighting in one way or another. First, she was a runner for the Tiger battalion. Now she is a member of one of the British-backed Sierra Leone army's more colourful units, the West Side Boys. The motley collection of young men with an array of weapons as varied as their clothing helped to seize the strategic town of Masiaka from Revolutionary United Front rebels at the weekend.

"We want to capture Foday Sankoh alive and then we kill him because of what he has done to Freetown and Sierra Leone," Bin Bah said. "I will shoot any rebel I see. Anyone I am on top of I will kill. I will kill you, no problem. I will kill anyone, then there is no more problem."

But there is a problem.

"We need food on the ground. We are fighting for our country but we need to eat. We suffer. We don't get rations," she said.

The soldiers also complain of an ammunition shortage. Communications are dire. The commanders have no batteries for their radios. They are unable to warn each other of attacks.

And then there is the sometimes violent rivalry between the regular government forces and the Kamajor militia. It helped contribute to a chaotic retreat from the town on Sunday morning before it was retaken.

"We do need ammunition, food and medicines," said the commanding officer in Masiaka, Lieutenant-Colonel AC Kenny. "But now we have very cordial relations with the Kamajors. There is perfect command and control around town. There is unity and there is oneness."

Few of the soldiers in Masiaka have proper uniforms. Many wear flip-flops. One donned a well-fitting woman's wig. Another, who called himself "General Nomore", sported a UN beret and a bloodied jacket. He boasted that he had "captured" it from an RUF soldier killed in the fighting for the town.

The dead rebel - a certain "General Backblast" - lay in the road with his eyes pecked out by birds. His was one of 11 RUF corpses.

General Nomore is proud of his UN beret. He views its capture as a small recompense for peacekeepers surrendering hundreds of weapons, including 13 armoured vehicles, to the rebels. They were then turned on the army.

"It's the fault of the UN. When the rebels walk up and say 'give us your weapons' they just do it, they don't fight. And then the weapons are used against us. That's why we don't want the UN at the front with us. They will just give their guns to our enemies," he said.

But yesterday afternoon, Jordanian UN soldiers were grinding up the road in armoured vehicles to reinforce Masiaka so the army can press on to the next objective - a strategic bridge seven miles down the road toward Makeni, the RUF headquarters.

Every civilian has fled Masiaka. The discarded shoes and the car baby seat left upside down beside the road are a testament to the speed at which they left. But in the middle of the town, a soldier registers a line of young men.

They were soldiers who three months ago were sent off to the demobilisation camp at nearby Kono for disarmament and reintegration into civilian life. Yesterday they walked out of the camp and back into Masiaka to sign up as soldiers again.

fields.headline: No: 1636 Inspector Morse
fields.trailText: Age: Unspecified. But technically dead, in any case.
fields.body:
Age: Unspecified. But technically dead, in any case.

Long-hidden ridiculous first name: Endeavour, which probably explains why it was long-hidden.

Job description: Curmudgeonly 'tec bent on bringing justice to the mean streets of, um, Oxford.

Appearance: An awful lot like TV's John Thaw.

And he's dead? I must have missed that episode. Don't worry. So far he's only died in Colin Dexter's final Morse novel, The Remorseful Day.

Poisoned/stabbed/bludgeoned by a demented Wagnerian opera singer/Oxford housewife/ Lonsdale College classics don (delete as appropriate)? Nothing so macabre. Everybody's favourite misanthrope suffers a coronary in his flat, is rushed to hospital and slips into an afterlife full of real ale and Schubert CDs. Or at least that's what happens in the book.

You mean it'll be different on TV? In next October's screen adaptation Morse kicks the bucket as he and loveable Geordie sidekick Sgt Lewis hurtle down Fifth Avenue pursued by a giant fireball, in a vintage maroon Jaguar wired to explode if it goes slower than 30mph, as meteors rain down and Godzilla rips up the surrounding skyscrapers.

That sounds almost incredible. Well, it's one interpretation of this week's shocking news that Carlton writers have altered the final story to give Morse a "drawn out, Hollywood-style death".

There are other interpretations? How about: Morse is diagnosed with terminal cancer but, under the care of an angelic, ditzy nurse (Meg Ryan), hangs on just long enough to hold the boy he has conceived with loveable Geordie sidekick Sgt Lewis.

You have no idea, do you? No - because Carlton executives have sworn actors and crew to secrecy. "We think Mr Dexter will forgive us when he sees it," said one.

And what does Mr Dexter say? "The people who make these decisions are at the very top of their professions... there are, though, times when you wish they could have done it more faithfully to the novel."

Coming soon to a TV near you: Miss Marple: The Phantom Menace.

webTitle: Toxic waste found in scrap metal

fields.headline: Toxic waste found in scrap metal
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: One gram of plutonium in scrap metal fed through a Sheffield smelter has turned 50 tonnes of reclaimed material into nuclear waste.
fields.body:
One gram of plutonium in scrap metal fed through a Sheffield smelter has turned 50 tonnes of reclaimed material into nuclear waste.

Radioactive alarms went off at the vesta Foundry, in Sheffield, after the plutonium was already in the works, making it impossible for the contamination to be stopped.

This is the first time plutonium, the most toxic substance in the world, has been discovered in scrap metal. It has caused alarm at the Department of the Environment.

This is the third time this year that nuclear material has turned up in unauthorised places, and the discovery is leading to increasing fears about the possibility of widespread contamination, although so far none has occurred.

In March a scrap firm, Mormet (Alloys) of Tamworth, Staffordshire, reported finding a uranium fuel rod in its warehouse during routine checks, and the same month Nicholas Remblance, a rubbish tip manager from Ipswich, found that he had been carrying around 20lb of uranium in his van for six months.

The origin of the plutonium is unknown and the health and safety executive and the environment agency are trying to find out if a criminal offence has been committed.

The incident happened on March 31, but the fact that plutonium was involved was not known at the time and was kept secret subsequently.

About 16 tonnes of metal and slag are so badly contaminated that they will have to be stored for many years until Britain finds somewhere to dispose of the material.

Plutonium 238 is used in medical equipment as well as the nuclear industry, so the source could be hard to track down.

According to Environmental Data Services, the journal which revealed the plutonium contamination, there is increasing alarm about the dangers of recycled nuclear material.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The London market may have had news of the biggest merger in months to digest, but with the Fed's open market committee due to start discussing the American cost of borrowing today, few of the market's big players had any real appetite for trading.
fields.body:
The London market may have had news of the biggest merger in months to digest, but with the Fed's open market committee due to start discussing the American cost of borrowing today, few of the market's big players had any real appetite for trading.

So the market as a whole was left to drift, leaving the FTSE 100 35.8 points lower at the close at 6,247.7. Some 1.3bn shares changed hands which, 18 months ago, would have been seen as a heavy day's trading. Now, after the speculative excesses of the past six months, it is seen as light business.

In fact, the volume would have been 130m or so lighter but for the business in bid target Thomson Travel (up 10p at 172p), where American investment bank Goldman Sachs moved into the market on behalf of Germany's Preussag.

There is a near-consensus in the market that US interest rates will go up by half a point, so a good selection of London's heavyweights were under pressure again. Glaxo Wellcome , for example, shed 40p to £19.16, Colt Telecom shrank from £22.10 to £20.61 and Telewest fell back from 325p to 300p.

Aside from the action in Granada (up 6.5p at 639.5p after touching 660p) and Compass (down from 902.5p to 771p), market tongues were set wagging after shares in GKN rose from 911p to 949p for no apparent reason. In fact, the only piece of "news" flitting across dealers' screens yesterday was a formal statement that one director had exercised options for over 70,000 shares and sold the lot for a pre-tax profit of £400,000.

There were some selective buyers in the technology sector, where Fibernet Group ran up from £18.65 to £19.50 and Staffware put on 100p to £19.50. Since the beginning of the month, Staffware had drifted back from the £25 level, having traded above £46 back in February.

Sir Alan Sugar's Amstrad jumped towards 190p after news that the consumer electronics group had signed up its second advertiser, insurer Direct Line, for its new email telephone, the e-m@iler. Britannia Music signing up last month to sell CDs and videos over the new technology, the first company to do so.

But the market in the stock soon calmed down and the shares ended the day at 175p, up 5.5p on balance and somewhat shy of the 607p struck at the end of March.

A weekend newspaper tip was said to be behind the rise in restaurant business Belgo, where the shares added 1p to 5p. Another penny punt, Multimedia Group , moved up 1p to 7p after the software group announced a small profit for 1999.

fields.headline: Focus  Enic
fields.trailText: Enic, the investment vehicle spanning the sports, media and restaurant sectors, is believed to be ready to move a step closer to becoming a group more clearly focused on sports and online gaming by agreeing to buy web betting service UKbetting.com.
fields.body:
Enic, the investment vehicle spanning the sports, media and restaurant sectors, is believed to be ready to move a step closer to becoming a group more clearly focused on sports and online gaming by agreeing to buy web betting service UKbetting.com.

The deal is small - thought to be worth around £500,000 in cash - but is a significant step in chief executive Daniel Levy's strategy to build a company offering a variety of online gaming facilities across a range of platforms.

UKbetting.com was an early mover into online gaming. It was set up in 1998, and has about 3,000 customers spending an estimated £3m a year.

But it is its clear brand name and the distinctive domain address that will appeal to Enic.

The company has already agreed to buy Victor Chandler International, the Gibraltar based tax-free betting opera tion run by the bookmaker of the same name. VCI has an extensive global network of customers througout the US and Far East, and UKbetting.com will serve to reinforce Enic's domestic presence.

However, Mr Levy still has to conclude the VCI deal, which was first announced last summer. The due diligence process has taken much longer than expected owing to a lack of clarity in VCI's accounts. Despite the frustrations felt by both sides the parties remain committed to the deal - they have until the end of the year to seal it before their initial agreement lapses, but both will hope to conclude it well before then.

Victor Chandler was one of the pioneers of offshore betting, but bigger rivals like Ladbrokes are catching up fast, and Enic will have to invest significantly and quickly if its advantage is not to be lost.

Its shares, trading at around 370p in March, also need a lift again: last night they closed up 4p at 179p.

Further small acquisitions like the UKbetting.com deal can be expected.

Enic is at present best known for its stakes in European football clubs - including Glasgow Rangers - as well as for glitzy assets such as the Warner Brothers stores and a 3.7% stakeholding in Autonomy, the successful internet software firm.

fields.headline: Moscow mines a surreal vein
fields.standfirst:
News Analysis Platinum fiasco reflects Russia's deepening chaos
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia had little luck during the Soviet era in achieving its aim of disrupting the hated western capitalist enemy. But it is doing a lot better now it has embraced the market economy and private enterprise.
fields.body:
Russia had little luck during the Soviet era in achieving its aim of disrupting the hated western capitalist enemy. But it is doing a lot better now it has embraced the market economy and private enterprise.

It is not just the country's mafia-run banks whose laundered funds - allegedly - churn like a tidal bore through financial markets. Yesterday's Platinum 2000 report from Johnson Matthey, the speciality metals group based in Hatton Garden, London, highlights Russia's capricious behaviour in the strategically critical area of "white metals", principally platinum and palladium.

Indeed, post-communist Russia has emerged as the Saudi Arabia of platinum-group metals, the "swing" producer that can send prices sharply up or down.

Regrettably, it has yet to learn Saudi habits of restraint, diplomacy and responsibility.

In a normal year Russia supplies about a fifth of the world's platinum. In 1999, it decided, for reasons best known to itself, to supply less than half that amount.

The price shot up from $342 (£227) a Troy ounce to an 11-year high in February last year of $573.

In palladium - where Russia's position is even stronger, mining two thirds of the world total - supplies were "erratic," notes Johnson Matthey, with again a price surge coming on the back of Russian shortages from $334 an ounce to $444 by the end of 1999.

With both metals, the US defence department had to sell thousands of ounces from its own strategic stockpile to avert a global demand-supply crunch.

In the popular imagination, platinum is known mainly as the rather vulgar chief component of flashy jewellery for trashy jetsetters, whereas "palladium" rings few bells at all, other than as a music hall.

In reality, both metals - and their little sister, rhodium - are increasingly in demand across the industrial spectrum. Chemical industry use of platinum rose 15% in 1999, according to Johnson Matthey, while in the electrical sector demand was up 50%.

Palladium is popular in different corners of the electronics industry and is in heavy demand as a dental alloy.

But for both metals, the largest chunk of industrial demand is from the car industry. For, by an interesting coincidence, at about the time the cold war was drawing to a close, Russia's new capitalist friends - led by the United States - were cleaning up their environmental act, with an emphasis on restricting vehicle exhaust emissions.

One jurisdiction after another demanded that new cars be fitted with so-called catalytic converters.

These devices work best with the use of large quantities of palladium, which is efficient at converting polluting hydrocarbons into carbon dioxide and water.

There are substitutes - up to a point. Unfortunately, these are platinum and rhodium, both subject also to Russian-triggered price swings.

The "cleaner and greener" legislative movement in the west during the late 1980s and early 1990s was based on careful costings, to ensure the bills for the economy at large could be absorbed more or less painlessly.

Years of disruption to white-metal exports from Russia could make a nonsense of those costings. And car makers, already suffering from huge overcapacity, could become the chief victims as they buy in ever more expensive catalytic converters.

In some ways, the blockages of Russian metals would matter less were Moscow to be pursuing some devilishly clever strategy to humble the west. But official behaviour - given that the country is crying out for hard currency earnings - suggests less a reconversion to Bolshevism than a belated discovery of surrealism.

Johnson Matthey notes platinum and rhodium exports were strangled by the extraordinary clause 19 in the Russian budget, passed in December 1998, pro hibiting all but government agencies from selling the two metals. Clause 19 - for which "there has been no satisfactory explanation" - was buried only last month.

Palladium, meanwhile, seems to have been subjected to some sort of bureaucratic power struggle, which may explain a mystery cut in production in January, which pushed the price to $800, nearly double its December 1999 level.

More extraordinary still, shipments were inhibited by a new export tax, presumably designed to punish those trying to earn dollars for Russia.

Amid all this uncertainty, an admirable sang froid was on display in Hatton Garden yesterday, with Johnson Matthey noting that 1999 "was a year full of incident". That is one way of putting it.

webTitle: Glynwed could still make a tasty dish

fields.headline: Glynwed could still make a tasty dish
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Shares in Glynwed International, the company that makes Aga cookers, rose 8% in early trading yesterday as investors thought a nice plump bid was being baked between management and rival George Fischer.
fields.body:
Shares in Glynwed International, the company that makes Aga cookers, rose 8% in early trading yesterday as investors thought a nice plump bid was being baked between management and rival George Fischer.

The stock then plunged like a failed soufflé as the Swiss engineer denied there was any question of a £600m offer. Glynwed shares ended the day down 11.5p at 228.5p.

There is nothing like disappointment to encourage a sell-off, but in Glynwed's case there is reason to believe it has been overdone.

Ever since the Charter group found itself on the receiving end of a healthy bid, the engineering sector as a whole has been on bid alert.

If George Fischer is not interested in Glynwed then others such as American rivals Wavin or Upinor could be in the frame, even though these particular US companies are considerably smaller than their British rival.

It is not the Aga or Rayburn ovens that would turn on trade buyers and venture capitalists, but its innovative pipe systems, which make up 80% of the business now the metal distribution side has been hived off.

Glynwed is seen by some as an attractive company with a new focused approach and strong management. The company's shares have been clobbered like the rest of the engineering sector by the fad for technology stocks, but unlike companies such as TI Group or Morgan Crucible, Glynwed has nothing of the mini-conglomerate tag to it which might put predators off.

Charter was eventually taken out with an agreed offer by Lincoln Electric Holdings of the US which valued the business at double its stock market rating.

Glynwed is thought by many to deserve similar value. Chairman Ewen Macpherson told the company's annual general meeting last month that the company's prospects were better than ever.

Trading profits rose last year from £53.6m to £86.7m and management is promising operating margins up to 12% and a return on capital of 15% this year.

Glynwed has been promising to sell fine wines, recipes, and exotic holidays over the internet to its affluent individual customers. The company could yet find corporate buyers clicking on to its charms as well.
