fields.headline: Flawed evidence led to 'mission creep'
fields.standfirst:
The decision to send British troops in was taken amid terrible confusion, Whitehall sources say

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The decision to send British troops into Sierra Leone was taken against a confused, chaotic and fast-moving background. Even the Blair baby played a part, albeit a minor one, in the decision.
fields.body:
The decision to send British troops into Sierra Leone was taken against a confused, chaotic and fast-moving background. Even the Blair baby played a part, albeit a minor one, in the decision.

Normally, Tony and Cherie Blair would have spent the weekend at Chequers, but because of the pending birth they have been playing safe and staying at Downing Street. The prime minister was there on the afternoon of Saturday, May 6, when a recommendation came from key ministers that Britain should set in motion plans to evacuate UK, European and Commonwealth citizens trapped in the west African civil war.

The request came at an awkward time for Mr Blair. He had been in Belfast, reviving the Northern Ireland peace process while at the same time dealing on the periphery with the fallout from the disastrous council and London mayoral elections. He had flown back from Belfast the previous night, but was still preoccupied with Northern Ireland, in particular an IRA statement on decommissioning.

When the Sierra Leone request came in he did not delay in authorising the use of troops. Ministers and officials, some of whom had been critical about his role in international events, said he just felt it was something that was morally right. A Downing Street source said: "Whilst recognising that you can't do everything, and the days of being the global policeman are long gone, it does not mean you can't show leadership and do what [you] can to help."

The prime minister's decision may have been made from the highest motives, but strangely he and his ministers have been reluctant to take credit for it. They have gone out of their way to insist that Britain should play only a minimal role, though all the evidence on the ground, including from its own commander, Brigadier David Richards, points to Britain having taken the lead in the defence of the capital Freetown and the retreat of the rebels.

Even more peculiar were the circumstances that led to Mr Blair and his ministers giving the nod to intervention. Increasingly it looks as if they were acting on flawed military intelligence, both from the United Nations and from a 15-man British "technical assistance" team in Sierra Leone led by Brig Richards, who had commanded the British contingent in East Timor.

On the key weekend, the UN put out a panic-stricken report that Freetown was poised to fall to the rebels, which even the UN has subsequently admitted was overblown. And according to Whitehall insiders both the UN and the British military overestimated the effectiveness of the rebel Revolutionary United Front.

The first inkling of trouble in Sierra Leone came on May Day, when information began arriving at the Foreign Office in London. Kenyan UN peacekeepers had attempted to decommission rebel weapons in the RUF's diamond producing stronghold. An argument turned ugly and the UN force was captured by the rebels.

It was proving to be a turbulent baptism for the new British high commissioner, Alan Jones, who had just arrived in Freetown.

On Tuesday, May 2, officials from the Ministry of Defence and the Foreign Office as well as intelligence officers gathered at the FO to discuss the turmoil in the former colony. The next day they moved to the Cabinet Office in Whitehall, where they have been meeting daily ever since.

The run-up to the decision to intervene was difficult. "There was terrible confusion. The reports from the UN and others were contradictory. Even now, we still do not know what is happening on the ground," a Whitehall official said.

On Friday, May 5, the officials met for what turned out to be the crucial meeting. Both the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, by now in daily contact, agreed with the officials' conclusion that troops might have to go in to carry out the evacuation.

When Mr Cook left on Friday night for an EU meeting in the Azores, the evacuation was just a possibility: by the time he arrived in the Azores, four hours later, it was almost a certainty. Such was the speed at which the military situation appeared to be deteriorating.

Mr Cook discussed the crisis with the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, who was keen to see British troops help out the beleaguered UN force. Mr Cook's critics in other Whitehall departments claim that the foreign secretary may have succumbed to flattery from the UN chief.

The first hint that a decision had been taken to send Britain's "spearhead battalion" of about 700 men came early on Sunday, May 7. Whitehall sources say the decision was taken by ministers on the advice of the FO.

According to one of those present at a meeting of all Whitehall officials at the MoD that afternoon, "there was a sense of confusion. No one was clear what the remit was."

Sources say that what "galvanised" ministers was a report from Mr Jones, backed up by advice from the 15-man team led by Brig Richards.

That evening the foreign secretary gave Mr Jones the power to "trigger' the evacuation, and last Monday the high commissioner did just that.

The early emphasis from ministers was on the evacuation plan, and that alone. But the government became in creasingly sensitive to potential criticism that it was simply looking after European civilians, leaving the UN and Sierra Leone in the lurch. There was also a fear that by conducting an evacuation, Britain was undermining the UN force.

Mr Cook saw Mr Blair on the Tuesday, May 9, and the following day, at prime minister's question time in the Commons, the prime minister changed the emphasis, saying that British troops were also there to back up the UN force.

As last week went on though, it became increasingly clear that British troops on the ground in Sierra Leone were doing far more than ministers had admitted.

Ministers continued to insist that the mission was strictly limited and "specific", but this was contradicted by their actions and those of the British force in Sierra Leone. Last Friday, senior defence sources said that they had delegated authority to Brig Richards.

"He can employ the movement of assets as he decides. It is not something for London," the sources said.

On the same day that the MoD was claiming that the British mandate in Sierra Leone had not changed, Brig Richards was interviewed by Sierra Leone's Radio Democracy. Asked about the mandate, he replied: "There is discussion of that. But because I have personally a great affection for Sierra Leone and the people, and all that you have been through - as has my government - that mandate is being liberally interpreted."

That is a more honest appraisal than anyone in Whitehall is prepared to give.

fields.headline: $40m deals make Friends happy
fields.trailText: Friends, the most-watched sitcom in the United States, was saved for another two years yesterday when a deal was struck with its six stars.
fields.body:
Friends, the most-watched sitcom in the United States, was saved for another two years yesterday when a deal was struck with its six stars.

Courteney Cox, David Schwimmer, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc, Jennifer Aniston and Matthew Perry will each get $750,000 (around £470,000) an episode.

They had asked for $1m and NBC, the network that carries the show, said that it was ready to drop the series rather than give in to the demand. But the deal, which includes 1% of the producer Warner Bros's future syndication profits, will give each of the six thirtysomethings at least $40m - a huge pay increase.

Previously they had to make ends meet on $125,000 an episode.

Only Kelsey Grammer of Frasier and the comedian Drew Carey have salaries anywhere near the Friends deal. It is not a record, however. Jerry Seinfeld was paid $1.2m an episode for the last series of his show two years ago, and Tim Allen received $1.25m for the final season of ABC's Home Improvement.

"We are pleased to be returning," the cast said in a statement. "Friends is one of the best written, produced and directed shows on television."

Garth Ancier, entertainment president of NBC, said: "We're more than pleased and we anticipate upcoming strong seasons from a 'must-see' cast and producing team that's still at the top of their game in creating appointment television."

But the negotiations went to the wire before agreement was reached.

"It was tense, but not oppressively so," a source said.

"Cooler heads prevailed. Ultimately, for the cast, it wasn't about money: it was a matter of whether they wanted to continue doing this for the next two years."

Programmes such as Friends are the holy grail for television networks, the last shows they can rely upon to evoke the golden age when it was possible to create the impression that the country was sitting down together in front of its television sets.

The networks' grip on the industry has been eroded by cable television's focus on lucrative niches. NBC has agreed to pay Warners up to $6m for each episode, in return for which it now earns about $7m.

The show gives NBC popularity with the young adult market most attractive to advertisers.

The networks' grip on the industry has been eroded by cable television's focus on lucrative niches. NBC has agreed to pay Warners up to $6m for each episode, in return for which it now earns about $7m. The show gives NBC popularity with the young adult market most attractive to advertisers.

fields.headline: Opposition rallies against Milosevic's clampdown
fields.trailText: A Serbian opposition leader wearing a T-shirt with the clenched-fist symbol of the youth resistance movement warned President Slobodan Milosevic to "leave our kids alone" at a demonstration in the capital Belgrade yesterday.
fields.body:
A Serbian opposition leader wearing a T-shirt with the clenched-fist symbol of the youth resistance movement warned President Slobodan Milosevic to "leave our kids alone" at a demonstration in the capital Belgrade yesterday.

"If you touch our children, you touch our future and this is the end. There is no step back after that," Zoran Djindjic, leader of the Democratic Party, said at the rally in Republic Square, attended by around 30,000 people.

The demand came as the Milosevic regime acted against students and activists from the youth movement Otpor (Resistance) after the weekend assassination of a senior government figure in the northern city of Novi Sad.

Opposition leaders called the demonstration after cancelling a rally in Pozarevac, Mr Milosevic's home town, last Tuesday, accusing the author ities of blocking access to roads and detaining activists and independent journalists.

It had been planned as a protest against the alleged beatings of three supporters of the Otpor movement in the town.

Student organisers admitted that they were disappointed with the turnout at yesterday's rally, which drew only a fraction of the 100,000 people who attended a rally in Belgrade on April 14.

Tension increased at the weekend after an unknown assassin shot Bosko Perosevic, a senior official in Mr Milosevic's Socialist party and head of the Vojvodina provincial government.

Official spokesmen blamed the murder on the youth movement, opposition parties and foreign governments.

At yesterday's rally, Branko Ilic, a 20-year-old member of Otpor, called for a minute's silence from the crowd as a mark of respect.

"For us Brako Perosevic is a victim," he said.

The police detained several activists at the weekend, but released them after questioning. They also issued wanted posters for the arrest of two Otpor members, saying they were sought in connection with Perosevic's murder.

The resistance movement dismissed the allegations. It said the two wanted youths were in Bosnia at the time of the murder and had been there for a month.

The Yugoslav information minister, Goran Matic, warned that the authorities would take action against Otpor.

It was not a registered organisation and would no longer be tolerated, he said. Members who continued with street actions would be arrested, he said, adding: "The time of street spectacles is over."

The assassination of Perosevic was caught on television. He received a call on his mo bile phone while he was attending an agricultural fair. He moved away from his official delegation to take the call and was shot at close blank range by a security guard.

The police gave chase and arrested the man.

Mr Matic said that the man held for the murder, Milivoje Gutovic, 50, was linked to the opposition.

He said police found Otpor propaganda in his flat, and manuals on terrorism.

"It has been firmly established that Gutovic is a member of Otpor, and according to his own statement, a member of the Serbian Renewal Movement with close ties to some of the party members and sympathisers," he said.

But the Democratic party said its local representative in the Novi Sad area knew Mr Gutovic.

It denied that he was an opposition supporter, saying that he was a supporter of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party.

fields.headline: Forest fire razes bomb laboratories
fields.trailText: The birthplace of the atomic bomb succumbed to the forces of nature at the weekend when the site of the secret wartime Manhattan Project was burned down by a forest fire sweeping across New Mexico, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
The birthplace of the atomic bomb succumbed to the forces of nature at the weekend when the site of the secret wartime Manhattan Project was burned down by a forest fire sweeping across New Mexico, it was reported yesterday.

The complex of buildings where US scientists worked on the prototype bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki was razed as the fire - originally started as a "controlled burn" - encroached on the Los Alamos nuclear laboratories. They had been earmarked by the White House as historic sites under the "Save America's Treasures" programme.

Nearly a third of the 43 sq mile site was affected. According to a damage assessment report quoted by Reuters: "The historic V-site complex from the Manhattan Project has been lost except for the high-bay building where the Trinity high explosive assembly was configured."

The Trinity bomb was the first atomic weapon detonated, on a test site in the southern New Mexico desert, on July 16 1945.

Officials at Los Alamos said firefighters had succeeded in keeping the flames away from the current plutonium storage sites and radioactive waste dumps. The energy department had assured nearby residents that there was never any danger of a nuclear accident because the storage sites were protected by heavy concrete shells.

State officials said yesterday that the fire, which has already burned 42,000 acres (16,800 hectares) of New Mexico forest, was "28% contained", and 7,000 local residents were allowed to return to their homes. But they said the Los Alamos laboratories were not out of danger, because anticipated high winds could fan the fire again.

The fire began last week as a deliberately set "controlled burn" intended to clear dry bush along a cordon to limit the spread of future forest fires. But high temperatures and strong winds fanned the blaze out of control in an area suffering its worst drought for more than two centuries.

The blaze has already caused an estimated $1bn (£625m) in damage, destroying 260 homes and sending 20,000 people fleeing for safety. The national parks official who ordered the "controlled burn" has been sent on leave while the fire is being investigated.

Yesterday the fire was reported to be to within half a mile of ancient native American cliff dwellings and the small adobe town of Abiquiu, the setting and inspiration for many of the paintings of the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, who lived there for nearly 40 years.

fields.headline: Scandals darken Korean summit
fields.trailText: South Korea is being racked by two corruption scandals which threaten to overshadow the plans for next month's unprecedented summit with North Korean leaders in Pyongyang.
fields.body:
South Korea is being racked by two corruption scandals which threaten to overshadow the plans for next month's unprecedented summit with North Korean leaders in Pyongyang.

One involves love letters written by a former South Korean defence minister while he was in office to an attractive lobbyist for a US armaments firm. The other suggests that large kickbacks and bribes were paid to senior officials and politicians to influence the award of a prestigious high-speed-railway contract.

"To lovely Linda," Lee Yang-ho wrote to the Korean-American Linda Kim in April 1996 while negotiating a $210m (£138m) deal to buy hi-tech surveillance equipment. "Let me know as soon as you sign the contract."

Ms Kim, who was handling the account for E-System of Texas, had apparently charmed the minister by ending a letter to him with the words "I love you".

"Your conclusion," replied Mr Lee, "could shield and harmonise all complications. Let us make joint efforts not to forget our pure and beautiful feelings." Mr Lee's ministry subsequently accepted E-System's bid for a remote-control signal intelligence system that could be used to spy on North Korea; the price agreed is said to have been higher than rival bids from France and Israel.

In the second scandal, transport ministry officials and national assembly members are suspected of corruption in connection with the TGV rail project, which will link the capital Seoul with Pusan when it is finished.

The contract appears to have gone to the well-connected French firm Alstom; one lobbyist acting for the company is the wife of head of its Seoul branch. Another lobbyist, who allegedly shared kickbacks to talling £7.2m, has fled to the US and was last spotted dining in Los Angeles.

It is not the first time Mr Lee has come under scrutiny for corruption. In October 1996 he went to jail for taking bribes in another case. Last week he admitted having an "inappropriate relationship" with Ms Kim, but said that he had only urged her to persuade the US firm to lower its price.

Ms Kim denies accepting money in return for favours but admits that the letters are genuine. The US company says she was paid a standard commission for the deal. It was investigated in 1998, but no action was taken.

fields.headline: US general 'attacked defeated Iraqi army'
fields.trailText: One of the most lauded generals in the US, now a member of President Clinton's cabinet, ordered his troops to open fire on retreating Iraqi forces two days after the Gulf war ceasefire was declared, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
One of the most lauded generals in the US, now a member of President Clinton's cabinet, ordered his troops to open fire on retreating Iraqi forces two days after the Gulf war ceasefire was declared, it was claimed yesterday.

Seven hundred Iraqi tanks, armoured cars, and trucks were destroyed and numerous soldiers, women and children were killed in one of the most one-sided clashes of the war for the future of Kuwait, according to an article in the New Yorker by the investigative journalist Seymour Hersh.

The articles quotes several former colleagues of General Barry McCaffrey, commander of the 24th Infantry Division, who is now the president's drugs tsar.

One, Lieutenant General James Johnson, commander of the 82nd Airborne Division in the war, is quoted as saying: "There was no need to be shooting at anybody. They [the Iraqis] couldn't surrender fast enough. The war was over."

Gen McCaffrey's conduct in the battle of Rumaila and two earlier attacks - in one of which it is said the Iraqis had already surrendered - has been investigated by the army. The general was cleared of misconduct but Mr Hersh, a Pulitzer prizewinner, spent six months interviewing more than 200 veterans, and says that key information and witnesses were overlooked.

"They were a defeated army going home and he attacked them," he said in a television interview yesterday.

Gen McCaffrey responded that two of his company commanders were under fire.

"This is nonsense, this is revisionist history. We obviously had to support our soldiers," he said.

Mr Hersh's article claims that on March 2 1991, two days after the ceasefire and the day before formal peace talks were to open, officers at Gen Mc Caffrey's headquarters disagreed about the strength of an Iraqi attack; indeed, there was a dispute about whether there had been an attack at all.

There was also disagreement about the appropriate response, and finally Gen McCaffrey ordered the assault. No accurate account of the dead could be made because they were buried so soon after the battle.

"Many of the generals interviewed for this account believe that McCaffrey's attack went too far and violated one of the most fundamental military doctrines: that a commander must respond in proportion to the threat," Mr Hersh writes.

One major general is quoted as saying: "That's the way we're trained. A single shot does not signal a battle to the death. Commanders just don't willy-nilly launch on something like that. A disciplined commander is going to figure out who fired it and where is came from. Especially if your mission is to enforce a ceasefire. Who should have been better able to instill fire discipline than McCaffrey?"

Lieutenant General John Yeostock, the officer in charge of enforcing the ceasefire and another critic of Gen McCaffrey, said that by the time of the battle of Rumaila there were no organised Iraqi units, equipment had been abandoned and prisoners were being evacuated.

"What Barry ended up doing was fighting sand dunes and moving rapidly," he says., adding that the general was "looking for a battle".

Lieutenant General Ronald Griffith, in command of the 1st Armoured Division of VII Corps, said many of the tanks destroyed in the encounter were being towed back to Baghdad on trailers and had their canons pointed backwards.

"It was just a bunch of tanks in a train and he [Gen McCaffrey] made it a battle when it was never one. That's the thing that bothered me the most, he said.

The New Yorker says that three days earlier armoured vehicles from Gen McCaffrey's division fired machine-guns at more than 350 disarmed Iraqi prisoners. Although he had no personal part in this, the general is accused of setting a tone that encouraged excessive gunfire.

"Why are we shooting at these people when they are not shooting at us?" says one soldier on a tape quoted by the magazine. "It's murder," said another.

But Gen McCaffrey has his supporters. He says: "I believe that my actions at Rumaila were completely appropriate and warranted in order to defend my troops against unknown and largely unknowable enemy forces and intentions."

And Lieutenant General James Scott, then an assistant divisional commander, said: "Eventually we became convinced that it was a real no-shit attack by the Iraqis."

The original military reports on Gen McCaffrey's actions have done him no harm. He was promoted several times, becoming commander of US forces in Latin America, and he is now director of the White House office of national drug control policy.

webTitle: Sidelined and whispered about. But Mowlam is the most popular

fields.headline: Sidelined and whispered about. But Mowlam is the most popular
fields.standfirst:
PM is barely an election asset, while public still warms to cabinet office minister

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's personal rating with the voters has fallen so sharply in the past year that he can only just be counted as an electoral asset to the Labour party, according to the third annual Guardian/ICM cabinet rankings.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's personal rating with the voters has fallen so sharply in the past year that he can only just be counted as an electoral asset to the Labour party, according to the third annual Guardian/ICM cabinet rankings.

The prime minister's net approval rating with voters has fallen from +34 points a year ago to only +1 point now, with 44% of voters saying they are satisfied with the job he is doing and 43% disagreeing.

But the survey of the standing in the country of the leading lights of the cabinet shows that if Tony Blair is now barely a net vote puller, Mo Mowlam continues to prove the popular success story of the Labour government, who now far outshines the prime minister.

Her personal rating of +40 points may be down slightly on her rating of a year ago but it still puts her in the "national treasure" class when compared with the rest of her cabinet colleagues. Even 54% of Conservative voters are satisfied with her performance.

An enormous 58% of all voters say Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, is doing a good job and only 18% believe she is not up to it. This performance shows that she remains Labour's strongest electoral card and is likely to lay to rest the Westminster whispering campaign against her and any lingering questions over her future in the cabinet.

In fact, the ICM survey shows that the three senior Labour women in the cabinet all do better than their male counterparts even if in the cases of Margaret Beckett, the leader of the House of Commons at +18, and Clare Short, the international development secretary at +12, their low profile means that more than one in three voters does not have an opinion on whether or not they are doing a good or bad job.

The third annual Guardian/ICM cabinet rankings survey appears to show that the voters are beginning to discriminate quite sharply between the way they view the leading players in the government.

While the popularity of the "big-hitters" such as the chancellor, Gordon Brown, Jack Straw, the home secretary and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, are quite closely grouped around that of Tony Blair at around +3 to -7, John Prescott, the deputy prime minster, is by the far most unpopular of the leading lights, with a negative popularity rating of -22 points.

Even among Labour voters only 46% think he is doing a good job compared with 38% who are dissatisfied with his performance.

It almost as though Mr Prescott is acting as a lightning rod for the government and attracts all the hostility of voters who believe it has yet to deliver.

However, the poll also shows that Peter Mandelson's return to the cabinet has been surprisingly well received by voters. His performance as Northern Ireland secretary ranks him as the fourth most popular cabinet member, with a rating of +14. He also has a higher recognition factor than at least one of those above him.

This has been an impressive performance by Mr Mandelson since in the two previous years he was among the most unpopular ministers in the public's judgement. It seems that the "master of spin" has proved adept at persuading the public to forgive his transgressions and see him as a serious politician. No doubt the recent breakthrough in the Northern Ireland peace process has helped him.

Another cabinet minister who has outperformed most of his colleagues is David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, whose +14 rating (down 7) must reflect the fact that Labour is seen to have made some headway in schools.

In contrast Alan Milburn, who is in charge of the national health service, is suffering badly with a -12 rating compared with his predecessor Frank Dobson's rating of +15 before he left the cabinet to launch his unsuccessful campaign to become London mayor.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who has been battered by crises at Rover and Ford, is not seen as a great success by voters. Only 29% said he is doing a good job, with 34% saying they were not satisfied. This, added to a low visibility factor, gave him a net rating of -5.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone between May 13 and 15. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Journalist faces 'dirty tricks' arrest
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: One of Northern Ireland's leading journalists is facing prosecution under the Official Secrets Act over a series of articles on military intelligence dirty tricks.
fields.body:
One of Northern Ireland's leading journalists is facing prosecution under the Official Secrets Act over a series of articles on military intelligence dirty tricks.

Scotland Yard's special branch wants to question Liam Clarke, Northern Ireland editor of the Sunday Times, in London, and is warning him he will be arrested. Mr Clarke is taking legal advice.

The articles, which appeared late last year, were based on interviews with Martin Ingram, a pseudonym for an ex-member of the force research unit, a shadowy outfit in military intelligence. Its responsibilities included recruiting and running army agents, and infiltrating them into terrorist groups on both sides.

One of those double agents was Brian Nelson, who earned £28,000 a year from the army while also acting as intelligence officer for the Ulster Defence Association. He was implicated in the unresolved murder of Catholic solicitor Pat Finucane in 1989, one of the murkiest episodes of the troubles.

Ingram told the Sunday Times that undercover intelligence mounted an arson attack on offices outside Belfast occupied by Sir John Stevens, now the Metropolitan police commissioner, when he was investigating allegations of collusion between loyalists and members of the security forces in 1990. Fire broke out hours before he planned to arrest Nelson, destroying evidence.

Ingram also claimed at least one soldier was killed because army handlers of an IRA quartermaster in Londonderry refused to sabotage weapons, fearing it would compromise him. The IRA later discovered his double life, and murdered him.

Detective Inspector Alan Learner makes it clear in a registered letter to Mr Clarke he is seeking to interview him be cause of a complaint from the Ministry of Defence and not over suggestions of British intelligence wrong-doing. Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, is believed to have played a key role.

Mr Clarke said yesterday: "I am exposing the activities of military intelligence in the public interest. But the MoD's attitude is to shoot the messenger rather than examine the message. I am willing to be interviewed, although would prefer it to be in Northern Ireland. It was here I wrote the stories, after all.

"I don't think it is necessary to arrest me. I have already offered to give a voluntary undertaking not to identify in any way any undercover operative or to compromise national security."

The move comes as Martin Bright, home affairs correspondent of the Observer, is threatened with contempt of court proceedings and imprisonment for refusing to hand over to the special branch notes relating to interviews with ex-MI5 operative David Shayler

Campaigners suggest Mr Hoon is using both the civil and criminal law to prevent disclosures of illegal activity within the security services. He won a broad injunction preventing Mr Ingram revealing anything more, and now Mr Clarke is facing criminal charges.

The Northern Ireland human rights commission, set up under the Good Friday agreement, yesterday said that arresting Mr Clarke would "further muddy the waters" surrounding army intelligence units in Northern Ireland. Brice Dickson, head of the commission, said: "We will be watching to see if Mr Clarke's human rights are being respected."

Alex Attwood, an assembly member for the Social Democratic and Labour party, urged that the threat of action against Mr Clarke be lifted. "The move fuels suspicions about the conduct of the government and its security agencies."

webTitle: Arsonist killed seven in grudge attack

fields.headline: Arsonist killed seven in grudge attack
fields.standfirst: 'Extremely dangerous man' had history of mental illness
fields.trailText: An unemployed man with a psychopathic disorder yesterday admitted carrying out an arson attack that killed seven people, including four generations of the same family.
fields.body:
An unemployed man with a psychopathic disorder yesterday admitted carrying out an arson attack that killed seven people, including four generations of the same family.

Richard Fielding, 21, who has a history of psychiatric problems, pleaded guilty at the Old Bailey to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He set light to petrol he had poured through the letterbox of a three-storey house in Chingford, east London.

Police believe Fielding started the fire because of a grudge he held against Lee Day, 22, a childhood friend who lived at the house. Mr Day perished in the attack in March last year along with his grandmother Kathleen Day, 76, his mother Sandra Day, 51, his girlfriend Yvonne Culverhouse, 17, and his three children - twin girls Maddison and Rhiannon Himpfen-Day, three, and Reece Himpfen, two.

The only family member to escape was Lee Day's father Brian Day, 52, who was rescued from an upstairs window by neighbours.

Orlando Pownall, prosecuting, said the decision to accept the defendant's plea of manslaughter had been a difficult one. But, he said, in the end the weight of psychiatric evidence that concluded Fielding was mentally ill meant "there could be no realistic prospect of a conviction for murder".

Mr Pownall told the court that on the night of March 6 last year Fielding left his home in Walthamstow following an argument with his mother, and cycled to a nearby petrol station where he filled a five-litre can with four-star petrol.

Fifteen minutes later he arrived at the Day family home where he poured petrol through the letter box and lit the vapours with a match before pedalling off.

In the minutes that followed neighbours battled desperately to save the family from the fire. David Garner kicked down the front door, but was unable to get in because of the ferocity of the blaze.

Another neighbour, James Barnett, tried to smash the back door down, but the heat of the fire was causing the windows of the house to explode, showering glass on those below.

Mr Garner took a ladder to the front of the house where Craig Durrell was able to get Brian Day out.

Fielding was arrested nine days later and charged with the murders. Initially he denied the attack, claiming he knew nothing about it, but later confessed in a series of conversations with police officers. "You'll never get me for murder, I will get off with arson or criminal damage," he told one.

Police were initially baffled as to the motive for the crime, but Fielding appeared to have held a perceived grudge against Lee Day.

The two men had been at secondary school together, and Fielding alleged they had been involved in a robbery in which he injured his hand. Fielding became increasingly paranoid about the injury, claiming it was stopping him working as a DJ and that no woman would want him because of his disfigurement.

He is also understood to have alleged Mr Day supplied him with drugs that damaged his nose, ruining any chance he thought he had of becoming a male model.

The court was told that Fielding had displayed behaviour since childhood the severity of which amounted to a psychopathic disorder.

He began glue sniffing at the age of nine, before progressing on to cannabis, LSD and ecstasy, and at the age of 12 he was excluded from school because of his conduct.

Sarla Verma, who had treated Fielding at the high security Rampton hospital in Nottinghamshire, told the court he was an "extremely dangerous individual" who had shown no remorse for his crimes.

The Recorder of London, Michael Hyam, is due to pass sentence today on Fielding, who denies a charge of attempted murder against Brian Day.

webTitle: Five dead in Spanish fireworks explosion

fields.headline: Five dead in Spanish fireworks explosion
fields.trailText: An explosion ripped through a fireworks factory in south-east Spain yesterday, killing five workers and raising fresh fears about the safety of the manufacturing industry.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and agencies
fields.body:
An explosion ripped through a fireworks factory in south-east Spain yesterday, killing five workers and raising fresh fears about the safety of the manufacturing industry.

Another two people were reported missing in the blast just outside Rafelcofer near Valencia, which came just three days after a devastating fireball from a fireworks warehouse destroyed parts of the Dutch town of Enschede. The cause of the explosion in Spain was not immediately known.

In Holland, shock at Saturday's blast was giving way yesterday to widespread anger that a fireworks depot could legally be located in the heart of a residential area.

As forensic teams resumed the search for remains of bodies from the explosion - which killed 20 and injured 600 - media coverage focused on security lapses and possible links with recent arson attacks in the town.

Enschede's local paper, Tubantia, reported expectations of full compensation from the city authorities.

"I believe there are some very serious questions to be answered by the town council," said lawyer Ernst Foke, whose offices are just streets away from the centre of the blast. "Under Dutch law, they are going to be held responsible."

The owners of the warehouse, identified only as R Bakker and W Pater, have contacted the city and said they will be available for an investigation into the cause of the disaster, said Erik Helder, a deputy mayor.

Puzzlement and consternation were evident across the Netherlands. "It is incomprehensible that something like this can happen in a well-ordered country, with so many rules," the Amsterdam-based newspaper De Telegraaf said in an editorial.

The Dutch prime minister, Wim Kok, announced on Sunday that he was ordering a full investigation into the disaster, the country's worst since an El Al cargo plane crashed into an Amsterdam apartment block in October 1992, killing 43 people.

Pope John Paul II sent a telegram to the Dutch Cardinal Adrianus Simonis expressing his "deep sorrow" in light of the tragedy and saying his prayers were with the victims.

House-to-house searches of the devastated Roombeek neighbourhood resumed at first light, but Dick De Jong, the head of the disaster victim identification team, said he was not optimistic that anyone might still be alive under the rubble, even though only 20% of the blast area had been searched, after rescue efforts were hampered by intense heat. "If you see what has happened and the state of the area, I'm afraid not [anyone else has survived]," Mr De Jong said.

Police Chief Herman van Ruggen said streets on the periphery of the damaged area had been declared structurally sound and were reopened.

Many of the 2,500 residents began returning to their shattered homes. But some people were angry when they arrived only to find that their houses were in the inner restricted area and police turned them away. "We thought we were go ing to be able to go home," said Aryan Curre, 45.

It is still not known what caused the explosion, but some reports have mentioned the possibility of arson after a spate of smaller fires in the area in recent days.

Tubantia said local officials had known how many boxes of fireworks were stored at the site but were not capable of assessing their explosive power, which was thought to be greater than that of commercially available fireworks.

De Telegraaf asked: "Why didn't everyone know that the building was a fireworks warehouse? Are there more fire work depots in the middle of residential areas? Was there enough supervision?"

It called on the government's investigation to look beyond Saturday's tragedy to other fireworks companies and warehouses, as well as the laws and regulations governing fireworks storage.

webTitle: Scotland faces problem of 1m illiterate adults

fields.headline: Scotland faces problem of 1m illiterate adults
fields.trailText: Scotland is suffering from an epidemic of illiteracy affecting as many as one in four adults, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Scotland is suffering from an epidemic of illiteracy affecting as many as one in four adults, it was claimed yesterday.

Estimates drawn up by the Scottish executive suggest that up to 1m Scottish adults are functionally illiterate; 400,000 of them are unable to work because they lack the basic skills to hold down a job; and 1.2m cannot do the basic sums needed to calcuate how much change they should get.

There has never been an attempt to gather statistics on illiteracy in Scotland, but the estimates are consistent with research released last week by the basic skills agency which suggested that 24% of adults in England have poor basic skills.

Henry McLeish, the Scottish enterprise and lifelong learning minister, said efforts would be made to gather exact statistics to tackle the issue. "The problem has got to the stage where it has to be addressed. It is unacceptable in a modern society and we have to take action now to make sure that everyone in Scotland has the same opportunities," he said. "The problem also has a major impact on the economy. We have 120,000 job vacancies and 120,000 people out of work. It could be some of these people could get these jobs if they could meet the required levels of numeracy and literacy."

Literacy campaigners point out that in England and Wales there is a statutory obligation to provide adult basic education but in Scotland it is discretionary. A literacy worker said: "The executive is saying one of the problems they have is that people won't confess they have a problem. But in Scotland how the hell would they know where to go? The main problem in Scotland is that there are very, very few programmes available."

fields.headline: Armed man holds children hostage
fields.trailText: A man brandishing a gun seized about 35 children and adults in a kindergarten in western Norway yesterday but freed all but seven of his hostages unhurt several hours later, the police said.
fields.body:
A man brandishing a gun seized about 35 children and adults in a kindergarten in western Norway yesterday but freed all but seven of his hostages unhurt several hours later, the police said.

Five children and two adults remained trapped with the man about seven hours after their ordeal began in the daycare centre in Hjelmeland, a sleepy coastal village north of the oil port of Stavanger.

The gunman called the police shortly before midday to say he was holding 25 children and 10 adults captive. He threatened to kill the children, who are aged up to six.

About 20 armed police officers, some wearing ski masks, cordoned off the daycare centre, and distraught parents waited nearby for news. In the late afternoon, two lawyers arrived to try to negotiate a deal.

"Two lawyers have arrived, we hope for a solution," the police chief, Olav Sonderland, said after the releases. He declined to reveal the gunman's demands, saying: "We are still negotiating."

The internet version of the daily Dagbladet said the man had been due in court in Stavanger yesterday charged with attempted rape. It said one of the women in the kindergarten had been due to testify against him.

Mr Sonderland said that the man was involved in a court case in which there had not yet been a ruling, but he declined to comment on Dagbladet's report.

"This is the most dramatic experience of my life," said Odd Harald Olsen, the husband of one of the employees who was freed. He said that he spoke briefly to her before she was whisked away to see a psychologist.

"She told me that none of the kids or adults was hurt. Things seem to have been OK."

Fred Roger Johansen, leader of the local council, said the man was armed with a handgun, rather than a shotgun as the police initially believed. The police declined to confirm what type of weapon he had.

"Even though the number [of hostages] has decreased the situation is still serious," Mr Johansen said.

The police declined to comment on reports that the man was the father of one of the children at the centre. Reuters, Oslo

webTitle: Climate change to cost UK billions

fields.headline: Climate change to cost UK billions
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Adapting to climate change will cost Britain £95m a year for 50 years just to keep the sea and rivers from overwhelming existing flood defences, the Department of Environment said yesterday in the first assessment of the cost of the problem.
fields.body:
Adapting to climate change will cost Britain £95m a year for 50 years just to keep the sea and rivers from overwhelming existing flood defences, the Department of Environment said yesterday in the first assessment of the cost of the problem.

Other significant costs include the provision of new water supplies which could be as much as £5bn over the next 30 years to make up for a 20% shortfall, and a similar sum for designing buildings to withstand wind storms.

The document said there were costs in abandoning nature reserves to the sea and replacing them with new ones.

It is the first time any country has attempted to estimate the cost of climate change. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said: "Even if the international community succeeded in cutting its carbon dioxide emissions by 60% to 70% we would still face these costs because of the greenhouse gases we have already put into the atmosphere."

Water companies have been required to submit 25-year plans on how they are going to meet new supply requirements. Experts working for the department believe there may be up to a 30% shortfall in supplies by then.

The figures show it is much cheaper to introduce more efficient domestic appliances and water meters, and recycle waste water, than to build reservoirs or transfer water from north to south.

Roda Verheyen, climate change campaigner at Friends of the Earth, said: "This report should also be a wake up call on the need for urgent action to prevent a global catastrophe."

webTitle: Watchdog attacks Straw's 'back to front' bill

fields.headline: Watchdog attacks Straw's 'back to front' bill
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's freedom of information bill has been attacked for being "over complex" and drafted " back to front " by Elizabeth France, data protection commissioner - the very person whom the home secretary wants to appoint to oversee the new legislation.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's freedom of information bill has been attacked for being "over complex" and drafted " back to front " by Elizabeth France, data protection commissioner - the very person whom the home secretary wants to appoint to oversee the new legislation.

In a speech to the Society of Editors Ms France told journalists she was "no apologist for government policy" and attacked the bill for concentrating on what could not be published, rather than telling the public about their new rights.

She told newspaper editors: "I think it is very important if we're going to have freedom of information law, that there should be as much clarity as possible and there I am prepared to say that I find it incredible that the drafting of recent legislation of which I had to take an interest, is so complex.

"I actually cannot understand why it is so complex."

She added that even her own lawyers found the legislation difficult, and they had the job of providing her with expert advice on what to release to the public and the press.

Ms France went on: "There are actually some important new rights within the legislation, but it ís drafted back to front."

She pointed out that there was nothing in the bill to define its purpose, which would make it very difficult for her to decide how to take decisions on what could be released.

She reiterated her concern that the bill should have a "purpose clause" defining exactly what her new role should be.

The home secretary has refused to include such a clause and made it clear that he does not want officials to have the powers to overrule cabinet ministers on what can be published under the new legislation.

Mrs France warned that she would have no truck with civil servants complaining they had to spend too much time drawing up codes of practice to allow the public the right to access government information.

She said: "There are people already lobbying the Home Office to say that the NHS is going to grind to a halt if everybody has to produce publication schemes.That shouldn't be the case."

Ms France's attack on the bill comes as the government is gearing up for strong opposition in the House of Lords. Peers are expected to press for her to have the power of equivalent information commissioners in the United States, Canada and Ireland to overrule ministers.

They will also press for relaxation of bans covering commercial secrecy and policy papers and for a number of private bodies such as Railtrack, which is responsible for passenger safety, to be brought within the scope of the bill. Ministers have still to set aside time for the bill to be examined clause by clause in the Lords.

She added that even her own lawyers found the legislation difficult, and they had the job of providing her with expert advice on what to release to the public and the press. Ms France went on: "There are actually some important new rights within the legislation, but it ís drafted back to front." She pointed out that there was nothing in the bill to define its purpose, which would make it very difficult for her to decide how to take decisions on what could be released. She reiterated her concern that the bill should have a "purpose clause" defining exactly what her new role should be. The home secretary has refused to include such a clause and made it clear that he does not want officials to have the powers to overrule cabinet ministers on what can be published under the new legislation. Mrs France warned that she would have no truck with civil servants complaining they had to spend too much time drawing up codes of practice to allow the public the right to access government information. She said: "There are people already lobbying the Home Office to say that the NHS is going to grind to a halt if everybody has to produce publication schemes.That shouldn't be the case." Peers are expected to press for her to have the power of equivalent information commissioners in the United States, Canada and Ireland to overrule ministers. They will also press for relaxation of bans covering commercial secrecy and policy papers and for a number of private bodies such as Railtrack, which is responsible for passenger safety, to be brought within the scope of the bill. Ministers have still to set aside time for the bill to be examined clause by clause in the Lords.

fields.headline: Iranian Jews 'spied for 15 years'
fields.trailText: For more than 15 years the 13 Iranian Jews on trial for espionage lured potential informants to wild drinking parties to collect information related to Iran's war with Iraq to pass on to the Israeli intelligence service Mossad, the chief judiciary official involved in the case alleged in an interview with the Guardian yesterday.
fields.body:
For more than 15 years the 13 Iranian Jews on trial for espionage lured potential informants to wild drinking parties to collect information related to Iran's war with Iraq to pass on to the Israeli intelligence service Mossad, the chief judiciary official involved in the case alleged in an interview with the Guardian yesterday.

His comments were the first public statement of the specific accusations against the 13 in the trial, which is being held in secret and has outraged the western world and put Iran on the defensive.

Hossein Ali Amiri said that the spy network, centred in the southern town of Shiraz, was well organised. The mastermind, he alleged, was an Iranian who now lives in an unnamed third country with which Iran does not have an extradition treaty.

The accused were motivated by religious commitment to Israel and the Zionist cause. "Israeli intelligence was after all kinds of information, classified and unclassified. Members of the network were not on limited missions. They were instructed to act in a broad manner," Mr Amiri said.

His file showed that they were given instructions on how to pollute Shiraz's water supply. They had gathered information on military garrisons, including bases in Shiraz, and had drafted scale maps of some military installations.

"Equipment used for espionage has been seized from the suspects," he said. "We also know the places where meetings with Mossad agents were held in third countries. In another case, we learned of a meeting with known Mossad agents in a European country."

Iran has been severely criticised for holding the trial behind closed doors in a revolutionary court. Western gov ernments say they were given private assurances that the trial would be open, despite Iran's public statements that the final decision lay with Judge Sadeq Nourani.

Asked why the trial has been closed, Mr Amiri said the it involved classified military information and national security interest would be at risk if the material became public. He added that judiciary officials were concerned that an open trial might inflame Muslim hostility against Iran's 30,000 Jews.

Esmail Nasseri, the lead defence lawyer, said the accused did indeed collaborate with a foreign state. Responding to the prosecution's case, he described the accused as "religious extremists" who spied from the same commitment with which they led Hebrew lessons and otherwise perpetuated the Jewish faith.

But Mr Nasseri disagreed with Mr Amiri that the material passed to Mossad was classified. Eight of the accused have already confessed to espionage, according to both sides.

Mr Nasseri said he was convinced that the confessions had not been made under pressure. "I asked them in a private meeting, 'Did you make these confessions under duress?' and they said, 'No.'"

Foreign diplomats and Western human rights organisations have accused Iran of forcing the suspects to confess. But both Mr Amiri and Mr Nasseri pointed out that confessions alone are not enough to convict the accused under Iranian law.

Both Mr Nasseri and Mr Amiri said no suspect was likely to receive the death penalty. An initial charge against eight of the 13 of being " mohareb " - one who takes up arms against God - which carries the death penalty, has been quietly dropped, Mr Nasseri said.

webTitle: Rail powers plan starts border row

fields.headline: Rail powers plan starts border row
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A row over whether Whitehall or Holyrood has the final say over train services north of the border threatens to trigger a fresh dispute over devolution.
fields.body:
A row over whether Whitehall or Holyrood has the final say over train services north of the border threatens to trigger a fresh dispute over devolution.

An alliance of Labour, Liberal Democrat and Scottish National Party MPs are opposing moves by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to hand ultimate control to the London-based strategic rail authority.

The MPs, supported by Strathclyde passenger transport authority, claim the plan undermines assurances given two years ago.

Michael Moore, Lib Dem transport spokesman, said: "It is bizarre that in a dispute a quango in London would be able to dictate to elected ministers in Scotland. I think that's patently against the spirit of devolution."

Under the transport bill the strategic rail authority, chaired by former Eurotunnel boss Sir Alastair Morton, could overrule the decisions of Edinburgh's elected ministers.

The MPs believe Holyrood, not the strategic rail authority, should have the final word on timetables and fares of services running exclusively in Scotland such as the Edinburgh-Glasgow route.

They point out that former Scottish minister Henry McLeish, now a member of the Scottish executive, told the House of Commons in March 1998 that post-devolution Scotland's ministers would be able to "instruct" the authority. Mr Moore accused the government of flouting the undertaking and is seeking to have the bill amended. Peers are threatening to challenge the powers of the rail authority when it is debated in the Lords. Mr Prescott has already suffered an embarrassing Commons revolt over plans to part-privatise air traffic control.

Passenger Transport Executives in six English conurbations - Tyne and Wear, Merseyside, Greater Manchester, West Midlands and South and West Yorkshire - are also concerned about the role of the rail authority.

Rail is a "reserved" power but the London government's remit was expected to stretch only to services in England and Wales plus those connecting with Scotland.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Traffic chaos hotspots
The midlands is the worst place for traffic jams with 95% of drivers saying they were delayed each day, followed by Lancashire and the Scottish Borders (93% each), a survey for Autonational Rescue said yesterday. London is considered the seventh worst.
fields.body:
Traffic chaos hotspots
The midlands is the worst place for traffic jams with 95% of drivers saying they were delayed each day, followed by Lancashire and the Scottish Borders (93% each), a survey for Autonational Rescue said yesterday. London is considered the seventh worst.

Mother wins libel damages
The mother of comedian Keith Allen's daughter yesterday accepted undisclosed libel damages in the high court over a claim in the Mirror's Saturday magazine that she was a liar and mentally ill. Razi Mireskandari, representing Anjele Tabatha of Kentish Town, north London, said that the article alleged her daughter, Galoushka, was not Mr Allen's child .

Straw's brother denies assault
A brother of the home secretary Jack Straw pleaded not guilty to a charge of common assault on a 16-year-old girl when he appeared at Nottingham magistrates court yesterday. William Straw, 46, a regional secretary for the Open University, was granted bail until June 20.

Showers follow hottest day
London enjoyed the hottest day of the year yesterday as temperatures reached 28C (82F) but a PA WeatherCentre forecaster warned that the current spell had peaked and cooler, showery weather was on its way.

Help for fans
England football fans at next month's European Championships in Holland and Belgium will be able to get help at special supporters embassies in cities where the team plays and at rail and ferry terminals.

fields.headline: Appeal to dads
fields.standfirst: Posters boost breastfeeding
fields.trailText: New fathers are to be targeted for the first time in a government poster campaign to promote breastfeeding - but without a single suckling baby in sight to offend their delicate sensibilities.
fields.body:
New fathers are to be targeted for the first time in a government poster campaign to promote breastfeeding - but without a single suckling baby in sight to offend their delicate sensibilities.

The posters, show photographs of real parents proudly showing off their breastfed babies.

They were unveiled by the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, yesterday to mark the launch of National Breastfeeding Awareness 2000 Week.

The Department of Health chose not feature pictures of babies breastfeeding because research by health professionals suggested that some men were "put off" by such images while many young mothers on low incomes, whose breastfeeding rates are among the lowest, were "disgusted" by the sight of babies being fed in public.

Ms Cooper described as "stunning" the series of 12 posters encouraging mothers and fathers to "give your baby the best" as part of a national drive to increase awareness of the health benefits of breastfeeding. The campaign aims to boost breastfeeding rates in the UK, which remain among the lowest in Europe with only two thirds of new mothers naturally feeding their infants, falling to less than a quarter of young mothers and those on low incomes.

A health department spokeswoman said the posters, which are to be distributed to hospitals, maternity units and GPs' surgeries, gave natural feeding a positive image, explaining: "Research repeatedly shows that the physical act of breastfeeding is unfortunately still not accepted in public places, especially by men."

fields.headline: Moms in a muddle
fields.standfirst:
US women voters could spike gun lobby

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The "Million Mom March" in Washington and dozens of other US cities at the weekend will increase pressure on the Republican-controlled congress to reconsider its opposition to modest and much-needed gun control measures ahead of this November's general election. But the idea that politicians who receive campaign backing and funds from the pro-gun lobby will pay a heavy price at the polls is optimistic.
fields.body:
The "Million Mom March" in Washington and dozens of other US cities at the weekend will increase pressure on the Republican-controlled congress to reconsider its opposition to modest and much-needed gun control measures ahead of this November's general election. But the idea that politicians who receive campaign backing and funds from the pro-gun lobby will pay a heavy price at the polls is optimistic. Although guns claim about 32,000 lives each year, including many thousands of teenagers and children, America's women voters seem to be as confused as everybody else about what to do and who should do it. The marchers do not aim as high as a total ban on handguns and assault weapons, as in post-Dunblane Britain. This may simply reflect the harsh politics of the possible. But nor do women voters support, in convincing numbers, the Democratic presidential candidate, Al Gore, who, unlike his Republican rival, George W Bush, at least seems sincere in wanting to try to stem the carnage.

Mr Gore has put forward a raft of gun control measures including photo- licensing for handgun sales, child-proof trigger locks, a three-day waiting period for gun purchases, and tougher penalties for gun-related crime. This is hardly radical stuff. But Mr Bush, in contrast, opposes national gun registration, stresses the need to enforce existing laws more effectively, and constantly reiterates, for the benefit of the deeply unpleasant National Rifle Association and its acolytes, his unthinking belief in the "law-abiding American's constitutional right to own guns to protect family and home".

This overall stance puts Mr Bush at odds with public opinion. Gallup surveys show 61% of Americans favour stricter firearms controls; 68% support a ban on semi-automatic assault guns; and 73% back handgun registration. And yet it is the gung-ho Mr Bush who is currently gaining in national polls. He leads Mr Gore among male voters (including key swing states with a large hunting fraternity like Ohio) and also, increasingly, among women. They, reportedly, find the boyish-looking Mr Bush more appealing on television than his earnest rival. If such whimsy translates into votes, it will be depressing. While the men have proved incapable of ending this national scandal, all of America's moms together could swiftly vanquish the gun menace. They have the electoral firepower. But will they bring it to bear?

fields.headline: Gervase Cowell
fields.standfirst: British spymaster behind Oleg Penkovsky, whose disclosures sparked the Cuban missile crisis
fields.trailText: Gervase Cowell, who has died aged 73, has a place in espionage history as a member of the husband-and-wife team from the British Secret Intelligence Service (SIS) which ran Colonel Oleg Penkovsky, probably the most productive spy ever recruited by the west during the cold war.
fields.body:
Gervase Cowell, who has died aged 73, has a place in espionage history as a member of the husband-and-wife team from the British Secret Intelligence Service (SIS) which ran Colonel Oleg Penkovsky, probably the most productive spy ever recruited by the west during the cold war.

Cowell and his wife Pamela, a former SIS secretary whom he married in 1954, were sent to Moscow to "service" Penkovsky - to pass on SIS and CIA requests, to provide him with film for his spy camera, and to collect both his photographs of top-secret Soviet documents and his written assessments of what was going on in the Kremlin.

Since this was in 1962, at a time when the Soviet Union and the west hovered on the brink of nuclear war over the Cuban missile crisis, their assignment carried heavy responsibilities. The American authors, Jerrold L Schecter and Peter S Deriabin, who have examined both western and Soviet archives of the period, regard Penkovsky as "the spy who saved the world". If this is true, the Cowells deserve credit for the part they played as frontline members of the joint SIS/CIA team that ran the superspy.

Penkovsky was a dream defector. He was well-placed in the Soviet hierarchy, and was prepared to remain in place gathering what information he could for as long as the KGB did not suspect him.

The first husband-and-wife team to run him were Charles "Rauri" and Janet Chisholm. Mrs Chisholm would take her three children for a walk in a Moscow park, Penkovsky would wander past, stop to admire the baby and leave his packet of information in the pram. But Mrs Chisholm was recalled to London in June 1962 because she was pregnant. The Cowells replaced her, but the plan for servicing Penkovsky was different.

All official British flats in Moscow kept a tin of Harpic in the bathroom. Penkovsky would be invited to a party in one of the flats. Mrs Cowell would go to the bathroom and replace the Harpic tin with one that had a false bottom containing film and instructions. Penkovsky would enter the bathroom, remove the film and insert his material - ready for Mrs Cowell to collect.

But Penkovsky had already supplied his most vital piece of information. A year earlier, he had handed over photographs of a Soviet missile manual, which had enabled the Americans to identify launch sites the Soviets were building in Cuba as being for SS-4 missiles. With a range of 1,100 miles, these were quite capable of hitting Washington.

Challenged over this disclosure by President Kennedy, the Soviet leader, Nikita Krushchev, refused to back down and remove the weapons without concessions over American missiles in Turkey. In the end, both leaders realised that their intransigence could result in a nuclear war, and they quickly reached an accommodation.

After that, the Cowells did not last much longer in the Soviet Union. The KGB, suspicious of Penkovsky for some time, arrested him on October 22 1962, put him on trial and executed him on May 16 the following year. In the subsequent fall-out, the role of the Cowells was revealed and they were speedily expelled from Moscow.

Cowell had joined SIS in 1951, having been spotted by secret service recruiters at St Catharine's College, Cambridge, where he took a first-class degress in Russian and French. He was an ideal recruit; a reserved manner concealed a steely determination and a deep love of his country.

Born in Sale, Cheshire, he had studied under Jesuits at St Bede's College, Manchester, before volunteering for the RAF as soon as he turned 18. After the war, he worked for GCHQ, the government agency which intercepts military and commercial communications for intelligence purposes. Cowell's task was listening to Soviet traffic.

After training, he was posted abroad under Foreign Office cover, first to the political division of the allied control commission in Germany, and then, in 1958, to the British embassy in Jordan. In between these postings, he worked as a desk officer at SIS headquarters in London.

After his expulsion from Moscow, Cowell served in Bonn from 1964-66, in Paris from 1972-76 and in Tel Aviv from 1978-81, when he took early retirement. Four years later, having found no satisfactory outlet for his energy, he returned to SIS to do research work in its archive. In 1988, the Foreign Office made him its adviser on the wartime work of the Special Operations Executive (SOE), helping historians assess its importance.

The work gripped him, and on his final retirement in 1996 he became chairman of the historical sub-committee of the Special Forces Club. He also used his considerable artistic talent to design two memorial plaques, one in Westminister Abbey to commemorate the work of SOE, and the other at the site of Ravensbruck concentration camp, in memory of SOE women agents who were executed there.

Cowell enjoyed Russian literature and translated several Russian authors, including Ivan Valeriy and Vladimir Tendryakov. He was made an MBE in the last new year's honours list. He leaves his wife, two sons and two daughters.

fields.headline: Charles Boxer
fields.standfirst: Magisterial historian of Portugal and its dark imperial past
fields.trailText: Professor Charles Boxer, who has died aged 96, was one of the best British historians of early European overseas expansion and empire- building in Asia and Brazil. As such, he was perhaps better known and honoured internationally than in his native England.
fields.body:
Professor Charles Boxer, who has died aged 96, was one of the best British historians of early European overseas expansion and empire- building in Asia and Brazil. As such, he was perhaps better known and honoured internationally than in his native England. Upon the news of his death in Portugal, he was hailed as the academic who had opened the "musty store-chests" of the past to disclose a vast panorama of corruption and exploitation behind the image of golden ages promoted by cultural diplomacy.

Boxer's main subjects were the Portuguese and Dutch overseas expansions and rival conquests in Asia, Brazil and Angola, on which he produced more than 350 writings, including a dozen major essays in book form, as well as the classic panoramic text- books, The Dutch Seaborn Empire, 1600-1800 (1965) and The Portuguese Seaborn Empire: 1415-1825 (1969).

In 1947 he was appointed as Camoens professor of Portuguese studies, at King's College, London University, a post founded and co-funded by Lisbon, and, at the time, the only such chair in the English-speaking world. He held the position until his retirement in 1967 (since when he has been professor emeritus), with an interruption from 1951 to 1953 as the university's professor of the history of the far east.

Longevity, hard research and fecund writing, combined with a somewhat hedonistic attachment to social life, were not the only unusual marks of Boxer's life and career. Born at Sandown, on the Isle of Wight, he was educated at Wellington College and Sandhurst, from where his precocious interest in Japanese language and culture opened an early career in the army.

In 1923, he joined the Lincolnshire regiment as a second lieutenant, and, by 1930, was attached to the Japanese army as a language officer. From 1936, he served in military intelligence in Hong Kong, and in December 1941, during the Japanese attack, he was wounded and captured. His knowledge of the language, and all things Japanese, earned him the respect of his captors.

Boxer resigned from the army with the rank of major in 1947 when offered the Camoens chair. With access to neglected Dutch and Portuguese colonial archives in the far-flung Asian outposts, he developed his interest in those histories. His range of themes, as exemplified in books such as Race Relations In The Portuguese Colonial Empire (1963) or Mary and Misogyny: Women In Iberian Expansion (1975), were early explorations of the themes of feminism and anti-racism, providing evidence of the relation between the past and the present.

Boxer's attachment to maritime and military history is shown in the variety of themes in dozens of articles, essays and monographs, such as The Anglo-Dutch Wars Of The 17th Century (1974), which followed The Tragic History Of The Sea (1959) and Fort Jesus And The Portuguese In Mombasa (1960). In his fluent and entertaining style, his vision travelled far and wide, both in chronology and geography. But it is in his writings on Brazil and its former empire that he rose above much academic erudition.

Despite lacking a university degree himself, Boxer held five successive chairs in Portuguese and maritime studies in as many universities in Britain and the US, as well as honorary doctorates and scholarships, and the highest national decoration from Portugal, among other countries. Some critics noted his conceited delight at these honours, but even they admitted that he had plenty to be conceited about.

As Boxer discovered, the secret of Portugal's longevity as an imperial power was a singular record of repressive and obscurantist rule, aided and abetted by its historic alliance with Britain. And, since the history of Portugal has become intertwined with that of other countries, and Portuguese is the language of Brazil, Angola, Mozambique, Guinea Bissau, Cape Verde and St Tome Island, Boxer's pioneering achievement in opening the "musty store-chests" has as much relevance for 180m Brazilians and Africans now rediscovering their past.

Boxer was a larger than life figure. His scholarship, both specialist and interdisciplinary, was gained by research and reading - he owned a library of institutional proportions - as well as by experience in his extensive travels.

He was also a man of great sensitivity. When I thanked him for some kind words he had written concerning my then somewhat lonely fight against the Salazar regime in Portugal, he just said he felt he was only doing a duty, adding, "I like action - moral courage is much less common than intelligence." He had once himself been declared persona non grata in Portugal, after his refutation of Dr Salazar's claim of the miracle of non-racialism in the empire.

In his later books, he made impressive links between early maritime and space exploits, not least by pointing out that the Portuguese invested decades of endeavour and resources without being sure what lay beyond the oceans. The analogies were used by American astronauts to plead for continued support for the Nasa space programme.

Boxer's second wife, Emily, whom he married in 1945, died in 1997. He is survived by his daughters Carola and Amanda.

fields.headline: Jack Best
fields.standfirst: Resolute PoW involved in the great Colditz glider escape plan
fields.trailText: Jack Best, who has died aged 87, will be remembered as an irreconcilable PoW of the Germ- ans in the second world war, who was indefatigable in his attempts to escape captivity. He was eventually imprisoned in the notorious Castle Colditz, which housed some of the most obdurate allied PoWs, and took part in the audacious plan to build a glider and fly out of the castle.
fields.body:
Jack Best, who has died aged 87, will be remembered as an irreconcilable PoW of the Germ- ans in the second world war, who was indefatigable in his attempts to escape captivity. He was eventually imprisoned in the notorious Castle Colditz, which housed some of the most obdurate allied PoWs, and took part in the audacious plan to build a glider and fly out of the castle.

Born at Vivod, near Llangollen, in north Wales, Best was educated at Stowe school and, in 1931, settled in Kenya as an apprentice farmer. At the outbreak of war, he trained for a civilian pilot's licence and joined the RAF, gaining his wings at a military flying school in Iraq.

His first duties, as a ferry pilot, involved flying from what was then the Gold Coast to Cairo. In 1941, he transferred to Malta, and flew twin-engined Maryland bombers on reconnaissance patrols. On one operation, he ran out of fuel off southern Greece and ditched in the Mediterranean. He was captured and sent to a series of German prison camps.

While at Stalag Luft III, in Silesia, Best made several attempts to escape. His most successful foray was in June 1942, when, with William Goldfinch and Harry Lamond, he dug an 80ft tunnel well beyond the perimeter wire and walked out into the nearby woods.

The three escapees planned to steal a Junkers Ju 52 transport plane and fly out of Germany but, after observing several airfields, they abandoned the scheme in favour of stowing away on a Sweden-bound ship at Stettin (Czezecin). Surviving on raw potatoes, they reached the river Oder, but were discovered asleep under a skiff and sent to Colditz.

At the castle, Best continued his escape activities, becoming a prominent "ghost". These were PoWs who hid within the prison area, leading the authorities to believe they had escaped, but, in reality, leaving them time to continue their tunnelling activities. In 1944, Best did escape with a fellow officer, and crossed Germany from Saxony to Rheine on the river Ems, before his prison pallor betrayed his disguise as a Flemish labourer. He was quickly returned to Colditz, where the PoWs conceived their plan to build a glider and fly to freedom.

Work began in a secret room behind a false wall built by Best in the chapel roof. The glider drawings were made by Goldfinch, and saws and other tools were improvised from iron window bars, bedsteads and gramophone springs. The wingspars and parts of the fuselage were made from floorboards and bed slats. The control wires were utilised from electric cable, and the glider's wing and fuselage material was fabricated from the PoWs' cotton sleeping bags. Best worked assiduously on the project for nine months until construction was completed.

The glider was to carry two men to freedom, taking them over the river Mulder on what was literally a flying start ahead of any pursuers. The plan was to break a hole in the chapel wall and drag the fuselage on to the roof. The 32ft-span wings would then be manhandled out and attached to the fuselage. An improvised catapult, based on pulley systems, was to launch the aircraft. But it never flew because the Americans liberated Colditz in April 1945.

Yet the plan could have worked. In 1993, Best and some companions returned to Colditz and flew a model glider, one-third the size of their original, from the chapel roof. More conclusively, last February, Best and Goldfinch saw a replica of their glider successfully piloted by John Lee at RAF Odiham, Hampshire, for a Channel 4 documentary, Escape From Colditz.

Best was awarded an MBE (military) in 1945, and subsequently farmed in Kenya. In the early 1960s, he returned to Britain and farmed for many years in Herefordshire. His 1938 marriage to Constance Otter was dissolved in 1959, and he married Elizabeth Bunting. She survives him, as do the son and daughter of his first marriage.

John William 'Jack' Best, pilot, wartime escaper and farmer, born August 6 1912; died April 22 2000
