webTitle: Anarchy reigns in cities, say police

fields.headline: Anarchy reigns in cities, say police
fields.trailText: Police Federation leaders last night claimed that the hearts of many British cities were now no go areas where disorder and anarchy reigned because of a lack of officers.
fields.body:
Police Federation leaders last night claimed that the hearts of many British cities were now no go areas where disorder and anarchy reigned because of a lack of officers.

Fred Broughton, chairman of the federation, is this week to ask the home secretary, Jack Straw, to set up a royal commission to review the structure of forces, police training and the merits of patrolling.

Mr Broughton, briefing reporters at the beginning of the federation's week-long conference in Brighton, said the centres of London, Manchester, Liverpool and Leeds were now effectively no-go areas because of violence and a complete lack of a police presence.

"There is a sense of disorder and anarchy in many of these areas. Most people would avoid these hot spots altogether as there are no police officers to turn to," he said, adding that he was particularly talking about areas outside pubs and nightclubs between 10pm and 2am.

He said that alternatives such as neighbourhood watch and special constables had failed to replace effective policing and communities were emerging which had no policing at all.

He claimed there were now fewer police officers in England and Wales per head of population than anywhere else in the European Union except Denmark.

The case of Tony Martin, jailed for killing an intruder, had highlighted the scandal of rural policing. "Irrespective of whether Tony Martin was guilty or not, the problem is that communities such as his are unable to rely on the police," he said.

The closure of local police stations for financial reasons had been disastrous, he added.

The public were now more likely to see a traffic warden patrolling the streets than a police officer and it was an indication that the public was not getting the service it was entitled to.

The call for a new royal commission on policing will be made by Mr Broughton just before Jack Straw addresses the conference on Wednesday morning. The last royal commission on the police reported in 1966 and led to a large number of amalgamations of small police forces.

Mr Straw will be followed by a much trailed speech by the Conservative leader, William Hague, on Thursday morning. Mr Hague is expected to launch an onslaught on the liberal influence within the criminal justice system as well as confirming his plans to scrap the ancient "double jeopardy" rule whereby somebody cannot be tried twice for the same offence.

 The police are guilty of institutional sexism with women discriminated against and patronised by male colleagues, a Police Federation meeting heard yesterday.

Female officers were often passed over for promotion and given "soft" tasks, unsuitable uniforms and equipment, and inappropriate training.

Jan Berry, general secretary of the Police Federation and a chief inspector in the Kent force, told a meeting in Brighton that women were still suffering discrimination despite high profile cases brought to tribunals in recent years. "Just as we have institutional racism in the service so we have institutional sexism.

"Some of the different treatment is deeply set. There may be no intention to treat differently but the treatment is different and it is because we are female."

The majority of women accepted the discrimination because they wanted to be "part of the team. We weigh up the cost of putting our heads above the parapet and we decide that it is less painful to say nothing."

fields.headline: Craig Stevens
fields.trailText: Some actors toil away virtually unrecognised for years, until one role comes along with which they will always be identified and which suddenly makes them visible to a wider public. Craig Stevens, who has died aged 81, was in the movies for 17 years, in both leads and supporting roles, before, in 1958, being offered the part of the suave private eye in Peter Gunn, one of the first of the elegant, cool and witty detectives to be seen on television.
fields.body:
Some actors toil away virtually unrecognised for years, until one role comes along with which they will always be identified and which suddenly makes them visible to a wider public. Craig Stevens, who has died aged 81, was in the movies for 17 years, in both leads and supporting roles, before, in 1958, being offered the part of the suave private eye in Peter Gunn, one of the first of the elegant, cool and witty detectives to be seen on television.

It is surprising that it took so long for the tall, dark and handsome Stevens to make his mark. Born in Montana, he was studying dentistry at the University of Kansas when he decided he would rather become an actor.

His career started well after he signed a contract with Warner Bros in 1941, with hardly any professional experience to his credit. He was given the romantic lead as a bridge-builder in one of his first films, Steel Against The Sky (1941), opposite Alexis Smith, whom he married three years later. As a pilot in Dive Bomber (1941), he had to watch Errol Flynn and Smith as lovers. Later, he played an airman again in God Is My Co-Pilot (1945).

Warner Bros only risked him as a lead in second features, such as Spy Ship and Secret Enemies (both 1942), in which he tracked down Nazi agents. He and his new wife were together again in Doughgirls and Hollywood Canteen (both 1944), but over the next few years Stevens slipped further down the credits, while Smith retained her top-ranking status at Warners. When Stevens left the studio to go freelance in 1950, his wife followed suit.

Even after that, his career did not exactly take off. He soon found himself playing straight man to the Bowery Boys in Blues Busters (1950) and Abbot And Costello Meet Dr Jekyll And Mr Hyde (1953). In The French Line (1954), he played heiress Jane Russell's stuffy and acquisitive fiancé, and in the cheapo horror film The Deadly Mantis (1957) he was a solider trying to destroy a mammoth insect.

Luckily, Blake Edwards came along and gave Stevens the title role in his TV series, Peter Gunn. With his deadpan humour, well-cut suits, attraction for sophisticated women and modern jazz, he offered a new image of the private eye. Edwards also shot the series in a quietly understated, film-noir style, counterpointed by the jazzy instrumental score of Henry Mancini. In 1967, he directed a harder-edged, but rather salacious, feature film version called Gunn, in which Stevens repeated his most famous role. His last screen role was in Edwards's bilious satire S.O.B. (1983).

In 1993, just short of their golden anniversary, Alexis Smith died. In recent years, Stevens lived with Frances Bergen, widow of ventriloquist Edgar Bergen and mother of Candice.

fields.headline: Cannes
fields.trailText: Pop star Dave Stewart lashed out at how he is perceived as a "mental patient" in Britain after his debut film was shown in Cannes yesterday.
fields.body:
Pop star Dave Stewart lashed out at how he is perceived as a "mental patient" in Britain after his debut film was shown in Cannes yesterday.

Stewart, one half of the 1980s supergroup the Eurythmics, launched the attack after Honest, his gem robbery caper set in the London of the swinging sixties and starring three members of the band All Saints, got a surprisingly warm reception, particularly from the Americans. Critics had anticipated another Spiceworld, the Spice Girl vehicle they gave a panning - although it did boom at the box office.

"Back in Britain, you have some success and they want to kill you," Stewart said, before blaming the British press for getting the film an 18 certificate. "The censors were so paranoid because of the pile of bollocks about sex and drugs. They write anything they want. [They say] I'm a mental patient, who has a nudist colony in the south of France, and that I teach hairless dogs to speak.

"There is also an assumption that you shouldn't make a film if you are a pop musician. It's nice to be in a country where they are interested in writing about the film rather than my hairless dog farm."

Stewart talked at length about how he drew on his own drug taking to shoot the film's acid trip scenes. "A lot of method went into [researching] the drug scenes," he said. "Apart from taking LSD hundreds of times myself I watched a lot of 1960s films like Jacob's Ladder. Having a lot of experience of taking these drugs was a help, not that it helps me in my everyday life."

Stewart also revealed that the Jimmy Hendrix estate refused to allow his music to be used in the film because they "did not want Jimmy's name connected with sex and drugs".

He also expounded on his theories about the "paradise syndrome" brought on by consumerism that has kept the present generation of young people from rebelling. All Saint Melanie Blatt complained that modern youngsters were too apathetic to be as exciting as their 1960s counterparts. "I would love to be part of a rebellion about something. Kids today are too spoilt. They have everything they want and nothing to rebel about. There's a lot less to fight for. They are happy to play video games."

The shock yesterday in Cannes, however, was flamboyant dancer Michael Flatley unveiling his latest incarnation - as a charming and almost modest film star.

Flatley, whose stage show has played to 1m people in Europe in seven weeks, declared: "I might make a hell of a movie star."

The $20m love story, provisionally called Lord Of The Dance, will be shot in Britain and Ireland this summer, and has been written by Flatley and Shane Connaughton, who wrote the Oscar-winning My Left Foot. "I've heard the jokes already," said Flatley. "It'll be My Two Left Feet. I don't fancy myself as a great actor, but I might make a hell of a movie star."

 Several distributors yesterday walked out of the Cannes screening of a British-made film incorporating genuine footage of shootings and hangings.

Cold Fish, the debut film by commercial photographer David Fairman, tells the story of an aspiring reporter, played by Jon-Paul Gates, who uncovers the world of video artists who record real-life acts of violence.

To convey the depravity of the video nasties and their makers, Fairman has used archive footage of violent deaths, including Russian soldiers being hanged by the Nazis and Los Angeles police department officers watching a man shoot himself.
fields.bodyText: Pop star Dave Stewart lashed out at how he is perceived as a "mental patient" in Britain after his debut film was shown in Cannes yesterday. Stewart, one half of the 1980s supergroup the Eurythmics, launched the attack after Honest, his gem robbery caper set in the London of the swinging sixties and starring three members of the band All Saints, got a surprisingly warm reception, particularly from the Americans. Critics had anticipated another Spiceworld, the Spice Girl vehicle they gave a panning - although it did boom at the box office. "Back in Britain, you have some success and they want to kill you," Stewart said, before blaming the British press for getting the film an 18 certificate. "The censors were so paranoid because of the pile of bollocks about sex and drugs. They write anything they want. [They say] I'm a mental patient, who has a nudist colony in the south of France, and that I teach hairless dogs to speak. "There is also an assumption that you shouldn't make a film if you are a pop musician. It's nice to be in a country where they are interested in writing about the film rather than my hairless dog farm." Stewart talked at length about how he drew on his own drug taking to shoot the film's acid trip scenes. "A lot of method went into [researching] the drug scenes," he said. "Apart from taking LSD hundreds of times myself I watched a lot of 1960s films like Jacob's Ladder. Having a lot of experience of taking these drugs was a help, not that it helps me in my everyday life." Stewart also revealed that the Jimmy Hendrix estate refused to allow his music to be used in the film because they "did not want Jimmy's name connected with sex and drugs". He also expounded on his theories about the "paradise syndrome" brought on by consumerism that has kept the present generation of young people from rebelling. All Saint Melanie Blatt complained that modern youngsters were too apathetic to be as exciting as their 1960s counterparts. "I would love to be part of a rebellion about something. Kids today are too spoilt. They have everything they want and nothing to rebel about. There's a lot less to fight for. They are happy to play video games." The shock yesterday in Cannes, however, was flamboyant dancer Michael Flatley unveiling his latest incarnation - as a charming and almost modest film star. Flatley, whose stage show has played to 1m people in Europe in seven weeks, declared: "I might make a hell of a movie star." The $20m love story, provisionally called Lord Of The Dance, will be shot in Britain and Ireland this summer, and has been written by Flatley and Shane Connaughton, who wrote the Oscar-winning My Left Foot. "I've heard the jokes already," said Flatley. "It'll be My Two Left Feet. I don't fancy myself as a great actor, but I might make a hell of a movie star."  Several distributors yesterday walked out of the Cannes screening of a British-made film incorporating genuine footage of shootings and hangings. fields.headline: Yesterday: good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Bad day
fields.body:
Bad day

Tony Blair was recently to be found taking a computer course with members of the public in Durham. The caring premier turned to his neighbour during an exam and tried to put him at ease, saying he should ignore the fact he was sitting next to a prime minister. But the fellow trainee merely replied: "That's not why I'm feeling uncomfortable. On every test I'm getting the right answers and you're getting the wrong ones, I'm long-term unemployed and you're the bloody prime minister."

Good day

For two small English market towns, Needham Market in Suffolk and Market Rasen, Lincolnshire. Both have been put firmly on the parliamentary map thanks to two recently ennobled lords. Suffolk county councillor Ros Scott, 42, took her seat on the Liberal Democrat benches as Lady Scott of Needham Market. Former MSF union chief Anne Gibson, 59, joined Labour peers as Lady Gibson of Market Rasen.

Today

Commons: Foreign Office questions. Debates initiated by Tories on UK manufacturing and enterprise, and future of the teaching profession. Backbench debates in Westminster Hall include wealth, poverty, and the economic system, opened by Tony Benn. Lords: Electronic communications bill, report. Terrorism bill, committee.

fields.headline: That's the right medicine
fields.trailText: I have cancer and have seen more than 16 doctors in the last three years. Only one was "uncaring and arrogant" (Uncaring doctors, May 13).
fields.body:
I have cancer and have seen more than 16 doctors in the last three years. Only one was "uncaring and arrogant" (Uncaring doctors, May 13). My GPs, main specialist and all the others have discussed options, explained procedures fully, talked things through person to person and seemed to show an interest in me. They are/were great!

We need a system which enables patients to report someone with an arrogant or uncaring attitude without feeling that treatment might be affected. I found it tricky to do anything about the arrogant doctor. I just asked my GP to try to arrange for me to see someone else. Patient satisfaction should be measured, anonymously.
Janet Nightingale
Rowley Regis, West Midlands
janet.nightingale@which.net

 Many medical schools are questioning a selection procedure based primarily on academic results. Doctors need empathy as well as straight As. Students are now taught communication skills. Postgraduate training in general practice emphasises patient-centred consultation. To communicate properly doctors and nurses need time with people. Time is a resource which has been eroded by "efficiency" and "cost savings".

I have never come across a doctor or nurse who wanted to be bad but I have met many who, through exhaustion, frustration and depression, have had the flame that brought them into medicine snuffed out.
Martin McShane
Chair, North east Derbyshire PCG
Martin.McShane@tesco.net

webTitle: Envoys warn of inner EU group with closer ties

fields.headline: Envoys warn of inner EU group with closer ties
fields.trailText: The French and German ambassadors to London served notice yesterday that their countries intend to form the engine room of a small group of European Union states co-operating more closely than the rest.
fields.body:
The French and German ambassadors to London served notice yesterday that their countries intend to form the engine room of a small group of European Union states co-operating more closely than the rest.

The move will alarm Britain which fears it could be excluded as pro-integration countries press ahead, using the cloak of enlargement of the EU to do so.

The two diplomats told a Lords select committee hearing on Europe that the inner group of countries must be allowed to press ahead with closer co-operation without other member states vetoing their plans.

Both men, speaking in advance of Thursday's Franco-German summit, said the idea of enhanced co-operation will form a central part of the agenda for the EU inter-governmental conference (IGC) in December.

The summit is being billed as an attempt to relaunch the Franco-German alliance on European policy before France takes up the six-month EU presidency in June.

Last week the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, called for a more integrationist agenda to deal with the enlargement of the EU to as many as 25 countries. Discussing the political impact of enlargement, the German ambassador, Dr Hans-Friedrich von Ploetz, told the Lords committee: "Everyone should be able to join up, but such a big group needs some kind of engine."

He claimed the EU would lose authority in the eyes of its citizens if progress was restricted to the pace of the slowest after enlargement. If integrationist states were banned from going further and quicker using the institutions of the EU, they would reach co-operation agreements outside the EU.

The French ambassador, Daniel Bernard, cited education, culture, single currency and environment as areas where an inner group might be allowed to co-operate.

Mr Bernard added that both Germany and France would be pressing at the IGC for majority voting to become the norm on the council of ministers. He said the veto should only be retained for issues regarded as constitutional importance to nation states.

At present within the IGC there is almost no agreement on the areas where the existing national veto might be dropped.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We moved mountains, page 13, yesterday, in a report headed Putin redraws the map of Russia. We, rather than the Russian president, placed the Urals, 900 miles west of Moscow. They are, of course, east of Moscow.
fields.body:
We moved mountains, page 13, yesterday, in a report headed Putin redraws the map of Russia. We, rather than the Russian president, placed the Urals, 900 miles west of Moscow. They are, of course, east of Moscow.

We wrongly referred to Glamis Castle as the birthplace of the Queen Mother, in a report, page 5, May 13. She was born at St. Paul's Waldenbury, Hitchin, Hertfordshire.

There were two slips in our quiz, page 11, Sport, May 13. We attributed the "jaw-jaw" remark to Harold Macmillan instead of Winston Churchill (speech at the White House, June 26, 1954; Oxford Dictionary of Quotations). A mis print suggested that Lady Jane Grey spent her brief period on the throne in 1774. That should have been 1553 (she was executed in 1554).

There was a mathematical lapse in our article about the athletics manager Lorna Boothe, page 8, G2, May 4. We said she was 11 when she joined her local athletics club, 30 years ago. Later in the piece we said she was now 45. We should have said she joined her athletics club 34 years ago.

Homophone corner, from a column, page 28, May 13, in which we referred to "...the City lawyers who these days pour over flotation documents..."

Another one, from page 3, Office hours, yesterday, "Certainly without pneumatic seats and articulating backs and ergonomic lumber support, most of us would be laid out flat with back ache for much of the year."

fields.headline: Children on display
fields.trailText: It's not true, as Ann Evans suggests (Letters, May 15), that Tate Modern and the Globe are the only London arts institutions to welcome whole families. We have taken our children - now 12, 10 and seven - to virtually all London museums since they were in pouches, buggies and backpacks or toddling in reins. Few of them make specific provision for children.
fields.body:
It's not true, as Ann Evans suggests (Letters, May 15), that Tate Modern and the Globe are the only London arts institutions to welcome whole families. We have taken our children - now 12, 10 and seven - to virtually all London museums since they were in pouches, buggies and backpacks or toddling in reins. Few of them make specific provision for children - the Science Museum is a rare exception - but even when ours were in nappies we encountered few problems. Although there was that National Gallery guard who flinched at a baby being breastfed in front of a picture of the Virgin and the infant Jesus in pretty much the same situation. Britain isn't child-unfriendly: just be brave and do it.
Alan Burkitt-Gray
London
alan@bg.clara.net

 Tate Modern child friendly? We went on Saturday and were perplexed to find only one baby changing facility on seven floors. For £150m I would have thought a couple more would have been possible. Unless we changed our son on the artworks, perhaps...

There were only four lifts to supplement the escalators. These were so overcrowded that anyone in a wheelchair, or with a pram, could be waiting 20 minutes for a space.
Stephen Cox
London

 As far as I'm concerned, the more places from which children are banned the better. Art galleries especially. Parents too often seem oblivious to the disruption their little darlings cause. What on earth do you expect them to gain from the experience anyway?
Luke Tredinnick
London

fields.headline: A less green Rhineland
fields.standfirst: Where the wee frees ride again
fields.trailText: The Christian (sic) Democrats played the race card in Sunday's state elections in North Rhine-Westphalia and a fat lot of good it did them.
fields.body:
The Christian (sic) Democrats played the race card in Sunday's state elections in North Rhine-Westphalia and a fat lot of good it did them. "Children not Indians" - a pun in German - they said, contrasting their pro-family stance with chancellor Schröder's plan to relieve information technology shortages by recruiting Asian professionals. It was a thoroughly mixed message. The Christian Democrat Union (CDU) has just elected as leader a woman who has little time for patriarchy; under the Social Democrats (SPD) numbers of successful asylum seekers have fallen as procedures have toughened.

In the event both Germany's main parties lost. The CDU got fractionally less than last time round in 1995, when Helmut Kohl was riding high. The SPD was down 3.2% but their man will continue as regional prime minister; more importantly, the haemorrhage of SPD support to the CDU during Gerhard Schröder's dog days last year looks to be over. The CDU's Angela Merkel has a lot to do to exorcise her party's demons. As the economy picks up and joblessness falls - without adopting too much Anglo-Saxon "flexibility" - the Schröder coalition looks set to do reasonably in the next set of regional elections, in Baden-Württemberg and Rhineland-Palatinate, next spring.

Except that "coalition" has now become problematical. The main event in North Rhine-Westphalia was the poor showing of the Greens, coalition partners of the SPD in Düsseldorf as in Berlin. Their voters abstained - the turnout was a record low. Former CDU voters opted for post-war Germany's balancing item, the Free Democrats. These notionally free market liberals have made coalitions with both left and right. Their immediate value to chancellor Schröder is as a threat to his cabinet Greens. If they do not toe the line - and show more flexibility on nuclear energy, say - he now has an alternative partner.

webTitle: Archbishop may not be adopting the best attitude

fields.headline: Archbishop may not be adopting the best attitude
fields.trailText: I can understand the Archbishop of Canterbury's indignation that his son had problems when he and his wife were attempting to adopt though, as a former social worker, I am sure the son was clear about the reasons for the lengthy and rigorous assessment (Carey urges easier adoption laws, May 12).
fields.body:
I can understand the Archbishop of Canterbury's indignation that his son had problems when he and his wife were attempting to adopt though, as a former social worker, I am sure the son was clear about the reasons for the lengthy and rigorous assessment (Carey urges easier adoption laws, May 12).

Dr Carey states that those who adopt "are motivated by love". While this may be true for the majority of adopters, love may not be the only motivation, or even the strongest.

Many seek to adopt to fulfil their own desire for a child; through pressure from others to conform to the family stereotype; or to satisfy a partner's needs. There will be a few who have more sinister motives - and one of the reasons for the rigorous examination of potential adopters is to exclude such people. Sadly, some slip through even with the high standards of assessment we use now: children have been abused in foster and adoptive homes as well as in residential care.

If children have suffered systematic abuse or neglect in their original families, they may expect this to continue in their new families; they may even seek to replicate it, since it has been the only consistency they have known. "Love" may be an alien concept to them, and normal parenting approaches just don't work.

Adoption may be a minority issue, statistically, but given that many adopted people develop problems that impinge on health, education and social services, and that many people who grew up in care are now homeless, in psychiatric care or in prison, marginalising adoption costs this country dearly. If the government's current interest in improving adoption services results only in further responsibilities being placed on local authorities without the funding to carry them out, a great opportunity will have been wasted.
Patricia Swanton
Otley, West Yorkshire
 The Archbishop's concern that he would not be accepted as an adoptive parent is understandable. However, recent research on adoption undertaken by voluntary agencies between 1994 and mid-1998 demonstrated that in fact 94% of applicants were approved. This overturns popular belief that most people are turned down as potential adopters.

The Department of Health has commissioned us to prepare a report outlining UK standards for adoption practice; this will include issues surrounding recruitment of potential adopters, their assessment and approval. It is essential with assessments that a balance is drawn between a transparent and speedy process for applicants which also safeguards the requirements of children who often have complex social needs.

We welcome the Archbishop's interest in this important area, but we must always remember that the child's needs must be put above the wishes of adults.
John Simmonds
British Agency for Adoption and Fostering

fields.headline: Justice in jeopardy
fields.trailText: The Tory initiative on double jeopardy (Retrial plan hijacked by Hague, May 15) shows that Labour is not alone in its readiness to jettison the principles which underlie the rule of law. We do not re-try people after an acquittal, in order to protect the innocent from being hounded by the authorities.
fields.body:

fields.headline: Manifesto fails the test
fields.trailText: John Carvel's manifesto (Vision for a more prosperous society, May 15) will be warmly welcomed by David Blunkett and could indeed have been written in his private office: it simply asks for more of the same and so echoes his repeated speeches which avoid every controversial educational question.
fields.body:
John Carvel's manifesto (Vision for a more prosperous society, May 15) will be warmly welcomed by David Blunkett and could indeed have been written in his private office: it simply asks for more of the same and so echoes his repeated speeches which avoid every controversial educational question. In fact, it meets Mr Blair's first criterion for the next manifesto - it must not upset readers of the Daily Mail.

Thus there is no mention of the undermining of comprehensive education and the retention of selection through specialist schools, the existing grammar schools and all sorts of gifts to the selected few. Performance related pay, which has rent the profession and put it in furious conflict with the government, is dismissed in an airy phrase with no recognition of the damage it will do in staffrooms.

It evades the disruptive influence of Ofsted and league tables. There is not even a mention of one of Labour's biggest about-turns: the steady onward march of privatisation which has upset so many in both the local authority and the educational worlds.

Failure to deal with these controversial issues has already cost Labour many thousand votes. Such a manifesto will lose it more. Carvel has done us a service in exposing what a second term will be like unless the government returns to its true Labour roots.
Max and Margaret Morris
London
 John Carvel fails to identify one of the most urgent problems, which I predict will become a running sore in the next couple of years: governors. While rightly calling for "less prescription from Whitehall, a less confrontational attitude from Ofsted, and more discretion for headteachers", he doesn't go on to explore the potentially fraught relationship between staff and headteachers on the one hand and governors on the other.

The powers and obligations of governors have increased to a point of unreasonableness. They are expected to run vast bureaucracies and, despite lack of professional competence, judge the professional competence of headteachers and deputies.

Is it not time for governors to return to an advisory and supportive role, allowing headteachers the scope to run their schools without the enormous bureaucracies which present arrangements require?
Nick Baines
Leicester
baines@leicester.anglican.org

 Our whole educational system seems to be based on an extraordinary assumption that taking more tests makes you a better human being. The new manifesto should acknowledge that swotting for 10 GCSEs does not make you into a more productive member of the workforce.
David Gribble

South Brent, Devon
kca48@dial.pipex.com

 I hope your reporter read David Blunkett's lips incorrectly at the Rivington lecture (Blunkett attacks leftwingers who 'sneer' at change, May 12). The National Literacy and Numeracy Strategies are not compulsory.

The secretary of state and his DfEE officials have in fact emphasised the importance of teachers being free to use their professional judgment to ensure whatever methodology used for literacy and numeracy best meets the needs of the children.

The NUT believes that applying such professional freedom to nationally implemented strategies is vital if children are to avoid Mr Blunkett's feared "dreary, miserably mediocre sameness" in terms of their educational experience.
Doug McAvoy
General secretary, National Union of Teachers

fields.headline: Fighting the big C
fields.standfirst: Cancer patients face a better future
fields.trailText: Cancer horror stories continue to rumble in. It is a familiar media syndrome. One awful case triggers reports of others. The case of the South Yorkshire businessman, whose tumour went undetected on 22 visits to 12 different doctors and is now inoperable, has been followed by others.
fields.body:
Cancer horror stories continue to rumble in. It is a familiar media syndrome. One awful case triggers reports of others. The case of the South Yorkshire businessman, whose tumour went undetected on 22 visits to 12 different doctors and is now inoperable, has been followed by others. The same Barnsley hospital which failed to diagnose the businessman's throat cancer is now accused of missing a lung tumour in a 52-year-old woman. The BBC Today programme found a third victim, in a different area, who was incorrectly diagnosed even with a tumour the size of a grapefruit. Where will it all end? And what do we do about a disease, which the latest studies show will develop in 40% of the present population, killing one out of four?

There are two immediate points which can be made. The first, which these columns have long argued, was aired in our letter columns by Dr Ben Fox on Saturday: the need to correct unrealistically high public expectations, fueled by the belief that doctors can get their diagnosis right in every case. They can't. As Dr Fox noted, not all diseases have symptoms, not all symptoms relate to diseases, and any symptom has a number of causes. Even with all these caveats, however, the South Yorkshire case remains a scandal. As the cancer tsar, Mike Richards, conceded, Yorkshire medics did not pay enough attention to the patient's persistent symptoms.

The second point to note is the danger of judging a service on a handful of horror cases. Over 250,000 new cancer cases occur every year. There are over 200 different types of cancers, but just four account for half of them - lung, breast, large bowel (colorectal) and prostate. Cancer numbers have risen as the treatment of old killers, like pneumonia and septicaemia, has become more effective. Rising life expectancy inevitably leads to more cancer: 65% of current cancers are diagnosed in people over 65.

However, the low state of cancer services is not based on last week's horror stories but on a succession of comparative studies and the comments of cancer specialists working in the system. All comparative studies need to be handled with care, but the thrust is clear and not contested by ministers or most medics: Britain is near to the bottom of the European league in terms of treatment and survival rates - and even farther behind the US. Britain's survival rates for breast, prostate and colon cancers continue to improve, but still lag far behind Europe and the US. For colon cancer, for example, 36% of patients in the UK are still alive five years after diagnosis, compared to 48% in Germany and 60% in America.

The good news is that no government has ever been more specific about tackling a disease. The health secretary identified cancer - along with heart disease and mental health - as his three main priorities on coming into office last year. The target could not be more specific: reducing cancer deaths in people under 75 by at least a fifth by 2010 compared with 1997. This would save 100,000 lives. Cynics may scoff but cancer death rates dropped by 16% between 1985-98. Ministers are not sitting back and expecting the trend to continue. They have asked the cancer tsar for a comprehensive plan. Already in the pipeline is a 50% increase in the nation's 400 oncologists; closer monitoring of hospitals; approval of new drugs for ovarian and breast cancer; and the reorganisation of cancer services, based on specialist centres. What is needed now is a speed-up of the reorganisation, a major investment in diagnostic and radiotherapy equipment, and national access to all approved drugs.

webTitle: Sellers of faked goods 'no Del Boys'

fields.headline: Sellers of faked goods 'no Del Boys'
fields.trailText: People should abandon their sentimental image of a Del Boy selling counterfeit designer clothes, football strips, perfumes, CDs and videos, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
People should abandon their sentimental image of a Del Boy selling counterfeit designer clothes, football strips, perfumes, CDs and videos, the government said yesterday.

Buyers of fake goods were helping to finance drug gangs, terrorists and international racketeers, said Kim Howells, consumer affairs minister. At worst, sellers of fake replica soccer shirts to parents were the same people who tried to sell drugs to their children outside schools.

Launching a public information campaign about the £6bn a year threat to jobs and companies' profitability, Mr Howells also told some honest manufacturers of trendy goods that their "crazy prices" might be part of the problem. "If people are making big mark-ups they should not come whingeing about the temptation that is out there for people to buy this [faked] stuff."

Rather than seeing street sellers as being like Del Boy in Only Fools and Horses, the comedy about a south London dodgy dealer with a heart of gold, "you have to ask yourself: where did Del Boy get his goods from? Where are they made? You don't make a tape recorder in somebody's front room in Peckham."

Mr Howells is considering having a national hotline for the public to inform on fakers, after an experiment in Leeds. He said he hoped government managers would allow time in the next parliament for a bill to toughen punishments for manufacturers and retailers of fake goods. He praised Manchester United for cooperating with trading standards officials to fight sales of fake kit and memorabilia, estimated to have cost the club £6m in the past decade.

fields.headline: £2.4m awards for creativity
fields.trailText: The national organisation dedicated to encouraging British creativity and innovation will today announce the winners of its first awards, worth a total of £2.4m.
fields.body:
The national organisation dedicated to encouraging British creativity and innovation will today announce the winners of its first awards, worth a total of £2.4m.

The National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts will present awards to 24 individuals and fledgling businesses across Britain at a ceremony in London. The winners include scientists, film-makers, designers, educators, creative writers, and a surgeon.

The grants and fellowships for creative and innovative projects are the first of three sets of awards, totalling £10m, to be made over the next 12 months.

Nesta was set up by the government in 1998 with a £200m national lottery endowment. The board of trustees received more than 500 applications for the invention and innovation awards. Thirteen fellowships worth up to £75,000 each are to be announced, from 50 nominations, to help people pursue creative ideas and fulfil their potential.

Recipients include Richard Brown, creator of the computer-generated Neural Net Starfish in the Mind Zone of the Millennium Dome; astronomist Michael Hobson; Oxford don and poet Tom Paulin; and black film-maker Paula Watson.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Belgian guilty in genocide case
A Belgian journalist pleaded guilty yesterday to two charges related to Rwanda's 1994 genocide.
fields.body:
Belgian guilty in genocide case
A Belgian journalist pleaded guilty yesterday to two charges related to Rwanda's 1994 genocide.

Georges Ruggiu told the UN International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda he had no defence against charges that his broadcasts for Radio-Television Libre des Mille Collines helped incite and promote the slaughter of more than 800,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

He is the only non-Rwandan being tried by the court. Reuters, Arusha

Western Sahara talks falter
The Polisario Front, the independence movement for Western Sahara, said yesterday that UN-brokered talks with Morocco on the territory had made no progress, and called for international pressure to end Moroccan "intransigence".

Brahim Mokhtar, Polisario's representative in London, said ex-US secretary of state James Baker, who chaired Sunday's talks, would try again in June.

The UN has been trying for eight years to organise a referendum on the future of the territory, which is mostly controlled by Morocco. Reuters, London

Minister among Kashmir dead
Five people, including a provincial minister, died in south Kashmir yesterday when a bomb planted by suspected guerrillas blew up their car, police said.

Junior power minister Ghulam Hassan Bhatt and the four others died in Anantnag district, south of Srinagar. Reuters, Jammu

War crimes trial starts in Kosovo
In the first war crimes trial arising from the Kosovo conflict, a Serb man appeared before ethnic Albanian judges in a district court in Gnjilane yesterday charged with genocide.

Milos Jokic, 21, is accused of leading a paramilitary group during the war in Kosovo. He is charged with killing one Albanian, ordering another killing and forcing thousands from their homes. His lawyers say he is innocent. The trial was adjourned until June 20. Reuters, Pristina

Russia quizzed about 'visitor'
The chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, yesterday demanded an explanation from Russia about reports that the Yugoslav defence minister, indicted last year for crimes against humanity, recently visited Moscow.

Dragoljub Ojdanic was indicted when he was head of the Yugoslav army in command of Serb troops in Kosovo. He is said to have attended victory day celebrations in Moscow on May 9. Richard Norton-Taylor

Scientist dies at South Pole
An Australian astrophysicist has died at a US research station at the South Pole and his body will not be recovered until conditions relent in November, officials said yesterday.

Rodney Marks, 32, died on Friday at the National Science Foundation Amundsen-Scott South Pole station. His death is thought to be due to natural causes. Reuters, Sydney

fields.headline: Search on for cybercrime fix
fields.trailText: Bitten by the Love Bug that savaged global computer systems this month, 300 hi-tech experts and government officials from the world's leading industrialised countries met in Paris yesterday to discuss ways of combating the growing menace of cybercrime.
fields.body:
Bitten by the Love Bug that savaged global computer systems this month, 300 hi-tech experts and government officials from the world's leading industrialised countries met in Paris yesterday to discuss ways of combating the growing menace of cybercrime.

Held behind closed doors, the G8 summit aims to explore how the private and public sectors can "co-regulate" the internet, preventing it being used for crimes as varied as credit card fraud, spreading child pornography or racist propaganda, destroying corporate networks, and tampering with government data.

"The duty of governments and business leaders is to send a very clear message: we are working together to find technical and legal solutions that will raise levels of security and confidence in these new technologies," the French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, said in his opening address.

Countries must make it clear to their citizens that the internet is not a lawless zone, he said. "

Teenagers must understand that even if they are very gifted in computer science, the tricks they can play on the internet could be serious crimes," he added. "The internet isn't a toy anymore."

Police from the G8 states - America, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Russia - admitted that the authorities and the private sector faced problems in dealing with cybercrime.

"It's a huge issue involving the police and private companies, national and international law," said Hubert Marty, a French police specialist.

"We need solutions urgently . . . What if someone hacks into an airport or hospital system? Then there's a real risk to life."

One difficulty facing the authorities is the lack of international agreement on what constitutes a cybercrime. The Love Bug virus, concealed in a seductive email titled "I love you", hit computer systems around the world earlier this month.

Launched from the Philippines by a trio of students, it followed high-profile attacks on such big commercial internet sites as Yahoo! and Amazon.com in February. Some estimates put the amount of damage it caused as high as £10bn - yet computer attacks are not universally recognised as a crime.

Similarly, web-based Nazi propaganda outlawed in France, Germany and the Netherlands is permitted in the United States under freedom of speech laws.

Mr Chevènement urged the early adoption by all G8 members of a treaty currently being drawn up by the Council of Europe, which would require countries to define internet crime more precisely and to harmonise laws against hackers, virus writers, software pirates and other internet fraudsters.

Other countries with a strong internet potential, including India, China, South Africa, Israel and some in central Europe, should also sign up, so as to produce a truly global treaty, he said. "The idea is to produce a global text so there cannot be 'digital havens' where anyone planning shady business could find the facilities to do it."

Announcing that the French government was setting up a central agency to fight "crime linked to information and communication technologies", he urged Interpol to create a 24-hour internet group staffed by experts to ease cross-border cooperation.

But he refused to support an American proposal for an international cyber police force, reflecting the broader European concern that patrolling the internet could lead to "Big Brother" interference with individual liberties.

fields.headline: Missile hoax backfires
fields.trailText: Two students were sentenced to a year's hard labour in a penal colony yesterday for sending out a hoax internet message threatening imminent nuclear missile attacks on major European cities.
fields.body:
Two students were sentenced to a year's hard labour in a penal colony yesterday for sending out a hoax internet message threatening imminent nuclear missile attacks on major European cities.

The students, claiming to be officers in a Russian army nuclear missile unit, threw western security forces into a panic when they warned that they would attack western Europe unless their salaries were paid and other demands were met.

The trick backfired when FBI officials, alarmed by the apparently genuine notice, asked the Russian police for help in finding the culprits. Austrian police also alerted their Russian counterparts when they spotted the threat.

Since the Soviet Union collapsed, there has been widespread concern about the capacity of demoralised, underpaid Russian army officers to wreak havoc with the country's nuclear arsenal.

Officers from the FSB (the main successor to the KGB) traced the two students - who have not been named -to a vocational college in the small city of Kaluga, 125 miles south of Moscow, earlier this year.

The pair, posing as impoverished nuclear rocket commanders from the nearby Kozelsk strategic missile division, which has an arsenal of light nuclear missiles, had sent out the message as a joke.

But their sense of humour was not shared by the judiciary. They were convicted in Kaluga under a statute which forbids alarmist hoaxes that could cause material damage or danger to the public.

The pair, posing as impoverished nuclear rocket commanders from the nearby Kozelsk strategic missile division, which has an arsenal of light nuclear missiles, had sent out the message as a joke. But their sense of humour was not shared by the judiciary. They were convicted in Kaluga under a statute which forbids alarmist hoaxes that could cause material damage or danger to the public.

fields.headline: Broadmoor patient's court win
fields.trailText: A Broadmoor patient yesterday won permission to fight a decision blocking his attempt to use the internet to proclaim his innocence.
fields.body:
A Broadmoor patient yesterday won permission to fight a decision blocking his attempt to use the internet to proclaim his innocence.

The patient, B, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was given leave to seek judicial review of a decision his lawyers say is unlawfully preventing him from publicly asserting that he was the victim of a miscarriage of justice.

He is being detained indefinitely under the Mental Health Act at the top security hospital.

Mr Justice Tucker, sitting in London, banned the media identifying him or reporting details of his offence.

Paul Bowen, counsel for B, who has been held as a mental patient for more than 25 years, said the case raised important and fundamental issues of personal freedom and the right of mental patients to have statements put on the internet.

In April last year the Broadmoor hospital authority decided to prevent B sending a five-page document by post which he ultimately wanted published on the internet.

The hospital took action following concern that the victims of his offence and his own family would be distressed by widespread publicity.

Mr Bowen argued that, even if there was a likelihood of distress, the hospital should not have exercised its discretion to withhold the document as that involved a restriction of B's freedom of expression, guaranteed both at common law and by article 10 of the European convention on human rights.

Giving permission to seek judicial review, Mr Justice Tucker said it was "a very interesting application". Press Association

fields.headline: Last farewell, Dunkirk veterans disband
fields.trailText: The oldest and youngest members of the Dunkirk Veterans Association yesterday marked the 60th anniversary of the evacuation at their last official reunion.
fields.body:
The oldest and youngest members of the Dunkirk Veterans Association yesterday marked the 60th anniversary of the evacuation at their last official reunion.

William Stone, 99, and Joe Barnes, 74, joined around 50 other members of the association at the Imperial War Museum in south London. The association is being disbanded and the last annual parade of Dunkirk veterans will take place in France next month.

Mr Stone, from Watlington, Oxfordshire, was a Royal Navy chief petty officer who went back to Dunkirk five times during the evacuation of British troops in 1940. Mr Barnes, from South Ockendon, Essex, was the youngest person involved, at just 14. Unknown to the captain, he was in the hold of a ship when it left for France.

Yesterday veterans gathered round the smallest surviving boat in the evacuation, the Tamzine. The 15ft fishing boat was built in 1937 by Leonard Cotton Brockman of Margate. His 10-year-old great-great granddaughter was present yesterday.
Press Association

webTitle: Tribute to Elgar for Hallé season

fields.headline: Tribute to Elgar for Hallé season
fields.trailText: The Hallé Orchestra is likely to break even this year, lifting the cloud of financial uncertainty which has blighted it in recent years.
fields.body:
The Hallé Orchestra is likely to break even this year, lifting the cloud of financial uncertainty which has blighted it in recent years.

Two years ago debts reached £1.4m but after a year in which audience figures hit 250,000, the threat of extinction has receded.

John Summers, chief executive of the Hallé, said yesterday: "The last financial year has been very good and has been significantly better than what we budgeted for."

He said the results allowed the orchestra to look forward to the arrival of its new musical director Mark Elder in the autumn.

Mr Elder yesterday announced that his first season would combine the brass fanfares of Janacek's Sinfonietta with Elgar's Symphony No 1, which was first performed by the Hallé 92 years ago.

Mr Elder will conduct his first concert at the Hallé in October when Elgar's Symphony No 1 will be performed at the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester.

He said he was determined to take the orchestra's music to other northern towns and cities such as Bradford and Leeds.

Mr Elder has dedicated part of the season to the Italian composer Giuseppe Verdi. Next January will be the centenary of his death.

At a concert to mark the anniversary, act II of Aida will be performed at the Bridgewater Hall.

webTitle: Historic moment when trumpets sounded to turn relief into spontaneous celebration

fields.headline: Historic moment when trumpets sounded to turn relief into spontaneous celebration
fields.trailText: News of the relief of Mafeking (now Mafikeng), an obscure cattle town in north central South Africa, produced one of the greatest outbursts of rejoicing in British history.
fields.body:
News of the relief of Mafeking (now Mafikeng), an obscure cattle town in north central South Africa, produced one of the greatest outbursts of rejoicing in British history.

It gave the world a new verb, maffick : to celebrate excessively.

The relief ended a 217-day siege of a British garrison and civilians in the Anglo-Boer war. When word reached London the day after, October 18 1900, a witness report said: "White-haired old ladies were to be seen carrying large union jacks in each hand. Young women had colours pinned across from shoulder to shoulder.

"Sober young men in spectacles stood at street corners blowing tin trum pets with all their might ... well-dressed young women of unusually proper demeanour traversed roadways arm-in-arm, six abreast, carrying flags and occasionally bursting into song. There was a singular absence of any official stimulus."

In the London stock exchange "the work of both members and clerks was abandoned as groups shook hands and sang patriotic songs and, with much fervour, the national anthem.

"Such euphoria was repeated all over the empire. In Canada a correspondent reported that every town and village went wild with patriotic fervour. In Melbourne guns were fired, bells rang all day and crowds packed the streets."

The event was seen as a turning point after the battering British troops had taken during the war. It made a hero of Robert Baden-Powell, leader of the garrison, who went on to found the boy scout movement and died a hereditary peer in 1941.

But after victory in South Africa Britain soon handed back control to the white supremacist Afrikaner minority. In the late 1940s this consolidated its rule with anti-black laws which caused almost a further half-century of repression.

Baden-Powell was long admired for his military flair and jokes. On the 200th day of the siege, when the Boers proposed a cricket match, he urged them to try new bowlers: his side was already 200 not out.

But since 1960 his name has been darkened by a series of allegations over his "leave or starve" policy towards some blacks in Mafeking.

Thomas Pakenham, in his standard book on the war, says the verdict on Mafeking is summed up by a remark by the British administrator Lord Milner: "You have only to sacrifice 'the nigger' absolutely and the game is easy."

fields.headline: Physics
fields.trailText:
The Physics Factory
***
Aimed at: everyone
fields.body:
The Physics Factory
***
Aimed at: everyone

"Physics is not all boring old men with beards," declares the author of this site, formerly head of the subject at a Surrey school. Unfortunately, the Factory is one of those sites that never truly got off the ground, possibly because it lacked publicity, and laudable features such as the Problem Page seem to be under-used. This is a pity, because the GCSE and A-level features are written with enthusiasm.

Bad Astronomy
*****
Aimed at: everyone

Trying to correct popular misconceptions about astronomy could be a tedious business. Not so on this site, which explains exactly why films such as Mission to Mars get it wrong and points to some of the most interesting astronomical developments being covered on the web.

The Wizard's Lab
*
Aimed at: everyone

Since the result of attempting to blend physics and magic was alchemy, a science of the most dubious kind, the Wizard's Lab seems an unlikely proposition. And so it is: riddled with dead links, poor grammar, incomplete explanations and redundant sound files, the Lab should be avoided at all costs.

Lift off to Space
*****
Aimed at: everyone

Lift-Off and its sister site, Nasa Kids, will appeal to children at KS2 onwards and are both ideal for researching projects. The Kids site has a substantial section for teachers with classroom resources. Puzzles is a wonderful site for children to explore with parents: there are stories, colouring pages, quizzes, models and activities of all kinds.

Amusement Park
***
Aimed at: everyone

This site explains the physics behind rollercoasters, bumper cars, carousels and pendulums and challenges visitors to design a rollercoaster that is both safe and exciting. An absorbing site, which could act as a follow-up to a post-exam amusement park visit.

How Things Work
***
Aimed at: everyone

"Think of this site as a radio call-in programme that's being held on the WWW instead of the radio," writes the author, a professor of physics at the University of Virginia. He has a gift for answering questions - which are of the Notes and Queries variety - vividly, and already has a substantial archive of replies. Unfortunately, the professor has 17,435 questions waiting in his inbox, so it's unlikely that he will be able to answer yours.

Physics 2000
***
Aimed at: everyone

Physics 2000 sets out to explain concepts in an engaging question-and-answer format which, while not substantially different from a good textbook, is well illustrated. The more interesting features are the applets which demonstrate, for example, how heat affects the movement of atoms in a memorable way. This is a US site and the content is in no way tied to the national curriculum, so its resources should be used selectively.

Revision
***
Aimed at: everyone

Electrical and Electronic Revision is a small and simple project by a Northamptonshire school. This online test invites you to revise electronic and electrical symbols.

fields.headline: In a state of failure
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan explains what connects diamonds and civil war in the warring west African nation of Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan explains what connects diamonds and civil war in the warring west African nation of Sierra Leone
fields.body:
The national anthem of Sierra Leone starts like this: "High we exalt thee, realm of the free,/ Great is the love we have for thee/ Firmly united ever we stand/ Singing thy praise, O native land."

Sadly, these words about freedom and unity don't mean anything now in this small west African country. More than eight years of civil war have left more than 50,000 people dead. All law and order has ceased to exist and half of the population of 4.5 million have left their homes. In most areas, becoming a soldier in a rebel army is safer than staying an unarmed civilian at risk of murder, rape or kidnapping. And so far all attempts by foreign countries to help Sierra Leone have failed.

Why is Sierra Leone in the news?

A civil war has broken out over who has control of its vast reserves of diamonds. Last July it looked as if things might be getting better. A peace agreement between the three main rival groups was signed, which gave each a share in government and promised their war crimes would be forgiven. To make sure everything went to plan, the United Nations sent 11,000 troops to Sierra Leone to help police the country.

But instead of being welcomed, the UN troops met fierce resistance from one of the rebel groups called the Revolutionary United Front (RUF). Units of the United Nations' force were attacked, robbed of their equipment and more than 300 of them were kidnapped.

Fears that the civil war was starting again have caused panic in the population. Britain has just sent 700 heavily armed paratroops and several ships to help evacuate UK and European citizens. The fear is that they too will be attacked and become part of the conflict.

Why did the United Nations mission go wrong?

In Sierra Leone there are many proverbs, or sayings, that include animals. One goes: "Don't try to scare a monkey with a dead baboon." Unfortunately, the poorly equipped and inexperienced UN force were just like "a dead baboon" when it came to trying to get the rebels to put down their guns and give up control of areas rich in diamonds. This has been a disaster for the UN and its secretary general, Kofi Annan. The UN already has a terrible record in Africa of not being able to stop this type of slaughter.

Why is the UK getting involved?

One answer is that they are trying to protect the ordinary people. Another is that if any western country were going to send troops, it should be Britain. Britain used to rule Sierra Leone and helped to make it into a country in the first place. In fact many of today's problems began because of the way in which Sierra Leone was set up.

In 1787 Britain founded Freetown on the west African coast. Freed slaves made up most of its population. Later on, in the 19th century, when British forces conquered the tribes living away from the coast, it became the capital of the country. Sierra Leone is still a mass of different peoples. Between them they speak some 23 languages and hundreds of dialects.

When Sierra Leone became independent of British rule in 1961, its leaders were mainly made up of a few powerful families descended from those original slaves. They set about robbing the country of its natural wealth - particularly the diamond fields discovered in the 1930s. Many people were angry at this. They felt they had no share in the wealth, and so the RUF was founded. It was led by Alfred Foday Sankoh, an ex-corporal and television cameraman. In 1991, the RUF started the uprising against the government that is going on today.

How does such a poor country manage to fight such a costly war?

The cost of the war has been met by diamond smuggling. The diamonds in Sierra Leone are alluvial - washed out of the rock and deposited by rivers - they don't need mining and they are easy to transport.

One of the RUF's most important allies is President Charles Taylor of neighbouring Liberia. Liberia does not have many diamond deposits, but it is guessed that its current diamond exports are worth over $300m. According to Africa expert Comfort Ero: "Taylor has provided a safe haven for RUF fighters and has helped to establish their trade in diamonds, in return for a large share of the profits." He thinks the RUF and the international criminal groups behind the smuggling want the civil war to keep going.

What are the chances for peace?

It is when the soldiers leave that the troubles will start. Many people are calling Sierra Leone a "failed state": a country that that doesn't work properly. It is now hard to imagine the leaders who signed the 1999 peace treaty truly working together. The population is terrified of the RUF rebels who have carried out acts of great brutality. Unless order is restored, Sierra Leone may be a threat to peace in west Africa.

fields.headline: Governors
fields.trailText: f you're one of the 300,000 school governors in Britain, you probably - according to the Department for Education, at least - dedicate 20 hours a term to the job.
fields.body:
If you're one of the 300,000 school governors in Britain, you probably - according to the Department for Education, at least - dedicate 20 hours a term to the job. Chairs spend double. But it wasn't until performance management came along that the workload increased dramatically, according to Chris Gale of the National Governors' Council.

"I think just about everyone involved in education is overwhelmed with performance management," says Gale. "Governors are fed up with bureaucracy." Not only is the government thrashing out what governors should be responsible for, but the trend to delegate more local education authority decisions to schools has created a lot of anxiety. But these fears, Gale adds optimistically, will probably not be justified once things get under way.

Nonetheless, rumours that the number of governors might be allowed to fall are certain to worry existing volunteers. While many belong to the NGC or the National Association of Governors and Managers, governors are never going to benefit from half-price laptop offers or other ICT help that would make their job easier.

"A lot of governors don't have any access to the net at all," says Gale. "At the other end of the scale, you have business governors who do everything electronically." These people are in an excellent position, she argues, to help bring more ICT into schools. "Certainly, in my own school, they can be extremely helpful. I had no idea what was possible until I talked to my business contacts. It was just brilliant."

Governors who actually work in ICT and feel they have something to offer might like to visit www.japonite.org.uk, the site of the Joint Advisory Panel on ICT in Education. Some governors are also concerned that the integration of the Human Rights Act into British law this year will make it easier for governing bodies to be sued over issues such as exclusion. The DfEE has posted advice on its governors' site, and a fuller guide is available at www.homeoffice.gov.uk/hract/ for anyone interested in the subject.

Governors can cut down on their DfEE paperwork by signing up to receive news and forms in an electronic in-tray.

 Apologies to Matthew Platts of the Sussex Language Institute for omitting the address of his site in a recent column, which is www.sussex.ac.uk/langc/

fields.headline: Dressing to impress
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones  wonders whether power dressing for the inspector is really necessary
fields.trailText: Janet Jones wonders whether power dressing for the inspector is really necessary
fields.body:
We are dressed to kill in our college. (We have been inspected. And we are going to be inspected again.)

We have had such a primping and crimping and colouring and curling and measuring and matching and brushing up and smoothing down. The records of work are ready in red. The tutorial records are lined up in blue. The course folders are wearing green. Dressing up the paper work is fast becoming essential to The System. It threatens, in fact, to outshine the paperwork itself, which has been ruling The System of late.

Let us take the registers. If it's Monday, the registers are in yellow. If it's Tuesday, they're in blue. If it's Wednesday, they're in pink. Thursday? They're in green. Friday? White. This power dressing extends beyond the colours. Anything written by hand is suspect. Everything should be word-processed, but not into sentences and paragraphs - rather into boxes and columns. Numbers are, increasingly, preferred to words.

An anomaly is evolving: if it looks "right" it is "right". If it does not look "right," it is not "right". So long as the paperwork is in its proper uniform, so long as the spitting and polishing have been done by the rules, all is well.

When we workers are getting heated under the strain of mobilising the ranks of our files we refer to them as "Liesandhypocrisy". When we are cooler, we are just sorry that the lamb that is our work has to be forcibly embellished to emerge on parade as mutton.

A batch of hand-written homework is about the uncoolest thing you can be seen with in further education. The best-dressed work is photo-copied and scanned, from source to assignment, manicured into plastic and clipped into covers. It is hygiene turned inside out: the human touch obliterated as if it were a bad smell.

Similarly, if work has been through the spell check, it is spelt right. Never mind the fact that the spell check cannot recognise spelling mistakes: "Their wood of bean know cheque four yew" is fine according to the spell check. And have you ever put a verse or two of the Bible or Shakespeare or Ted Hughes through the grammar check? The grammar check will tell you that they got it all wrong.

That is the kind of craziness that over power-dressing leads us into.

Fortunately, even in further education, we can't avoid human beings: "He didn't look at any of those..." my colleague gestured at a Himalayan mount of files prepared for an inspector who was not interested in them. It may have been the same inspector who took this sanity a little far: he was much exercised by the fact that some of our students keep their coats on for classes. He did not appreciate that, far from hiding their lights under bushels, they were in the armour necessary to venture into such hostile territory as a college. For that you need protective clothing.

I don't think there is one teacher in our staff-room who needs to cover their work in any kind of security blanket before it is exposed on the catwalk of an inspection. Why does further education have to be such an emperor in his new clothes? Let's hope the inspectors continue to look straight through them.

fields.headline: Youth workers
fields.trailText: Youth workers
fields.body:
Hi! Hello

May I come in? It depends what you've got in the bag.

Pardon? You'll have to open the bag if you want to come in.

They're just some books. Very nice, but we'd still need to look.

This is a youth club, isn't it? That's right.

So why are you so determined to search me? Well, some kids have been known to try to bring in alcohol.

Ah. But I've come to find out how to become a youth worker. You'll still have to open your bag.

Can't I just leave it at the door? No. Now let's have a look. Ah, ha.

I can explain. It's only cider. That's alcohol.

Well, yes but we always smuggled cider into the youth clubs I went to. No doubt, but times have changed.

And we smoked ourselves silly. It's no smoking here.

What? There's only ping pong left? Does anybody turn up? Oh yes.

So what do youth workers do? They are concerned with promoting the personal and social development of young people, usually aged between 11 and 26, the majority falling between 13-19.

What's the aim? Youth work tries to ensure that each young person has an equal opportunity to fulfil their potential as an individual and member of the community.

Where do they operate? Over 50% of youth workers are based at youth clubs/centres or other informal settings. The majority are employed part-time, or on a voluntary basis, especially those based at smaller clubs, as full-time posts are limited.

What does the work entail? Young people go to centres or clubs to meet friends, take part in leisure and recreational activities or even just spend time away from home in a safe, non-judgemental environment. Centre-based youth workers should lay on a wide programme of activities that young people can enjoy, are educational and will help develop skills and confidence, whilst giving a greater understanding of issues that affect their lives, such as health and politics.

What about work outside clubs? Youth workers sometimes operate outside youth centres in order to reach young people. They're known as "detached" or outreach workers and meet young people on their own turf - in amusement arcades, shopping centres, pubs, etc. They work with them on issues most relevant to their lives and also try to encourage them to make use of existing youth service provision.

Who employs them? The main employers are local authorities or voluntary organisations such as the YMCA, Girl's friendly Society and the National Association of Boy's Clubs (who often work in partnership with local authorities), though some schools and further education colleges also employ youth workers.

What qualities are desired? They should include excellent communication skills - especially the ability to listen; informal counselling skills; sensitivity; maturity and being able to relate to, and gain the trust of, a wide variety of people.

What about entry requirements? To become a full-time youth worker you can choose between several routes and qualifications, all endorsed by the National Youth Agency. There are courses at diploma, degree and postgraduate level. Colleges require five GCSEs, including two at A level. Mature applicants without formal qualifications, but with relevant experience, are welcome. Older applicants can also undertake an access course in youth work.

 National Youth Agency, 17-23 Albion Street, Leicester, LE1 6GD, Telephone: 0116 285 3700

 National Council for Voluntary Youth Services, 2 Plough Yard, Shoreditch High Street, London, EC2A 3LP, Telephone: 0207 422 8630

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Opposing instincts
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair used to say make the bosses pay, recalls  Alan Tuckett
fields.trailText: Tony Blair used to say make the bosses pay, recalls Alan Tuckett
fields.body:
The crisis at Rover and the announcement of Dagenham's closure as a car production plant will have a major impact on the aspirations of the government to create a learning society. Rover and Ford were in the vanguard of the movement to offer workers paid support for learning for personal development. Like many other employers they took training seriously, and both believed that learning "leaks" - skills and confidence gained in learning for pleasure - can be harnessed for the workplace.

Ford's Dagenham plant, with its dedicated learning centre, has been a beacon of the learning society - with everything from family numeracy to plastering for beginners.

These are not isolated examples, and illustrate a problem that threatens the government's commitment to learning for all. Despite the expansion of further and higher education by successive governments, and despite this government's welcome overhaul of post-school education, participation levels remain stubbornly low. Some of this can be explained by the 1990s' habit of robbing Peter to pay Paul - winding down community learning to expand courses leading to qualifications, at the expense of older people in particular.

The shift from large scale employment to small, medium and tiny employers, and to the growth in self-employment has also had a major impact. While most big employers have a good record in staff development and training, far too many small scale enterprises don't. Almost every gain in participation in the formal sector is offset by changes in what happens at work.

You can see this in the West Midlands, where overall participation fell in the 1990s, despite the rise in provision by universities, colleges and community providers alike. When Rover shrank its workforce from 180,000 to 36,000 more than 100,000 regular learning opportunities were lost. The people displaced by de-industrialisation recognise that learning makes a difference to your job prospects, but too many men cannot see themselves joining in. As one reported in a North Yorkshire study: "College is a step up for women, but a step down for men." You learn at work or not at all.

Where you work is as important as where you live to your chances of lifelong learning. Investors in People makes a demonstrable difference to firms, but countless thousands, of tiny, small and medium-sized firms don't take part, leaving their workers high and dry.

Eight years ago Tony Blair, then Labour's spokesman on employment, was clear what needed to be done about this. He wrote then, in the Financial Times, "We... do not believe a voluntary approach to training will work... We believe all employers should make some minimum investment in training their staff or make a payment to the local or national training effort." Alas, in office his government has persisted with the same mix of voluntary strategies for securing employer investment that has failed for a decade.

The National Advisory Group for Community Education and Lifelong Learning (Nagcell) proposed the adoption of work-place codes of practice, along the lines of health and safety codes. Over time these would make a real difference to what the CBI recognises as the long tail of under achievement. They would also increase the investment in lifelong learning - and help the government to afford the National Skills Task Force recommendation that adults, as well as young people, need an entitlement to learn if lifelong learning is to avoid being a two speed policy, in which adults limp along in the slow lane. Blair was right in 1992. We can no longer afford to indulge the ignorance of those firms that won't invest in the capacity of their people.
