fields.headline: Surfing the screen
fields.standfirst: A new film school is about to open, but this one is on the web and anyone can go
fields.trailText: A new film school is about to open, but this one is on the web and anyone can go
fields.body:
The annual round of "it should have been me" has long been a tradition in the film business. And no, it's not the Oscars I'm talking about. It's the selection process for the prestigious postgraduate courses at the National Film and Television School (NFTS) in Beaconsfield. Each year the school receives hundreds - if not thousands - of applications for its 50 to 60 places, so inevitably a huge number of wannabe Quentin Tarantinos are left crying into their film stock.

The NFTS has become a past master at defending itself against charges of elitism, but, in an age when there are too many TV stations to count, let alone watch, when a few mates can disappear into a forest with a camera and come back with a multi-million pound international commercial success, aka The Blair Witch Project, and when any self-respecting geek has a web-cam to record every detail of his, and it is usually his, stultifyingly dull life, the organisation has begun to look a little, well, out of touch with the mood of the industry.

Not for much longer, though. Today the Culture Secretary, Chris Smith, is attending the UK curtain-raiser for the Global Film School, a collaboration between the NFTS and the equally well thought of Australian Film, Television and Radio School and the University of California in Los Angeles School of Theater, Film and Television. The Global Film School is designed to offer professional training online so students at computer terminals in any city or village in the world will be able to study directing, producing, screenwriting, editing, design, cinematography and music composition.

The school proposes to offer four main programmes. The most advanced is the Centre for Advanced Studies which will allow professionals already working within the industry to retrain in new and changing technologies. Pitched slightly lower, but not much, is the Global Conservatory, which will offer the highest level of moving-media instruction - roughly on a par with the existing NFTS course, but with a more international feel. Both these courses require proof of prior knowledge and ability before students are accepted and, as such, are really just the NFTS core business carried on by other means.

The true democratisation of film-making is to be found in the other two programmes. The first is a free Education for Youth Programme in media literacy, which is aimed at primary and secondary students; the second is the Lifelong Learning Programme, which will offer tuition in a variety of disciplines at a nominal cost for those who fancy learning a few new skills.

"There are no prerequisites for joining the Lifelong Learning Programme," says Stephen Bayly, director of the NFTS. "What we are offering is something truly revolutionary in the film industry. We are empowering people all over the world to use the new technological tools. One of our people in LA was talking to a taxi driver who was going to buy an iMac computer because he wanted to hook it up to a digital camera and make movies. The digital revolution has opened the way for everyone to take part in film-making."

The school is in the process of setting up the content for the courses and of putting in place a certification programme. However, some courses are likely to be run in parallel to allow for different cultural perspectives. For instance, the American and European models of production are often very different.

"In Britain, it's customary to look for production money from TV and subvention funds," Bayly explains. "But this system doesn't exist in the US; instead you look for funding from venture capitalists."

Much of the teaching will be online, with the odd summer or winter school thrown in. The first courses are expected to start in the autumn and those interested should check the website, www.globalfilmschool.com Those looking at the Lifelong Learning programmes may do it just out of interest, or to pick up technological skills to use elsewhere. But judging by the quality of some current TV, there may be a career to be had as well.

fields.headline: Capital stuff
fields.standfirst: With your own venture capital fund you could plan a lifetime's training
fields.trailText: With your own venture capital fund you could plan a lifetime's training
fields.body:
Rachel decides to return to work after a ten-year break raising a family. Let's say she is one of the million people promised an Individual Learning Account worth £175 by the government. She puts in a £25 contribution and receives £150 of state cash and decides to spend the money on a basic computer accounting course. She gets a part-time job with a local voluntary body and gets some experience of running an accounts system.

So far so good - but then Rachel looks at local pay rates and decides she should try to get an accountancy technician qualification. How does she get her hands on the money to fund a course which she knows will boost her future earnings and pension? Could she draw on the pension fund she has already contributed to before taking a career break? Her increased earnings in the future would rebuild her pension investment if only she could be a bit more flexible now...

The government's offer of a million Individual Learning Accounts is a good start but does it go far enough to spark the kind of learning revolution which education pundits and economists alike think is necessary for the UK's international competitiveness?

The Institute for Public Policy Research, a centre-left think-tank, believes more radical solutions are needed to give people access to the wealth they will generate over the lifetime of earning and saving. Everyone should have their own venture-capital fund.

Take control of your life and career is the mantra of the growing army of personal development counsellors. Education and training is life-enhancing, empowering and one of the most powerful determinants of career success. Yet access to and funding of post-16 education and training remains substantially under the control of the state and employers.

The philosophy of individual control of one's own destiny led to the 1980s personal investment drive, which saw the introduction of Peps and Tessas, and the privatisations which aimed to establish popular capitalism by offering small investors a share of state enterprises. But this did not carry over into education and training.

Over the past five years, a succession of reports (Dearing on higher education, Kennedy on further education, Fryer on lifelong learning, the annual Competitiveness White Papers and the three reports of the National Skills Task Force) have argued that in the global knowledge economy, intellectual capital, skills and innovation will be more important than the traditional economic factors of capital, land and raw materials, and labour.

Just as the stock-market value of knowledge-based businesses based on the intangible assets of intellectual property has overtaken that of businesses valued on physical assets, so national competitiveness will increasingly depend on human capital, and on people's ability to learn and to innovate by applying their learning.

That means that nations cannot rely on a well-educated and innovative elite alone. The overall level of skills matters. Every report contrasting the UK and Germany, for instance, makes the point about Germany's superiority in technical and vocational training and the contribution of this to industrial performance. When jobs depend on minds rather than materials, education and training count for even more.

As the Henley Centre for Forecasting has commented: "In the global marketplace it is societies, not economies, that compete." Learning for all needs to be promoted by a partnership between individuals, state and employers. But the driving force must be individual motivation. People must want to learn and develop. And as with other forms of personal investment, a key way to motivate people is to give them more control and responsibility for their future.

So how can individuals take more control of their own education and training? The answer is to extend the concept of the Individual Learning Account into a Personal Development Account (PDA) based on an individual's lifetime earnings and savings to give real leverage to the cash one has to invest in education and training.

This could be done in phases, but the ultimate goal might be an integrated personal investment vehicle, one's own venture capital fund. A similar idea in America has the engaging acronym of USA (Universal Savings Account), and the Virgin One account appears to be moving in the same direction.

There are a number of options for a PDA. The first is to route part of the funding of further and higher education through an individual student's account, and to manage the loan element as well through the PDA. Turning the present Student Loans Company into the type of Learning Bank envisaged by the Commission on Social Justice in 1994 would throw a more positive light on investing in higher education. And making funding follow student choice would increase the market responsiveness of further education colleges and universities. If colleges eventually set their own fees, the case for buyers to have control of both state and individual purchasing power in their own fund becomes even stronger.

The second option is to look at an individual's lifetime earnings and savings, particularly in pension funds. Most of us are compelled to save in occupational pension schemes for 30 years or so of working life, but cannot access these accumulated funds until we retire - by which time it's a bit late to invest in learning for career development.

This is a passive and inert form of investment. Increasingly, with the trend towards money-purchase pension schemes, there is the possibility that individuals might draw down some of those funds during their working lives. The evidence is that, overall, education and training investment is repaid in higher lifetime earnings, so individuals who draw down cash from their pension into their PDA can top up their pension afterwards from their increased pay.

The third is to route employer training and development funds through an individual's PDA as part of the personal development plan process. Three options are:

 a set percentage of total payroll to be spent on training and development

 an opt-in model, similar to pension contributions, where if employees put an amount of their own money in, it automatically triggers an employer contribution, say on a 1:2 or 1:3 ratio

 a disclosure requirement of amounts spent on training and development as part of a company's annual report, assessed against a sector benchmark.

These options would significantly increase the volume of funds flowing through an ILA/PDA over an individual's lifetime. This in turn might increase the interest among financial institutions, who have so far been lukewarm towards the ILA concept.

But what would be the incentives from the state? Corporation tax exemption for training and development spending is sufficient for employers. The government has already indicated that contributions through ILAs from employers will not count as taxable benefits for employees as long as all employees get access to training. Beyond this, there is a case for a tax credit for funds put into an ILA/PDA, just as you would invest in additional voluntary contributions to a pension or make donations to an educational charity.

If we are serious about the massive cultural change in becoming a learning society, we need to signal the need for investment in intellectual capital. We need to make it at least as good to put your money into your brain as into your bank. The ILA/PDA concept brings the two together.

Different paths

Mark leaves school with average GCSEs and no wish to do further education. He gets a low-level sales assistant job, but finds he has a flair for selling. His company gives him advanced sales training and promotion, which is repaid in the orders he brings in. In his late 20s he begins to feel that lack of formal qualifications is a handicap and decides to do a certificate and then a diploma course in marketing. He puts £400 of his bonus into a Personal Development Account, triggering an £800 pay-in from his company and a £100 tax credit. This funds both courses and leads to further promotion and higher pay.

Sima is the first girl in her family to go to university, and she wants to avoid being a burden on her parents, who run a small shop. She organises her fee payments through her PDA, gets an excellent degree and a job with one of the major consulting firms. After three years, her employers suggest she does an MBA, and she borrows part of the cost of this through her PDA. He decides that all the staff should do something mind-expanding but not necessarily directly work-related to keep their creativity high, and guarantees a payment of £600 from the company into individuals' PDAs if they put in £200 themselves. Most take up the offer and plan their own learning programmes - with an annual award voted on by all staff to the one considered the most inventive.

fields.bodyText: Rachel decides to return to work after a ten-year break raising a family. Let's say she is one of the million people promised an Individual Learning Account worth £175 by the government. She puts in a £25 contribution and receives £150 of state cash and decides to spend the money on a basic computer accounting course. She gets a part-time job with a local voluntary body and gets some experience of running an accounts system. So far so good - but then Rachel looks at local pay rates and decides she should try to get an accountancy technician qualification. How does she get her hands on the money to fund a course which she knows will boost her future earnings and pension? Could she draw on the pension fund she has already contributed to before taking a career break? Her increased earnings in the future would rebuild her pension investment if only she could be a bit more flexible now... The government's offer of a million Individual Learning Accounts is a good start but does it go far enough to spark the kind of learning revolution which education pundits and economists alike think is necessary for the UK's international competitiveness? The Institute for Public Policy Research, a centre-left think-tank, believes more radical solutions are needed to give people access to the wealth they will generate over the lifetime of earning and saving. Everyone should have their own venture-capital fund. Take control of your life and career is the mantra of the growing army of personal development counsellors. Education and training is life-enhancing, empowering and one of the most powerful determinants of career success. Yet access to and funding of post-16 education and training remains substantially under the control of the state and employers. The philosophy of individual control of one's own destiny led to the 1980s personal investment drive, which saw the introduction of Peps and Tessas, and the privatisations which aimed to establish popular capitalism by offering small investors a share of state enterprises. But this did not carry over into education and training. Over the past five years, a succession of reports (Dearing on higher education, Kennedy on further education, Fryer on lifelong learning, the annual Competitiveness White Papers and the three reports of the National Skills Task Force) have argued that in the global knowledge economy, intellectual capital, skills and innovation will be more important than the traditional economic factors of capital, land and raw materials, and labour. Just as the stock-market value of knowledge-based businesses based on the intangible assets of intellectual property has overtaken that of businesses valued on physical assets, so national competitiveness will increasingly depend on human capital, and on people's ability to learn and to innovate by applying their learning. That means that nations cannot rely on a well-educated and innovative elite alone. The overall level of skills matters. Every report contrasting the UK and Germany, for instance, makes the point about Germany's superiority in technical and vocational training and the contribution of this to industrial performance. When jobs depend on minds rather than materials, education and training count for even more. As the Henley Centre for Forecasting has commented: "In the global marketplace it is societies, not economies, that compete." Learning for all needs to be promoted by a partnership between individuals, state and employers. But the driving force must be individual motivation. People must want to learn and develop. And as with other forms of personal investment, a key way to motivate people is to give them more control and responsibility for their future. So how can individuals take more control of their own education and training? The answer is to extend the concept of the Individual Learning Account into a Personal Development Account (PDA) based on an individual's lifetime earnings and savings to give real leverage to the cash one has to invest in education and training. This could be done in phases, but the ultimate goal might be an integrated personal investment vehicle, one's own venture capital fund. A similar idea in America has the engaging acronym of USA (Universal Savings Account), and the Virgin One account appears to be moving in the same direction. There are a number of options for a PDA. The first is to route part of the funding of further and higher education through an individual student's account, and to manage the loan element as well through the PDA. Turning the present Student Loans Company into the type of Learning Bank envisaged by the Commission on Social Justice in 1994 would throw a more positive light on investing in higher education. And making funding follow student choice would increase the market responsiveness of further education colleges and universities. If colleges eventually set their own fees, the case for buyers to have control of both state and individual purchasing power in their own fund becomes even stronger. The second option is to look at an individual's lifetime earnings and savings, particularly in pension funds. Most of us are compelled to save in occupational pension schemes for 30 years or so of working life, but cannot access these accumulated funds until we retire - by which time it's a bit late to invest in learning for career development. This is a passive and inert form of investment. Increasingly, with the trend towards money-purchase pension schemes, there is the possibility that individuals might draw down some of those funds during their working lives. The evidence is that, overall, education and training investment is repaid in higher lifetime earnings, so individuals who draw down cash from their pension into their PDA can top up their pension afterwards from their increased pay. The third is to route employer training and development funds through an individual's PDA as part of the personal development plan process. Three options are:  a set percentage of total payroll to be spent on training and development  an opt-in model, similar to pension contributions, where if employees put an amount of their own money in, it automatically triggers an employer contribution, say on a 1:2 or 1:3 ratio  a disclosure requirement of amounts spent on training and development as part of a company's annual report, assessed against a sector benchmark. These options would significantly increase the volume of funds flowing through an ILA/PDA over an individual's lifetime. This in turn might increase the interest among financial institutions, who have so far been lukewarm towards the ILA concept. But what would be the incentives from the state? Corporation tax exemption for training and development spending is sufficient for employers. The government has already indicated that contributions through ILAs from employers will not count as taxable benefits for employees as long as all employees get access to training. Beyond this, there is a case for a tax credit for funds put into an ILA/PDA, just as you would invest in additional voluntary contributions to a pension or make donations to an educational charity. If we are serious about the massive cultural change in becoming a learning society, we need to signal the need for investment in intellectual capital. We need to make it at least as good to put your money into your brain as into your bank. The ILA/PDA concept brings the two together. His company gives him advanced sales training and promotion, which is repaid in the orders he brings in. In his late 20s he begins to feel that lack of formal qualifications is a handicap and decides to do a certificate and then a diploma course in marketing. He puts £400 of his bonus into a Personal Development Account, triggering an £800 pay-in from his company and a £100 tax credit. This funds both courses and leads to further promotion and higher pay. fields.headline: Independent's day
fields.standfirst: The new NUS president tells  Rebecca Smithers that the coming year is a vital one for students
fields.trailText: The new NUS president tells Rebecca Smithers that the coming year is a vital one for students
fields.body:
Owain James fought his campaign to be elected as the new president of the National Union of Students using the slogan "It is time for change". Now he has won the top job, he is acutely aware of the fact that he must deliver this promise, and of the need to drag the largely discredited NUS kicking and screaming into the new millennium and back into the real world.

His opponents think he shows a naive optimism in believing that he can crush the political in-fighting which, while inevitable in student politics, has alienated the organisation from its mainstream membership. But his supporters hope that as the first independent president of the organisation in three decades (albeit also a Labour party member) he will show absolutely no fears about taking the government on.

After all, for a great many outside observers as well as students, the once-radical and militant NUS appears to have become little more than a government mouthpiece as well as a guaranteed career ladder for Labour prospective parliamentary candidates. The body has become the victim of a double-edged sword - vilified by those disenchanted by the student movement, and largely ignored by those whose interests it claims to represent.

James regrets that the NUS missed what was arguably the biggest opportunity to make a difference for its 3.5 million student members by letting the government push through controversial plans to end universal grants and introduce tuition fees, which were not in its election manifesto.

Determined not to have a repeat performance in his own presidency, he is already planning his strategy to kill off the threat of top-up fees, which is looming ever large. Education secretary David Blunkett dropped his bombshell in February after the now famous Greenwich speech when he appeared to break Labour's cast iron pledge not to introduce US-style top-up fees. James does not officially take over from his predecessor Andrew Pakes until July, but wants all political parties to rule out such fees in their general election manifestos.

James believes the country's education system is in crisis and that the Labour government has reneged on its pre-election promises on higher education. His own interest in politics was stirred in his early childhood when he spent four years in the Sudan, where his father was an aid worker helping the famine victims. "That had a big impact on me and my personal politics because of what it revealed about inequality," he explains.

"Seeing huge numbers of people starving to death, not because they had done anything, but because of the lottery of life, made me think that we should be paying a lot more attention to what is going on in these countries. But despite global media and communications, there is very little awareness."

James returned to south Wales at the age of nine and, while at school, became interested in domestic politics through the impact of Thatcherism and the devastation wreaked on local mining villages.

At Warwick University, where he studied the curiously named Morse course (mathematics, operational research, statistics and economics), he got involved in campaigning, initially helping to organise One World Week, which has become a regular event and is now more popular than freshers' week. From a student executive position running external affairs and campaigns, he then took a sabbatical as communications officer and won a seat on the NUS national executive as national secretary.

In the spring NUS elections, he defeated the "independent Left" candidate Alison Angus by 91 votes, in what he sees as student support for unity. "This is a vital year for students in the run-up to the general election, and this vote for unity means we can influence and change education policy."

Ending the union's political in-fighting is central to his agenda for change. "I'd like to try and put an end to the factional politics within the NUS. We have been tearing ourselves apart instead of working together and trying to bring unity to our campaigns."

Around 98% of student unions are in the NUS, with a network of around 700 student union officers in individual colleges. "We are very strong structurally," James points out. "But when you ask people what they think the union does for them, and whether they are engaged, the answers are very disappointing. We're not getting across what we're doing and people don't feel a sense of ownership. That has got to be changed."

Linked to this strategy is broadening out the NUS's campaigning to a much wider audience - including parents who will have to pick up the tab for their children's education. He points to the worrying findings of the recent poll in Guardian Education in which 41% of parents didn't know what they thought about tuition fees.

"We want to involve as many people as possible in what we are doing, not marginalise or alienate them," he says.

Linked in with the main funding issues are the crises of mounting student debt (now topping £1.5bn), hardship and increasing stress and pressure. James also has plans for ambitious networking projects linked to the internet, where he thinks there are enormous opportunities.

James must decide in December whether to seek re-election for a further year at what, as the election creeps nearer, will be a critical time. But, in the meantime, he has plenty to be getting on with.

fields.headline: Shout it out
fields.standfirst: A woman's play about the despair of illiteracy proves a powerful tool for tackling a national scourge
fields.trailText: A woman's play about the despair of illiteracy proves a powerful tool for tackling a national scourge
fields.body:
On the skimpy report Sue Torr took away on her final day at secondary modern school 30 years ago nothing nasty was written. She was truthful, it said. Honest, too. She had won colours for netball and rounders and was an enthusiastic competitor.

"Made me sound prime minister material," she says.

But it was quite useless for one shrieking omission. Not a clue did it drop to the fact that she could not read the simplest line in a book. Staggering as it now seems in these days of targets and tests, nobody had picked up on this during her 11 years of statutory schooling. But then somehow over the past half century millions of her fellow citizens had also completed a decade or more of schooling without attaining reasonable levels of basic skills.

Sue Torr herself wasn't to realise that her own school report had overlooked this critical deficiency until 20 years later when she asked her adult literacy teacher to read it out to her.

This is one of many poignant ironies during Shout It Out, the play she wrote and now performs, about her experience and the grim experience of millions with poor basic skills.

It is a moving piece, as Estelle Morris, the minister for school standards readily acknowledged after a performance at the Palace of Westminster last week.

"Through all my years of teaching and time as a minister that was one of the most powerful ways I've ever seen of getting this across," Morris said.

Alan Wells, director of the Basic Skills Agency, said: "I started teaching people who couldn't read and write 30 years ago and I've never failed to be moved by that message, particularly powerfully put by Sue."

It is only when people with woeful levels of literacy and numeracy confront the rest of us with their constant problems that we glimpse the true nature of the affliction.

From the first anguished declaration that she can't read, as her four fellow performers circle her, taunting her with her deficiency, the eyeballs are starting to smart.

Since she devised it in 1992, just after she finally sought help for her illiteracy, Shout It Out has been performed in hundreds of venues: schools, prisons, community centres, universities, teacher training colleges. It won Sony Radio and Unesco awards.

"The response has always been absolutely brilliant. Teachers cry. People sometimes walk out because it relates to them."

That is why the project has been granted £73,000 from the government-funded Basic Skills Agency to carry on hawking its message around the nation.

However shocking the report produced by the working group on post-school basis skills, chaired by Sir Claus Moser, however wise and comprehensive its recommendations, and however eager the government is to implement them, nothing can beat the stark encounter with the authentic voice of experience for persuading people that this is an outrage needing to be fixed.

People were staggered at the finding that seven million adults - about 23% of the population - had more or less severe problems with basic skills, particularly with functional literacy and functional numeracy.

But the problem with the bald seven million figure was lack of credibility. It sounded wrong. It implied that every fifth person we met couldn't read.

Now the figure has been reinforced and refined by further research soon to be published by the Basic Skills Agency. This breaks down the one broad category of poor skills into three, and measures the incidence of these categories in the populations of the 529 English parliamentary constituencies.

These statistics will be followed shortly afterwards with even more finely drawn categories - at least a dozen of them - for every local education authority.

So, we will know the scale of the problem as never before.

But the voices of Sue Torr, and others like her, will be indispensible. For them, daily life is a never-ending struggle to negotiate ways around the written word while doing their utmost to avoid the shame of being found out.

"Sorry, forgotten my spectacles." "I've got a terrible headache." "Must dash, urgent appointment."

In Sue Torr's case, and for many others like her, the strategies for avoiding humiliation started early. How did teachers never pick up on her fundamental problem?

"When it came to my turn to read in class, I'd say something like: 'Aargh, I've got a bad stomach ache, I've got to leave the room.'

"The teachers never cottoned on."

Didn't, or didn't want to.

In her play, Sue, now a parent herself, goes to her son's school to talk to the head about his progress. Each recognises the other. Years earlier, he had taught her. Her memory of him was of a man leaning against the classroom doorpost smoking during a lesson.

She took the easy escape route by getting married at 18 and having babies, she says.

"I never told my husband I couldn't read." He was away at sea in the Royal Navy.

"Writing letters to him was hell. I used to get friends to write to him, and I got somebody to read his letters.

When I had to write to him, I would pick words out of his letters and make up one page that way.

"He complained my letters were boring and short.

"I wanted to tell him everything, the way I felt, tell him he was absolutely fantastic. But I'd have to make do with 'nice' because I couldn't spell anything better."

The big picture

New research is bringing a more detailed picture of the seven million adults estimated by the Moser report as having low basic skills.

It confirms the Moser findings that one in five adults suffer from poor literacy and numeracy, says Alan Wells, the Basic Skills Agency director.

It divides the seven million into three categories of severity: A - low, B - lower and C - very low levels of literacy and numeracy. And it has estimated the percentages of adults in each category in each of the 529 English parliamentary constituencies.

Nationally, 24% of adults have poor literacy skills. The majority of them, 15% of all adults, fall into category A; 5% are classed B, and 4%, the lowest category C.

A casual glance at the constituency table shows that Birmingham Sparkbrook (12%) and the London seat of Camberwell and Peckham (11%) have three times above the average in the C category. Nowhere does the C percentage drop to two.

What do the categories mean?

At the top end, A, are people who wouldn't do as well as the average 11-year-old, explains Wells.

"Some of them would deny having poor basic skills if asked. They're probably pretty OK at reading, not great at spelling, not great at writing and not particularly bothered by it. They think they can read the newspaper and that's OK."

But it is not really adequate given that employers are demanding higher basic skills than before, he says. Adults in the A category would probably not need an intensive college programme, but would benefit from a self-access computer course of the sort promoted by learndirect.

Adults in the C category have weaker literacy and numeracy skills than the average seven-year-old, says Wells. "This is certainly an emergency category. These people need urgent help."

B falls between the A and C, he says. "They'll be slow writers, hesitant readers and they, too, need help."

New research emerging in the next few weeks is going to make even finer distinctions sorting people with low basic skills into up to 14 categories, says Wells.

fields.headline: Stop taking the tablets!
fields.standfirst: GPs experiment with alternative academic cure for chronic patients
fields.trailText: GPs experiment with alternative academic cure for chronic patients
fields.body:
A group of doctors is to try encouraging patients to take up learning, rather than prescribing them pills. They are acting on new research by the National Organisation for Adult Learning (Niace) which reveals that studying is beneficial for people's physical, mental and emotional health.

The group of GPs in Nottingham is to offer patients the option of a free ticket to sign up for a course at one of the city's colleges or at any other local learning centre.

If the scheme, announced to coincide with this year's Adult Learners Week which begins on Saturday, proves popular, the hope at Niace is that every medical practice in the country will eventually have a facility to refer patients to learning providers instead of pharmacists.

Learning's power to make people feel better emerges unequivocally in responses to a questionnaire Niacesent to 2,000 individuals and 750 groups nominated for Adult Learners' Week awards over the last two years.

They were quizzed about links between learning and physical health, and learning and mental/emotional health. "Learning" was widely defined and included any taught courses which led to qualifications or were designed to develop skills in a job, or a practical or artistic skill - for instance driving or playing an instrument - and evening classes. It also included working on one's own from a provided package and trying to improve one's knowledge about a subject without taking part in a course.

Only 13% of respondents said they had noticed no benefits to their physical health. The rest said that learning made their illness or pain more bearable, or they specified actual physical benefits, or they noticed other indicators of their well-being which they linked with learning.

"My mental and physical health have improved dramatically - I no longer smoke and have been able to come off medication for angina," wrote one male in his 50s.

"I am not bored, have no depression and hardly ever see the doctor these days," responded a woman in her 50s. "Before I was lonely, depressed, always ill and suicidal and lived at the GP's."

An even higher proportion, 89%, felt their emotional or mental health had benefited from learning. Some spoke candidly about mental illness and how learning had helped. "I am less depressed and I dwell less on my illness. I am optimistic about the future and feel more in control of my life," wrote an unemployed woman in her 20s.

Others said that time spent learning stopped them dwelling on things. One unemployed woman in her 50s said: "My brain is happier at having something specific to work on."

Doctors who have seen the survey results confirm that they chime in with their experiences, says Peter Lavender, Niace's director of research and development.

Three GPs' practices based on council estates in south Nottingham will take part in the scheme.

"Rather than rip a leaf off a pad to take to a chemist, the GPs, with a patient's agreement, will be able to hand over a chitty which entitles them to free or almost free learning," Lavender says.

Colleges and other learning providers in the city have enthusiastically agreed to participate.

Grants totalling £45,000 from Niace and the local health action zone will fund a learning adviser to move between the surgeries dispensing advice on learning opportunities to patients who want it.

fields.headline: Red is no answer
fields.standfirst: Many universities are massively in debt but staff hope for pay rises
fields.trailText: Many universities are massively in debt but staff hope for pay rises
fields.body:
More than 50 universities and higher education colleges are in the red or only just breaking even, according to figures released today by the Association of University Lecturers.

But new accounting rules have disclosed that the sector as a whole was better off than the public realised and could well afford to pay staff more than universities were offering, the union insisted as it prepared to meet the employers over pay. The union, which represents staff at the old pre-1992 universities, last month rejected an offer of 2.5%.

The union's analysis of data from the Higher Education Statistics Agency shows a huge variation in the financial health of institutions, ranging last year from an £18m surplus at City University to a £6m deficit at Queen Mary and Westfield College, London, which is struggling to merge three medical schools and where staff are facing redundancies.

As a percentage of their total income, the deficits at Aberystwth (£3m), Goldsmiths College (£2.2m), Hull (£4.8m) and Aston (£3.3m) are even higher. However, in general, institutions had bigger reserves than previously disclosed, according to David Triesman, the union's general secretary. "We always felt some of the institutions pleading poverty had a far higher capacity than they let on. It is certainly possible for a number of institutions to make a significantly better pay offer."

He pointed out that almost every university and college spent less on its academic staff than institutions in leading countries overseas. Abroad, institutions spent on average 44% of their total budget on teaching staff, compared to a UK figure of 35%. "Year by year the proportion of money spent on staff is going down and down," said Triesman.

Both lecturers' unions and university vice-chancellors are lobbying ministers and senior civil servants behind the scenes as the government's Comprehensive Spending Review reaches its crucial stages in the next few weeks. Both want more money for higher education but there are disagreements over staff pay and conditions.

Today's national negotiating meeting between the union and the Universities and Colleges Employers Association could be one of the last, Triesman believes. In his speech to members at last week's annual council meeting at Eastbourne, he predicted the break-up of national bargaining. This is not something the union wanted but a development that could turn out to the advantage of staff at the more prestigious universities in the Russell group, which would pay more to attract the best researchers and academics.

This is turn would put pressure on other institutions to match the leaders, he predicted. Just as football clubs like Everton or Tottenham had to spend more than they might want for talented players to stay in contention in the league, so universities would have to improve pay and offer more job security. "I don't want the breakup of a national system, but I would be a pretty poor union negotiator if I did not take advantage of it. Aggregate wages are likely to rise quite significantly."

On the casualisation of academic staff - alongside pay the biggest bugbear for academics - a report last week said conditions were improving for 30,000 contract researchers but there were still deficiencies to remedy.

The second report from the Research Careers Initiative, chaired by Sir Gareth Roberts, vice-chancellor of Sheffield University, called for further action by institutions, and by the funding councils - who, it says, should reward steps to develop research staff's careers. Roberts said: "We are clear that the single most important initiative that can now be taken to embed improved management of contract research staff is by the funding councils. At present, the funding systems offer academics little incentive to attend to the career needs of their researchers."

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: My daughter has just started her "study leave". How can I help her to make the most of this time?
fields.body:
My daughter has just started her "study leave" prior to GCSE exams this summer. Having failed to do as much as she could have done since starting year 10, she is now beginning to panic. How can I help her to make the most of this time? Has she left it too late, as I've been telling her?

Anita Naik is the author of The Little Book of Exam Calm.

Let me begin with a quotation for Thomas Edison: "If we did all the things we're capable of doing, we would literally astound ourselves." Simple, but true.

Exams are not the most important things that anyone ever does. The fact is, pass or fail, a person is more to their family and friends, to themself, and to society in general than a grade on a piece of paper. If parents/guardians can help them to remember this, their children can avoid being sucked head-first into exam hysteria.

That said, here are 10 tips for you and your daughter:

1 Tell your daughter it is never too late to start studying, to start revising or to ask for help.

2 Encourage her to prioritise her workload. Try doing the complex tasks first - which may in her case mean making sure that all outstanding coursework is completed - even if it will be rather slapdash.

3 Cramming works for a lot of people, and while your daughter may not pass with straight As, she can still pass.

4 Studies show that the more you exercise your brain in the morning, the better your memory will be all day. So get your daughter to spend her mornings, when her mind is fresh, on the subjects she's spent the least time on, and then afternoons can be spent on subjects she likes or at least has done some work towards.

5 Suggest she makes up a work revision schedule before she does anything. No plan can lead to revision being a waste of time. Planning also helps to get rid of the fear of the unknown, and to give you a sense that you're working towards something. Then get her to update the plan daily so she doesn't feel ruled by it.

6 Tell her not to try to read everything. Suggest she chooses wisely (maybe with the help of her teacher or friends) and sticks to key texts, and key parts of those. Concentrating on key words rather than piles of notes will help retain information.

7 Give her opportunities to talk through her worries. Studying with friends can help - asking other people questions will actually make it easier for her to recall and retain answers - and can help her let off steam. Remind her that you took exams, too, so you know how it feels.

8 Tell her it is the most natural thing in the world to feel stressed about exams.

9 It is only natural that you want your daughter to do the best she can, but she will need to be reassured that it is not the end of the world if she fails a few subjects. She can always take exams again!

10 Finally, try not to conduct a big post mortem as to how she got into this mess. Be as supportive and encouraging as possible - deal with what's in front of her, not behind.

In closing, you may want to ask your daughter if she sees herself as a no-hoper. If so, tell her that now is a good time to defy that stereotype - she can change the record any time she wants.

 Adapted by Amanda Roper

 Further advice for students of all ages approaching exams can be found in The Little Book of Exam Calm, written by Anita Naik, illustrated by Jennifer Graham and published by Hodder Children's Books 2000 at £2.50.

 For guidance and revision in English literature and language, maths and science, you can now visit the Guardian's own educational website at www.learn.co.uk

Next week's query: I read with interest the problems facing the parent whose daughter is approaching her GCSEs in last week's "If you ask me". My son has been revising methodically since before the Easter break. He's made a revision timetable and copious notes for the eight GCSE subjects he is studying, but he's now completely overwhelmed at the prospect of trying to take it all in. How can I help him to make the revision process more effective?

fields.headline: A haven in a storm
fields.standfirst: There is now help for students trying to take exams while beset by domestic problems
fields.trailText: There is now help for students trying to take exams while beset by domestic problems
fields.body:
In John's A-level year his father died suddenly from heart disease. As the final exams approached he confessed to feeling listless and to lacking motivation. "I know what I'm capable of doing, and I'm not doing it," he said, but was reluctant to apply to the exam boards for a postponement. "The trouble is, if I get off now, I might never get back on again."

For Amy, the problem preying on her mind as she prepared for her GCSEs was the suicide of her best friend's father. She did not feel it was something the exam board would take into account but she was worried about whether she was supporting her friend adequately. "I don't know how to deal with this - I've had no experience".

Nobody at school apart from Tom's close friends knew that his parents were in the throes of a divorce in the January before his GCSE exams. On the surface he was dismissive but soon admitted: "It does get really bad sometimes - I have to admit it."

Julie conceded that her part-time job was potentially harmful to her A-level chances as the time for revision approached, but maintained that she had only been allowed to stay at school by her single-parent mother on condition that she worked. "I wouldn't want my mother to be paying to support me anyway."

In all these cases, the final results were mediocre - in one case, disastrous - and not as good as general expectations of the students. Neither A-level student achieved the results necessary for their comparatively modest university/college offer targets.

Exams are not a level playing field. My experience suggests that up to 25% of students face non-academic obstacles that can affect their chances, ranging from illness, bereavements of family or friends and students' responsibilities for caring for sick relatives, to parental divorce or strained relations, and family economic problems such as parents' redundancy and the need for students to work.

In March, I launched ExamAid, a voluntary organisation to help students in these situations try to get through the year successfully rather than drop out and present exam boards with virtually insoluble problems. How do you assess the performance impact of a grandparent's death or a father's redundancy? And, given that someone will always abuse the system, what proof could you possibly ask for?

ExamAid aims to provide help in areas which schools find difficult, such as helplines in out-of-school hours and a website featuring "advicemail" and networks for ill, isolated, part-time working or carer students, available 24 hours a day. There is also new research on the extent and nature of the problems in specific areas and the kinds of difficulties students are experiencing with part-time employment.

Regular magazine publications will list resources on such problems as bereavement, provide information on revision material that students can use entirely at home and report back on what research is suggesting. While some people have misgivings about voluntary organisations, it's difficult to see how else some of these problems can be approached - even present expectations can't demand 24-hour attention from year heads and pastoral tutors, and most schools haven't the time or resources to do detailed research into these problems. It's also true that many students, like their elders, do not like mixing their work and home lives and are inclined to look for out-of-school solutions to out-of-school problems.

Early recruits to the organisation include Alan McMurray, an Ofsted inspector and ex-head. "For many students under pressure as a result of personal or domestic circumstances, the need for support can often be at its most urgent at night."

Roger Phillips is a counselling psychologist who, referring to successful help given to a student, believes that not being a teacher can be an asset: "The whole thrust of the intervention hinged on my detachment from the staff, my not being in a position of power."

Other members include a learning support head in a large independent school, a teacher who is training as a counsellor and a teacher motivated by a student's suicide. Institutional members include a college and a department within a college.

Rather than rely on vague requests for donations (welcome as these are!) the organisation offers membership packages for both institutions and individuals that make access to services quicker and include magazines and research. Helplines and the website will be open services. Members who staff helplines must have at least four years' qualified professional experience in education, and we are now working towards Charity Commission registration with the help of a sympathetic lawyer.

 ExamAid, PO Box 5541, Swadlincote, Derbyshire, DE12 6ZQ. Tel: 01530 415765; fax: 01530 563592. email: bharrisma@aol.com

fields.headline: Call to arms
fields.standfirst: A growing number of students are being recruited on British campuses by Islamic extremists - and end up on the world's frontlines
fields.trailText: A growing number of students are being recruited on British campuses by Islamic extremists - and end up on the world's frontlines
fields.body:
Three students from Queen Mary and Westfield College, London, withdrew from their studies last February to train abroad and eventually engage in "jihad" - the holy war. They are the latest in an increasing number of British Muslim students who have been recruited from campuses by extremist Islamic parties to train abroad and fight in regions like Kosovo, Chechnya and Kashmir.

Such recruitment, which has been going on for more than a decade, has attracted a large number of students over the years, some of whom have actually fought in different war zones and died.

Students as young as 16 are known to have been recruited for military training abroad, often without their parents knowing anything about it.

The Queen Mary students, two of whom were studying computer science and the other engineering, were recruited by the extremist party Al-Muhajiroun, which is active in British campuses throughout the country, and which has been banned by several universities for its extreme views.

The founder of Al-Muhajiroun, Sheikh Omar Bakri-Muhammad, based in London, personally arranged the recruitment of the three students through his contacts in Britain and abroad.

Sheikh Bakri-Muhammad, who founded the party in Saudi Arabia in 1983, says it is the duty of all Muslims to engage in jihad. He said: "I believe in the divine cause for Muslims to struggle."

Al-Muhajiroun, which has a network of centres around the world, is divided into two wings, said Sheik Bakri. "There is the Da'wah (propagation) network, and there is the Jihad Network," he added. It is the Jihad Network of the party that recruits people for military campaigns, while the Da'wah wing "spreads the word of Islam" through lectures, conferences, stalls and leaflets.

It is the Da'wah Network that attracts students to the party in campuses, as universities are key venues for lectures and talks. Students interested in the party become members, after which they are told of the possibility of engaging in military struggles "for the sake of Islam".

The president of the National Union of Students, Andrew Pakes, has described the military recruitment of Al-Muhajiroun and other parties as "morally reprehensible". He said: "I condemn the behaviour utterly. It is morally wrong to recruit students via the universities to become involved in paramilitary training and campaigns of violence."

Pakes admitted that the NUS, which has banned Islamic parties in many campuses around the country for reasons of anti-Semitism and homophobia, was never aware of such military recruitment.

He promised that the NUS would exercise a "no-platform policy" for any parties that engaged in such activities. "I think I'd be encouraging the NUS to be on the lookout for such recruitment," he said.

It is difficult, however, to spot parties like Al-Muhajiroun recruiting students, as it is done with great secrecy. Although the Da'awah Network of Al-Muhajiroun openly condemns Israel, Russia's actions in Chechnya and India's stance in Kashmir, and calls on Muslims to fight towards creating a global Islamic state (khilafah), it seldom discloses its Jihad wing to the wider public.

Members of the party who want to go abroad and become Mojahedin (jihad warriors) contact key party figures. They introduce them to sources in Britain that have connections with guerrilla training camps in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

Sheikh Bakri-Muhammad admitted that there is a global network of agents with connections to the military camps, some of whom work from Britain.

Abdullah (not his real name) was a student at a London University college when he became attracted to Islamic parties in his final year. "In my final year I turned towards Islam. I listened to a few people and groups, visiting speakers, etc. That helped my Islamic awakening," he says.

Since then he has become a devoted member of an Islamic party, which he wouldn't name. Through the party he has gone abroad for military training, and returned to England after completing it six months ago.

"There are quite a few people in the UK who can arrange for you to go to the camps," he says. The route the recruits take to the military camps from countries like Britain are complicated, full of stops and changes to prevent authorities from tracing them.

"Often you would go from England to France, and from there to another country, and so on," he says. "Then once you are in the right country you would go by car or rail to a specified destination, and then be guided to the actual camps.

"The majority of spaces are filled by students. Even 16- to 17-year-olds skip schools to go on training." Often people of 16 or 17 lie to their parents, saying they are going on a summer holiday to places like America. fields.headline: So who gets the job?
fields.standfirst: Lee Elliot Major  on damning revelations about our appearance-obsessed employers
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major on damning revelations about our appearance-obsessed employers
fields.body:
Graduates from ethnic backgrounds are up to three times more likely to end up on the dole after university than white students with the same degrees, unpublished government research has found. The findings confirm the conclusions of earlier studies that physical appearances, rather than mental abilities, often determine job prospects. Academics have shown that tall men enjoy higher earnings, while obese women are on average paid less than other employees.

Officials are now concerned that ministers' calls for universities to be judged, and funded, according to the number of graduates securing jobs will only encourage institutions to ex clude ethnic minority groups when enrolling new students.

The study, by the Higher Education Funding Council for England, is the first substantive evidence confirming what many job applicants have always suspected: employers are prejudiced towards certain types of people when hiring staff.

The analysis took into account the wide differences in the experiences for specific ethnic groups - Asians, for example have better job opportunities than Afro-Caribbeans - and found that overall the chance of ethnic graduates being unemployed was between 1.5 and three times that of whites, even with the same degree grades in the same subjects. The report says the findings are only preliminary, but "the effects are so large it seems likely that they will still be significant when a more comprehensive model is developed".

Previous research has shown that employers systematically discriminate against those perceived as unattractive or short. "This work did not look at graduates specifically, but it is certainly possible, indeed it is likely, that such discrimination operates in the graduate market," says the report.

Officials fear increasing pressure on academic institutions to monitor the employability of university leavers will undermine efforts to enrol more students from poorer backgrounds.

Apart from limiting their milk-round visits to a small number of elite institutions, many employers use A-level grades as a screening device, and restrict graduate positions to those under 25. So graduates with non-traditional entry qualifications and mature graduates experience higher unemployment rates.

"Given the government's policy to widen access, it would be perverse to produce an indicator that would have the effect of discouraging institutions from recruiting such students," says the report. "One rational response to performance indicators would be for institutions to anticipate employers' preferences and prejudices."

Funding council officials are trying to develop a new measure to gauge the job prospects promised by different universities - one which will not penalise institutions with lots of students from poor or ethnic minority backgrounds. In his Budget statement last year, chancellor Gordon Brown said that performance indicators on the employment outcomes of graduates would have to be published before the end of the year.

The employability measure will take into account factors such as the age, sex, ethnicity, disability, degree subject and entry qualifications, as well as the local labour market of the university. It will compare the number of unemployed graduates with the combined total of those employed and unemployed, ignoring those taking up further study. It is also likely to distinguish between graduate and non-graduate jobs, and involve surveys of students six months and 18 months after graduating.

The measure is expected to be used to allocate extra student numbers and teaching grants to universities.

fields.headline: Growing plains
fields.standfirst: Britain's threatened, rare orchids are being rescued by pupils at Writhlington School near Bath
fields.trailText: Britain's threatened, rare orchids are being rescued by pupils at Writhlington School near Bath
fields.body:
Ophrys apifera flourishes on school rugby fields - apparently. Ophrys isn't an imported flank forward brought in to revive Britain's fortunes in sport. It's an orchid, a Bee orchid, and at Writhlington School near Bath they can tell you a thing or two about orchids.

Teacher Simon Pugh-Jones has just brought a party of sixth-formers back from the South American jungle, where they worked on an orchid-rescue project.

"This part of south-eastern Brazil was very similar to the Mendips," he says. "Only about 4% of the original forest remains. Most of the species are there, but under great threat."

One orchid, Masdevallia infracta, was restricted to a small population attached to one ancient tree, which had recently fallen. The Somerset sixth-formers worked to relocate the orchids to more hospitable territory.

Back in the Mendips, modern farming techniques with high nitrate usage have destroyed the traditional grassland environment for British orchids.

"There haven't been any extinctions," says Pugh-Jones, "but the population is under threat." School fields, however, are not heavily fertilised and provide a natural environment for some species.

"We let the grass grow in the spring and summer and cut it for hay," says Pugh-Jones. "You can create fantastic biodiversity."

The school has a greenhouse programme and works with local organisations to re-establish world orchid populations in the local area. Sixth-formers on advanced GNVQ programmes use the plants in their study of genetics and hybridisation.

Next month the school is hoping for good news from the Barclays New Futures award scheme. The bank works with Community Service Volunteers to promote community projects and Writhlington is one of seven schools shortlisted for the Challenge award - worth £20,000 to the winner.

"Schools have a real opportunity to make a difference," says Pugh-Jones. If he wins, he plans to help create orchid areas in local schools, residential homes and workplaces.

"It would show that communities can develop the skills to make orchid habitat reconstruction a possibility throughout the country," says Pugh-Jones, "and begin to roll back the decimation of some of our most easily threatened flora."

 More information on UK orchids at the Hardy Orchid Society.
Application packs for Barclays New Futures awards are sent to all schools in the autumn term. Or contact: barclaysnewfutures@kallaway.co.uk

fields.headline: A long shadow
fields.standfirst: The pupils of Frankley Community High know all about mood swings. As hopes fluctuate for the Rover car factory on their doorstep, they try to get down to GCSEs
fields.trailText: The pupils of Frankley Community High know all about mood swings. As hopes fluctuate for the Rover car factory on their doorstep, they try to get down to GCSEs
fields.body:
Clive Owen was ideally placed to register the change in local atmosphere when the news broke that BMW was to pull out of Rover cars. "I drive to school past the Longbridge factory gates just as the morning shift is going in," he explains. "Normally it's flooded with people. The morning all this broke there was no one there, it was quite remarkable - literally no one. That said something about the shock that was felt around here."

Owen is deputy headteacher at Frankley Community High School, six miles from the centre of Birmingham, which has recently been under the long shadow of uncertainty cast by the Rover car factory and the protracted negotiations over its future. Last week's well-publicised £10 sale has saved jobs for now, but for how long?

With 50% of children on free school meals and nearly half its mainly white, working-class intake coming from homes where regular employment is a rarity, Frankley is the kind of place where raising educational standards is hard enough at the best of times. But with more than 20% unemployment, and the area's most significant employer on the brink of closure for the last couple of months, the difficulties faced by its hard-pressed teaching staff have merely increased.

"We are always going to have problems here," says the school's full-time learning mentor, Charmian "Charlie" Nex. "But this has just added an extra weight to it. This time of year we've got exams coming up and we're struggling to keep the children going, and then it's like, 'oh, we've been dealt another blow'. The school has been very unsettled."

In 1997, with attendance among its 450 pupils down to 74%, and with only 5% achieving five or more A to C grades at GCSE, Frankley was placed under the dreaded special measures. But two years later, funding from the government's Excellence in Cities project enabled the headteacher, Sue Bates, to employ Charlie to work with its most disaffected and underachieving pupils.

Together with what Owen calls "a new ethos of aspiration," the school has dragged itself up to the official status of "serious weaknesses" - last summer, 21% achieved five or more A-Cs, and attendance has risen to 87.5% - only to see the community hit by this new source of instability.

"There is a massive, grey cloud around that is making people, especially our pupils, wonder 'well, where am I going to end up?'," says Bates. "Before the Longbridge thing broke, we had been trying to establish a new agenda for the school and we're probably far enough down the road not to have all our good work undermined by this episode. But in the community around us there is a real feeling of uncertainty."

Charlie has certainly noticed it. Much of her work involves chasing up absent pupils and encouraging them back to the classroom. Often it means trying to persuade sceptical parents of the value of school to their children's futures. She reckons her workload has increased by something like 10%-20% in the last few weeks.

"The atmosphere from the Rover stuff is definitely affecting them," she says. "You can see the older children thinking, 'what's the point?' even more than they used to. A lot of year 11 children have been dropping out and that must be partly a result of the general feeling - you know, 'if jobs can disappear that easily, why bother?' "

"This is an area of poverty anyway," says Owen. "Of those parents that do have jobs, many are part-time or temporary. And our attempts to raise standards are not always supported by them. But now, even those children who have seen their dad with a job that pays OK are thinking that even that rug might be pulled from under them."

A large number of parents of Frankley pupils work at the Rover plant, in a few cases both parents. Many others work for one of a handful of nearby factories that supply parts to Rover, or at the retail park just down the road which partly relies on the spending power of Rover workers and their families. It's no coincidence that the last couple of months has seen a sharp increase in the number of applications for free school meals.

"You can feel the anxieties of the parents through the children," says Owen. "They're obviously worried about their futures and about what might happen in their families if they suddenly have to face not having enough money."

Year 10 pupils Krystle Priestley and Kelly Walton are both aiming for higher education but are acutely aware of what's happening. "My mum talks about it all the time," says Krystle. "Every day she'll tell you the latest news. And you can hear other kids at school talking about it, worrying about their dads' jobs or whatever."

In fact, several members of school staff have partners who work at Longbridge. And there are direct links to what's called the Rover Learning Centre, which in the past has invited pupils to tour the factory and talk to employees about their jobs. Usually, in June, five or six pupils would go to the plant for two weeks' work experience, and workers go to the school to do mentoring sessions with children, talking to them about the personal qualities needed in the world of work. This year, all that has gone.

Year 10 pupil Mark Williams had applied to do work experience at Rover this year. "I'll just have to go somewhere else," he says. That's not so bad for someone who hopes to be an actor, rather than a car worker. But about 10% of Frankley's school leavers usually apply to do apprenticeships at the plant every year. "I haven't had any requests from Rover for references this year," says Owen. "Normally there's quite a few by now. No one has said directly they are not going to apply, but many of them clearly thought it would close, or at least they think it will be a less viable employer around here."

If anything, the staff at Frankley feel an even greater sense of responsibility than before. "As a community school, I recognise that we are one of the first ports of call when the community experiences difficulties," says head Sue Bates. "We actually take the children away from the area where the tension is sharpest, which is in the home. For some children, the school is the most comfortable environment they've got at the moment. So although we might be more proactive in getting them in here, in terms of how we work we have tried to be as normal as possible."

In the long term, whatever happens to jobs at Longbridge, Bates feels there may be a positive side to the turmoil. "If it actually makes some people think it is better to stay on at school, rather than assuming there will be a job out there, maybe there will be a less cavalier attitude to education. It will take some time, but for some, what is happening at Longbridge could throw into sharper relief the idea that they do need education."

fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: The relationship between the headteacher and governing body of a school is like a precious and delicate Fabergé egg - and can be just as rare.
fields.body:
The relationship between the headteacher and governing body of a school is like a precious and delicate Fabergé egg - and can be just as rare. It is the key that allows schools to unlock the potential of both adults and children. It is made up of mutual trust and respect, and is worked upon and embellished over time. Its fundamental elements are a shared understanding, clear information, common purpose and the ability to be constructively critical without taking or giving offence. In short, it's a genuine partnership.

Every school should have a Fabergé egg, or be creating one. But how do you produce this much sought-after asset?

 Step one: the design process. You will need to take the time to discuss and agree on what exactly your school stands for and in which direction you are going. To use the jargon, put in place a mission statement and long-term planning to achieve your aims and objectives. But make sure that this isn't just a paper exercise: make it real.

 Step two onwards: each design is different so I'm afraid you're on your own here! The steps that you take to make your Fabergé egg depend on the unique circumstances of your school. However, by working through these steps, you will inevitably reach...

 The last step: do all the pieces fit? If not, then this suggests that a true partnership between head and governing body is not possible - so one of the key players must consider their position, and this may even mean resignation.

The latter might sound extreme, but remember that young people only have one journey through school, and the governing body exists to make it the best possible.

So, go make an egg!

 Fred Browning is senior governor development officer with Essex local education authority.

fields.headline: European unity
fields.standfirst: As Europe unveils its motto, Brussels is invaded by hundreds of students
fields.trailText: As Europe unveils its motto, Brussels is invaded by hundreds of students
fields.body:
Twenty-four months of preparations; over 2,000 entries; 40 newspapers; 15 Grand Jurors and 90 minutes of deliberations. Add them up and what do you get? Just four little words (three in English) - Unité dans la diversité, or Unity in diversity - in other words, our new Motto for Europe.

The motto was unveiled at the seat of the European Parliament in Brussels on May 4, following a Europe-wide competition for young people. The idea was conceived two years ago by Patrick La Prairie, manager of the school press department at Ouest-France, France's largest daily newspaper, who was thinking about the euro. The word for currency in French is "devise", which also means motto, and La Prairie got to thinking about the value of having a motto to express the essence of Europe.

From the start, the Caen Memorial in Normandy was heavily involved. The memorial aims to encourage its 350,000 annual visitors to think about the scourge of war and to strive for peace. With the involvement of Ouest-France, France-Telecom and, in the later stages, 40 EU media partners including the Guardian, the project set out to ask schoolchildren to dream up the motto. The winning class from each member state was invited to Brussels for the final, although the entries had been whittled down by then to just seven. The Grand Jury met during the morning to decide on the winner. Representing Britain was Lord Watson of Richmond.

In the afternoon the winning entry, whose country of origin is not known, was handed over to Nicole Fontaine, president of the EP, who said: "It is 55 years since Robert Schuman suggested European unity so that there would be no more war. We have peace, but Kosovo reminds us that war is always possible. Our youngsters have expressed their hope for unity."

It was extraordinary to see the parliament chamber filled with so many young faces. Britain was represented by a class from Lytham St Anne's High Technology College.

The atmosphere was one of co-operation across boundaries, which reflects well on the aims of the EU.

Jacques Delors, former European Commission president, concluded: "The youngsters of Europe have expressed, in their proposals for a motto, all the hopes and sentiments of Robert Schuman and his fellow founders of a European union back in 1957; freedom, peace, unity, future, hope, equality. You have refreshed the hopes of our founding fathers, and some of you will carry our torch".

 Sixth-formers at Lytham St Anne's High Technology College in Lancashire went to Brussels after coming up with Britain's entry. Eighteen-year-olds Richard Smith, Emma Rouen, Lindsay Wilkinson and Rachel Lyons, all studying A-level French, dreamt up the British winner: Europe, where borders are merely lines on a map.

"Europe is much stronger than Britain in going it alone, and borders only keep people out, but as countries we should be sharing our cultural experiences," says Richard. "I chose to study French as a way of exploring other cultures."

The students have to study Europe as part of their A-level syllabus and teacher Anna Gist set them the task of coming up with a slogan for their homework. "I thought it would be a fun way for them to put their French into practise as well as encourage them to think about Europe," Gist says.

Of their invitation to the awards ceremony at the European Parliament in Brussels on May 4, Lindsay said: "It's a chance to meet up with other young Europeans, which will be a fantastic opportunity to break down barriers."

 Emma Bird

fields.headline: Girl died after undetected pregnancy
fields.trailText: A teenage girl whose pregnancy went undetected by her doctor for almost six months collapsed at home with fits and died from complications after her baby was stillborn, an inquiry heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A teenage girl whose pregnancy went undetected by her doctor for almost six months collapsed at home with fits and died from complications after her baby was stillborn, an inquiry heard yesterday.

The girl, 15, "ballooned" from eight and a half stone to 13 stone, but no pregnancy tests were carried out, the General Medical Council's professional conduct committee was told.

Barbara Thomas, of Newport, south Wales, is accused of serious professional misconduct. She allegedly failed physically to examine the girl, referred to as Miss A, or ask for tests.

She is also said to have failed to determine whether the teenager was sexually active, although the girl had a 19-year-old boyfriend.

Tom Kark, counsel for the GMC, told the hearing that it was insufficient to take the word of a 15-year-old that she had not had sexual intercourse.

The girl was taken to a GP surgery in Pontnewydd, south Wales, where Dr Thomas was then practising, in late May or early June 1995, after she told her mother that she had missed her period.

She told her mother she could not be pregnant. Mrs A believed her.

Mrs A claimed Dr Thomas saw her up to five times before she collapsed in November 1995.

The doctor disputed the number of visits, but conceded there was at least one occasion when she had failed to examine the girl.

Mr Kark said Miss A's weight soared and her face, body and legs began to swell so
much so that she could not put on her shoes to go to school. Dr Thomas suggested a blood test the day before the girl collapsed at home with fits.

She was rushed to hospital and found to be 28 weeks pregnant. The baby girl was alive in Miss A's womb at the time of admission to hospital, but when she was delivered by caesarian section the next day, she had died.

Miss A then developed blood poisoning and kidney failure.

On December 2 it was decided that no further treatment could be undertaken.

The cause of death was given as sepsis and eclampsia - a toxic condition that sometimes develops in the last three months of pregnancy, characterised by high blood pressure, weight gain and convulsions.

The hearing continues.
